HEADLINE: LOS CEDRALES JOURNAL;
On Disputed Land, Paraguay Reaps a Whirlwind

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS CEDRALES, Paraguay

 BODY:
As his five children played barefoot in a manioc field, Cesar Galeano folded and unfolded an eviction order and wondered what the next few weeks would bring.
In December, the police arrived at the squatter settlement here and dismantled 70 shanties with chainsaws. In January, just before harvest time, a tractor arrived at the homesteads and plowed under 150 acres of cotton. 
 Here in eastern Paraguay, a peasant occupation of a German company's farmland is part of a nationwide upheaval caused two years ago by a coup that ended the 35-year rule of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.
The overnight collapse of Latin America's longest-running Government unleashed pent-up social demands in a country where the majority of the four million inhabitants still live in the countryside.
With 78 percent of farm and ranch land in the hands of 41 foreign companies and several hundred Paraguayans, peasants started to organize, occupying land.
"I don't think that private property that is unjustly distributed is sacred," said Mr. Galeano, a onetime motorcycle mechanic who is a leader of the 362 families squatting on the German company's land here.
 
Detentions Called Shocking
 Often making large estates owned by foreigners, largely Germans, Japanese and Brazilians, their target, about 12,000 peasant families jumped over Paraguay's slow-moving land redistribution bureaucracy and occupied land.
After a period of indecision and negotiations, the new Government of President Andres Rodriguez is fighting back with tough tactics that, critics say, differ little from General Stroessner's.
"The sheer number of detentions is shocking," Americas Watch said recently in a report on violence surrounding Paraguay's land disputes. Noting that 167 detentions of peasants took place in the last two years of the Stroessner Government, the New York-based human rights group reported that 800 detentions took place since Mr. Rodriguez, also an army general, was elected President in May 1989.
To enforce eviction orders, rural policemen have burned squatters' homes, beaten peasants and stolen their property, Americas Watch asserted.
"The police take machetes, watches, household property, chainsaws and motorcycles," said Leonardo Ayala Balmoris, a lawyer for a Roman Catholic group that defends the squatters.
 
'Little Has Changed'
 To critics, the violence in the countryside is evidence that the change in Government has not resulted in a change in the traditional tactics of rural control.
"As in many countries, the revolution starts in the city and is slow in getting to the countryside," Juan E. Mendez, executive director of Americas Watch, said in an interview in Asuncion, Paraguay's capital. "Allowing the courts, the police and the army to be manipulated in favor of landowners shows that little has changed."
In response, the Government says property rights must be respected to encourage foreign and domestic investment in agriculture, Paraguay's economic mainstay. Publicity over illegal occupations, Government officials say, draws attention away from a program that is to distribute land to 30,000 certified landless peasants in a two-year period ending this December.
"We have inherited a very serious land problem," said Basilio Nikiphoroff, president of the Rural Welfare Institute, Paraguay's land redistribution agency. He estimated that 50,000 families want land to farm.
Working within the law, the American-trained agronomist continued, the Government is establishing 66 new agricultural colonies that offer settler families access roads, soil surveys and other support. A computer system weeds out land speculaors.
 
'A Tough and a Sad Job'
 In contrast, Mr. Nikiphoroff said, the Government will not give land to peasants who use pressure tactics, like the peasants who have occupied the Roman Catholic Cathedral in Asuncion for the last six months.
"We could empty the cathedral but it would just fill up again," he said of the peasant protesters. "The image of the occupied cathedral is the image of a democratic country."
Responding to the Americas Watch criticism, Mr. Nikiphoroff said all evictions take place with judicial orders.
"The police have to break the shanties and knock down the churches," he said of makeshift churches raised by the homesteaders. "The police have a tough and a sad job."
Despite the Government's hard line, many Paraguayans say they believe that land occupations will continue, especially around election time. New multiparty elections for Congress and for mayorships have meant a sudden political enfranchisement of Paraguay's impoverished rural majority.
 
Courting the Squatters
 At Los Cedrales the other day, the new political reality was on view.
In the morning, Mayor Miguel Angel Riquelme Barreto commiserated with the town's largest landowner, saying, "Public authorities can't support these kinds of invasions."
Later in the day, the Mayor's lunch was interrupted by a truck carrying Mr. Galeano and about 40 squatters who were returning from a demonstration against eviction.
The Mayor, who faces re-election in May, waved cheerily from his veranda and sent his wife out to the potential voters with a bottle of rum.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Government of Paraguay has begun to evict peasant families who had occupied land after tiring of waiting for land redistribution. Peasants demonstrated recently in Ciudad del Este against their evictions. The signs read, "We have the right to life," and "Don't throw us out of our homes." (Elizabeth Brooke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Alliance Plans Housing in 20 Cities

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Seven philanthropies and the Prudential Insurance Company of America are beginning an ambitious program to revitalize poor neighborhoods in 20 major cities.
Their coalition, called the National Community Development Initiative, will build or restore 7,500 housing units for low- and moderate-income families. In some cities, including New York, the coalition will set up child-care centers. 
 What makes the program special is that the projects will be carried out by Community Development Corporations, which are local nonprofit groups that have had solid track records over the last two decades in transforming decaying neighborhoods through the development of housing, commercial and industrial prjects.
"No foundation and no financial institution in this world can reverse the scourges of poverty or provide adequate housing with money alone," said John Mutz, the president of the Lilly Endowment, one of the philanthropies involved. "We must rely on local heroes who will invent strategies, muster consensus and see a plan through."
 
$62.5 Million in Grants and Loans
 The eight financial sponsors have committed $62.5 million in grants and loans, which they say is the most money ever amassed from private sources for neighborhood renewal projects. The Rockefeller Foundation, the Lilly Endowment and Prudential each gave $15 million. Smaller shares were given by the Pew Charitable Trusts, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, the Knight Foundation and the Surdna Foundation.
The sponsors expect the program to raise at least $500 million more within three years from banks, government agencies, investors and local foundations to complete construction. A crucial element in attracting these resources, they said, was the participation of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The corporation, known as Freddie Mac, will guarantee financing for $100 million in housing loans to the Community Development Corporations -- providing a stable source of long-term and low-interest money that has not previously been available.
"Families in these communities who borrow to rebuild their lives and their neighborhoods are some of the toughest, most determined performers around," Peter C. Goldmark, the president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said Wednesday at a Washington news conference, where the project was announced."Even from a narrow business view, I'd rather put my money in a neighborhood C.D.C. than in Donald Trump's Taj Mahal."
 
Different Plans for Cities
 The programs will use different strategies in different cities:
*In Boston, the focus will be on preserving or creating 1,000 housing units for single occupants, many of them now living in shelters.
*In the District of Columbia, 800 deteriorating rental units will be rebuilt. Tenants will not be forced to move as they often are in renovation projects. Some, in fact, will be employed by the renovators.
*In Columbus, Ohio, two Methodist parishes and a Baptist parish are helping to form a group to create and improve housing in a deteriorating neighborhood of 2,000 families.
*In New York, plans call for 15 child-care centers for 1,000 children in or near the housing being rehabilitated. In addition, three sites in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the South Bronx will offer broader programs known as Community Life Centers, providing services like child care, job training as well as other educational programs and family counseling.
 
Role of Two Intermediaries
 The other cities are Atlanta, Baltimore, Chattanooga, Tenn., Chicago, Cleveland, Miami, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Los Angeles, Newark, the Oakland-San Francisco Bay area, Philadelphia, Portland, San Antonio, Seattle and St. Paul. In Miami, renovation has already begun on an apartment building for 82 elderly tenants.
Two of the country's leading development organizations will act as intermediaries between the eight financial sponsors and the Community Development Corporations, and will seek additional financing for the projects. One of the organizations, the New York-based Local Initiatives Support Corporation, created by the Ford Foundation and corporate and philanthropic sponsors, has over 11 years induced 700 corporations, foundations and financial institutions to commit more than $420 million for community development, and attracted $1.4 billion from government and private sources for 26,000 housing units and commercial ventures. The other development group, the Enterprise Foundation, established in 1982 by the Maryland developer James W. Rouse, has helped create or rehabilitate 13,500 housing units for lower-income families in 40 cities.
Until now, few philanthropies have ventured to provide financing to Community Development Corporations, which have spread to 2,500 communities from an experimental start 24 years ago in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. Five of the sponsors of the project announced yesterday will be making their first grants or loans to the local groups.
"Unfortunately, C.D.C's are not well known by potential supporters," said Mitchell Sviridoff, a former president of the initiatives group who advised the coalition. "Most folks think C.D.C. means Centers for Disease Control."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against other major currencies yesterday, lifted overseas by the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war and on domestic markets by speculation that United States interest rates would remain stable.
Gold moved sharply higher in response to the gulf developments. The price of the March contract advanced $5.70 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $367.40 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $366 a troy ounce, up $5.20. 
 Dealers said the end of fighting in the Middle East gave support to the dollar in Europe, where traders viewed the cease-fire as a good sign for the United States economy.
In later New York trading, analysts said the market was shifting its focus from the war to the latest economic data.
 
Purchasing Survey
 A survey of purchasing executives in the Midwest found that business activity picked up for manufacturing companies in February. The survey, taken by the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago, is considered a precursor to the national purchasing managers' survey, which is scheduled to be released today.
Currency traders believed the purchasing managers survey might relieve some of the pressure on the Federal Reserve to again relax interest rates to stimulate business. Since higher yields make the dollar more attractive, the possibility that interest rates will not fall any further moved the United States currency higher.
Mike Faust, a currency market analyst with MMS International in Chicago, said traders were looking ahead to February employment figures to be released next week.
In the meantime, "the general view is that the Fed is taking a less aggressive stand toward easing" interest rates, Mr. Faust said.
The dollar rose to 133.03 Japanese yen in New York from late Wednesday's 132.245. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.85 yen, to a closing 131.95 yen, and later in London it was quoted at 132.98.
The British pound fell to $1.912 in New York, from $1.9177 late Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.9105, from $1.9155 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.52425 German marks, up from 1.5225; 1.3248 Swiss francs, up from 1.3163; 5.1890 French francs, up from 5.1780; 1,139.00 Italian lire, up from 1,137.75, and 1.14975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15145.
While gold prices were rising, silver moved sharply higher in New York on speculation about a possible strike by Peruvian silver miners, an action that could drive up the price of the metal.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Plans to Reduce Salaried Work Force

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Faced with mounting losses, the Ford Motor Company announced plans today to cut its salaried work force through layoffs and early retirements, in an effort to save $3 billion by the end of the year.
Speaking by closed-circuit television to the company's 53,000 salaried employees in the United States, Ford's chairman and chief executive, Harold A. Poling, said, "It's becoming increasingly clear that some salaried layoffs are inevitable in the short term." 
 Mr. Poling said the company had already cut $1.5 billion and planned to cut a similar amount by the end of this year.
A Ford spokesman said the company would not know how many people would be laid off until April, the deadline for workers to accept early retirement.
Automotive analysts said the plan outlined today increased the likelihood that Ford would cut its dividend. The company's next dividend meeting is scheduled for April 11.
The deepest slump in car and truck sales since the recession of 1982 has auto makers scrambling to hold down their costs. In recent weeks, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have both announced plans to reduce their salaried work forces, and G.M. also halved its dividend.
Ford posted a loss of $519 million in the fourth quarter, and Mr. Poling acknowledged today that it appeared likely that the company would "have a substantial loss in the first quarter of this year."
The cost-cutting measures announced today, which affect 140,000 salaried employees worldwide, include freezing salaries for top executives for the next year and limiting raises for other salaried employees. The company has also suspended matching contributions to employee savings and stock investment plans.
Ford's stock was up $2.125 a share today, to $32.625, on the New York Stock Exchange as all of the Big Three auto makers showed solid advances. Several Wall Street analysts issued favorable opinions on the companies on the expectation that the slump in auto sales would ease as the Mideast war ends and the United States economy recovers.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending In Big Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Consumer spending, which slipped severely in the final quarter of last year, dropped an additional six-tenths of a percent in January, the Government said today. It was the steepest decline in consumer spending in more than four years.
Contributing to the cutback was a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in personal incomes, the largest such decline in more than two years. 
 "Consumers are in a lot of trouble," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.
 
$3.72 Trillion Rate
 The Commerce Department said spending in January fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.72 trillion, the steepest slide since a 1.3 percent decline in January 1987 and more than erasing an advance of five-tenths of a percent in December.
John E. Silvia, an economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said the decline was more evidence that the January-to-March period of this year would be the second straight quarterly contraction -- meeting the classic confirmation of recession. Consumer spending provides two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
On Wednesday, the Commerce Department reported that the gross national product, the total output of the nation's goods and services, fell at an annual rate of 2 percent from October through December.
The G.N.P. report included a huge 2.9 percent drop in consumer spending for the final quarter of last year.
 
No Money to Spend
 And while the apparent end of the Persian Gulf war is expected to increase consumer confidence and provide an initial boost in spending, Mr. Steinberg said any rebound was not expected to be robust.
"The problem has not been a lack of confidence," he said. "The problem is that consumers don't have any money to spend."
Indeed, the drop of five-tenths of a percent in personal incomes reported today by the Commerce Department was the largest decline since a similar drop in November 1988.
Incomes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.72 trillion, down from a gain of six-tenths of a percent posted in December.
 
6.2% Unemployment Rate
 The Labor Department reported earlier this month that the nation's unemployment rate climbed to 6.2 percent in January, its highest level since 1987. Over the seven months that ended in January, 1.2 million people have become jobless.
And while some incomes rose because of a Federal Government pay rise and an increase in Government benefit payments, it was offset by a decrease in farm subsidies and a jump in Social Security withholding, the Commerce Department said.
The report said Americans' disposable incomes, incomes after taxes, sank by five-tenths of 1 percent, erasing a similar gain the previous month.
As a result, Americans' savings rate, savings as a percentage of disposable income, edged up, to 4.3 percent in January from 4.2 percent a month earlier.
 
Inflation Adjustment
 The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending actually fell by 1.1 percent, the largest decline since a 2.2 percent drop in January 1987. Inflation-adjusted spending rose by four-tenths of a percent in December.
Disposable incomes, when adjusted for inflation, slumped by nine-tenths of a percent after a five-tenths of a percent gain in December.
Two critical components of the income category, wages and salaries, fell by $14.2 billion after rising $22.8 billion a month earlier. They were unchanged in November.
Spending on durable goods, items ranging from cars to computers that are expected to last more than three years, plunged by $23.6 billion after a $2.4 billion drop in December.
 The Commerce Department said the decline "was mainly in purchases of motor vehicles," continuing the pattern reported in the fourth-quarter G.N.P. The October-to-December decline "was centered in output of motor vehicles," it said.
Spending on nondurable goods, which include food and clothing, was virtually flat, edging up just $200 million after a $1.1 billion decline the previous month.
And spending on services, which until recently had been immune from most recessionary pressures, slowed to a $2.4 billion gain, from a $20.9 billion increase a month earlier.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: WORLD REACTION;
Now, Allies and Others Begin Offering Competing Bids for Postwar Future

BYLINE: By Alan Riding, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Having stood firmly alongside the United States during the climactic days of the Persian Gulf war, Western European governments are quietly preparing to compete with Washington for political influence in the Middle East now that the fighting is over.
The allied victory was hailed across Europe today, with Britain and France particularly cheered by the low loss of life among their combat troops. But already the focus of attention seemed to be shifting to the political and diplomatic challenges ahead. 
 "If we cannot win the peace, our military victory could turn out to be a Pyrrhic victory," the Italian Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, said today. "Winning the peace will be much more difficult than winning the military conflict."
In London today, there were no victory parades or pealing church bells, but British political leaders in the House of Commons paid tribute to President Bush and their own and allied forces for their swift success.
"The victories of peace will take longer than the battles of war," Prime Minister John Major said in the House of Commons. Regional security, he said, "must also deal with the other problems of the region, above all, that of the Palestinians."
Britain and France feel confident that their participation in the war has already earned them places at future negotiating tables. But Germany, Italy, Spain and other European Community nations are also claiming a role in promoting security, stability and development in the postwar Arab world.
 
France Takes 'No Orders'
 Signaling France's intention to play an active role after the war, President Francois Mitterrand said last weekend, "We will spell out the objectives that we consider just, and no one will give us orders." France will demonstrate, he added, that "it has not gone to war against Islam or Arabs."
Today, the European Community promised "a global approach" to the problems of the Middle East, a phrase that Community foreign ministers defined last week as dealing with the Arab-Israeli conflict, the Palestinian question and the Lebanese crisis as well as the aftermath of the gulf war.
Driving the diplomacy is acute awareness that Europe's historical, cultural and geographical links to the Arab world make its interests different from those of the United States. It therefore hopes to insure that Washington is not alone in determining the future of the region.
It also wants to protect European companies that have long done good business in the Middle East. The only recent sign of disharmony between London and Washington came last week when Britain complained that most contracts for the reconstruction of Kuwait were going to American companies.
In the months leading up to the war, though, the 12 showed anything but unity. Unable to agree on a joint response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Britain strongly backed the United States, France offered its own peace plans and other nations refused to send ground troops to Saudi Arabia.
 
Regional Bloc Frays
 Yet now that the fighting is over, the cohesion of the anti-Iraq coalition may again be tested by differences within Europe as well as by competition between Europe and the United States. Indeed, in recent weeks European governments have acted more individually than as a regional bloc.
Britain, for instance, has strong historical and economic ties to Kuwait and the gulf emirates and seems most interested in helping to build a security system in the region, albeit without direct participation of British ground troops. In this, its position is almost identical to Washington's.
For Bonn, the war has been a diplomatic disaster, as Germany was criticized for its reluctance to help the allies and embarrassed by revelations that German companies developed Iraq's chemical weapons capacity. Earlier this month, it sent Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to Israel and then to Jordan, Egypt and Syria in the hope of patching up ties.
France, Spain and Italy, which have large populations of North African immigrants, are most alarmed by the deterioration of their relations with Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia, where pro-Iraqi sentiments were running strong. "We must avoid hurting Arab public opinion that felt solidarity with Iraq," a French politician said today.
Paris, Madrid and Rome also believe that the bitter legacy of Iraq's defeat can be buried in these and other Arab countries only if the Palestinian problem is addressed. But they recognize that only Washington can persuade Israel to take part in an international conference that tackles this question.
European governments do at least agree that the Palestine Liberation Organization has destroyed its credibility by supporting Iraq in the war. "The question of the P.L.O. will have to be looked at differently in the light of many of its reactions in recent weeks," Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said today.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Goes Above $19 a Barrel; OPEC Talks Are Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices rose above $19 a barrel yesterday as a new calm in the Persian Gulf was quickly overtaken by other concerns in the futures market's first postwar trading session.
"That war is not a factor any more," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. "The war premium is completely gone from this market, and all the focus now is on the upcoming OPEC meeting on March 11. It's a complete turn now to look at fundamentals." 
 Perceptions that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will soon move to cut back production have been pushing oil higher much of the week.
Crude oil for delivery in April settled yesterday at $19.16 a barrel, up 30 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Just a week earlier, crude had settled below $19 a barrel for the first time since the Persian Gulf crisis began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. At the market's peak, in October, oil traded above $40 a barrel.
But oil traders discounted the end of the war last week, and crude prices have been inching ahead on speculation that the postwar oil market will not be as glutted with crude as some experts had predicted.
The war ended Wednesday night when President Bush said that the United States-led coalition forces were suspending their offensive military operations against Iraq. By yesterday oil analysts were no longer using the words "war" and "peace" to explain what was moving the price of petroleum up and down.
"People are focusing on what OPEC is going to do and that there is more damage than they thought in the Middle East," said Sandy Weinberger, an oil broker at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Oil experts said it could be months or even years before Iraq and Kuwait could repair all the damage the war brought to their oil industries.
Refined petroleum products also traded higher, as the futures contracts for their delivery in March expired in New York.
Unleaded gasoline for delivery in March settled at 67.92 cents a gallon, up another 0.72 cent after several strong gains in recent sessions.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
'Junk Bond' Price Rise Continues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of high-yield "junk bonds" continued to rise yesterday and finished February with their best-ever monthly return.
An index of 339 high-yield issues compiled by the First Boston Corporation posted a return of 8.6 percent in February, the highest monthly return since the firm began compiling monthly statistics in 1985. For the first two months, the index has posted a return of 11.6 percent. 
 Robert Long, head of high-yield research at First Boston, said the rise in junk prices was a result of bargain-hunting, as well as the recent sharp rise in the stock market.
 
'Market Was Clearly Oversold'
 "The high-yield market was clearly oversold from years of negative news," Mr. Long said, "and the stock market seems to be indicating that people are confident the recession will be brief. If the latter is true, and recovery comes quickly, the high-yield market should have significant upside potential from here."
Concern that the economy may be about to improve was also prevalent in the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday, but with the opposite result: prices fell and interest rates rose.
A speedy end to the recession would benefit investors in high-yield securities because a recovery would probably reduce the risk that companies that have issued junk bonds would fail.
 
Effect of 'Bombing Baghdad'
 "Market psychology took a tremendous turn for the better the night we started bombing Baghdad," said David Fineman, a high-yield trader at Jeffries & Company. "At this point, confidence has improved to the point where the market could take a new issue."
Although a number of less-than-investment-grade companies have sold issues through private placements, it has been about a year since a company held a public offering of high-yield securities.
Mr. Fineman and other high-yield traders said that prices of most issues rose by about a quarter to a half of a point yesterday and that gains of that magnitude have been recorded steadily over the last two weeks.
The price improvement has pushed the yield on First Boston's index down to 16.8 percent, from 18.4 percent at the end of January. The interest rate differential, or spread, relative to Treasury issues of comparable maturity has narrowed to 9.09 percentage points, from 10.85 a month ago.
 
Unloading AAA-Rated Securities
 As high-yield investors have been making money on the prospect of an early end to the recession, participants in the AAA-rated Treasury securities market have been unloading positions in the last week or so for fear a recovery would increase inflationary pressures. Investors in highly rated fixed-income securities dislike any increase in inflation because it erodes the value of the asset.
Some signs that might presage an economic rebound were apparent yesterday, but signs of continued weakness were in evidence, too. Traders chose to concentrate on the former.
Specifically, a survey of purchasing managers in the Chicago area suggested that economic activity during February improved marginally from a month earlier, even though it remained at a low level.
 
Effect of Money Supply Report
 And prices moved lower later in the day after the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply posted larger-than-expected increases in the week ended Feb. 18.
Specifically, traders and analysts said they were surprised with the $6.8 billion increase in M-2, the monetary aggregate the Fed watches most closely.
Earlier this year, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, expressed concern about sluggish growth in the monetary aggregates. In so doing, Mr. Greenspan seemed to suggest that the weekly numbers had regained lost importance in determining future policy moves.
"Right now, M-2 growth is just under its interim target," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International. "At the moment, there is no monetary imperative for the Fed to do anything. Everybody in the market was loaded to the gills expecting rates to come down, and they have been disillusioned."
Essentially overlooked was a report showing that personal income and consumption expenditures fell sharply in January.
 
The Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 96 11/32, down 3/4 point, to yield 8.20 percent, up from 8.13 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 5/32, down 13/32, to yield 8.02 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 13/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 7.07 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved higher.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.03 percent, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.05 percent.
 
Corporate Offerings
 A number of issues were offered in the investment-grade corporate bond market yesterday, including a competitive offering of $150 million worth of first and refunding mortgage bonds for the Duke Power Company.
The 8 3/4 percent securities, which mature March 1, 2021, were priced at $96.457, to yield 9.096 percent, 95 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
A bid from Merrill Lynch won the issue, which is rated AA-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The bonds are nonrefundable for five years.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to down as much as 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
What Happens To Oil Prices?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AN effort to assess the economic consequences of the crushing of Iraq and the expulsion of Saddam Hussein's forces from Kuwait must start with the effect on oil prices and supplies.
It was the Iraqi leader's aim, long before the invasion of Kuwait, to gain more oil resources, force up oil prices and achieve the wealth and arms he needed to dominate the Arab world. After being frustrated by Iran, he turned against Kuwait. 
 Last summer, in the midst of an oil glut partly caused by Kuwait's frantic step-up of sales to the West, Iraq stepped up its pressure on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, among others, acceded. On July 27 an OPEC agreement raised the target price to $21 a barrel. At the time, John H. Lichtblau, a leading oil analyst, said of the agreement: "It's a sea change. Higher prices were always within OPEC's grasp if they adhered to discipline. This time, discipline is guaranteed by a principal player which carries a loaded gun."
In the new issue of Foreign Policy, Prof. M. A. Adelman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology writes: "As a beneficiary of this increase, Saudi Arabia conveniently ignored the Iraqi threat. But then the enforcer, like many before him, decided there was more profit as a hijacker."
Now that the enforcer-hijacker's power has been broken, what happens to the oil price? Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, said in an interview yesterday, "That depends on whether Saudi Arabia decides to keep its oil production up." He credited the Saudis with "averting a bad problem" during the oil embargo and the war.
Despite the run-up past $40 a barrel early in the Persian Gulf confrontation, the oil price has come down almost to where it was a couple of weeks before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last Aug. 2, but it is still well above the $13 price that Saudi light crude touched last June. Oil closed yesterday at $19.16.
Mr. McCormack noted that OPEC's target price was still $21 a barrel, but said he favored "letting the market do its thing." He opposed "a misguided attempt" by the United States or other governments to try to set the price.
But Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other OPEC members can be expected to make a strong effort to stabilize the price at $21, the target set before the Iraqi invasion. They will argue that such a price will be crucial to pay for the reconstruction of Kuwait, including the cleanup of the oil-polluted gulf. They also argue that they need the money for plan to redistribute wealth to the poor Arab states, ostensibly to assuage the anger of poor Arab individuals and states against rich Arabs and their Western allies.
Skeptics say such arguments are only rationalizations for the wealthy oil producers' desire to stabilize prices at a high level.
But they may get some support in the West. Some American officials, who insisted on anonymity, said France would try to support the Arabs in this effort to stabilize oil prices, for two reasons: first, because President Francois Mitterrand is a Socialist and favors redistribution of income, and second and more important, because France wants to puts its arm around the shoulder of wealthy Arab countries and be in a position to get big contracts for building roads, air bases, factories, generating plants and weapons.
But there could well be conflict within the United States Government on whether to seek a stabilized oil price at a high level; this is a position that might be supported both by contractors or oil producers looking for business in the Middle East and by domestic producers seeking wider profit maragins. Factors strengthening forces that want to see the Arab oil states earn more would be the huge United States budget deficit and the opposition to using taxpayer dollars to finance reconstruction in the gulf.
Mr. McCormack contends, however, that it would be impossible to stabilize the oil price at a high level, even if the United States wanted to, because of the competition from natural gas, coal, nuclear and other energy sources. Further, he said, OPEC now controls less than half the world's oil. "All previous oil price run-ups," he said, "have resulted, without exception, from political acts, and it is a complete illusion that we could or would do that now -- nobody is prepared for it." Nevertheless, he expects OPEC, trying to counter the market, to "do its thing."
The resolution of these forces, in his view, will be an oil price of about $18. Professor Adelman thinks that with wide oscillations that price may be about right in the year ahead. Some oil industry analysts put the average price somewhat lower -- at $15 a barrel.
The elimination of Iraq as the enforcer or hijacker makes it likely that a lower price than OPEC's $21 target will prevail, and the lower price will help to support American and world economic recovery. So, too, will the ample flow of contracts to United States companies and the replenishment of military stockpiles in the near future. Such factors are not great enough, relative to gross national product, to provide the basis for expecting a boom, but they do support expectations of a gradual American recovery.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wal-Mart's Net Up 13%; 2 Others Fall

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's fastest-growing retailer, yesterday reported record profits and sales for the fourth quarter and the year ended Jan. 31. But two other leading chains, the J. C. Penney Company and the May Department Stores Company, said their fourth-quarter nets fell below those of the previous year.
But despite Wal-Mart's higher earnings and the other companies' disappointing fourth-quarter earnings, investors showed a mixed reaction. Wal-Mart's shares closed lower yesterday, while Penney and May's stocks advanced. 
 "The companies' results are all in line with expectations," said Robert Raiff, research director of C. J. Lawrence & Company, in New York. "Only a couple of retailers were expected to show full-year rises in net income. People expected more from Wal-Mart because of its great record. May has become the biggest department-store operator, while Penney's seems to have lost direction."
Commenting on the retailing outlook, William R. Howell, Penney's chairman and chief executive, said, "Despite the continuing weak consumer demand in 1991, we believe J. C. Penney is well positioned to resume its pattern of sales and earnings growth as soon as the recession clouds lift and consumers once again display confidence in their own, and the country's, well-being."
While yesterday's results showed that Wal-Mart remained America's most profitable retailer, it is not quite yet the largest in sales. Sears, Roebuck & Company still retains that position with sales in the year ended January of $33.95 billion, or about $1.3 billion more than Wal-Mart's $32.6 billion and even more ahead of the K Mart Corporation's $32.1 billion. But given Wal-Mart's 20 percent-plus growth rate in sales versus Sears's much smaller one, analysts expect Wal-Mart to become No. 1 in a month or two.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Wal-Mart
Wal-Mart reported a 13 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings, with its net totaling $481.8 million, or 42 cents a share, against $425.9 million, or 38 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 28 percent, to $10.36 billion from $8.11 billion.
Wal-Mart was the only American retailer to record at least $1 billion in annual net income. Its net for the year rose 19 percent, to $1.29 billion, or $1.14 a share, from $1.08 billion, or 95 cents a share, the previous year. Annual sales rose 26 percent, to $32.6 billion from $25.81 billion.
But investors reacted with disappointment to the quarterly earnings rise, having expected Wal-Mart's traditional gain of more than 20 percent each year. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the company's shares lost $1.25, to $35.375.
David Glass, president and chief executive of Wal-Mart, described the year just ended as "one of tremendous challenge and opportunity."
 
J. C. Penney
Penney said its net income in the final quarter fell 44 percent, to $206 million, or $1.68 a share, from $367 million, or $2.95 a share in the period a year earlier. Sales were flat at $5.53 billion. In the full year, net income fell 31 percent, to $577 million, or $4.59 a share, from $802 million, or $6.31 a share, the previous year. Annual sales rose 2 percent, to $17.41 billion from $17.06 billion.
Citing the recession, Penney said its operating profit had declined in the final quarter and the year because of sales and an increase in its inventory accounting charge because of inflation, especially in women's apparel and fine jewelry.
Penney's stock was up 50 cents yesterday, to $53.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
May
May Department Stores said its fourth-quarter net income fell 11 percent, to $252 million, or $1.91 a share, from $283 million, or $2 a share, in the 1989 period. The recent quarter had an inventory accounting charge of $17 million against an inventory accounting credit of $34 million in 1989's fourth quarter. Sales rose almost 2 percent, to $3.28 billion from $3.22 billion.
For the full year, May reported almost flat earnings of $500 million, or $3.74 a share, compared with $498 million, or $3.52 a share, for 1989. Sales for the year rose 6 percent, to $10.04 billion from $9.46 billion.
May's stock rose $1.125 yesterday, to $50.625.

HEADLINE: Bottom of the Housing Slump Is Seen in the New York Area

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
The New York area's housing slump may have finally hit bottom, or come close to it.
Lenders say that in the last two months, during what is normally a winter lull, demand increased for mortgage loans. Brokers report a sudden surge in sales contracts and say that more people have been attending open houses in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. 
 "This is not a big new wave coming in to buy homes," said Eugene Sherman, chief economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, which supplies money to mortgage lenders in the three-state area. "But it looks like the tide is no longer going out."
While brokers are buoyed by the renewed interest, they remain cautious about the near-term prospects.
There are signs that people are showing greater interest in buying homes elsewhere in the country as well. A survey of 300 builders this month by the National Association of Homebuilders found that prospective buyers were visiting new subdivision sites at nearly twice the rate they did at the start of the year.
In the West, "There has been a distinctive turnaround in our sales in February in the San Francisco Bay area and the Seattle area," said Larry Knapp, president of the northwest regional operations for Coldwell Banker.
Brokerage companies in the South also report more closings and dwindling numbers of unsold houses.
In a report to Congress yesterday, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said his agency also saw signs that the nation's real estate slump might be about to turn around, for residential and commercial property.
Falling home prices have combined with declining interest rates to bring housing to its most affordable point since 1977, he said. Already, there is anecdotal if not statistical evidence that home sales are picking up, he said.
In Mercer County, N.J., which includes Princeton and Trenton, the inventory of homes for sale was lower in January than a year earlier, falling to 4,717, from 4,867. "We have passed the bottom," said Richard A. Weidel, president of a Princeton brokerage that bears his name. It reported 223 home sales in January, 30 more than a year earlier.
More than a half-dozen New York City brokerage firms that deal in condominiums and cooperative apartments report increased sales. Among them are the Corcoran Group, which said sales were running 40 percent higher this month than in February 1990, and Brown Harris Stevens, which said its sales more than doubled beginning in January.
 
Mortgage Rates Down
 "The fever has broken," said William Raveis, president of William Raveis Real Estate, a large brokerage in Fairfield County, Conn. He said his company sold 392 homes in January, 100 more than in January 1990.
In Montville, N.J., hopeful buyers began lining up at 4 A.M. on Saturday, Feb. 16, for the opening of a sales office for 78 two-story town-house condominiums priced at $130,000 to $165,000. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., a large home builder that is offering the condominiums, said purchase agreements were signed for all 78 by the next day.
If the housing market has indeed reached its trough, there is ample cause, economists and analysts say. They point to the sharp decline in mortgage interest rates, now well below 10 percent, and to the even steeper fall in home prices. Those declines have converged to make houses, condominiums and co-ops bargains -- at least compared with the lofty prices of the mid-1980's.
Prices over all are continuing to fall, in fact, as buyers seem to be seeking out the less expensive homes, brokers said.
Chemical Bank, a major mortgage lender in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, said home loan applications jumped 46 percent in January from January 1990, and were up 62 percent from December. In Westchester County, Haber Mortgages Ltd., a broker of loans for 40 banks, said its applications rose 50 percent in January, and are up another 50 percent in February.
Arbor National Mortgage Inc., which is based on Long Island and has lending offices throughout the New York area, said its applications were also up 50 percent in January, and another 50 percent this month.
 
Many Delayed Purchases
 Surveys have found that thousands of New York area residents have been postponing home purchases. And while no one is predicting a return of the go-go 80's, marriage, children, job transfers, retirement and other family needs are persuading some to wait no longer.
In this shifting market, two people who earn their living by keeping a keen eye on the local real estate scene now have something else in common. Both have entered the market to buy homes.
The two, Michael Giliberto, a Wall Street real estate analyst, and Kevin Miller, a New Jersey appraiser, are among a ripple of buyers that has emerged since December.
"Lower interest rates help; reality has finally dawned on sellers, and I need shelter," said Mr. Giliberto, a vice president in the real estate research department of Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm.
Since moving to New York City from Dallas early in 1989, Mr. Gililberto has rented a Manhattan apartment, saying he did not want to risk buying while prices were falling. But that changed on Feb. 14, he said, when he contracted to buy a house in Larchmont, the suburban Westchester County town. He made his decision in part because he is getting married and in part because he felt the time was right to make a deal.
To be sure, some measures suggest that the New York area market remains deeply mired in the slump. The National Association of Realtors, a trade group in Washington, said the number of home sales fell 14 percent in New York, 16 percent in New Jersey and 13 percent in Connecticut in the fourth quarter of 1990, compared with the comparable period of 1989.
It also said that a similar pattern had emerged in much of the nation. "This was probably the lowest point for the economy and housing we've seen in several years," said John A. Tucillo, the group's economist.
Construction of new homes has plummeted across the Northeast, falling another 30 percent in January, according to the Commerce Department. Inventories of unsold homes remain bloated, and analysts warn that they might expand with the first strong signals of strengthening demand. Many homeowners who wanted to sell but decided not to try in a sagging market might then jump in.
 
Prices Still Sliding
 Home prices show no immediate signs of rebounding after a free fall that has lasted at least two years.
"The sustained slide has been the most severe in the relatively young history of the city's co-op and condominium marketplace," said the Corcoran Group, which surveys sales of expensive Manhattan apartments. It reported a 26 percent price decline between the spring of 1989 and the end of last year, and in January, despite increased activity, it reported another 3 percent slip.
The recent buying spurt could be a fluke. Unusually warm winter weather could be a reason. And house hunters might be experiencing the same surge of consumer confidence that has propelled stock prices since the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war. But now, with the war over, they could retreat from the market as attention shifts to problems in the regional economy and their own household finances.
Still, signs of a strengthening market abound.
In what may signal future demand, HSH Associates, a New Jersey company that publishes information on mortgage rates and terms, said sales of its newsletter soared 300 percent in January, with most of the increase in the New York area. Part of the spate of loan applications and inquiries came from homeowners electing to refinance their mortgages at lower rates. But executives said most of the demand had been from buyers.
"Suddenly, we are inundated," said Hall Wilkie, vice president of Brown Harris, who said it sold 22 apartments in January, compared with only 9 a year earlier. It said sales in the first half of February had already exceeded February 1990.
 
First-Time Buyers Lured
 Industry executives say inexpensive homes -- particularly those within reach of first-time buyers -- have been attracting the bulk of recent demand. And while these purchasers may allow some sellers to move to larger houses, the experts say there is little evidence that demand is "trickling up" to the most expensive homes.
More expensive properties, ranging from two-bedroom condominiums in Manhattan priced at more than $500,000 to large suburban houses priced over $1 million, have experienced the steepest erosion in value, and may not recover for years, according to some forecasts.
"We have simply run out of people who can afford to pay $500,000 for a house," said Michael Aronstein, president of Comstock Partners, a Wall Street money management firm. Since 1988 his company has been predicting a decline in home values, particularly at the high end of the market, that might last until the late 1990's.
Nonetheless, he added that the recent increase in activity among those seeking "shelter for utility" might signal a turn for middle-income residents across the New York area.
 
Planning a Family
 One prospective first-time buyer is Mr. Miller, the New Jersey appraiser, who is 27 years old. Since December, he said, he has looked at 20 houses, hoping to find something for $150,000 or less.
One reason to buy now, he said, is that he and his wife, Kathleen, are planning a family. A more immediate reason, he added, is the drop in interest rates, now below 9 percent on 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages offered by some New Jersey lenders.
"Those rates might not last," said Mr. Miller, who two weeks ago bid $139,000 for a house in Hunterdon County that is in need of repair, but was originally priced at $169,000. After second thoughts, he said, he moved on to look at other properties.
For many would-be buyers who already own homes, the question now is less a matter of finding properties they like at a discount, but first selling what they already have. Many fear being saddled with the expense of paying for two homes at once.
Still, some people have concluded that there are enough signs of an increase in potential buyers that they can buy what they want now, and be able sell what they have later.
"I know I am taking a calcuated risk," said Cheryl Burton, a psychiatrist and part-time real estate broker in Westchester County. Last week she signed a contract to buy a house in Greenburgh even though her other house in the same town has been on the market for eight months.
Ms. Burton said she was able to buy the home she wanted for under $300,000 -- 20 percent less than the seller had asked. She plans to close the deal by May, and said her other house "has been attracting a lot more attention from buyers, and will certainly sell by the spring."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
The New York area's housing slump may finally have hit bottom, or come close to it. Lenders say that in the last two months, during what is normally a winter lull, demand increased for mortgage loans. Brokers report a surge in sales contracts. [Page A1.]
Consumer spending dropped 0.6 percent in January, the Government said, after slipping severely in the final quarter of last year. It was the steepest decline in more than four years. [D1.] 
 Seidman proposed a plan to shore up the ailing deposit insurance fund that calls for the F.D.I.C. to borrow $64.4 billion over five years from other Government agencies. [D1.]
Prices farmers get for raw products declined 0.7 percent from January to February, the Agriculture Department said. [D2.]
The Keating Five case moved from the Senate Ethics Committee to the unpredictable arena of American politics. [A22.]
A business group warned that school improvement would fail unless companies were more active in child health programs. [A22.]
 
Companies
Revlon is in talks about a possible sale of the company with Procter & Gamble, L'Oreal and Unilever. The talks are reportedly preliminary and could last two to four weeks longer. [D1.]
Wal-Mart reported record profits and sales for the quarter and year. But Penney and May said profits were down. [D1.]
The Henri Bendel store about to open will be the first large new store on Fifth Avenue in years, a distinction that carries as much uncertainty as it does promise. [D1.]
Citicorp expects loan delinquencies to continue to rise this year, especially in the first quarter, its chief financial officer said. [D5.]
Ford Motor announced plans to cut its salaried work force through layoffs and early retirements. [D4.]
The Daily News and its striking pressmen's union halted their talks, saying they remained deadlocked on critical issues. [A1.]
Prudential Insurance and seven philanthropies are beginning an ambitious program to revitalize poor city neighborhoods. [A18.]
 
International
Money flowing from the U.S. to Iraq for weapons was suspected as a jury indicted three former officials of the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and four Iraqis on fraud charges involving more than $4 billion in loans to Iraq. [D1.]
Lufthansa and Air France moved quickly to restore Mideast flights that had been suspended because of the war. [D2.]
 
Markets
Stocks fluctuated wildly, with prices closing mixed as investors moved out of highfliers and into less-favored stocks. The Dow lost 6.93, to 2,882.18. [D8.]
Prices of "junk bonds" continued to rise, and finished February with their best-ever monthly return. [D15.]
The dollar advanced, lifted by the cease-fire and speculation that U.S. interest rates would remain stable. Gold rose. [D16.]
Oil prices rose above $19 as a new calm in the Persian Gulf was quickly overtaken by other concerns. [D16.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: REPARATIONS;
War Damages and Old Debts Could Exhaust Iraq's Assets

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Iraq has very little money to pay war reparations, and had overdue debts to many creditors even before it invaded Kuwait, current and former United States Government officials and other experts say.
The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Oct. 29 that made Iraq liable for war damage and losses suffered by Kuwait and other countries. When President Bush specified Wednesday the allies' conditions for a permanent cease-fire, he included Baghdad's "acceptance in principle of Iraq's responsibility to pay compensation for the loss, damage and injury its aggression has caused." 
 Iraq said Wednesday that it would comply with all 12 resolutions.
But forcing Iraq to pay reparations will be difficult, given its lack of money, and will conflict with other American interests, said Richard W. Murphy, a former Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.
 
Empty Coffers Influence War
 Iraq's near-empty treasury has been a cause of the war and an obstacle to its conclusion.
On Feb. 15, when Iraq first said it would consider negotiating a withdrawal, one condition was the cancellation of its foreign debts and thoseof neighbors who had not assisted the allied war effort.
An eight-year war with Iran ended in 1988 with Iraq virtually bankrupt. "They were in a very tight condition financially, which is why we had the invasion" of Kuwait, Mr. Murphy said.
The scarcity of overseas Iraqi assets has prompted speculation that the only way to raise the money may be to garnish Iraqi oil revenues.
Iraq's debts and potential liabilities dwarf its overseas assets, which were frozen Aug. 6 by the United Nations, said Sharif Ghalib, Director of the Africa and Middle East department of the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based research group.
Estimates of the frozen assets range from $4 billion to $6 billion. By comparison, Kuwait has said it would seek up to $60 billion in reparations and United States companies are preparing damage claims that could total several billion dollars, said Javade Chaudhri, a partner in international corporate law at Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington.
Other countries can also make claims, with the Kuwaitis saying they will seek the return of property looted by Iraqi military forces.
 
Iraq Owes Billions
 Iraq owes $35 billion to Western governments and banks, $11 billion to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, and as much as $40 billion to other Arab countries.
Mr. Murphy pointed out that garnishing Iraq's oil revenue would conflict with threats to block its oil exports to force the opening of its nuclear, chemical and biological research sites to international inspection.
Iraq's oil exports are worth about $17 billion a year, assuming a price of $20 a barrel and a return to 1989 production levels of 2.4 million barrels per day, said Fareed S. Mohamedi, an economist at the Petroleum Finance Company in Washington.
Out of those revenues, plus a pittance from date exports, Iraq must service its debt, rebuild its infrastructure, and import several billion dollars in food and foreign parts and equipment.
A state-run Iranian newspaper said yesterday that a Security Council resolution on July 20, 1987, made Iraq liable for reparations from its war with Iran. But the resolution called only for an investigation of the causes of the war.

HEADLINE: Ultimately, Customers Will Bear the Cost

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bankers said yesterday that the higher deposit insurance premiums they must pay the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will be spread without great pain among their customers and shareholders. But they complained that all banks, including the strong, were being required to pay for the problems of the weak.
"Everybody is going to try to pass along the cost to their customers with higher fees, lower interest rates on deposits and higher rates on loans," said Raymond V. O'Brien, chairman of the Emigrant Savings Bank, New York. "We can afford it, but it definitely is going to put a dent in our bottom line." 
 Bank deposit insurance premiums will rise on July 1 to 23 cents per $100 of deposits, nearly double the 12 cents charged a year ago and up from the 19.5 cents that went into effect Jan. 1. The 23-cent premium will raise about $870 million a year for the F.D.I.C.'s Bank Insurance Fund. Banking industry profits last year were estimated at more than $17 billion.
 Under the current system, where insurance premiums are charged only on deposits in domestic offices, the impact is greatest on those banks that rely heavily on domestic deposits and whose earnings are already at a low level.
John W. Spiegel, executive vice president at SunTrust Banks Inc., in Atlanta, said the need for banks to keep profits high enough to attract capital will require that the higher insurance costs be eventually passed on to customers. "Most of the banks in our system were planning for a 19.5 cent premium this year, though some had anticipated it could be higher," he said.
"It is reasonable to expect the banking system to pay for its deposit insurance system" Mr. Spiegel said, "though I think higher-quality banks should pay lower premiums than weaker banks, just like non-smokers pay lower life insurance premiums than smokers."
James W. Kienker, executive vice president at Boatmen's Bancshares, St. Louis, said that collecting the higher deposit insurance premiums from bank customers and shareholders was ultimately not much different from collecting the cost from taxpayers. "Indirectly, all taxpayers are customers of ours or some other deposit-taking institution," he said.
Orin Kramer, a New York consultant to financial companies, said that questions about the health of the banking system were more important than the debate over how to refinance the F.D.I.C.
"The more important question still facing the F.D.I.C.," he said, "is which banks are going to fail and how fast will they be closed."
Because insurance premiums are charged only on deposits in domestic offices, a recent analysis by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods concluded that the higher rates will hurt many banking companies in the economically troubled Northeast and Middle Atlantic States. These banks, the study said, are already financially weak and rely heavily on domestic deposits for their capital.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
"Since Eve ate apples, much depends on dinner," wrote Lord Byron, alluding to the affinity between romance and gastronomy, which has been celebrated in literature, theater and art over the centuries. When it comes to restaurants, though, the forums for seduction are becoming as rare as gentlemen's duels for a lady's hand. Economics and fashion dictate that restaurants today be big, boisterous and fast paced. Happily, the Sign of the Dove remains an exception.
 Andrew D'Amico, the enterprising chef who has run the kitchen since 1986, continues to refine his fundamentally Provencal menu, which has tributaries from Morocco, Italy and America. There is something for every taste in his repertory, and dishes are as distinctive as they are thoughtfully orchestrated. 
 If there is one area that needs tightening at this restaurant, it is the front desk. Upon entering, you are greeted by a hostess who directs you to the coat room, then dispatches you down a hallway to see the maitre d'hotel. The greeter, however, is nowhere to be found. Men in dark suits scurry up and down the stairs. You try to make wistful eye contact with all of them. No luck. After three or four awkward minutes, I started to feel like a job applicant who had arrived at an inopportune moment. My dinner companions, who arrived later, had the same experience. In all other respects, though, the service staff is well regimented and professional, although the kitchen can be slow.
The Sign of the Dove's main dining rooms, separated by brick arches with wrought-iron filigree, are enchanting with clusters of flowers, skylights, soft indirect lighting and roomy, well-separated tables. Virtually every appetizer can be recommended. One of my favorites was a crunchy pancake of coiled capelli, or angel hair pasta, surrounded by perfectly cooked sweetbreads seasoned with capers, brown butter and port. Sweet little clams came in a peppery broth chunky with potatoes, lean Chinese sausage and watercress. A casserole of lobster meat and oysters in a light shellfish stock, bound with cream and perfumed with fresh fennel, was a paragon of delicacy. A delightful special one evening had a Moroccan flair: shrimp marinated in the chef's variation of chermoula, the Moroccan condiment. His interpretation of it combines paprika, cumin, cayenne, garlic, lemon juice, cilantro and olive oil. The marinated shrimp were grilled and served in a snappy fish broth with butternut squash.
 If you are in the mood to splurge, there is a luxurious little igloo of glistening salmon slices encasing salmon caviar and creme fraiche over a slice of brioche.
 The Sign of the Dove has a wide-reaching wine list with prices that are generally fair. The best selections for the money are found among French, Alsace and Loire labels, as well as American chardonnays, cabernet sauvignons and pinot noirs.
 A unifying strength of this kitchen is the delicacy of the sauces. This can be seen in the pink-cooked medallions of lamb over a light but robustly flavored stock sauce. In the center is a packet of cabbage holding minced lamb sausage, pine nuts, raisins, bulgur and sweet peppers. The same goes for thick, tender veal medallions in a rosemary cream sauce with buttery herbed green noodles on the side.
 Sauces could not salvage an overcooked $36 veal chop (although on a second sampling, it was delicious), nor a rib-eye steak that lacked a beefy punch. A good example of Mr. D'Amico's international approach can be tasted in his roast baby chicken served in a shallow bowl over cumin-perfumed Basmati rice, cardamom-spiced lentils and okra. A solid all-American dish is his grilled Muscovy duck breast, well charred and deliciously smoky, paired with moist little pumpkin pancakes, cranberry chutney and roast pears.
 Seafood is no less enticing. Roasted snapper in a coating of herbs and bread crumbs is excellent in a grainy mustard sauce with (tough) braised endive. Perfectly grilled salmon is set over couscous moistened with a piquant fish broth with chickpeas, carrots and squash.
 Sweets to cap off a flirtatious evening abound. A tropical fruit trifle served in an oversize brandy snifter would be a challenge to share. Blueberry strudel made with sourdough pastry is outstanding, as is the chocolate-dusted mascarpone torte afloat in a pool of mocha sauce. Warm lemon cream tartlet is unbalanced, with too much crust and not enough lemon. Go instead for the terrific coffee granita drizzled with Sambuca cream.
 It's a pleasure to see that the Sign of the Dove continues to fly high. If, indeed, much depends on dinner, there are few equal settings in town.
 
The Sign of the Dove ***
 1110 Third Avenue, at 65th Street, in Manhattan, (212) 861-8080.
Atmosphere: Romantic and roomy dining rooms separated by brick arches. Piano bar.
Service: Regimentally correct and efficient. Kitchen sometimes takes too long between courses.

HEADLINE: Fortunes and Spoils of War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL NORMAN; Michael Norman, the author of "These Good Men," a book about war and comradeship, is an associate professor of journalism at New York University.

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y.

 BODY:
CIVILIZATION'S worst nightmare has always been history's best story.
Here, for example, on a white pedestal in a glass display case is a steel helmet: 1 pound 11 ounces, gray-blue flecked with rust. The helmet was worn by a Frenchman in 1916 during the 10 months of bloody siege at Verdun. By some estimates, 40 million rounds of high explosive artillery were spent by both sides in that battle. By some estimates, nearly 900,000 Germans and Frenchmen were left missing, wounded or dead. 
 One of these surely was the wearer of the blue steel helmet that now sits on the pedestal in the case at the West Point Museum here. The helmet has a hole in the right side, a roughly rectangular opening, one and a quarter inches high and half an inch wide. The edges of the hole curl inward, inarguable evidence that a large piece of high-speed shrapnel punctured the helmet just above the wearer's right ear.
There are other items in the display case -- grenades, barbed wire, long-barreled rifles, a light machine gun -- but it is the blue helmet with its jagged and mortal hole that seems to capture those who pass.
"This guy didn't do too well," said a short woman in a red raincoat, pausing with a companion. "Look, he got a hole in his head. Look at it!"
 War has been everywhere in recent weeks. It has slumped in a seat on the morning bus, it has queued up at the lunch counter, it has held the airwaves late at night. And in every venue there has been an argument. Few on the home frontreally knew exactly where to stand or sit. Dinner parties often turned on "political realities" and "moral imperatives." What began as an innocent chat often ended in an ideological harangue.
Having a sense of history, of course, does little to mediate the arguments or still the discord; the early hours of any war are filled with passion, not perspective. But there is something about a museum -- like the one here in Olmsted Hall, a neo-Gothic, brown-brick building just outside the main gate of the United States Military Academy -- a museum of flintlocks and cannon and bombs, that leaves a visitor strangely serene.
Although the United States Army has been collecting war trophies since the late 18th century, it did not gather them together for public display until 1854. The West Point Museum has 45,000 objects in its collection with some 1,300 on display at one time: weapons, uniforms, flags, portraits. In September 1989, the collection -- described by the director, Michael E. Moss, as the largest diversified military collection open to the public -- was moved to its current site, a building with two main wings behind the Academy's visitors center. Mr. Moss estimates that 300,000 people a year make their way across the museum's terrazzo floors and through its six galleries. "If I had to sum up its message, I suppose it would be that leaders continue to emerge, civilization goes on, time proceeds," he said.
It is hard to say why three floors of martial memorabilia and lethal artifacts have such a calming effect. Perhaps the feeling comes from simply strolling around old annals. The detached past is always a relief from the troubled present. A rusting steel helmet with a hole in it can convey a sense of peace that a newly made coffin does not. Maybe it is simply that a museum is like a blank slate. "People create their own version of history," said Roy Rosenzweig, a historian at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va. "An exhibit can mean different things to different people. It is possible to take away different messages."
The West Point Museum, of course, speaks most directly to the patriot. Here, for example, are two portraits of George Washington, one as a colonel in the Virginia Militia -- roughly at the age of 40 -- and the other as commanding general of the Continental Army. In the former he is dark-haired, fresh-faced and eager. In the latter, he is pale, gray and resolute.
 
A British War Prize
 Nearby is a large kettledrum captured from the British Ninth Regiment of Foot, which fell to the Americans at Saratoga in 1777. Kettledrums and the trumpets have long been the musical mainstays of armies. They keep the cadence of march, they herald the advent of battle, they announce the great victory.
"Beat! beat! drums!" wrote Walt Whitman. "Blow! bugles! blow!"
Among the other war trophies, tokens of triumph, is the bejeweled baton that belonged to Hermann Goring, the shrewd air marshal and economic chief of Nazi Germany. Captured by American forces in 1945 and later sentenced at Nuremberg, Goring committed suicide in 1946, the day before he was to be hanged. His baton -- an ivory wand decorated with 20 gold eagles, 640 diamonds and caps of lustrous platinum -- is truly a despot's staff, corrupt and audacious.
Upstairs is a Civil War oil on canvas based on an 1861 woodcut by Thomas Nast. The painting shows a "Grand Parade" of Union troops with flags unfurled, marching up Pennsylvania Avenue in long red-and-blue ranks. It is a stirring scene, so many men, so willing to fight, so ready for self-sacrifice.
 
Oddities of History
 But there is plenty here on display for pacifists as well. On almost every wall and in almost every glass case there is something -- an artifact, a piece of text, a rendering -- that fills the rooms and corridors with a powerful irony.
"Man has engaged in organized war since at least the fourth millennium B.C.," says a wall panel introducing an exhibit on the history of warfare. "Since that time there has been a war of some sort in progress all the time through the present day . . . Unquestionably, war-making is an aspect of human nature which will continue as nations attempt forcibly to impose their will upon others."
A display on ancient battle explains that it was the early Middle Easterners -- Assyrians and Persians -- who developed "the fundamental tactic" of striking quickly and with great force to overwhelm the enemy.
Farther along is a picture of the father of "modern warfare," Gustavus Adolphus, the Swedish king, who, during the Thirty Years' War, organized his army into squadrons and brigades, basic fighting units that endure today. His talent for war, however, did not make the king immune to chance. On Nov. 16, 1632, Gustavus Adolphus was on a battlefield enveloped in fog and he strayed into the fight. His horse, wounded, and no doubt out of control, carried the king headlong into the enemy ranks, where he was brought quickly to the ground and killed with a shot to the head.
 
Napoleonic Artifacts
 Here too are pistols and a gold-and-silver sword that belonged to Napoleon. The panel that explains the Emperor's end seems to foreshadow the battlefield politics -- and expectations -- of a later era: "Two of the most important factors in Napoleon's downfall were the improvement in the ability of the coalition opposing him to act in concert and losses incurred by French armies."
World War I was the first war that really turned on technology: "Organized science was enlisted in direct technical support of military effort. The machines that were most influential were the airplane, the tank, the submarine, and the radio. The introduction of lethal gas also presented a new dimension into warfare."
Finally, near an exit, not far from the blue helmet with the hole in it, is a long white placard that offers some "Reflections."
"Peace," wrote Thucydides, "is an armistice in a war that is continuously going on."
"Only the dead know the end of war," said Plato.
"Nothing is worse than war?" asked Winston Churchill. "Dishonor is worse that war. Slavery is worse than war."
"It is well that war is so terrible," said Robert E. Lee, "we would grow too fond of it."
 
Where and When
 The West Point Museum is near Thayer Gate at Highland Falls, N.Y. Hours are 10:30 A.M. to 4:15 P.M. daily. Free admission. Information: (914) 938-3590 or (914) 938-2203.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Coming to America, to a Chilly Welcome

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
In "Misplaced," a proud Polish woman and her teen-age son immigrate to the United States for political reasons, and rebuild their lives in an environment that is often less than friendly. Settling with relatives in Virginia, they must contend with economic hardship, lack of suitable job opportunities, loneliness, and the supercilious behavior of those not eager to make them feel welcome in a new land.
Halina Nowak (Elzbieta Czyzewska) quickly finds that her mother and half-sister cannot easily accommodate her in their small suburban house, and that after years of separation the family is less than close. ("I always wanted to bring you over, but the time just went by," says Halina's mother, played by Viveca Lindfors.) Halina and her son, Jacek (John Cameron Mitchell), move to a drab apartment and begin the difficult task of making it a home. Meanwhile, Halina also looks for a job. Though she is an accomplished linguist, she can find nothing better suited to her talents than cleaning work at Voice of America headquarters. 
 The film -- which opens today at the Quad Cinema -- proceeds quietly, and without any more fire than its title suggests, to show how Halina and Jacek gradually put down roots. As directed by Louis Yansen, who makes his feature debut with this semiautobiographical story, it is often attractively sincere. The women's roles, though, are written (by Mr. Yansen and Thomas DeWolfe) as virtual catnip for any actress equipped to convey noble suffering, and both Miss Czyzewska and Miss Lindfors have many opportunities to play this to the hilt.
Miss Lindfors, in one scene, confronts street hooligans and shames them into going away. Miss Czyzewska, in another, corners two selfish yuppie women and shames them into giving her an audition as a Voice of America announcer. "I am just a cleaning woman, is that it?" she shouts, bristling with anger. Together with Miss Lindfors, who is also supposed to be doing work of this kind, they make the two most stately, dignified cleaning women imaginable. That may be Mr. Yansen's point, but it is overworked.
Jacek's section of the story is more easygoing. Mr. Mitchell does extremely well in conveying this high school student's shyness, intelligence and eagerness to fit in. Jacek is as obviously superior to his new surroundings as his mother is, but he is less inclined to say so, even to the teen-age girls who make fun of his loud, low-budget American clothes. Mr. Mitchell's Jacek has enough quiet dash to make those teen-age girls eventually see the error of their ways.
Mr. Yansen's direction is plain and sometimes even blunt, but he succeeds in offering a clear and affecting sense of the Nowaks' ordeal. When Jacek struggles to learn the Gettysburg Address and complains of difficulty with the word "unalienable," his mother erupts with the anger that runs tacitly throughout the story. "A word is too hard?" she cries. "You tell me what is so hard about a word!"
 
Misplaced
 
Directed by Louis Yansen; script by Mr. Yansen and Thomas DeWolfe, story by Mr. Yansen; director of photography, Igor Sunara; edited by Michael Berenbaum; music by Michael Urbaniak; production designer, Beth Kuhn; produced by Lisa Zwerling; an Original Cinema Release . At the Quad Cinema, 13th Street west of Fifth Avenue, in Manhattan. Running time: 98 minutes. This film has no rating.
