HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Gulfstream to Be Host for 1992 Breeders' Cup

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 28

 BODY:
Gulfstream Park was named the site of the 1992 Breeders' Cup Series today, and for the second time in four years will serve as host for horse racing's day of champions.
The series of seven races, which was first run in 1984, is rotated each autumn among tracks in different parts of the country. It was held at Gulfstream Park in 1989 and at Belmont Park in New York last year. It will be staged on Nov. 2 this year at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., and on Oct. 31 next year at Gulfstream again. It has also been held at Aqueduct in New York and at Santa Anita and Hollywood Park in California. 
 The return to Gulfstream was announced at the track today by James E. Bassett 3d, president of the Breeders' Cup, who said the vote of the board of directors had been unanimous.
 
Reasons Behind Return
 "There were three compelling reasons for bringing it back to Gulfstream, besides the success we had here two years ago," he said. "The weather, the racing facility and the enthusiasm and support of the community in south Florida."
When Gulfstream was host to the cup in 1989 the event drew 51,342 fans, who wagered $12.3 million and shattered Florida's records for attendance and handle. The program closed with a sizzling stretch run in the Breeders' Cup Classic, with Sunday Silence winning over Easy Goer and going on to be named Horse of the Year.
Bertram Firestone, the chairman and owner of Gulfstream Park, and Douglas Donn, the president, said the track was honored to stage what they called "racing's greatest day." The 1989 event was credited with injecting $50 million into the economy of south Florida.
Bassett said the format for the series would not change, "even though some people have been concerned with the TV ratings." He added that the prize money would be reapportioned, starting this year, with a raise to winning owners from 45 percent of the purses to 52 percent.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: WORLD REACTION - EGYPT;
Cairo Counting Victory's Spoils

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Feb. 28

 BODY:
With the Iraqi Army fully routed, Egypt began looking today to turn its participation in the allied victory into concrete political and economic advantages for itself.
"This crisis has shown that Egypt is indispensible," a senior official said, and the Government seemed intent on making sure that its Western partners and fellow Arab countries appreciated the point and acted on it. 
 President Hosni Mubarak is generally viewed as a big winner in the gulf War, for having supported the United States from the start and for having committed a 40,000-member force that fought well and emerged from the land battle with few casualties.
High on the Cairo's wish list are new security arrangements for the Middle East that would guarantee Egypt's leading role as one of the strongest Arab nations. Egypt also wants its share of the billions that will be spent to rebuild Kuwait.
Kuwaiti officials visiting Cairo last week promised their hosts that they could count on receiving 13 percent of the projected costs, estimated at up to $800 million, for an emergency relief program.
But Egyptian business leaders want a lot more, and they are calling on the Mubarak Government to help them win some of the multi-billion-dollar deals expected when the real reconstruction begins.
"It's a big cake," said Taher el-Sherif, secretary general of the Egyptian Businessmen's Association. "We can have a big piece of it."
 
Long-Term Role in Gulf
 For now, Egypt is insisting that some of its troops remain in the gulf to keep the peace between Iraq and Kuwait and perhaps also along other borders in the region.
They also want the United States and other Western nations to withdraw their forces as quickly as possible, reflecting an undercurrent of suspicion here that these countries, although allies at the moment, may have an agenda of their own for the Middle East that does not take Arab interests to heart.
There are good reasons, diplomats say, for Egypt to want its troops to remain in Kuwait and Iraq. Their presence, it is argued, would be a reminder of Cairo's strategic importance, espcially to oil-wealthy gulf nations.
Next week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is scheduled to visit Cairo and other Middle Eastern capitals, and it is likely that he will be told that the time has come to deal with the Arab-Israeli conflict.
It is not clear, however, how hard Arab leaders will press the Palestinian case before the Americans, partly because the Palestine Liberation Organization won no friends here by casting its lot with Iraq. Even so, sentiment runs strong that Israel's occupation of Arab lands is as urgent a matter as Iraq's seizure of Kuwait.
Referring to the Palestinian issue, the daily newspaper Al Akhbar warned today that "If it remains unsolved, then 20 Saddams, not one Saddam, will appear, and the region will be marked by instability and coups."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE REACTION - WASHINGTON;
A Special Reason To Celebrate

BYLINE: By Peter T. Kilborn, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
After the Vietnam War, the Watergate affair and lesser embarrassments that sometimes made the Government look dumb, clumsy or worse, many career public servants have a special reason to celebrate a swift, successful war.
"It was uplifting that we did something right and it worked," said Pat Gurley, a 47-year-old secretary at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation who has worked for the Government for 28 years. 
 Joseph E. Talbot, 50, an economist at the Department of Labor, said: "I certainly felt quite proud watching the President's announcement. Not just because I'm a Federal employee, but because it's good for the country over all."
Mr. Talbot's department is now absorbed in assuring that the reservists among the men and women who went to war get their civilian jobs and keep all their other employment rights.
 
Thinking Positive About Bush
 Top officials are political appointees, and they predictably support the President down the line. But many career workers, who tend to leave their political biases at home, say they, too, are impressed by the Bush Administration's execution of the war.
Jacqueline Storey, a union leader in the American Federation of Government Employees at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission who is a paralegal aide at the agency, said the Administration terrified her co-workers a few months ago in proposing budget-cutting layoffs.
But the agency escaped the layoffs, Ms. Storey said. And now, with the gulf war, she said: "Opinions have changed regarding the President. I think they're more positive now. He let us know every step of the way what was happening. It was like soap opera. He did no more than what he had to do."
Joseph Jackson, a cartographer, said the Bush Administration's regard for his agency, the Commerce Department's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, must have improved in the war because of the agency's own little-heralded contribution.
Normally, the agency develops maps of the United States, but some of Mr. Jackson's colleagues were called upon to help the Defense Mapping Agency with its maps of the gulf region that pilots used in finding Iraqi targets.
Mr. Jackson said the maps "had to be constantly updated because Hussein was constantly changing the topography," digging trenches and building berms. The information was then fed into the computers the pilots used in firing their weapons.
Like many other Federal agencies, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has also faced budgetary threats, in its case proposals to hand its work over to private industry.
"We're coming through that all right," Mr. Jackson said. "I think our value has increased."

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Mother of All Columns

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
If we think hard enough now, and if after the troops come home we just hang on to what we learned, the United States can pluck a surprise bonus from the victory in the gulf: a few fine victories at home.
Oh, how drearily often during the war we got sophomoric lectures from the sob-sisters of journalism, politics and academia (both sexes) about how the war would still leave us with all the domestic problems bedeviling the country: drugs, crime, race, AIDS, S.& L.'s, homelessness, recession, teen-age pregnancy, graffiti, garbage, loud radios and paper cracklers at the movies. 
 The lectures came from the renowned experts who were against the war effort. They tried to paralyze us by warning of tens of thousands of American body bags, and now caution us against trying to get rid of Saddam Hussein lest some of his followers feel humiliated -- today's appeasement catchword.
Americans do not need the condescending lectures. They know the war was fought to eliminate a particularly vicious international serial killer bent on conquering a part of the world critical to us and our friends -- including people who live there. Goal enough. It was reached in 100 hours of ground combat, following brilliant campaigns of political and air bombardment.
 Finding lessons in the victory applicable to struggles at home will infuriate all those experts who were so wrong all along, so let's set to it.
 Education. Nobody can say again that American youngsters are a bunch of unmotivated, unskilled louts. The Persian Gulf war showed that the armed forces have done a far better job of teaching technological skills than has the American school system or American industry. How?
One clue: A year ago, Lee Iacocca told me that if he had the jobs he would hire every retiring armed forces technical instructor. Business owes it to itself to find the jobs. Letting that asset go is like not picking up a pot of gold in the street because your coat does not have a big enough pocket.
Race. The armed forces are more successful at integrating black and white, and promoting both -- the essence of real affirmative action -- than any other part of American society. It's insulting to blacks in the forces to treat them as victims shanghaied by economic deprivation instead of what they are -- particularly bright young people looking for advancement, and going where it can be found.
A first-rate study commission should be appointed to find out what the armed forces do about motivation and reward that can be copied in civilian life. It should be told to report in three weeks, no more!
It should start with Gen. Colin Powell, not only because he was a poor boy, an immigrant's son, who became Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, but because he is a graduate of the great City College of New York and C.C.N.Y. people are smarter than anybody.
Professionalism. Would Stormin' Norman have quit to make more money lecturing if the war had dragged on -- as did our drug czar after 19 months on the job?
 All top appointments needn't come from within the existing bureaucracy -- forfend. But maybe those chosen should have to demonstrate some commitment to a field before they are put in charge of the whole thing.
Taxes. The American public does not argue much about taxes for defense. I am sure we get rooked often, but Americans know they need strong armed forces. Americans realized the gulf war would cost a lot; that was that.
But we hate paying more taxes for education, low-cost housing, medical care for all, and other essentials of democratic society. No use blaming Congress -- not until we voters tell it otherwise.
Clarity. Also known as leadership. Mr. Bush concentrated his energies, clout and passion on getting the war fought and won. Once he got going, Americans had no doubt about that. The reward was the almost universal public support so critical to winning the war.
Mr. Bush also has promised he would be the Education President and would lift the scourge of drugs. Americans see no evidence of either promise keeping him awake by night or concentrating his energies by day. So that is one lesson of the war for Mr. Bush to think about in peacetime, after the parades.
Meantime, don't let Saddam get off -- and THANK YOU AGAIN, MR. PRESIDENT. My thanking him recently for his war leadership upset the doomsday experts who were so wrong all along, and whom it is such a delight to irritate. So this time it's in capitals.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: 'This Aggression Will Not Stand'

 BODY:
Yours is a society which cannot accept 10,000 dead in one battle. -- SADDAM HUSSEIN, July 25, 1990.
This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait. -- GEORGE BUSH, Aug. 6, 1990. 
 Right, and right again. American and allied forces suffered dozens of casualties, not thousands, in winning their lightning victory over Iraq's sadistic blusterer. It's a glowing moment for the soldiers and pilots of many nations, and their plain-spoken commander, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf.
They have earned the admiring gratitude of millions in this and other countries. The skill and coordination of the air war and then of the assaulting armies were as stunning as the speedy outcome.
The credit, however, goes beyond the field commanders. The world that overestimated Saddam Hussein also underestimated George Bush. This page, and others who agreed with the President's goals but thought he was pressing too fast, have to acknowledge that his choices at treacherous junctures proved as successful as they were bold.
Mobilizing the Coalition
Washington was caught by surprise when Iraq devoured Kuwait on Aug. 2. It had until then tried wishfully to placate Saddam Hussein. Mr. Bush immediately reversed course, seizing Iraqi assets, working with Turkey and Syria to close Iraqi pipelines and winning Soviet support for an arms embargo.
With Iraqi tanks poised on Saudi Arabia's frontier, he achieved a pivotal success, organizing a massive army with contingents from Britain, France, Italy, Egypt, Syria and other states.
Uniting the U.N.
All this was possible because Mr. Bush turned simultaneously to the U.N. Security Council for declarations condemning Iraq, imposing an enforceable embargo, calling for the restoration of Kuwait's Government and holding Saddam Hussein accountable.
This gave multilateral sanction to Desert Shield and blunted Iraq's efforts to depict its troops as holy warriors against an imperial America. It also made possible the punishing economic embargo.
Persuading Congress
By October's end, Defense Secretary Cheney startled Congress by suggesting that many more U.S. troops were needed. A few days after the Congression-al elections on Nov. 6, Mr. Bush ordered a doubling of the 150,000 troops already deployed. The timing was politically suspect and the explanation was murky.
The President provoked understandable criticism in Congress -- especially when he appeared to circumvent its war powers by going first to the U.N. for a resolution permitting use of force against Iraq.
In a vital course correction, Mr. Bush sought what some advisers insisted he didn't need: prior approval by Congress for an armed response if Iraq failed to leave Kuwait by the U.N. deadline of Jan. 15.
Saddam Hussein misread the debate as a sign of division and infirmity. More wisely, Mr. Bush recognized it as a source of strength. After a debate notable for reasoned eloquence, Congress gave the President, narrowly in the Senate, authority to wage war. The opposition quickly closed ranks behind the cause.
Unleashing the Air War
Despite fears that Saddam Hussein would strike back savagely with terror weapons, Mr. Bush launched the air offensive seven hours after the Jan. 15 deadline. Within days, flying thousands of missions, coalition warplanes won control of the air. To judge by the evidence so far, the crushing air assault achieved its objectives of demolishing military targets while holding civilian casualties to a remarkable minimum.
And Saddam Hussein failed to alienate Arab states from the coalition with his desperate efforts to draw Israel in. His barbarous Scud attacks on Israeli cities were thwarted by Patriot rockets, urgent U.S. diplomacy and anguished Israeli restraint.
Unleashing the Troops
Faced with last Saturday's deadline for a ground war, Saddam Hussein erred by not agreeing immediately to a Soviet peace bid. Mikhail Gorbachev wanted negotiations -- but not enough to put Soviet-American relations at risk for so incoherent a client. Mr. Bush stood firm, while carefully tending his personal friendship with Mr. Gorbachev.
The American President thus stands as unchallenged winner in an enterprise of high risks and high ideals. With this outcome, he holds a formidably strong hand in seeking support for his peace aims.
Granted, these were extraordinary circumstances. Saddam Hussein's brutality was amply advertised by his use of chemical weapons in the Iran-Iraq war. Then his troops tortured and plundered their way through Kuwait. He spewed oil into the Persian Gulf, made prisoners of foreign nationals and targeted innocent civilians with murderous missiles.
There was every reason for the world to respond collectively and massively. By absorbing Kuwait, Iraq was poised to control two-thirds of the earth's known oil reserves, rake in billions, build a nuclear arsenal and terrorize, at a minimum, its neighbors.
By making himself so universal a threat, Saddam Hussein provoked as universal a response. This was a war that had to be won. That it was won so swiftly and with so few allied casualties is cause for pride, and gratitude.

HEADLINE: Child Poverty Twice as Likely After Family Split, Study Says

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
After their parents separate or divorce, children are almost twice as likely to be living in poverty than they were before the breakup, the Census Bureau said today.
The percentage of children living in poverty jumped to 36 percent from 19 percent in just four months, Federal researchers found.
Only 44 percent of absent fathers were paying child support four months after the breakup, a figure that changed little a year later. Although mothers worked more after a breakup, their efforts did not compensate for the fathers' absence, and family income declined by 37 percent. 
 When adjusted for the drop in family size, the 37 percent decline in family income is actually 26 percent, the study found.
 
Link Between Poverty and Family
 The study, by Suzanne Bianchi and Edith McArthur, was based on data from the bureau's Survey of Income and Program Participation and was unrelated to the 1990 population census. Beginning in 1983, the researchers followed 20,000 households for 32 months, interviewing them every four months.
The findings come at a time of increased national concern about child poverty, and several social policy experts said they underscored the link between family structure and economic well-being.
Prof. David Ellwood, a child poverty expert at Harvard, said the research indicated the need for better enforcement of child support awards.
"The greatest source of insecurity in America is growing up in a single-parent home," he said. "We've done very little to see that absent parents do their share."
Professor Ellwood has called for the Government to make the payment itself in the event it fails to collect, to avoid penalizing a child.
 
Poorer Before and After
 Researchers have wondered whether family breakup causes poverty or whether the reverse is also true, that economic difficulties lead to separation and divorce.
The study found both forces at work. Families that experienced a breakup had only 83 percent of the income of those that did not.
"Children who experience a disruption are economically disadvantaged compared to other children, even before the separation occurred," Ms. Bianchi said in a telephone interview.
A similar pattern held true for children whose mothers were single when the study began. Those whose mothers married or reconciled with their husbands were less likely than others to receive food stamps and more likely to receive child support.
In unadjusted terms, the initial income drop of 37 percent declines to 29 percent after 16 months, as women work more, collect more from absent husbands or remarry.
 
Lack of Skills
 Ms. Bianchi said the data suggested that only some women were successful in increasing their amount of work. The percentage of women working full time, for instance, increased over four months to 41 percent from 33 percent four months later, and remained essentially the same after a year.
Similarly, many women who had not been working at all found part-time jobs. The percentage of nonworking women dropped to 31 percent from 43 percent four months later. But this change did not last, and at the end of a year, the figure returned to 43 percent.
Ms. Bianchi said she thinks the numbers show that some women "may not have the skills necessary to get jobs that make it worth working."
Like earlier studies, this one found a large difference in the experiences of blacks and whites. Of the whites, 77 percent remained in two-parent families over the course of the study. For blacks, the figure was 37 percent.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Israel;
ISRAEL'S LEADERS PUT UNITY ASIDE

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 1

 BODY:
The unifying threat of Iraqi missile attacks just one day behind them, Israel's leaders began breaking ranks today, issuing plans and pronouncements to stake out their positions on peace initiatives as they anticipate the visit next week by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
Even though it is unlikely that Mr. Baker will propose grand new plans or programs during his brief stop to Israeli politicians, his visit is beginning to take on far larger importance. 
 Mr. Baker has never visited Israel. And now many here are seeing his planned trip as a symbol of the shift in the world's attention, from the conflict in the Persian Gulf to the Arab-Israeli conflict and new efforts to solve it.
Sensing the new attention to this nation's role in the region, Shimon Peres, leader of the opposition Labor Party, issued a peace plan published in a Jerusalem city newspaper today. Among its provisions, it calls for a demilitarized West Bank and a unilateral withdrawal from Gaza.
 
'We Have Some Ideas'
 Under the Peres plan, a joint Jordanian-Palestinian negotiating team would choose a new governing structure for the West Bank from a number of options not including an independent Palestinian state.
But if there were already doubts that the out-of-power Labor Party could have much influence on whatever peace process develops, they grew deeper when Avraham Burg, a leader among the party's leftist camp, announced that he and his party colleagues would release their own, counter-Peres peace plan at the start of next week.
Within the Government, Yossi Ben Aharon, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's chief of staff, said "we have some ideas" to move peace initiatives forward. He would not disclose them, though he said he did not think they deserved particularly prominent advance billing.
But he said the Government still stood behind its own initiative calling for elections in the occupied territories. Mr. Shamir proposed that in February 1989, but then scuttled the plan under pressure from farther right-wing members of his Government.
 
Altering Levy's Image
 One of those who applied the pressure was Housing Minister David Levy. He is Foreign Minister now and is trying to alter his image from the "constraints minister" of the past.
Mr. Levy is agitating and protesting that Israel should come up with its own peace plan before the Americans come and try to impose one.
Israel needs to demonstrate that "it is not running away from peace," he said on Thursday. "Israel is the one that has initiated more than one peace proposal. The Arab states bear responsibility for rejecting them one by one."
In the last week, Mr. Levy has been trying to schedule a trip to Washington to meet with Mr. Baker and discuss his ideas. But Mr. Baker will come here first.
 
A Far-Right Proposal
 The chairman of the farthest right-wing party in the Government, Moledet, offered a plan of his own today. Moledet's platform advocates transferring all the Arabs out of the West Bank and Gaza.
The chairman, Yair Sprinzak, demanded today that whatever else Mr. Shamir tells Mr. Baker next week, he should also "make clear that Israel won't agree to hand over to foreign rule any portion of the West Bank of the Golan Heights." He made no mention of the Gaza Strip.
When a "new world order" is worked out for the Middle East, and political and economic reconstruction of the region is well under way, he said, the several hundred thousand Palestinian residents of West Bank and Gaza refugee camps should be "resettled in the Arab states."

HEADLINE: Managua Faults U.S. Bid to Soviets

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Nicaragua complained today that a Bush Administration request that the Soviet Union cut off military supplies to the Nicaraguan Army was inappropriate.
The protest, made in Managua by a senior aide to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, reflected a growing rift in the relationship between Washington and Managua over continued control of the army by Sandinista leaders. 
 After Mrs. Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in the February 1990 elections, she decided to appoint his brother Humberto as chief of the army to assure a peaceful transition. The Administration reluctantly supported Mrs. Chamorro's decision as it praised her as a democratic force who could revive her country after eight years of civil war.
But United States officials have expressed growing criticism of the relationship over the last two weeks after a reported army effort to smuggle weapons and explosives into Honduras and the assassination of a former contra commander, Enrique Bermudez.
Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and Valery Nicolayenko, his Soviet counterpart, held a meeting in Madrid today at which the American planned to ask Moscow to cut shipments of spare parts to the army and reduce its aid levels to Cuba as well. American officials say that current Soviet military aid to Nicaragua is small, but that the army's Soviet-supplied helicopters and trucks need the parts to remain operational.
Press reports preceding the meeting have produced unease in Mrs. Chamorro's Government, which is trying to tack a political course that will satisfy both her conservative supporters and leftist Sandinista leaders who can disrupt her economic policies by unleashing labor unrest.
Antonio Ibarra, the Vice Minister of the Presidency, said Mrs. Chamorro and other senior officials believed that Nicaragua was being used as a test case by the State Department to determine Soviet foreign policy intentions at a time when hard-liners are making a comeback in the Kremlin. He compared the Aronson-Nicolayenko talks to "someone talking behind your back to one of your neighbors."
"If the United States would like us to request that aid be cut off, Mr. Aronson should talk directly to us," Mr. Ibarra said. "Third parties should not be intervening in our relations with other countries."
A second senior Nicaraguan official, who reiterated Mr. Ibarra's concerns, said Managua was waiting to make a formal protest through diplomatic channels. Administration officials said they did not wish to respond to the protest through the press.
Managua's protest came at a time when a number of Latin American nations, led by Venezuela, are privately urging Washington to refrain from putting undue pressure on Mrs. Chamorro. They argue that Mrs. Chamorro has no choice but to establish a working relationship with the Sandinistas; otherwise she could face a renewed civil war.
But Administration officials have begun to voice concerns that the Sandinistas are slowly retaking decisive political power. They say they have collected circumstantial evidence from several sources in Nicaragua linking the Feb. 16 assassination of Mr. Bermudez to the army high command.
Only six days later, the Honduran Army captured a banana truck loaded with hidden RPG-7 rocket launchers, rockets, bomb detonators and wire three miles north of the Honduras-Nicaragua border. The driver, a Honduran, confessed on the radio that the weapons had been supplied by Sandinista soldiers and were destined for the Cinchonero Popular Liberation Movement, a Marxist guerrilla group that has attacked American military forces stationed in Honduras.
Senior Nicaraguan officials said that the charge that their army was responsible for the shipment appeared accurate, and that the Government was investigating.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
King Broadcasting's TV Asset Sale

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 1

 BODY:
The King Broadcasting Company agreed today to sell its six television stations and 13 cable systems to the Providence Journal Company and its joint-venture partner, Kelso & Company.
No price was disclosed for the television and cable operations, which represent about 85 percent of King Broadcasting. 
 Steven A. Clifford, King's chief executive, said the rest of King's assets, -- six radio stations and a mobile telephone company, would be sold to other buyers.
Last August, Priscilla Bullitt Collins, King's chairwoman, and her sister, Harriet Stimson Bullitt, announced the company was for sale and suggested it might be worth an estimated $650 million. The women, the company's controlling shareholders, also said about $100 million of the proceeds would be used to finance environmental causes.
"During the time the company has been for sale, the economy has not been helpful." Mrs. Collins said.
The company was founded in 1946 by Dorothy Bullitt, the women's mother, who died in 1989 at the age of 97. She was active in company mangement until her death and left most of her estate to the Bullitt Foundation.
The company's six television stations are in Seattle and Spokane, Wash.; Portland, Ore.; Boise and Twin Falls, Idaho, and Honolulu. The cable division has more than 200,000 subscribers in Washington, Idaho, Minnesota and California.
Stephen Hamblett, Providence Journal's chairman and publisher of The Providence Journal newspaper, said, "If we are successful in acquiring King Broadcasting, we will operate King in a manner consistent with the philosophy with which it has been operated by the Bullitts."
Bishop Cheen, a senior analyst at Paul Kagan Associates of Carmel, Calif., said the deal was a good fit because Providence Journal "knows how to run a medium-size market broadcasting operation." He added that Providence Journal was flush with cash and had avoided a large amount of debt.
Providence Journal, a diversified communications company based in Providence, R.I., was founded in 1829.
The company's four television stations are in Tucson, Ariz.; Albuquerque, N.M.; Louisville, Ky., and Charlotte, N.C. It also owns a cable television company, Colony Communications, with more than 500,000 subscribers in New York, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Florida and California.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Perception that Slump May End Soon

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against leading foreign currencies yesterday on the belief that the economy may be on the verge of rebounding, now that the Persian Gulf war is over.
Gold prices rose overseas but were slightly lower in New York, with the March contract dropping 40 cents on the New York Commodity Exchange to close at $367.00 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted gold at $366.50 an ounce, up 50 cents. 
 Traders found cause for optimism in the latest economic reports, reinforcing a perception that the recession will be shallow and brief.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index of business activity rose to 38.5 percent last month from 37.7 percent in January. Traders also saw a bright spot in the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators. The January drop in the index -- of four-tenths of a percent -- was not as bad as some economists had feared.
"There still is this tremendous optimism that the end of the war will give this huge boost to consumer confidence and help the economy rebound," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank.
Mr. Johnson described a "bandwagon effect" in the market. Trading was heavy throughout the day. He and other analysts said they thought the economy lacked the stamina to warrant such gains.
"My guess here is that it is a bit overdone," said Andrew Hodge, vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert. Despite their skepticism, analysts conceded that the optimism was infectious.
"Everybody, including myself, has begun to write off a deep recession," he said.
The dollar finished trading in London at its highest level against the German mark and Japanese yen since around Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations Security Council for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.
The dollar rose to 134.60 Japanese yen in New York, from a rate late Thursday of 133.025. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 2.30 yen to close at 134.25. Later, in London, it was quoted at 134.50 yen.
The British pound fell to $1.8960 in New York, from $1.9120 late Thursday. In London, the pound fell to $1.8970, from $1.9105 late Thursday.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.5385 marks from 1.5243.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Thursday prices, included: 1.3355 Swiss francs, up from 1.3248; 5.2415 French francs, up from 5.1890; 1,150.50 Italian lire, up from 1,139.00, and 1.1521 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1498.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Climbs Again on Belief that OPEC Will Cut Output

DATELINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices rallied late yesterday to close modestly higher for a fifth straight session in response to speculation that OPEC would soon take steps to cut production of crude.
"Going into an OPEC meeting, the trend of the market is always higher," said Nauman Barakat, a vice president at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. "There is considerable talk and perception that there is going to be a material reduction in the output of the cartel, and that would be able to stabilize the market." 
 Crude oil for delivery in April settled at $19.38 a barrel, up 22 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The per-barrel price of oil rose $1.47 for the week, as traders decided that the postwar glut of crude would not be as bad as some had predicted, particularly if the production cuts are achieved at the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on March 11.
Crude opened lower yesterday. Traders were selling oil to take profits from the week's increases, and oil was also depressed by a report in the French newspaper Le Monde that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was seeking asylum in Algeria. Traders thought Mr. Hussein's departure could prompt the United Nations to lift the international embargo on Iraqi crude.
 
 'It's Oil Either Way'
 "People were realizing Iraq would be coming back into production even if Kuwait wouldn't; it's oil either way," said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Dillon, Read & Company.
But the report was disputed by a variety of sources and crude moved into positive ground late in the afternoon.
One analyst suggested that the market was slowly moving ahead as the big futures players -- major oil companies hedging their business against unexpected volatility by trading futures contracts -- bought oil to replenish supplies.
The upward move was hurting smaller players who had sold oil on the theory that the price would fall during the ground war, said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Many experts had predicted that the ground war would send prices lower, but prices instead have risen every day since the ground war began last weekend.

HEADLINE: Fed's Stance On the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve said yesterday that it did not support the dollar through foreign exchange trading in the three months that ended on Jan. 31 because the conflicting pressures of the Persian Gulf war and the recession held the currency in check.
The Fed, which has the authority to buy and sell dollars to influence the currency's direction, has not intervened in the currency market since April 1990, the longest period of inaction in four years. 
 Over all, the dollar declined by an average of 1 percent against the leading foreign currencies in the quarter, the Fed said in its quarterly foreign exchange report.
"There was relatively little change in the dollar exchange rate," said Sam Y. Cross, executive vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "In these circumstances, we did not feel intervention was called for."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Saudi Arabia;
After the War, the Saudis Prepare For a New Role Among the Arabs

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 1

 BODY:
The military victory over Iraq has considerably strengthened Saudi resolve to play a stronger role in Arab politics as an ally of the West and an opponent of militant governments in the Middle East, senior Saudi officials say.
"The experience of asking the Americans to come over here is viewed by all classes of Saudi society, including the most conservative religious groups, as a wise and courageous move," said a ranking Saudi official who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. 
 "I think this is a watershed in the Middle East, where since the early 50's it has been fashionable to be anti-Western, and where the thought of an alliance with the West was viewed as a sin by wide segments of Arab societies," the official said in a long analysis of Saudi policy in the postwar era.
Saudi officials spoke of a new resolve to be more assertive in Arab politics and said they would not embrace a policy of reconciliation with some of those who sided with Iraq, most particularly King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman.
 
Pressing To Keep Embargo
 Among other things, Saudi officials say that unless President Saddam Hussein is removed from power in Iraq, they will block any attempts to lift the economic embargo against Iraq. These officials also say they will encourage Palestinians in the occupied territories and in the gulf region to abandon their attachment to Mr. Arafat as a symbol of the Palestinian movement, and to seek an alternative leadership, probably from the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
One well-informed official in the Saudi foreign policy establishment said if the Palestinians resisted such a change Saudi Arabia would encourage a "step by step" resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict starting with the Syrians instead of the Palestinians.
 
Palestinian Leadership
 "We are now hinting to the Palestinians to come up with a new leadership," the Saudi said. "If they are not ready or willing to do so we can start working on other aspects of the Arab-Israeli conflict like the evacuation of the Golan Heights by Israel in return for a Syrian-Israeli settlement."
Other Saudi officials policy makers also said that future Saudi policy would be based on a continued alliance with the United States, the abandonment of old policies of conciliation and appeasement with neighboring hostile Governments like Yemen and the strengthening of this country's bonds to Egypt and its tactical alliance with Syria.
On Iraq, the officials expressed great confidence that as the dimension of the defeat unfolds in front of the Iraqi people, there is every reason to believe Iraqis will remove President Saddam Hussein from power.
Until this occurs, the senior Saudi officials said, the alliance against Iraq will continue to exert maximum economic pressure, keeping Iraq's oil exporting pipelines to Saudi Arabia and Turkey shut down and banning all oil exports by Iraq and imports of goods other than essentials.
"It is up to the Iraqis to realize that what Saddam Hussein has done to them is disastrous," one Saudi offiial said. "But if we appear to push him out of power by force of arms we would make a martyr out of him."
Another senior official who asked not to be identified said: "The idea is for his leadership to be discredited completely and irrevocably. To do so, he must be seen by his own people and other Arabs as a catastrophe and an utter failure."
Saudi officials also say this country, which is burdened with an enormous budget deficit because of a major increase in war-related and other spending since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, will stop its policy of handing out money to friends or foes to shore up their economies or appease their hostile intent -- a policy that has been the hallmark of Saudi Arabia for 20 years.
One high-ranking Government official who took part in the conversation today said it is estimated that Saudi Arabia has given away about $100 billion since the early seventies when its oil income rose dramatically, adding that such largesse is now over.
"What has been proven is that handouts of money do not make friends," a senior Saudi official said. "We gave tens of millions of dollars to King Hussein and to Arafat and they turned against us. The feeling here now is that there will be no more handouts. This is not only a widespread sentiment among Saudi people but it is shared at the highest level of the leadership."
 
'Sinners' and 'Atheists'
 Saudi officials concede that when they first asked the United States to come to their defense they were worried about a backlash among the most conservative right-wing religious groups in the Kingdom who consider all non-Muslims as "sinners" and "atheists." But they said the shooting of Scud missiles at Saudi Arabia by Iraq has changed those sentiments among the large majority of the Saudi population.
"When the Scuds started to fall over here, even the most antipathetic elements to the West felt that if it were not for Western protection we would have suffered enormously," the ranking official said. "This is a very big change for Saudi Arabia, which has always been timid about the presence of foreigners."
Saudi officials also said they did not look favorably on proposals made earlier to station a pan-Arab military force in the gulf, adding that they would prefer to expand their army and depend on logistical and military support from the United States.
Another major change in this country, various Saudi officials pointed out, is a genuine opposition that has developed here among ordinary Saudis toward Jordanians, Yemenis and Palestinians as a people because of their support of Iraq in the war. "The idea of the mild Saudi has dissolved," said Abdlefattah Nazer, a prominent businessman from Jidda. "I think people here do not not want to help any of those who stood against us."
Mr. Nazer and other businessmen said they would not rehire Yemenis and did not expect the Saudi Government to rescind its decision to suspend privileges to Yemenis working in the Kingdom about four months ago because of Yemeni Government support for Iraq. The Saudi decision led to the departure of more than 800,000 Yemenites from Saudi Arabia.
Many of those who have left have now been replaced with Egyptian expatriate laborers, reflecting the vastly improving ties between Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: Purchasers' Index Posts Small Gain

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
According to a survey of purchasing managers, the nation's manufacturing economy remained in a malaise in February, but it did show a slight improvement from January.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its index of economic activity rose to 38.5 percent in February from 37.7 percent in January. That made February the first month since May that the index did not decline. Still, February's reading was the lowest of any in the last 12 months, except for January's. 
 An index below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is declining, while a reading above 50 indicates expansion. Economists said that despite some improvement, the level of new orders remained extremely weak, an indication that economic troubles would continue.
 
The Pace of Decline
 "These figures indicate that the recession is continuing," said Andrew F. Brimmer, president of Brimmer & Associates and a former governor of the Federal Reserve. "However, they also suggest that the pace of the decline in economic activity is slowing somewhat."
Mr. Brimmer said there was some encouragement in the slight rise in new orders. "But as far as encouragement goes, that is all there is to it," he said. "The numbers do not point to a recovery any time soon."
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers from a wide range of industrial companies. Each month it is the first important indicator of how the economy performed in the previous month.
 
 A Bit of Optimism

"Although the economy is still in decline, there are encouraging signs in February's report that we may have reached the bottom of the declining trend," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. "Over all, the light at the end of the tunnel may still be very dim, but it may very well be signaling that the worst is now behind us."
But Joseph McAlinden, director of research with Dillon, Read & Company, said the report indicated that the economy "is not showing much sign of a turn, other than the fact that it seems to be falling at a slower rate." He added, "The index still indicates that there is a decline in the economy."
The purchasing managers' new-orders index registered a rise, to 38.3 percent in February, from 35.7 percent in January. The report suggested that the February figure "might be the bottom of this current economic cycle and the beginning of an upward trend."
 
 A Crucial Component

The level of new orders is the most closely watched component of the survey because the level of orders affects production, prices and other indexes. Production followed the same trend as new orders, rising to 38.1 percent in February, from 37.1 percent in January.
New orders for exports increased, but at a sharply slower pace. The index of new export orders fell to 52 percent, down from 56.5 percent in January. The index of imports increased to 46 percent, from 43 percent in January.
Prices declined sharply in January, falling to their lowest level since December 1982. The purchasing managers' price index dropped to 41.8 percent, from 49.1 percent in January. The association said much of the decline in the price index resulted from lower prices for crude oil. Before February, the index had shown seven consecutive months of price increases, the report said.

HEADLINE: BANK REGULATORS SEEKING TO RELAX ACCOUNTING RULES

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
With banks in many regions of the country shying away from making new loans, Federal banking and savings regulators moved to ease that logjam today by recommending a relaxation of the standards used by banks to put a value on their loans.
Specifically, the regulators called for changes in the way banks evaluate commercial and real estate loans that are in trouble. The new accounting standards would enable banks to report greater profits on such loans, providing them with an incentive to extend credit to more borrowers. 
 Many banks and savings and loans are in trouble, mainly because of loans that went sour in a troubled economy. As these troubles mounted, banks and customers started complaining that bank examiners, with the savings and loan fiasco fresh in their minds, were becoming too aggressive in scrutinizing loans. This in turn was said to compound the tightening of credit, particularly in New England, where the economy has quickly eroded.
 
The Goal: Easier Credit
 Officials said the long-awaited measures were intended to counter these complaints and to make it easier for people and businesses to get loans.
"There is an atmosphere of fear in financial institutions out there that they are going to get whacked in the back of the head if they make any loan," said John E. Robson, Deputy Treasury Secretary and the senior Administration official coordinating the regulatory changes. "That is clearly not the atmosphere you want to have."
But critics said today's measures would eventually come back to haunt the industry and the Government because the changes dilute standards at a time when increasing numbers of large banks are failing or reporting lower earnings. They likened the proposal to the decisions in the 1980's to relax standards for savings institutions and to refrain from closing weak institutions.
"It's not as egregious a forbearance standard as the savings and loans, but it mirrors the excesses," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and a member of the House Banking Committee. "It conveys the notion that toying with the books is legitimate, and therefore obviates the need for commercial banks either to raise more capital or shrink."
Mr. Leach said the new standards would increase the likelihood of a taxpayer bailout of the Federal program that insures deposits at banks and would also have the effect of deferring "the necessary consolidation of the industry."
The guidelines clarify the way banks put a value on real estate loans and on their financing of transactions made with a large amount of debt. They also call for greater disclosure about loans on which the borrower has stopped paying interest. The changes have been urged by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
The guidelines were issued jointly today by the Federal Reserve, the Comptroller of the Currency, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
None of the proposals require legislative action, but the most significant one, involving the treatment of non-performing loans, is subject to final approval by the bank regulators and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees accounting standards. That is expected to occur after the 45-day period set aside for comments from accountants and industry representatives.
 
Allowing Some Leeway
 The proposal would allow so-called loan-splitting, in which a troubled loan still paying some interest would be divided into good and bad parts instead of being entirely written off. Existing guidelines require banks to label the entire amount of such loans as "nonperforming," which is the category for loans that are 90 days past due or are so troubled that the bank does not expect full repayment.
As an example of a loan that should not be written off entirely, regulators today cited a homeowner who is delinquent on mortgage payments, but who promises to start making payments after 90 days and then does so. Currently, the bank would have to write off the entire loan but under the changes the bank would be able to recognize the interest payments.
These are some of the other changes and guidelines:
*Banks and savings associations would not have to put a value on real estate in a troubled market, reflecting the depressed price the property would bring if it was sold immediately. Rather, the value put on a house, apartment building or commercial property should reflect its market value over a longer period, which would give the bank the chance to benefit from an upturn in the market.
*The definition of "highly leveraged transactions," which include company buyouts or other broad changes that rely on a large amount of debt, would be loosened so that it would no longer include certain kinds of debt. Bankers and regulators keep track of such transactions to help judge an institution's soundness.
*Weak banks would be encouraged to make loans to "sound borrowers" even though such loans would further dilute the bank's capital level, a formula that is generally viewed as an indicator of a bank's health.
*Financial institutions would be encouraged to provide greater disclosure of the details of their entire loan portfolio.
"We hope that the actions taken today will encourage lenders to make prudent loans and assure that examiners perform their review in a balanced, sensible way," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said, describing the measures as a "sensible approach to the credit crunch."
The pressure on regulators to act swiftly has been apparent for weeks. Senators and representatives from New England have threatened to oppose the Bush Adminstration's proposal to provide more financing for the savings and loan bailout until the Administration addressed the tightening of credit.
 
Quick Action Urged
 In a House Banking subcommittee hearing on Thursday, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d pursued an aggressive line of questioning and urged senior regulators to move quickly, even if it meant circumventing the normal process for changing the rules. Mr. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, suggested that the banks be permitted to ease accounting standards immediately, before the Securities and Exchange Commission formally acted, and then return to the old standards if the agency later objected.
But that idea was quickly rejected by Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C., who said he could not "throw the rules out the window," adding that 'the worst mistake made in the thrift disaster was the move to weaken accounting rules."
On Wednesday, Mr. Breeden said that "there is nothing inherently wrong" with the idea of loan-splitting, but that he wanted the commission to be able to study the concept fully before aprroving it.

HEADLINE: Wells Fargo, Security Pacific Soar on Rumors of Merger

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The possibility of a merger between the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles and Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco sent the shares of both companies sharply higher yesterday.
Officials of both companies, which are the second- and third-largest banks in California, declined to comment on yesterday's rumors about a potential merger or about the increase in their stock price. But the lack of official comment did not stop their stocks from rising steadily on heavy volume. By the close of trading, Security Pacific shares were up $4.125, or 14.8 percent, to $32 each on the New York Stock Exchange, while Wells Fargo stock was up $6.375, or 11 percent, to $76.625. Security Pacific was also the Big Board's third-most-active stock, with 3.9 million shares traded. 
 The merger rumors were taken seriously by traders because Security Pacific executives conceded in late January that they had talked about a merger with Wells Fargo as recently as late 1990. Bankers, Government regulators and investors say they expect a rash of large bank mergers within a year or two.
A combination of Security Pacific and Wells Fargo is widely seen as one example of such a merger that would greatly improve the profits of the two companies as they eliminate duplicated branches, executive positions and back-office operations.
"A merger would make sense economically, but I don't think it will happen in the immediate future," said Donald K. Crowley, a San Francisco-based analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
A person close to one of the banks, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that talks had not begun again and that there was no timetable set to restart them. But he said both banks still remained interested.
 
 $40 Bid Rumored
 Some analysts said a merger would be more likely to occur as a result of an exchange of shares by both companies for a new company, rather than Wells Fargo offering cash and securities for Security Pacific. One rumor yesterday said that Wells was preparing a $40-a-share bid for Security Pacific.
Michael Murphy, editor of the Overpriced Stock Service, a newsletter, said he told clients yesterday that "the Security Pacific board has decided they want to sell." Based on a conversation with a Los Angeles financier with close ties to the Security Pacific board, Mr. Murphy said that if an offer of $40 a share was made for Security Pacific, "it is a done deal."
The $40-a-share price was also quoted Thursday in a CNBC cable broadcast by Dan Dorfman, the financial columnist.
 
Profits From Streamlining

Ronald Mandle, a banking analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company said in a recent report that a merger of Wells Fargo and Security Pacific could result in $800 million in additional profit for the two companies.
In 1990, Wells earned $711.5 million while Security Pacific earned $161.3 million. Security Pacific's profits were reduced by a $357.6 million loss as it increased reserves for loan losses and incurred large costs from the closing of much of its wholesale corporate lending and securities trading business.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations;
U.S. Softens Stance at U.N. On Terms for Resuming War

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 1

 BODY:
Under pressure from the Soviet Union and China, the United States abandoned efforts today to have the United Nations Security Council explicitly authorize the anti-Iraq forces to resume hostilities if Iraq fails to comply with President Bush's terms for ending the gulf war, diplomats said tonight.
But an emerging new Council resolution implicitly allows the use of force again if Iraq threatens Kuwait and says that, before the Security Council can "establish the definitive end of hostilities," Iraq must tell the Council it has fully complied with the terms President Bush laid down this week when he announced a suspension of offensive operations. 
 The new draft resolution also expressly reaffirms that Resolution 678, which authorized the allies to expel Iraq from Kuwait by force, remains valid, implying that the allies still have the authority to resort to battle if Iraq threatens Kuwait's independence again.
The original American draft reaffirmed the right of the anti-Iraq coalition to "resume offensive combat operations" if Iraq failed to comply with all President Bush's terms.
 
Language Seen as Too Bellicose
 But diplomats said that China and the Soviet Union, two permanent Council members with a veto on decisions, opposed this language as overly bellicose and that the United States was forced to drop it. The Security Council decided tonight to continue its deliberations on Saturday.
The latest draft affirms that the 12 resolutions the Council already passed on the gulf crisis "continue to have full force and effect."
After noting Iraq's stated willingness to accept these resolutions in full, the latest draft says this means Baghdad must immediately rescind its annexation of Kuwait, accept liability for damage caused by its forces and release prisoners of war, detainees and seized Kuwaiti property.
In this draft, the resolution lifts the international economic sanctions imposed on Kuwait at the time of its annexation. But it maintains them on Iraq.
 
Embargo Goes On -- For Now
 As a result, Iraq will continue to be denied all new supplies for as long as the United States wants, because the embargo can be lifted only by a new Security Council resolution over which Washington has a veto.
But the United States and its allies say they may agree to lift the embargo as part of an agreement under which Baghdad would earmark some of its oil revenues for war reparations.
Some diplomats said the United States would like to see the resolution passed by the time commanders of the two opposing sides meet to discuss military arrangements for the end of hostilities. That meeting, originally fixed for Saturday, was delayed for at least a day because of logistical problems.
While negotiations were in progress, the heads of two United Nations humanitarian organizations appealed to allied forces in the Gulf to give some unused medical supplies to help relieve disease and suffering among Iraqi civilians.
 
Appeal for Medical Supplies
 "We hope that some of the vast mountain of medical supplies the military has built up there could be used for civilians and children," one of the officials, James P. Grant, executive director of Unicef, said at a news conference here today.
Calling for "very, very urgent action," Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, the director general of the World Health Organization, said that while army field hospitals are mainly equipped to deal with battle wounds, the military still has many medical supplies that are now in short supply among civilians in Iraq.
The heads of W.H.O. and Unicef were presenting a report on health conditions in Iraq prepared by a team of doctors and officials from the two agencies who visited Baghdad from Feb. 16 to 21, bringing with them some 54 tons of medical and other humanitarian supplies.
In Washington, Pentagon and State Department spokesmen had no comment on the call for allied medical supplies, but President Bush indicated that the United States might be willing to provide some medical assistance.
 
Military Supplies Suggested
 In answer to a question at a White House press briefing today the President said, "The United States will step up and do what it is -- that which we've always done, lay aside the politics and help the health care requirements, or help the children, especially."
W.H.O. officials said that military field hospitals could provide additional supplies of syringes, sutures and certain medicines.
In addition, they argued that the military forces in the gulf could help with the shortage of small electricity generators and the fuel to run them. The generators have been the only source of electrical power for Iraqi hospitals, laboratories and health centers since the public grid was destroyed.
Stressing the urgent need for fresh medical supplies in Iraq, Dr. Nakajima pointed out that average temperatures are likely to rise sharply in the next few weeks with the coming of spring, increasing the risk of serious outbreaks of cholera, typhoid and meningitis.
 
Food, Water Said Inadequate
 In their report on health conditions in Iraq, the W.H.O.-Unicef team said, Baghdad's water system is providing no more than 15 liters of inadequately treated water per inhabitant each day, compared with the prewar figure of some 500 liters.
Cases of severe diarrhea and respiratory diseases among children are up to four times normal rates, the report says.
The experts calculated that the basic Iraqi food ration now provides only about 1,000 calories a day, or less than half the needs of a five-year-old child. Families can supplement this from the free market. But with supplies scarce and prices high, the report concludes that most people barely receive their daily minimum requirement.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 27.72 Points, to 2,909.90

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Prodded by signs that the economy is mending, stock prices recovered from an early slump and moved ahead briskly yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average bounced back from a 27-point slide to close at 2,909.90, up 27.72, or nearly 1 percent. Showing that the advance was widespread, the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose at almost the same rate, gaining 3.40 points, to 370.47, a record high. And the Nasdaq 100 index of the top 100 non-financial over-the-counter stocks also reached a record high of 504.78, up 4.55. 
 Reports of new takeover talks between Wells Fargo and Security Pacific and between the failed Bank of New England and several other banks helped most of the banking stocks involved.
Heavy waves of program buying added a total of 26 points to the Dow throughout the day, Birinyi Associates said. One 10-minute flurry just before 11 A.M. accounted for almost all of the gain.
 
Strong Volume Continues

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange continued at a strong 221.5 million shares, down a little from 223 million on Thursday. Advances led declines by 3 to 2.
Seventy-two Big Board stocks reached new highs, including American International Group, the insurer. It jumped 2 3/8, to a new high of 93.
Gains for the week were thin, with the broad list of stocks scoring much better than the blue chips. The Dow edged ahead 20.54 points, three-quarters of a percent, while the S.& P. 500 rose 4.82 points, or a little more than 1 percent.
Traders were watching the Commodity Research Bureau index closely yesterday, sensing that it was giving off the first signals that the economy was strengthening. A brighter economy, they argued, would mean higher profits, and higher profits would lift stock prices.
The commodity index, rising more than 1 percent yesterday, climbed almost 4 percent for the week.
 
 Sign of End of Recession Seen

"That means we're coming out of recession," said Stuart Shinbein, senior technical editor of the research bureau, noting that the commodity index had moved higher all week.
"One of the first signs that we're coming out of recession," he said, "is a rise in commodity prices and a simultaneous decline in bond prices." Bond prices, he noted, had weakened in seven out of the last eight trading sessions, including yesterday's, a good sign that bond traders feel the economy is far too strong for the Fed to lower interest rates much more.
Responding to the weakness in bonds, stock prices slumped early on but moved ahead sharply with the help of heavy program buying. By 11 A.M. the Dow was ahead 40 points from the low, and by 1 P.M. it had climbed more than 50 points from the low.
Short-sellers, who sell borrowed stock hoping to profit from price declines, depressed prices several times but helped lift the market near the end of the day by buying back shares to avoid unforeseen problems with their positions over the weekend.
 
 Gains for Bank Stocks

An article in The Wall Street Journal helped Bank of Boston by reporting that the bank had approached Warren E. Buffett and the Tisch family, both in the billionaire category, about putting money into the company so it could bid for the failed Bank of New England. Mr. Buffett already has a big stake in Wells Fargo. The Tisches have one in the Bank of Boston, but earlier this month they reported selling a part of it. Bank of Boston, No. 9 on the Big Board active list, rose 1 3/8, to 8 3/8, with 2.2 million shares changing hands.
BankAmerica rose 3/4, to 33; Banc One 1 3/8, to 34 3/8, and Core States Financial 1 3/4, to 35. The three are among a number of potential bidders along with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout group.
I.B.M., gaining a strong 2 1/4, to 131, helped several other high-technology stocks. Digital Equipment tacked on 1 1/4, to 73 7/8; Compaq Computer 1 1/8, to 70 3/8, and Hewlett-Packard, which announced more powerful personal computers, 1 1/8, to 47 3/4.

HEADLINE: Child Care In Conflict With a Job

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Diane McCourtney said it made perfect sense to her when she lost her job as an account clerk at Seagate Technology in Minnetonka, Minn., last year because she took off too many days to care for her sick infant.
"James started getting sick all the time right after I went back to work from maternity leave," she said. "In four months, he had colds, the flu, bronchial pneumonia, sinus infections and two cases of pinkeye. My day care person couldn't have him in her house, because it wouldn't have been fair to her kids and the other kids she takes care of. Seagate had every right to terminate me, because they needed someone to work, and I couldn't do it reliably." 
 What angered Ms. McCourtney -- and what she has taken to the courts in an unusual case that women's advocacy groups are closely watching -- was the state's refusal to give her unemployment benefits.
"They say that it's my fault, that I got fired for misconduct and I'm not eligible for unemployment benefits," she said. "I say I didn't have any choice. I had a sick baby, and no one else to take care of him. I couldn't just leave him."
 
Cushion, for Some
 Unemployment benefits are supposed to provide a financial cushion only for people who lose their jobs through no fault of their own. And in the case now awaiting a ruling by the Minnesota Court of Appeals, lawyers for the state argued that legally, Ms. McCourtney's absenteeism was her fault.
"She made a choice, and even though it was a laudable choice, she is not entitled to unemployment benefits because she chose her family interests over her employer's interest," said Steven B. Liss, a special assistant attorney general handling the case for the state. "We've never had a case like this, and there is no provision for what she did in the law. I expect that the issue will ultimately be taken up by the Legislature."
A spokeswoman for Seagate said the company would not comment on the case.
Ms. McCourtney's quandary, the conflict between the demands of a job and a sick infant, is increasingly common. More than half the mothers of children under the age of 1 are now in the work force, and many, if not most, have no backup child care when the baby falls ill and cannot go to his or her usual day care.
"Survey after survey shows that emergency child care is the hardest to find," said Barbara Reisman, executive director of the Child Care Action Campaign, a national advocacy group. "If we care about the future, we have to stop penalizing parents for wanting to be good parents. We need a Federal family leave law, like the one that the President vetoed last year that would protect parents' jobs when they need time off to care for their kids. And we need more employers that try to accommodate their workers' family needs."
In recognition of the problem of caring for sick children, Minnesota last year passed the nation's first law allowing parents to use some of their own paid sick leave to care for sick children. But the law took effect too late to help Ms. McCourtney and, in any case, helps only those workers who have accrued enough sick leave to cover their children's illnesses.
 
11-Year Employee
 Ms. McCourtney had worked at Seagate for 11 years before James was born in September 1989 and was considered an excellent employee. She took 10 weeks off after giving birth, using maternity leave and vacation time. She then returned to work and paid $60 a week for her son to be cared for at the home of a friend, who looked after several children. But the next month, James got sick, and could not go to day care. Unable to find anyone to care for him, Ms. McCourtney stayed home, missing about half her normal work hours from January to April.
"My husband has back problems and couldn't do it, because he couldn't pick James up," said Ms. McCourtney, who is now pregnant with twins and plans to be a day care provider herself after giving birth. "And while we both have family in the area, they're all working, too, so there wasn't anyone who could stay with James. So I contacted all the day care places in the phone books, and there just isn't anything out there for sick kids."
Of the 10 places she sought out, only one took sick infants on a drop-in basis, and even that one could not provide care starting at 6:30 A.M., when her job began. Furthermore, the cost of that service was $11.50 an hour, or $103 a day -- more than double her net pay of $49.66 a day.
Women's advocacy groups say Ms. McCourtney's case is a textbook example of the problems facing working mothers. It is particularly serious, they say, for single mothers with no family nearby or families in which everyone works.
"There are a lot of women out there who lose their jobs because they're absent so much because of on-and-off illnesses," said Donna Lenhoff, legal director of the Women's Legal Defense Fund in Washington. "A few states have legislation that protects their jobs when they have to take time off, but Minnesota and most others don't."
Congress is considering a new family leave bill, like the one President Bush vetoed last year, that would require employers to allow up to 12 weeks unpaid leave for workers who are ill or who need time off to care for a family member. The House held hearings on the bill this week.
There is no uniform Federal law regarding unemployment benefits for women who have lost their jobs because of family obligations. In several states, Ms. Lenhoff said, women have received unemployment benefits after they took time off to care for a family member and then found their jobs filled when they were ready to work again. Other states, however, deny unemployment benefits in such situations.
 
Few Pursue Appeals
 While the issue comes up with some regularity, Ms. Lenhoff and others said, the McCourtney case is unusual in that few women who are denied benefits pursue an appeal.
"The basic theory is that you can get unemployment as long as you left your job for 'just cause,' not misconduct," Ms. Lenhoff said. "But these cases raise the question of exactly what family-related things are considered 'just cause.' And there is no clear answer on that because unemployment varies so much from state to state."
Currently, Connecticut, the District of Columbia, Maine, New Jersey, Rhode Island and Wisconsin have laws requiring employers to provide unpaid leave to workers with sick children, and Washington State provides leave when the child is terminally ill. Several other states allow state workers to take such leave but have no provision covering private companies.
"You can't leave a sick baby alone," Ms. McCourtney said. "And when they're crying and miserable, that's when they most need someone who loves them. The worst part of this was that everybody at work understood and said I was doing the right thing, and then they turned around and fought my getting unemployment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many employers have made no provisions for working parents who have a sick child. Although Diane McCourtney, left, with her husband, Larry Olson, and her son, James, was fired last year for taking too many days off to care for her sick child, she was not eligible for unemployment benefits. (John Haselmann for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Federal regulators moved to ease tight credit by recommending a relaxation of the standards used by banks to put a value on their loans. They called for changes in the way banks evaluate commercial and real estate loans that are in trouble. [Page 1.] 
 The index of leading indicators fell 0.4 percent in January, its sixth straight decline, the Commerce Department reported. [31.]
A foreign bank convicted of money laundering secretly controls First American Bankshares, the biggest bank in Washington, Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau has concluded. [31.]
The nation's manufacturing economy remained in a malaise in February, according to a survey of purchasing managers. [32.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Jordan;
Jordan King Asks 'Forgiveness' Among Arabs

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, March 1

 BODY:
King Hussein began an effort today to repair the diplomatic and economic damage his country suffered through its support of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, calling for forgiveness among Arabs and saying there should be no "gloating and apportioning blame."
In a somber television address to the nation, the King seemed to plead with hostile Arabs and the West not to exclude his small, poor kingdom from the effort to devise a new regional order, which he said should be based on forgiveness, democracy and resolution of the Palestinian issue. 
 Throughout the address, he made no direct reference to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Significantly, when he spoke of the rights of Palestinians to be represented in a peace process, he omitted all mention of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
More than half of Jordan's people are of Palestinian descent, and its people strongly supported President Hussein, who portrayed himself as a champion of Arab and Palestinian rights.
 
Castigated U.S. Allies
 As the war unfolded, the King tilted more and more toward Iraq's depiction of the conflict as a Western attack against the Arab world and castigated Arabs who sided with the coalition led by the United States. In return, the Arab allies -- particularly Saudi Arabia, Jordan's most important financial sponsor -- severed oil supplies and financial support.
"You know that after Iraq and Kuwait, Jordan suffered most from this crisis," the King said.
Apparently In an appeal to Arab nations that sided with the victors in the war, he said: "Gloating and apportioning blame are not Arab traits, nor are they compatible with their spritual values because they lead to enmity, hatred and alienation. On the other hand, forgiveness and burying the past lead to healing the wounds and closing the ranks of the nation once again."
"Let us turn over a new page, thanking God that the gulf war has ended, the bleeding has stopped and that the people of Kuwait enjoy their independence once again," he said. In his last, major speech on Feb. 6, the King did not refer directly to the occupation of Kuwait.
 
'Stand by the Iraqi People'
 "We all bear a responsibility towards Iraq, its heritage and history," he said, urging reconciliation between Baghdad and Kuwait. "We shall stand by the Iraqi people as they look forward to rebuilding their country and to healing their wounds."
"Today is a day for reflection and self-appraisal, to heal the wounds, restore Arab unity and lay solid foundations for a better future," he said.
"On this day," he said, "we urge the world again to address the question of Palestine by the same criteria that it has applied over the question of Kuwait. We should also like to renew our pledge to the world that we are committed to striving for the attainment of a just and durable peace that guarantees the national rights of the Palestinian people on their national soil."
"Foremost among these rights is their right to self-determination and to representation in a peace process aimed at resolving the Arab-Israeli conflict," he said.
He ended his speech with Koranic verse saying: "It may be that you dislike a thing which is good for you and it may also be that you prefer a thing and it may be the worst for you. God knows all, and you know not." The same verse was cited by the Iraqi President in a speech as the allied victory approached.
