HEADLINE: Salary Fame Is Fleeting And Henderson Is Angry

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 1

 BODY:
Fact A: When baseball players began cracking the $3 million barrier in November 1989, Rickey Henderson spent three days as one of the two highest-paid players (with Kirby Puckett).
 Fact B: Fifteen months later, Henderson is tied with five others for 36th. 
 Fact C: Henderson continued to be a no-show at the Oakland Athletics' spring training camp today.
 Given Facts A and B, Fact C should come as no surprise to anyone who knows Henderson.
"You know Rickey," Richie Bry, Henderson's agent, said today by telephone from St. Louis. "Rickey has expressed his feelings about the contract, which by any standards is outdated. He's not happy about it and I'm sure they know that."
 
Numerous Complaints
 Henderson is not the only player unhappy about his salary for 1991. Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs is not pleased with the Cubs' offer for a contract extension he is seeking to elevate his economic status. Ramon Martinez, a 20-game winner last year, has rejected the Los Angeles Dodgers' contract offers and has not reported to camp. Jay Howell, the Dodgers' top relief pitcher, indicated his displeasure with a $1.05 million salary in the last year of a three-year contract by missing the first four days of training. And Rob Dibble, Cincinnati's uninhibited reliever, has threatened to leave camp over a contract dispute.
Joe Magrane, on the other hand, is happy with his salary ($1.025 million), which more than tripled his 1990 pay, but the St. Louis Cardinals' No. 1 starter is very unhappy nonetheless. He learned today that he would miss the entire season because of an elbow injury. Magrane, who is scheduled to have surgery April 1, hurt his left elbow Feb. 16 when he was throwing on his own before the start of spring training.
Magrane's impending surgery was described by the Cardinals as similar to that undergone in recent seasons by the St. Louis pitchers Ken Dayley, John Tudor, Danny Cox, Greg Mathews and Todd Worrell. Worrell is the only one of the five still on the Cardinals' roster.
 No one other than Henderson knows when his spring training will start. The Athletics' first full-squad workout was Wednesday, and he hasn't been sighted. Under terms of the collective bargaining agreement, players don't have to work out until March 6.
 
Counting on Henderson
 "I don't let the owners' executive board or the Players Association set my priorities," Tony La Russa, manager of the A's, said in the Scottsdale Community College gym, where rain forced his players to work out. "What's March 6? That doesn't mean anything to me. What's important is the team's feeling, and Rickey is part of the team. We need him here."
 Henderson, the American League's most valuable player last season, knows how to take care of himself, La Russa added. "He's playing for the Hall of Fame so he's going to be fine," the manager said. But once he makes his statement, he has to be here for the team. Rickey's status in the game -- m.v.p., the best leadoff batter in history -- has nothing to do with what he makes. He has to understand that. At some point, his absence becomes a concern. The point is not today."
 Bry and Sandy Alderson, the Athletics' general manager, have discussed Henderson's contract several times, most recently last Tuesday.
 "I don't know if anything will be worked out," Bry said. "It depends on the A's and their feeling of fairness toward him. If they can give him something, he can give them something in return."
 Bry was talking about adding years to the three years left on the four-year, $12 million contract. Alderson, who has negotiated the highest payroll in baseball history (about $36 million), didn't sound eager to grant the extension.
 
Try to Be Equitable
 "We have sort of a conflict of principles," he said, walking quickly to his car in the rain. "We don't renegotiate contracts, and I define renegotiation as giving away something for nothing. That's principle No. 1. Principle No. 2 is never say never. We try to be equitable."
 The dilemma, he went on, is "we have a lot of players in Rickey's situation, players who are underpaid by March 1991 standards."
"If we were to address all the players, we'd go bankrupt," he said. "The problem in baseball today is people are never happy. They're constantly in a state of turmoil."
 The Athletics don't know what state -- or city -- Henderson is in now.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rickey Henderson, unhappy with his 1991 salary of $3 million, which ranks him at No. 36 in the major leagues, has not reported to spring training. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Consumer Who Uses Shopping to Try to Alter Many Corporate Policies

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Consumer advocacy has its personal limits, and three years ago Alice Tepper Marlin found one of hers. Her daughter insisted on eating Skippy brand peanut butter. But Ms. Tepper Marlin's book, "Shopping for a Better World" said that Skippy was a politically incorrect choice.
"At that time Skippy was still doing business in South Africa," said Ms. Tepper Marlin. "We rated Jif higher, but my daughter won't eat it." 
 Skippy's corporate parent, CPC International no longer does business in South Africa. Her daughter's peanut butter obsession has waned. But Ms. Tepper Marlin remains committed to changing the behavior of companies by using pocketbook politics.
As a result, she has also helped to spawn an era of what might be called socially conscious shopping. The ethos of the book (Ballantine, $5.95), of which Ms. Tepper Marlin is an author, is now mirrored in a rash of books. And corporate America has taken notice, wrapping itself in the "green" marketing movement, a development Ms. Tepper Marlin views with both excitement and unease.
Ms. Tepper Marlin, an animated 46-year-old with a wide, easy smile, said, "We are concerned to the degree that it has remained a public-relations issue, and how little change has taken place in the marketplace."
Not everyone is fond of Ms. Tepper Marlin, particularly corporations that have run afoul of her relentess and ever-widening campaigns. "We really don't have any comment, but thanks for calling," said a spokeswoman for Abbott Laboratories , which Ms. Tepper Marlin's book rates as cheap toward charities, insensitive about promoting women and intransigent about South Africa.
Married to an economist with whom she adopted two Korean children, Ms. Tepper Marlin has long tried to intertwine capitalism and social activism. In 1968, while a securities analyst, she was asked by a synagogue to help it invest in companies with no interests in the Vietnam War.
That and other experiences showed her that managers of such alternative funds need a source of reliable corporate data. The result was the Council on Economic Priorities, founded in 1969 by Ms. Tepper Marlin. Interests for the center, which is located in lower Manhattan, today focuses on not only information on corporate policies, but also on Federal military spending.
Last year, Ms. Tepper Marlin and her husband, Dr. John Tepper Marlin (who took his wife's maiden name as his middle name), traveled to the Soviet Union for a conference on converting United States and Soviet military plants to peaceful uses.
 
800,000 Copies of Book Sold
 But Ms. Tepper Marlin's biggest clout has come from "Shopping for a Better World," which in three years has sold more than 800,000 copies. "The rating of companies is a reality of life and we have no problem with her ratings because they are fair and objective," said Neil Nyberg, a spokesman for Kellogg Company, which received one of the book's highest ratings in the 1991 edition.
The book started as an effort to help interested shoppers buy products from companies that performed best in such as areas as the environment and charitable giving. Recently, it has added other categories like animal testing. Companies are downgraded for landing on the wrong side of public controversies, applauded if they provide day care.
"We are trying to get people to look at their entire shopping basket," Ms. Tepper Marlin said. "It is not a matter of looking at just one issue or just one company."
The book seems a bewildering array of symbols, and does not consider the quality of products. But its social messages are clearly reaching some shoppers and many businesses.
Just this week, for example, officials of Church & Dwight Company (very good on animal testing, but weak on promotions for women, according to the book) called Ms. Tepper Marlin's group to set up a meeting to discuss ratings for the company, which makes household products like detergents.
 
Oreos and Cigarettes
 But Ms. Tepper Marlin's nit-picking is not just with Fortune 500 companies. She claims some credit for getting Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. to phase out Oreo cookies as an ingredient in its ice cream. The reason: Oreos are made by one of her arch-enemies, RJR Nabisco , a purveyor not only of cookies but also of cigarettes.
"I will not buy anything made by a cigarette company," Ms. Tepper Marlin said. Rob Michalak, a spokesman for Ben & Jerry's, said he could not comment on Ms. Tepper Marlin's specific impact.
Ms. Tepper Marlin is also using other vehicles to push corporations to change. Last year, for instance, she played a pivotal role in the creation of Green Seal Inc., a public-interest group which plans to award a seal of approval to products deemed environmentally sound.
This whirlwind of activity seems to suit Ms. Tepper Marlin. When her children, now 13 and 16 years old, leave home in a few years Ms. Tepper Marlin sees not more time to relax, but more time to work.
"When my kids go to college," she said, "I'd like to return to being more of a workaholic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alice Tepper Marlin's Council on Economic Priorities gathers information on companies' policies on social, political and economic matters. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Disarming the Gulf

 BODY:
At his magnificent Wednesday briefing signaling the end of the war, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf was asked whether Iraq would rise again to threaten the Persian Gulf. No, replied the allied commander -- not unless "someone chooses to rearm them."
At this moment of weary relief, that seems unthinkable. But weapons have a way of finding their way to the Middle East, to a host of clients, including Iraq. Years of indiscriminate arms sales helped cause this war. Unless checked, arms peddling could cause other wars. 
 The sellers are as culpable as the buyers. Real restraint, and a durable regional peace, will thus require a collective effort by the U.S., the Soviet Union and President Bush's coalition partners to curb their own commercial instincts.
The gulf states have been buying weapons at an astonishing rate. From 1982 to 1989 Saudi Arabia and Iraq made nearly a third of all arms purchases by third world countries, reports Richard Grimmett of the Congressional Research Service. The Saudis bought $44.2 billion and the Iraqis, $42.8 billion. Iran ranked fourth, with $17.0 billion, and Syria fifth, with $15.6 billion.
The sellers were mainly the Soviet Union, the U.S., France and Britain. Though by all rights the gulf war should serve as a severe cautionary tale, these same countries may be tempted to sell more arms in the future.
Why? For one thing, the end of the cold war means that defense spending and military aid will decline. That will spur arms makers to promote foreign sales in order to keep production lines open and spread the cost per weapon.
Meanwhile, recession and reduced aid are forcing states outside the Middle East to cut back. In 1989 sales to the third world dropped by 25 percent, to $29.3 billion. U.S. sales fell 14 percent, to $7.7 billion; Soviet sales declined more steeply, by 21 percent, to $11.2 billion.
Finally, arms sellers face keener competition from Eastern Europeans, who are desperate to export anything they can, and from relative newcomers like Israel, Brazil and South Korea. Curbing deadly commercial traffic in this political and economic environment won't be easy. But there are ways worth trying.
Encourage Openness. Arms sales often go unreported. The United Nations has a useful response: register them. A registry would make it easier to keep track of sales and focus attention on suspected but unreported ones. The coalition could go further and establish an international clearinghouse to share intelligence on arms trafficking and target suspect "front" companies.
Resume Arms Talks. Soviet cooperation is essential. In May 1977 Moscow responded favorably to a U.S. invitation to talks on conventional arms transfers. The talks foundered when the U.S. insisted on excluding sales to the Middle East. These talks could be restarted and expanded to include France, Britain, China and other major suppliers.
Concentrate on Sales of Advanced Weapons. Technological change fuels arms races. A key to stability is to focus curbs on the sale of the most advanced arms of all sorts, not just nuclear and chemical.
Use Aid as an Incentive. Economic aid to Eastern European and third world arms sellers could be used to induce restraint and convert arms factories to civilian production.
Mr. Bush suggested yesterday that while he did not wish to thwart the legitimate security interests of individual nations, he would seek an end to unrestrained arms "proliferation." Old habits die hard. But unless Mr. Bush moves decisively to change them, he'll be hard pressed to realize his dream of a new world order.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Victims Of War

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Even as U.S. forces, at George Bush's command, raced to victory in the desert, Ron Brown, the Democratic national chairman, was whistling past the graveyard.
 "The fact that the war appears to be ending quickly and decisively helps us get back to a domestic agenda," he said. "And getting back to a domestic agenda is helpful to Democrats." 
 Well, maybe, if anything can be. Polls do show that Americans tend to give Mr. Bush low to middling marks on domestic policy but that their appreciation of him goes up sharply at the water's edge.
 A year ago, for instance, just after his quick hit on Panama and the Communist collapse in Eastern Europe, in a New York Times/CBS News poll Mr. Bush rated 73 percent approval for his handling of foreign policy and 76 percent approval for his work overall. This, despite the fact that on such home-front subjects as environmental protection, education and taxes, from 63 to 84 percent of respondents disapproved of his Presidency.
 Now, after a startling plunge in his poll standing last fall, Mr. Bush is back in the statistical stratosphere, with better than 80 percent backing in most surveys. The smashing military victory in the Middle East, not the concurrent recession at home, obviously has most impressed the public.
 The consensus among economic analysts, moreover, is that the briefer the war, the shorter the recession. The proof of that will be in the pudding; but that the slump might be over before the 1992 election starts is not the least reason why Ron Brown and his party have little cause for optimism.
 Even if the Democrats can campaign against recession, moreover, as well as such other domestic problems as a failing education system, high crime rates, a dubious drug war, a crumbling infrastructure and the savings and loan scandal, their Presidential candidate, if they can find one, will almost surely be a decided underdog next year.
 The most important reason is that the war against Iraq has given Mr. Bush the aura of a strong leader -- and more than that, a victorious leader, one who pursued his chosen course boldly and with considerable skill. Mr. Bush, in effect, has won his title in battle; and it will be difficult for any challenger to match that incalculable asset.
 Military victory probably also has silenced the Republican right wing, which before Desert Storm was restive at Mr. Bush's reversal of himself on taxes and his suspect devotion to the conservative cause. Less will be heard, from now on, about the possibility of a divisive intraparty challenge from the likes of Pat Buchanan, Pat Robertson or Pete du Pont.
 Nor will the Democrats easily find a candidate sufficiently equipped to take on the winner of the desert war. The emphasis on foreign and military affairs hurt all governors, who are perceived to have little experience in these fields, and the quick victory probably damaged those -- like Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia -- who opposed the war. Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee, who voted for and supported it, will still be out-warred by the President, who actually commanded Desert Storm; so Mr. Gore, too, probably would have to emphasize domestic issues.
 It seems to me, however, that Americans now count on their Presidents to be strong and effective in foreign affairs, to act as their chief gladiator in a tough world, but that they no longer expect or believe that any President can accomplish much in the tangled underbrush of domestic matters.
 Abroad, Americans can see themselves as the good guys vs. the bad, with the President their champion -- a sort of political Rocky Balboa. But at home, things are clearly more complicated, by conflicting geographic and other interests, private and public sectors, legal and constitutional barriers, Federal-state problems, racial divisions, party politics -- to name only a few.
 Given this domestic snarl, the more a President tries to do, the more he tends to provoke opposition; the less he attempts, the fewer enemies he makes. As long as a President provides strong leadership in the world, however, a laundry list of domestic accomplishments is neither necessary nor expected; and an active domestic policy may even increase his opposition.
 Even while losing to President Bush, of course, the Democrats might expand their representation in Congress, and perhaps add some governors. Those are the folks from whom the public seems to expect good schools, less crime, better roads, more services -- and the ones they mostly blame when they don't get the things they want.

HEADLINE: For Yugoslavia, Breakup Is Best Answer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
News reports reflecting the Bush Administration position may lead some to the conclusion that the unity of Yugoslavia needs to be preserved at all costs. Several arguments speak to the contrary. 
 The issue of a federal Yugoslavia versus a confederal Yugoslavia, as put forward by Serbia and Croatia, respectively, is of an academic, but not a substantive nature. Had Serbia truly abided by the federal principles, many of today's problems could have been avoided. Instead, federalism died in Yugoslavia in the early 1980's after Serbia dismantled the autonomy of Kosovo province and declared martial law against ethnic Albanians.
Nor did Serbia's actions tame further ethnic passions; rather, they exacerbated nationalist demands in other parts of Yugoslavia. A parallel could be drawn with certain Soviet republics that, threatened by federal authority, automatically increased their claims for more autonomy.
Given the already high proportion of Serbs in the diplomatic corps and the army, Serbian insistence on the preservation of federal Yugoslavia will continue to be seen as a fig leaf for Serbian supremacy. Part of the problem lies in the decades of intransigence by the Yugoslav federal leadership to accommodate the initially modest demands of Croats, Albanians and Slovenes for a more equitable ethnic representation on the federal level. It would be unwarranted to assume that Croats or Slovenes have been bent on seceding from Yugoslavia all along.
The often-heard argument among Western observers, including State Department officials, that independent Croatia or Slovenia would have no economic basis for survival as independent states misses the essential point. Rather than wondering whether Croatia and Slovenia can survive alone, one needs to ponder whether any Yugoslavia can continue to exist as a single state.
A serious commitment on the part of all republics to restructuring Yugoslavia along confederal lines had, until recently, a chance of success. Today this option is no longer possible. Each confederation plan presupposes friendly relations among its ethnic constituents, not armed threats against one another. With all Yugoslav republics having voted Communism out of power -- with the single exception of Communist Serbia -- one wonders what is the point in keeping Yugoslavia together? The timely dissolution of Yugoslavia now appears the only solution to civil war.
Those who placed high hopes in the Yugoslav experiment need to realize that the peaceful departure of its feuding peoples is far preferable to the violent imposition of military rule and the subjugation of one republic by another.
 
TOMISLAV SUNIC
Assistant Professor, Political Science, Juniata College
Huntingdon, Pa., Feb. 10, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President's Retirement Bringing Shift at Nucor

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Nucor Corporation, a leader in an efficient new steel technology, announced a shuffling of its management yesterday under F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman and chief executive.
The new lineup puts John D. Correnti, 43 years old, in the posts of president and chief operating officer; Samuel Siegel, 61, becomes vice chairman and continues as chief financial officer, and Terry S. Lisenby becomes vice president and corporate controller. 
 Mr. Iverson said yesterday from Nucor headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., that the changes, effective June 30, had been brought about with the planned retirement of H. David Aycock, 61, as president and chief operating officer. "He's been with the company and its predecessor for 32 years, and he'd like to do something else," Mr. Iverson said.
Mr. Iverson has led the successful steel mini-mill company since 1984 and backed its bet on a new technology. After a long break-in period, that technology, called thin slab casting, is beginning to produce high-quality steel cheaper and faster than traditional methods.
Mr. Iverson, 65, who has been with the company since 1962, said he had no plans to step down. "I enjoy my job," he said. "My health is good. You should know when the time is right to leave." But he added, "The mandatory retirement age here is 95."
Mr. Iverson said Mr. Correnti had not been designated as his successor at this point. "I don't like the heir-apparent thing," he said. "He'd be one of the three top executives."
Mr. Correnti has been with Nucor, the nation's 10th-largest steel company, for 11 years. He is now vice president and general manager of Nucor-Yamato Steel Company in Blytheville, Ark., a Nucor joint venture with a Japanese concern.
Mr. Correnti has previously been general manager of Nucor's steel division, based in Plymouth, Utah, and general manager of the Vulcraft division, in Brigham City, Utah. "He's a civil engineer who came to us from U.S. Steel," Mr. Iverson said. "He was the youngest man at U.S. Steel ever made a superintendent of construction."
Nucor's new steelmaking process, which is gaining worldwide attention from steel industry executives, is operating in the company's mill in Crawfordsville, Ind., and is still working out imperfections after a two-year start-up. Nucor is counting on the technology to buttress its no-layoff policy and to continue its string of profitable quarters, which it hopes to keep up through the current recession, Mr. Iverson said.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Forecast Predicts Years Of Budget Gaps

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Even if the broad budget cuts proposed recently by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo are adopted in full, state spending will outpace revenues in the coming years, the Cuomo administration predicted in a report released yesterday.
 The report, the administration's five-year forecast, sketches a gloomy picture of the state's finances through the middle of the decade. Over the next few years, it suggests, additional spending cuts or new taxes will be needed to maintain a balanced budget. 
Future budget action will be required to bring spending growth in line with a slower rate of revenue growth," the report says.
 The Cuomo administration predicts that the state will emerge from its recession at the start of next year. But even with a recovery, it says, growth in tax revenues will not be enough to support growth in spending.
 Over the next five years, it predicts particularly large spending increases for Medicaid, foster care and education of handicapped children.
 
Deep Cuts to Balance
 The budget that the Governor has proposed for the fiscal year starting April 1 calls for deep cuts in state programs, including aid to education, Medicaid and grants to local goverment. If these cuts are adopted by the Legislature, the budget will be in balance through next year, the administration predicted yesterday.
 By 1993, however, substantial budget gaps will develop, it said. By 1995, the gap could grow to almost $2 billion.
 If anything, the administration's five-year forecasts have usually proven overly optimistic. Last year, for example, the administration predicted that the state would face a $1 billion gap this year; it has turned out to be almost $6 billion, according to Cuomo administration estimates.
 Some financial analysts said yesterday that they believed the administration was once again being too optimistic. "We are predicting slower economic growth," said Charles Brecher, director of research for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
 He noted that the spending growth predicted by the administration was, at least in part, a function of its own policies. "That's all controllable," he said.

HEADLINE: Desert Storm and Then What? A Reader's Guide

BYLINE: By Fouad Ajami; Fouad Ajami is a professor of Middle Eastern studies at the School of Advanced International Studies of the Johns Hopkins University and the author of "The Arab Predicament."

 BODY:
After Operation Desert Storm there will be an American imperium in the Middle East and we shall be healers. Such is the promise of what will come to pass when the guns fall silent. This is a return to an old theme. Pick up the American trail in Iraq and Kuwait and trace it back from today's expedition to the first American ventures into the Arab and Muslim realms. The themes recur, the history telescopes easily. Always there is the promise that over the horizon -- two or three camel days away, as the Arabs of the desert would have once put it -- there will be bliss: the distant power giving something of its innocence and optimism to a region burdened by its feuds and obsessions. And always there is the response of that world: dependence and resentment, attraction to the power from afar and the need to cover up the attraction and the dependence.
Americans don't know the realms of Islam with any great intimacy and authority. The United States has been an unsteady presence in that region: bursts of intense activism alternating with periods of benign neglect. We have tended to think of Arab and Muslim societies as places that the Europeans knew and understood. We stand in awe of the great craft of the British writers and travelers, of the curiosity that took Richard Burton, T. E. Lawrence, Gertrude Bell, Freya Stark and Wilfred Thesiger deep into the lives of strangers. But there is not much in the diplomatic record to sustain a presumption that the Europeans divined the Muslim world and its wellsprings with any great wisdom or precision, or that the conduct of European imperial affairs was made any wiser by the books and the travelers. For its part, the United States will have to learn more about that world under the gun, as it were. There is no assurance that our texts will serve us any better than Europe's texts served her in the Muslim domains, or that we will walk away from this expedition with the sense that we have come to know that world as it really is. 
 What follows is a guide -- one reader's guide, inevitably a bit arbitrary as all such guides are -- to recent books about the Middle East. It includes works of historical narrative and political analysis, and a few works of fiction as well. Though the novel is of recent vintage in Arab realms, a younger generation of writers has taken to it. In the novel they have found the perfect medium for exploring political and cultural material declared off-limits by the custodians of order and orthodoxy.
We should begin to read where Saddam Hussein and those among the Arabs who have rallied to his banner usually begin their historical narrative: the demise of the Ottoman Empire, the making of the modern Arab world in the aftermath of World War I. David Fromkin's splendid and ambitious book, "A Peace to End All Peace," is a reliable guide through that thicket. Mr. Fromkin takes us back to the late 19th century, when the Islamic realms in Asia were viewed in the West as Europe's old, ruined neighborhood. He then reconstructs the schemes unleashed on that feeble neighborhood. His tale is one of great men, their large deeds and even larger follies. In the Arab version of this narrative the tale is told as some sort of passion play, one large story of greed and betrayal. Mr. Fromkin tells it in terms of hubris and incompetence. British hegemony was established in the region in the aftermath of the war. But the tide had gone out on empire. There was little treasure left in Britain to sustain the new domain. Britons ruled behind a facade of native rulers, but they did so, in Mr. Fromkin's words, "with no great sense of direction or conviction."
This is where Arabs might begin a historical narrative of their condition. But inevitably they journey back in time. Their great deeds and achievements are in the past; hence the journey. Historical memory -- selective as all national memories are, playing tricks with the mind -- recalls a time when the Arab/Muslim empire that began in western Arabia extended all the way to Spain. "A History of the Arab Peoples" by the distinguished scholar Albert Hourani is a work of synthesis that pulls together the history of the Arabs from the rise of Islam in the seventh century down to the present day. It is a meticulous book, depicting the growth of a dominant cultural tradition that ran through the Arab realms of Islam and gave them structure and unity.
"Something was stable" in that world, Mr. Hourani writes. A family from southern Arabia could move into Spain and still find itself at home. The Arabic language "could open the door to office and influence throughout that world." A body of knowledge "preserved a moral community" even as rulers rose and fell and power shifted from one city to another. Mr. Hourani depicts the ways of Islam, the culture of its ulema (men of religion) and its courts, the world of the philosophers, the growth of a "chain of great cities running from one end of the world of Islam to the other" and the order of rulers and merchants that governed these cities. He then takes that world through its political shifts of fortune. Mr. Hourani's eye is for order, for the way societies elaborate and refine it. He looks into the abyss of today's Arab politics, to be sure. But it is an older world, with its grace and manners, that holds him. With Mr. Hourani as a teacher we can summon the distant world of Cordoba, or Beirut before its fall. Different guides have to take us through the pandemonium of the present, some through a leap of the imagination.
A young and gifted Lebanese novelist working in France, Amin Maalouf, takes us into that Arab present in an allegorical work of fiction, "Leo Africanus." Set partly in Granada during the final years of Arab rule in Andalusia in the late 15th century, it is a dazzling tale of pending exile and ruin. Granada is made to carry much of the contemporary Arab reality. "This city," a character in the novel laments, "is protected by those who seek to despoil it, and governed by those who are its enemies. Soon . . . we shall have to take refuge beyond the sea." The Sultan of Granada finds a way out of the city's trouble, or so he thinks; he declares war against the Castilians. We know how that tale turned out. The Castilians won, and the people of Granada, both Muslim and Jewish, took to the road. But they took to their places of exile the keys to their houses in Granada; they lived on the hope that "thanks to the Great Sultan or to Providence, they will find their house once again, with the colour of its stones, the smell of its garden, the water of its fountain, all intact, unaltered, just as it has been in their dreams." The reference here is clearly to the Palestinians.
Memory and remorse: they are also the material of Anton Shammas' "Arabesques," a nearly magical novel written in Hebrew by an Israeli Arab born in the Christian village of Fassuta in the Galilee. Mr. Shammas himself is a year younger than the state of Israel. Part autobiography, part the collective memory of three generations of the Shammas family, "Arabesques" has Fassuta's melodic voice and Fassuta's way of telling a story -- meandering in and out of the plot, hinting at things known but not explicitly said, alternating between cunning wisdom and fantastic legend. Of the people of Fassuta a man from a neighboring village observes: "Their luck is good, these Christians from Fassuta. They've always hunkered down at the end of the road, where the warrior comes to rest." Lucky Fassuta that it did hunker down in 1948. Four decades later, it was blessed again by a native son who took its legends, its defeat and its stubborn survival, and fashioned out of it all an enchanting tale. "Rahat Phalasteen. Palestine is lost and will never return," the narrator says. In "Arabesques" we get as close as we are ever likely to get to that vanished world. Beyond blame and apologetics, Mr. Shammas depicts the lives of ordinary men and women caught up in large events. In one of the novel's most memorable scenes, the villagers of Fassuta break into a folk dance, a wild Galilean dabkeh as their village falls to Jewish soldiers. A thin layer of dust rises, and "as is the way of all dust, it did not distinguish between the conquering soldier and the conquered villager."
Nostalgia of a different kind -- less convincing in my view -- animates "Cities of Salt." Written by Abdelrahman Munif, the novel is the work of a Jordanian of Saudi origin. Set in an unnamed principality of the Persian Gulf, it spans three decades: from the arrival of American oilmen in the 1930's to the 1960's. Mr. Munif's themes are political through and through. Though cruel, the desert was home. "What is there in this dry desert besides dust, sand and starvation?" The American prospectors arrive. The peace of the desert world is broken. It ends badly, that encounter between the desert world and the foreign world that intrudes upon it. Something of the desert world is rendered by Mr. Munif. Though his characters are cutouts and his politics at times heavy-handed, Mr. Munif's sprawling novel provides a window to the world of the Gulf Arabs, and to the sensibility of the Arab nationalists of his generation.
In "Republic of Fear: The Inside Story of Saddam's Iraq" by Samir al-Khalil, we turn from the world of the imagination to that of fact and of history, racing past the pieties of Arab nationalism and its pamphlets. In a more benign era, Arab nationalism was an affair of the intellectuals. The Baath Party, which gave us Saddam Hussein, was founded in the 1940's by two French-educated pamphleteers. Three decades later the Baath hatched a monster. Thanks to Samir al-Khalil (the pseudonym of an Iraqi expatriate and historian) we have a superb account of the manner in which Mr. Hussein and his apparatus of terror took an entire society apart and reconstituted it. From its inception in the 1920's, Iraq was an unwieldy realm, a land of divided communities. The Baath conspirators who seized power in 1968 came to stay. Theirs has been a methodical regime that, as the Arabs would say, devoured the green and the dry. The country had become heavily urbanized, hence easier to monitor than the older agricultural society. The centralized economy has shored up the role of the despot. It is a large prison and, as Mr. Khalil shows, Mr. Hussein has been a skilled warden. In this sort of enterprise the master structures the universe. Men believe everything and nothing. From the evidence of this book, it is easy to see the frightened polity doing the master's bidding, bowing to avoid his wrath, prosecuting his war.
Published a year before Mr. Hussein overran Kuwait, "Republic of Fear" is principally a discourse on the ideological foundations of the Iraqi state. Readers in search of a brisk and authoritative narrative of the guns of August 1990 should turn to "Saddam Hussein and the Crisis in the Gulf" by Judith Miller of The New York Times, and Laurie Mylroie, a Harvard researcher. Though an "instant" book, it is compelling to read. Both the events that led up to Mr. Hussein's heist of Kuwait and the more distant background of Iraq's bid for primacy are handled with skill and care. The best part of the book covers the special relationship between Washington and Saddam Hussein. "We knew he was an S.O.B., but he was our S.O.B.," a former official of the Reagan Administration recalls, echoing Franklin Roosevelt's comment in the 1930's about the Nicaraguan dictator Anastasio Somoza. In Washington's view of things, Mr. Hussein was the region's gendarme. The result was an American policy that was "a curious blend of cynicism and naivete," a policy that did not discourage Mr. Hussein from making his bid for dominion over the Gulf. In Ms. Miller and Ms. Mylroie's book we have a sustained analysis of this cruel and audacious action.
"The Rape of Kuwait" by Jean P. Sasson is another instant book on the crisis. And it shows. It is a serviceable volume of a particular genre. Ms. Sasson, an American hospital administrator who lived in Saudi Arabia from 1978 to 1990, sought out Kuwaiti refugees in Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Britain and the United States. She recorded their stories of heartbreak and strung the interviews together. "This was a book about people and not about politics," she writes. Fair enough. There are some excursions into Kuwaiti history, clearly the work of an amateur historian, that are better skipped. Stick to the interviews. The testimonies of the Kuwaitis supply further evidence that the Iraqi regime had all along seen Kuwait as one large oil well.
It was only in 1946 that the Emir of Kuwait turned a silver valve wheel on a loading pipe and started the flow of oil that transformed the hitherto impoverished principality of pearl divers and fishermen into an object of envy. Those who love big books can glimpse the lands of the Arabian Peninsula and the Persian Gulf, Kuwait included, some six decades ago, as the scramble for oil began, in "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power" by Daniel Yergin. Mr. Yergin, an authority on the oil industry, ranges over the far-flung effects of the black gold. In the Peninsula and the Gulf, Mr. Yergin tells us, the early history of oil was, in good measure, a chronicle of the deeds of Frank Holmes. A New Zealand-born mining engineer whom the Arabs nicknamed Abu al-Naft (the father of oil), Holmes was a restless man who sold the rulers of the Gulf a vision of bliss and abundant oil. An oil find in Bahrain in 1930 vindicated the faith of Abu al-Naft. "It was a stab to my heart when I observed the oil work at Bahrain and nothing here," the Emir of Kuwait complained to Frank Holmes.
The discovery of oil in Bahrain clinched matters for the great desert warrior of the Arabian Peninsula, Ibn Saud. Desperate for funds, he opened his realm to the oil companies. Some 15 years after Ibn Saud took the plunge, President Harry S. Truman would write to him: "No threat to your Kingdom could occur which would not be a matter of immediate concern to the United States." From Truman's pledge to Operation Desert Storm: it is not that long a journey.
There is no way of knowing whether the Arabs would have fared brilliantly had they looked their troubles squarely in the eye. But the Arabs looked away. For there was always that great alibi of modern Arab politics: Israel and the Palestinians. Yet despite this obsession, it has been hard for the Arabs to produce works on Palestinian matters that depart from the received history. Revisionism, an honest look back, is apparently easier for the victors. The defeated have wars to fight and scores to settle.
That is why it is younger Israelis who have gone back to that fight between Arab and Jew and returned with some bold new stories to tell. The best revisionist book may be "The Politics of Partition: King Abdullah, The Zionists and Palestine 1921-1951" by Avi Shlaim, the Alastair Buchan Reader in International Relations at the University of Oxford. Mr. Shlaim's is a magisterial accomplishment: he re-examined the play of Zionists, Palestinians and, across the Jordan River, the Hashemite dynasty, producing an intricate portrait of the old diplomacy. Mr. Shlaim did not set out to rehabilitate the reputation of the Hashemite king Abdullah (King Hussein's grandfather); quite the contrary, perhaps. But the tale itself exonerates the man. Abdullah was the product of an old world, of court politics. He knew that the Jewish claim in Palestine could not be denied. Seeking the possible and a sly, saving bargain, he accepted the partition of Palestine and paid for it with his life; in 1951 he was struck down by a Palestinian assassin. I was 6 and growing up in Lebanon when Abdullah was murdered. My generation of Arabs inherited the view of the Jordanian monarch peddled by his Arab nationalist detractors. Reading Mr. Shlaim's book -- in effect, sitting in on those long sessions that brought together the Zionist emissaries and the Hashemite ruler -- one yearns for the saving ways of the old diplomacy.
The same spirit of revisionism and curiosity about Israel's past is at work in "The Birth of the Palestinian Refugee Problem, 1947-1949" by Benny Morris. Mr. Morris's is a book of extraordinary power and integrity, written by a young Israeli scholar and journalist. He takes that great tale of flight and tells it as it has never been told before: with precision and moral economy, with awesome detail. In Benny Morris this episode has its first chronicler and historian.
Did they flee or were they expelled, these 600,000 to 700,000 Palestinian refugees? Those who love their history unambiguous have been sure. But there is no simple verdict in the spectacle Mr. Morris re-creates. It was a terrible time of war and panic. The seams in mixed Arab-Jewish towns came apart. There were cases of flight and cases of expulsion. The Palestinian social structure collapsed. The well off were the first to flee. A "psychosis of flight" seized Palestinian towns and villages. "Flight proved infectious," Mr. Morris writes. Expulsions and border clearings came later, after lines of battle (and hearts) hardened.
The founders of Israel did their work. It fell to the sons, heirs to the triumph and its burdens, to rethink the legacy of the founders. That great tension between the two generations is the theme of Meron Benvenisti's remarkable book "Conflicts and Contradictions." A former deputy mayor of Jerusalem, born in that city to a family whose roots there go back to the 16th century, Mr. Benvenisti is the son of a distinguished geographer, a map maker who, says Mr. Benvenisti, devoted his life to creating a new Hebrew map of Israel. "The Hebrew map of Israel constitutes one stratum in my consciousness, underlaid by another stratum of the previous Arab map," he writes. "I can't help but reflect on the irony that my father . . . imprinted in my memory, along with the new names, the names he wished to eradicate." This is a stunning book that charts with clarity and passion and in distinguished prose the intimate enmity between Israeli and Palestinian. Two maps clashed. A war decided the issue. "We knew that had they won they would have destroyed our work. But we won. . . . Who is the victim? Who is the culprit? Who is the judge?"
In this tangled landscape and in the lives of Arabs and Israelis there appeared, a decade ago, The New York Times's correspondent Thomas L. Friedman, a gifted outsider with an eye for detail and a rare ability to tell a story. Clear-eyed and knowing, he has written a book, "From Beirut to Jerusalem," based on his reportage from the two cities, that is sure to stand the test of time and to rank with the very best of what the great travelers and outsiders have produced about this region. Mr. Friedman went to the Middle East with an all-American sensibility. A child of a Jewish family from Minneapolis, he arrived in Beirut in 1979; he left Jerusalem a decade later. He came to a region in the throes of great changes. Beirut, the celebrated Arab city, the essential city of traders and middlemen, unraveled before his eyes. A Palestinian presence of great pretense -- Kalashnikovs and swagger -- self-destructed. Modernity peeled off. Mr. Friedman caught on to what was happening in record time. Beirut was a "city with a false bottom." It lived a lie. Outsiders came and went. But the malady of the place eluded them. Mr. Friedman was there as the Israelis and the Americans strutted in and then walked out. He was there as well when Yasser Arafat and his men departed from Beirut in the summer of 1982, passing off their departure as a great legend of heroism and resistance. He chronicled it all, with anecdotes and vignettes that bear his unmistakable signature.
Five years after he arrived in Beirut, Mr. Friedman packed his suitcases and golf clubs for his passage to Israel. In Beirut, he had lived on a fault line between Christian and Muslim. In Jerusalem, he of course found another fault line, that between Israeli and Palestinian. It took him a while to find it, "to penetrate the forest of right angles and to discover the jagged and volcanic fault line that lurked just beneath the surface of Israeli society." His incredible luck, the curious outsider's luck, stayed with him. By 1987, he was busy at work reporting on the Palestinian intifada.
There was a time, we know, in the early 1980's, when the past came calling on the Muslim realms. It suddenly pronounced on contemporary matters with newly found stridency and authority. Fittingly, it swept from the east, conjured up by a turbaned savior from Qum, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The region had had its fling with modernity, with the glamour of the foreigner, and now came the revenge of tradition and of nativism. It was hard to interpret this phenomenon of Islamic activism. We saw it like some desert wind sweeping societies back to the past. But it was not so simple. The revolt of Islam was a revolt of a thousand discontents. So many of the Muslim rebels had the outside world under their skin.
In fact, Muslims have reinvented their tradition as they have gone along. (Men and women adopt the ancestors they need.) "A revised or reconstructed past is never the same as the past as it was," the historian Bernard Lewis writes in "The Political Language of Islam." Taking us through the three principal languages of the Islamic tradition -- Arabic, Persian and Turkish -- the most outstanding Orientalist working today demonstrates that even the very language of the radical Islamicists "owes an unacknowledged debt to the westernizers and secularists of the past century and their foreign sources, as well as to prophetic and classical Islam."
But the high walls of Muslim homes kept us out. That is what those high walls are for in that world, after all. One exquisite book, a notable exception to the way the new Islamic politics was interpreted, is that of the gifted Harvard historian Roy Mottahedeh. In "The Mantle of the Prophet: Religion and Politics in Iran," a study as subtle as the society it depicts, Mr. Mottahedeh finds at the heart of Persian culture a pervasive love of ambiguity that gives that culture a "flexible exterior and a private interior." It was precisely that ambiguity that the clerics were determined to snuff out as "something no longer tenable, a freedom that history no longer permits." The genius of Mr. Mottahedeh's book is its remarkable device: the life history of a colleague of the author's, a young mullah by the name of Ali Hashemi (a pseudonym), born in the early 1940's. The large narrative of Iran's history is woven around Ali Hashemi's life. It is through him that we see Iran's mosques and bazaars, the coming of the revolution and then the disillusionment with the reign of terror.
Ambiguity there was aplenty in the Middle Eastern realms. But despots and modernizers and zealots of every stripe have been on the loose, trying to straighten out the crooked alleyways of that tormented place. That old neighborhood has been remade. Millennial passions and new machines have transformed it beyond recognition. One does not have to be unduly old or unduly nostalgic to grieve both for what was lost and what has risen in its place.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 917 words

HEADLINE: The Youngest Victims of AIDS

BYLINE: By Bettyann Kevles; Bettyann Kevles writes frequently about science and medicine. Her most recent book is "Females of the Species."

 BODY:

IN THE ABSENCE OF ANGELS
A Hollywood Family's Courageous Story.
By Elizabeth Glaser and Laura Palmer.
Illustrated. 318 pp. New York:
G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95. 
 Newspapers in 1985 were filled with stories about the plight of Ryan White in Kokomo, Ind., and the three Ray brothers in Arcadia, Fla. -- all hemophiliacs who, having been infected with the AIDS virus by blood transfusions, had been ostracized and barred from their schools.
At just this time in Los Angeles, 4-year-old Ariel Glaser, whose father, Paul, portrayed Starsky in the popular television series "Starsky and Hutch," began experiencing severe stomach pains. Eight months later Ariel was diagnosed as having AIDS.
The trail led to Ariel's birth and her mother's transfusion with infected blood. Ariel had gotten AIDS from breast-feeding. Tests soon confirmed that her baby brother, Jake, was also HIV-positive. Paul Glaser remained uninfected.
Elizabeth Glaser's life had always been materially comfortable, and surrounded by family and friends. But as soon as she sought counseling for Ariel, she discovered that no child psychiatrist would take the case. Mrs. Glaser was well aware of the stigma of AIDS and of how the Whites and Rays were being treated. She knew that while contracting a fatal illness is awful enough, the ignorance and fear surrounding AIDS could make her family's life unbearable. So, to protect their children, the Glasers erected a wall of secrecy.
As Ariel's health deteriorated, Mrs. Glaser focused her energies on enriching the child's life. But by 1988 Ariel's condition was desperate. "In the Absence of Angels" is Mrs. Glaser's story of what she did for her children when her back was to the wall. She has written, with the help of the journalist Laura Palmer, an absorbing and poignant memoir.
Elizabeth Glaser explains that when her doctors had no solutions, she awakened suddenly to the reality that "there was no one waiting to make everything all right for us. I had convinced myself that at some moment when our lives seemed utterly hopeless an angel would suddenly appear to set everything right. Well, there weren't going to be any angels of that kind. If anything was going to be done, I was the one who would have to do it."
She went to Washington to do research on AIDS at the National Institutes of Health and quickly learned that neither the progress of the disease nor treatment for children was part of the AIDS agenda. She also discovered that people in power were willing to listen to her story. She was able to mobilize legislators like Senators Orrin Hatch and Howard Metzenbaum; they co-sponsored a fund-raising benefit in Washington for Mrs. Glaser's fledgling Pediatric AIDS Foundation.
With the help of her friends Susie Zeegen and Susan De Laurentis, she created the foundation to raise money for basic research. No one had yet asked why some fetuses contracted AIDS from their mothers while others did not, or why AIDS attacked the central nervous systems of children more traumatically than those of adults. The foundation also supported additional clinical tests for the medication AZT, which was prescribed for adults years before it was given to children.
"In the Absence of Angels" is a handbook on how the connected make waves in America. Thousands of people had been unable to call attention to the needs of their children. But the combination of the Glasers' Hollywood contacts and the California network of Ronald and Nancy Reagan enabled her to meet, while in Washington, with the Reagans, George and Barbara Bush and, as the campaign of 1988 rolled on, with Kitty Dukakis.
Although Mrs. Glaser seldom mentions her own precarious health -- focusing instead on her delight and anguish in the company of her dying yet buoyant daughter and irrepressible, still asymptomatic son -- death hovers near. She describes the strains the disease put on her marriage, revealing how each partner dealt privately with grief.
Elizabeth Glaser says that she is not religious, yet she believes in the transcendence of the spirit, and in a series of quasi-mystical experiences she extends her hand to her dead child.
The Glasers bear no grudges against the anonymous blood donor who infected them, or against the inert medical bureaucracy. But they are furious at the National Enquirer, which forced them to go public in 1989 to pre-empt a distorted disclosure of their private agony.
With the wall of secrecy gone, the Glasers found their community loving and supportive. In the few years since AIDS has become a national scourge, their city has been generous to the larger group of AIDS patients.
Mrs. Glaser's heroic reaction to personal tragedy has been remarkable. She has channeled her considerable energies toward working not only for her own family, but for the thousands of other families whose access to power is limited. "When I have met with people in power it's usually because they think I am one of them," Mrs. Glaser writes. "In terms of color and economics, yes, I look the same, but . . . my goals are not their goals. They want to protect what is theirs. They want a kinder and gentler America for them, but not necessarily for others. My family needs an America that is kinder and gentler to all."
Despite the book's title, the Glasers' story is filled with angels -- warm, generous, energetic and imaginative people who listened and helped. This is why Elizabeth Glaser's story, despite its sadness, is upbeat and inspirational.

PUB-DATE: March 3, 1991

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: If This Is Hell, Why Is It So Popular?

BYLINE: By Bryce Nelson; Bryce Nelson is a professor of journalism at the University of Southern California.

 BODY:

CITY OF QUARTZ
Excavating the Future in Los Angeles.
By Mike Davis.
Photographs by Robert Morrow.
462 pp. New York:
Verso. $24.95. 
 The most impassioned dinner table argument I ever heard happened long ago near Washington, at the home of a writer for Life magazine with a very promising career. The writer soon slumped in shock as the chief opponents -- his father-in-law, an eminent New Mexico scientist, and his bureau chief, Richard B. Stolley, now editorial director for Time Inc.'s many magazines -- mixed it up. The subject of this vehement debate was, perhaps not surprisingly, the worth of Los Angeles.
Mr. Stolley, who had spent years in Los Angeles, insisted on the city's wonderful qualities, while the writer's father-in-law argued that it was an unforgivable bane on the face of the earth.
The mere mention of Los Angeles often has that result. Mike Davis calls it "the city that American intellectuals love to hate." "City of Quartz" has already attracted attention from intellectuals and others -- favorably quoted in The Los Angeles Times and nominated for a National Book Critics Circle award. Such attention is not surprising. As Mr. Davis says, there is little of substance written about the place.
In his presentation, Mr. Davis attempts the historical equivalent of film noir. He offers a dark, almost unrelievedly oppressive picture of life in a tough, hardhearted city where the ruling elite crushes the poor, whites exploit people of color, public space is turned into fortresses, police abuse the citizenry, and traffic, pollution and urban decay conquer all. "City of Quartz" is the nonfiction equivalent of the novels of Nathanael West at his most somber. Not for Mr. Davis are the idyllic scenes of fruit trees and mountains painted on California orange crates or of Gidget at a late-night surf party. Rather, he depicts an "ecology of evil," of "Armed Response" signs on Westside lawns, of beaches "closed at dark, patrolled by helicopter gunships."
It's all a bit much. Mr. Davis spends so much energy attacking the big guys that it's small wonder that he has not spent more time understanding the ordinary folks.
The author makes little mention of the climate, scenery, economic zest and diversity that have made Los Angeles what he calls "the fastest growing metropolis in the advanced industrial world." The millions of newcomers to Los Angeles didn't go there for nothing and, having found a place that seems as close to livable as possible in this world, most feel no compelling desire to leave. Many are even glad that they moved there.
As in the case of other large cities such as New York, many Angelenos believe that the world revolves around their hometown. Their aspirations and viewpoints are often remarkably provincial. Although Mr. Davis, who teaches urban theory at the Southern California Institute of Architecture, obviously knows more of the world than California, his powerful vision is sometimes dimmed by the same provincialism. He often writes as if he did not know that the problems of crime, pollution, racism and poverty characterize every large American city and, indeed, cities elsewhere. He sometimes writes as if Los Angeles, sheltered by the ocean, mountains and desert, existed alone.
Los Angeles is Mr. Davis's ideal whipping boy for all the sins of capitalism. "The ultimate world-historical significance -- and oddity -- of Los Angeles," he writes, "is that it has come to play the double role of utopia and dystopia for advanced capitalism." He leaves the description of utopia to others; the task he sets himself is revealing the city as the darkest dystopia. The stark, striking photographs of Robert Morrow help the reader understand Mr. Davis's portrayal.
It is difficult to pinpoint the unifying theme for the major topics Mr. Davis has chosen. He hops around -- from a history of the development of the area under men such as Harrison Gray Otis and his son-in-law, Harry Chandler, to an excellent account of homeowners' success in passing "slow-growth" laws; from a chronicle of real estate development to descriptions of "Fortress L.A.," as the rich pull up their drawbridges; from an enlightening tale of the city's criminal gangs and the police department to stories about the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles, which, because of its huge membership, ethnic mix and political clout, is, he says, "perhaps the most fascinating institution in Southern California." This book is, perhaps inevitably, somewhat narrow in its focus, with insufficient attention paid to the region's millions of blue-collar workers, to the social position of women or to the city's large gay and lesbian communities.
Mr. Davis is, however, particularly worth reading on the ethnic groups in a city whose leadership has been split in recent decades between old-stock American business and banking moguls downtown and Westside Jewish potentates from the movie and building industries. Both groups are increasingly aware of the growing majority, which comprises Latinos, Asians and blacks. "The most WASPish of big cities in 1960, Los Angeles now contains more polyethnic diversity than New York," Mr. Davis contends, noting that 86 languages are spoken in the city's schools.
Mr. Davis is not always fastidious in giving full credit for his extensive borrowings from the works of other writers on Los Angeles. In places, he relies heavily on the work of Kevin Starr, the influential historian of California. (Despite his reliance, he is quite critical of Mr. Starr.) He uses Mr. Starr's apt phrase that Los Angeles is "the Great Gatsby of American cities" but relegates attribution to his footnotes. The book also contains errors, including the consistently incorrect spelling of the last name of former Gov. George Deukmejian.
A forceful polemicist, Mr. Davis is also a serious historian and social thinker. Although knee-jerk phrases appear ("fascist obliteration," the "affluent babbitry of the Middle West" that dominated the city for decades), they are infrequent. One of several worthy pieces of history and analysis in "City of Quartz" is that on the slow-growth success of homeowners' associations in opposing the dread Manhattanizing of the region -- building skyscrapers and businesses near residential neighborhoods. The strength of these "Nimby" (not in my backyard) protests, Mr. Davis writes, meant that the destruction of the inner city "became the great non-issue during the 1980s, while the impact of growth upon affluent neighborhoods occupied center-stage."
Despite this partial protection won by the middle class and the rich, much of value in the region is being plowed up and destroyed. To conclude his study of urban devastation, Mr. Davis writes about his birthplace of Fontana, 60 miles east of Los Angeles. It was a tacky town whose citrus groves were blighted by smoke from Henry J. Kaiser's steel mill. The author ponders artifacts of Los Angeles discarded in Fontana's trash heaps, and writes that "the past generations are like so much debris to be swept away by the developers' bulldozers." Los Angeles may be that rough beast slouching toward Fontana to be junked. For Mr. Davis, the once clear, crystalline glitter of Los Angeles now faces the "junkyard of dreams."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 57; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2045 words

HEADLINE: Children's Food;
Organically Grown

BYLINE: BY DULCIE LEIMBACH; Dulcie Leimbach writes the "For Children" column in the Weekend section of The New York Times.

 BODY:
My intentions were always genuine, if not resolute. What I couldn't control for my newborn son -- ozone depletion, pesticide runoff, even the college he would attend -- left me with the one course I could control: what he would eat. I nursed him, and when he was ready for more calories, I bought organic baby food -- whole-grain cereals, strained carrots, peas, green beans -- with a passion normally reserved for more intimate endeavors.
I anticipated the morning when I would stir the quick-cooking cereal over the stove, throwing in a little wildflower honey, a little milk to keep it smooth. I knew that if my son started the day with hot cereal, the rest of his day -- why, his life -- would unfold as surely as the phases of the moon. But something happened between the stove and the highchair, when the spoon touched Joseph's mouth and the cereal slid down his bib. He wouldn't eat it. 
 I am not alone in this picture. My friends who are mothers have also experienced such defeats, and we've discussed these matters with disbelief. Is this, we ask, what raising a child is all about? Are these slight -- though reverberative instances -- windows into a long future of rejections and rebellions?
Hannah Ruth Rizzi, an otherwise ladylike 1-year-old I know, recently refused her mother's offer of organic blueberries with apples. Never mind that Hannah's mother had just bought three cases of certified-organic, additive-free baby food. What was she left to do in these economically lean, environmentally overwhelmed 1990's but to spoon the rest of the stuff into her own mouth?
To some extent, many mothers nowadays are scrutinizing what their children eat and drink -- an awareness led by Meryl Streep's organization, Mothers and Others for a Livable Planet. As a result, many consider popular baby food imperfect, and are instead buying organic baby food: a business that competes for the crying mouths of the 10,000 babies born in the United States every day. And even though such rarefied food costs at least 25 cents more per jar than the ordinary fare, the most popular brand, Earth's Best, in Middlebury, Vt., estimates sales of about $10 million this year. A healthy baby hath no price.
Other certified organic baby foods have recently begun to liven up store shelves, like the German-made Perlinger. This brand is confined to health-food stores, unlike Earth's Best, which is also available in supermarkets in some areas of the country. We missed the boat on testing the Perlinger apples, rice and honey combination (worth having another baby?), because the company didn't get its products on the American market until about a year ago, when my son was past the runny-food stage.
So we carried on, slightly wary of who had the upper hand. In the air was a sense of the inevitable because I knew childhood wasn't complete without junk food. But why did it have to happen so soon? By the time Joseph was ready to chomp down on food with edges and crunch, I was ready to capitulate to all those convenience foods lurking out there, lying in wait for me: hot dogs, salty spaghetti sauces, chicken nuggets, potato puffs, french fries. How did I, someone who had scorned hot dogs since the days of Jimmy Carter's Presidency, let this happen?
A softening of the will, for one; mother-fatigue syndrome as well. Coming home from work and cooking squash for an hour, only to have my otherwise charming son turn his nose up at it, became a session of his stubbornness versus my determination. Sometimes I couldn't make it home in time for dinner, and his father, a guy who doesn't read labels, would be serving Joseph fish sticks, unaware that there was -- egad! -- MSG in them. More occasions like these ensued, until I realized I couldn't control my son's diet as much as I wanted, unless I wore a uniform and carried a large stick. Frozen macaroni, with all its unpronounceable, undefinable ingredients (why do they have to put "natural flavors" in?), was insinuating its way into my son's little mouth. Joseph, healthy but finicky, was going to eat what he wanted.
But there are better mothers than I, ones determined to avoid foods with preservatives, additives, sugars, salts. Take Nancy Teas, whose 2 1/2-year-old son, Jac, eats vegetables as if his mouth were a backhoe facing a mound of dirt. Envious? Sure, especially since Joseph hasn't let anything green stray near his lips since May 1989. Teas's life was made simple by a Happy Baby food mill when Jac was toothless, which ground up small portions of whatever she and her husband were having for dinner.
"It's not as if I go out of my way," Teas says. "But I generally feed him foods that require cooking, so it does take more time." Teas's tricks are simple: lots of brown rice and beans -- even popcorn. Her son is also a connoisseur of more foreign fare: tofu sticks (tofu strips marinated in soy sauce then baked in the oven), gomasio on broccoli, tahini and carob-chip graham-cracker sandwiches, even umeboshi plums -- Japanese pickled plums -- that he plucks from the package and drops into his mouth.
Though the following recipes don't call for fancy plums, they do enlist such ingredients as tahini and agar-agar, or kanten, an edible seaweed gel. The recipes were chosen with children in mind and refrain from using too much salt and sugar. Agar flakes, when cooked with apple juice, are transformed into a creamy, almost mousselike dessert. When rounded off with a piquant dollop of tofu whip, it moves far beyond the pale of packaged desserts. The muffins and soup are made with pureed vegetables, and are good, nutritious foods that can become an entire meal.
The tofu meatballs may not be your first choice for dinner tonight but if you just think of tofu as a chance to broaden your children's culinary horizons, and your own, it may not seem off-putting. It's as if you're approaching the universe of books. You like Tom Clancy, but occasionally think about reading something experimental, say, a Thomas Pynchon novel or two. At least you don't have to read the whole book.
 
CREAMY CARROT SOUP
(From Susan Gilbert, nutritionist at Earth's Best)
 
 2 tablespoons oil or butter
 1/4 cup chopped onion
 1 cup water
 1 medium potato, peeled and diced
 1 1/4 cup carrot puree (or use 2 jars organic baby food carrots)
 1 cup or more of whole milk
Freshly ground pepper, chopped fresh dill or ginger and cinnamon, if desired.
 In a saucepan, heat the oil or butter and saute the onion until soft, about 5 minutes. Add the water and the potato. Cover, and bring to a boil. Cook until tender, about 10 to 12 minutes. Puree the mixture and return to the cooking pot. Add the carrot puree and milk to desired consistency. Heat gently over low heat, being careful not to boil. Season as desired with fresh pepper and dill, or a little ginger or cinnamon.
Yield: Four servings.
 
CARROT MUFFINS
(From Susan Gilbert)
 
 2 cups whole wheat flour
 1 tablespoon baking powder
 1 teaspoon cinnamon
 1/2 teaspoon salt
1/3 cup brown sugar
 1/2 cup instant powdered milk
 1 egg, beaten
 1/2 cup vegetable oil
 2 1/4 cups carrot puree (or use 4 jars organic baby food carrots)
 1/2 cup raisins.
1. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees.
2. In a bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, salt, sugar and powdered milk. In a separate bowl, combine the egg, oil and carrot puree. Add to the dry mixture and mix until just moistened. Fold in the raisins.
3. Grease a 12-muffin tin or line with paper and bake for 10 to 12 minutes, or until the muffins bounce back when lightly touched.
Yield: Twelve muffins.
 
APPLE SNACK CAKE
(From Nancy Teas)
 
 Butter or oil for the pan
 1/2 cup softened butter
 1/2 cup vegetable oil
 2/3 cup honey
 1/2 cup plain yogurt
 3 eggs
 2 cups whole wheat flour
 1 cup soy flour
 1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
 1 teaspoon cinnamon
 4 cups peeled, chopped apples
 3/4 cup chopped walnuts (optional).
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
2. Grease 9-inch-by-12-inch cake pan.
3. In large bowl, beat together the butter, oil and honey. Add yogurt and eggs. Add dry ingredients, blending gradually. Fold in apples and nuts.
4. Pour batter into cake pan and bake for 30 to 40 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean and the top of the cake is nicely brown.
Yield: One 9-inch-by-12-inch cake.
Note: This is not your basic cake, but a cross between bread and coffee cake. We ate it for breakfast, lunch and dinner two days in a row. The soy flour, walnuts and yogurt provide a good dose of protein, so it is almost like a meal. You could even top it with tofu whip -- see recipe -- to jazz it up for a party.
 
TOFU 'MEATBALLS'
(From the Moosewood Restaurant, Ithaca, N.Y.)
 
 3 cakes soft tofu (about 12 ounces each)
 3 tablespoons vegetable oil
 1 large onion, finely chopped
 3 cloves garlic, minced
 1 large carrot, grated
 1 green pepper, finely chopped
 1 1/2 teaspoons dried basil
 1 tablespoon ground fennel seeds
 3/4 teaspoon dried oregano
 2 large eggs
 1 cup whole wheat bread crumbs
 3/4 cup walnuts, ground or finely chopped
 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
 4 1/2 teaspoons Dijon mustard
 1 1/2 tablespoons dark sesame oil
 3 tablespoons tamari soy sauce
 Freshly ground pepper to taste.
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Place the tofu between two weighted cookie sheets and set aside for about 20 minutes.
2. In a skillet, heat the oil and saute the vegetables and the herbs for 10 minutes, or until tender. In a large bowl, lightly beat the eggs, then add the remaining ingredients. Mash the pressed tofu either with a potato masher or your hands and add it to the bowl, along with the sauteed vegetables. Stir well: the mixture should be firm enough to form into balls.
3. Using your hands or 2 spoons, pat the mixture into 1 1/2-inch balls and place on an oiled baking sheet. Bake for 20 to 30 minutes, or until dark brown and firm to the touch.
Yield: Three to four dozen meatballs.
Note: Joan Adler, a partner in the Moosewood Restaurant, suggests serving the meatballs with spaghetti and sauce, stuffed into pita bread or shaped into burgers and topped with Russian dressing, lettuce and tomato. Or you can prepare and cook the mixture as meat loaf and serve with mashed potatoes and gravy.
 
FRUIT KANTEN
(From Frank Arcuri, a chef at Angelica Kitchen, Manhattan)
 
 3 cups juice (like apple or other organic fruit juice)
 1 cup water
 1/8 teaspoon salt
 2 tablespoons agar flakes
 2 tablespoons kuzu dissolved in 2 tablespoons water (kuzu is a root starch available in most health-food stores)
 Zest of one orange
 1/2 teaspoon vanilla
 Pinch mace.
 1 cup sliced fresh fruit in season.
1. In a saucepan, bring the juice, 1 cup water and salt to a boil. Sprinkle agar flakes over boiling liquid, stirring to dissolve. Lower flame and simmer 5 minutes. Stir in dissolved kuzu and cook for 1 minute. Add orange zest, vanilla and mace. Remove from heat.
2. Rinse a mold or shallow dish (about 9 inches by 9 inches) in cold water and pour in kanten mixture. Let sit until it begins to thicken, about 20 minutes, then add fresh fruit. Mix gently and let sit until jelled in refrigerator, about 1 hour. Serve garnished with tofu whip (see recipe) or chopped nuts.
Yield: Four to six servings.
 
TOFU 'WHIPPED CREAM'
(From Frank Arcuri)
 
 1 pound soft tofu
 1/2 cup maple syrup
 2 tablespoons tahini or almond butter
 Pinch sea salt
 1 cup apple juice
 1 1/2 tablespoons agar flakes
 2 teaspoons vanilla extract.
1. Place the tofu in a saucepan and cover with water. Simmer 5 to 10 minutes, or until the tofu floats. Drain.
2. In a food processor, place the tofu, maple syrup, tahini and salt and process until smooth. In a saucepan, bring the apple juice to a boil, sprinkle with the agar flakes and whisk to mix. Simmer 4 to 5 minutes, or until agar dissolves, stirring occasionally.
3. Pour agar-apple juice into tofu mixture and process just until combined. Add the vanilla and process again. Keep the mixture in the bowl of the food processor and refrigerate for about 1 hour, until jelled.
4. When the mixture has set, process again before serving.
Yield: Four cups.
