SECTION: Section 2; Page 29; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1740 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
CBS and the Steel Magnolia

BYLINE: By MARC GUNTHER; Marc Gunther writes about television for The Detroit Free Press.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Growing up as a smalltown Southern belle, Linda Bloodworth-Thomason was taught to be nice to everyone. She was a cheerleader at her high school in Poplar Bluff, Mo., where she was voted "most popular" in her class. "Women where I'm from are raised as real people-pleasers," she says.
But Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason, the 43-year-old creator and executive producer of the CBS comedies "Designing Women" and "Evening Shade" succeeded in the male-dominated television industry only after she learned that it's not always smart to be nice. 
 There was the time, for example, when CBS took "Designing Women" off the air during its first season. Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason and her husband, the producer-director Harry Thomason, fought back by organizing a letter-writing campaign that overwhelmed the network with daily sacks of mail. One executive literally raised a white flag outside CBS, promising to put the show back on.
Then there was the Emmy Awards broadcast by Fox in 1988. The "Designing Women" stars, who were presenting an award, joked that they felt right at home on Fox because they were used to being seen on an obscure network -- CBS, which was then suffering a dismal ratings slump.
These days, she feels appreciated. "Designing Women" (Monday nights at 9:30) has become a top-10 hit. CBS executives also lavish praise on "Evening Shade," which they call a hit in the making. It has grown in the ratings and has lately won its time period, on Mondays at 8.
More than that, CBS proved its commitment by signing the biggest production deal it has ever made with an independent producer. The deal requires CBS to buy five shows over the next eight years from the Thomasons' company, Mozark Productions, for an estimated $45 million. The Thomasons personally stand to collect more than $100,000 a week in fees for each show they have on the air, CBS executives say.
CBS is gambling, especially since Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason has created only one certifiable hit, the five-year-old "Designing Women." CBS has committed not only to putting five Mozark shows on the air, but to paying full production costs. Customarily, the networks pay only a portion of costs.
Experience suggests that expensive network commitments do not always pay off. CBS's last major deal, with Grant Tinker, the former chairman of NBC, brought nothing of value to the network. And, while ABC's exclusive arrangement with Steven Bochco produced a hit in "Doogie Howser, M.D.," it also stuck the network with the bill for a costly flop, "Cop Rock."
Mr. Bochco's 1987 ABC contract for 10 shows is the largest entertainment deal ever made by a network, which has also made major commitments to the writer-producers James L. Brooks ("The Mary Tyler Moore Show," "The Simpsons") and Glenn Gordon Caron ("Moonlighting"). NBC has been reluctant to make similar production commitments. "These multimillion-dollar payoffs and these deals where we don't have the flexibility to say no simply don't make sense in today's economy," Warren Littlefield, president of NBC Entertainment, has said.
Naturally, CBS executives say the risk is worth it. "It's incumbent on us to put our money on a few prize winners," said Howard Stringer, president of the CBS Broadcast Group.
Besides, "Designing Women" and "Evening Shade" have become so important to CBS that the network simply cannot afford to lose Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason. She, as a result, has joined an elite group of writer-producers who are guaranteed not only financial security but the freedom to pursue their own ideas in prime time.
It's nice, she says wryly by telephone from her home in Los Angeles, to feel loved after all those years of dating -- and sparring -- with CBS. "I had been going steady with them for 17 years," she says. "It was time to get married."
Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason's most successful year in television has been tarnished by a very public feud with an old friend, the actress Delta Burke. The war of words began last summer when Ms. Burke, who plays Suzanne Sugarbaker, the saucy ex-beauty queen on "Designing Women," complained to a reporter that the set was "not a good workplace" and blamed the Thomasons. They shot back with a statement accusing Ms. Burke of being irresponsible and churlish.
Ms. Burke went to court in January, seeking her release from the show. She may get her wish. Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason says: "I will never know why she did this. It's been hard to take." Ms. Burke, through her publicist, declined comment, citing the lawsuit.
Although Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason grew up among lawyers -- a grandfather, her father and an older brother all practiced law -- nothing in her childhood, she says, prepared her to do business in Hollywood. She can, however, trace her sense of humor and feel for dialogue back to her upbringing.
"Humor is just a Southern given," she says. "There was a lot of laughing at our house, a lot of arguments, a lot of passion. There was a lot of conversation that stirred things up."
On a whim, she abandoned plans for law school and moved to Los Angeles in the early 1970's. There she met the actress Mary Kay Place, who suggested they write a television script. The script did not sell, but it wound up in the hands of the producer Larry Gelbart, who became her mentor and bought five of her scripts for "M*A*S*H."
Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason spent the next few years unhappily working on other people's ideas. "I took every job I was sent on because I thought it would be rude not to," she said. "They would put me with some guys named Irving and Jeff who were correcting my scripts. They didn't have a clue about comedy, usually."
Only after she married a guy named Harry in 1983 did Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason decide to produce as well as write. They met at Columbia Pictures Television, where she had noticed his Arkansas accent and introduced herself. He was a soft-spoken ex-football coach who took a protective attitude toward his younger wife. (He is now 50.) They formed Mozark Productions -- Missouri meets Arkansas -- and undertook their first project, an ABC detective series called "Lime Street," starring Robert Wagner.
It became another unhappy experience, as the Thomasons were forced to share decision-making with studio and network executives. "They had me doing stories about people who were princesses and Robert Wagner was saving them," she remembered. The show was rejected by critics and viewers, and canceled after a few weeks.
So Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason dug into her Southern roots and found "Designing Women." The idea was simple: "Get four women together and listen to them talk." She picked actresses she knew: Annie Potts and Jean Smart from "Lime Street," Ms. Burke and Dixie Carter from an earlier failure of hers called "Filthy Rich."
CBS bought the idea, and Ms. Bloodworth-Thmason wrote the perfect counter to ABC's "Monday Night Football" -- a smart, sassy show about four highly opinionated women who talk up a storm. While some critics knocked it as shrill or preachy, Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason said the speechifying is by design. "In the South, preachy is an exciting way of talking," she says. "Southerners are very sentimental and they're very sloppy about it. They really let their emotions out."
Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason wrote the entire season of "Designing Women" -- 35 scripts -- in longhand, on a yellow pad, on deadline. Howard Stringer, a Bloodworth-Thomason fan, remains impressed to this day. "In the annals of literary achievement, you'll never get Pulitzers for that," he said. "But in raw creativity and accomplishment, that's just extraordinary."
Mr. Stringer's promotion to his current job in 1988 marked a turning point for the Thomasons' relations with CBS. Over a lunch designed to mend fences, Mr. Stringer quoted jokes from "Designing Women" back to Ms. Bloodworth Thomason and said he had been embarrassed by the incident at the Emmys. Mr. Stringer says he told her, "I don't want you ever to have to get up on a stage and say that CBS doesn't know what it's doing."
Some programs take root at power lunches. "Evening Shade" took root at a power sprawl -- with Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason on the floor of her office with her husband and two CBS executives, poring over casting books in search of a star.
Mr. Stringer was there, along with Jeff Sagansky, who had cultivated the Thomasons since becoming president of CBS Entertainment. This was early June -- CBS's fall schedule had already been announced -- but Mr. Sagansky wanted another show from Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason on the air by fall.
She wanted to do an ensemble comedy about small-town America, set in Arkansas and built around a Jimmy Stewart-type character married to a younger woman. Her parents and hometown were inspirations. It was Mr. Sagansky, she recalls, who mentioned Burt Reynolds.
"That's it. It's perfect," said Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason.
"But he's at ABC," said Mr. Sagansky.
"That's your problem," said Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason.
The next day, Mr. Reynolds and the Thomasons met for lunch. Mr. Reynolds agreed to play the role of Wood Newton, a middle-aged football coach, and managed to wrest himself away from ABC.
"In the final analysis, she had a better bead on my life," Mr. Reynolds says. "I don't want to be chasing some bikini down the beach anymore -- not that I want to play Robert Young, either. But Linda is the first person who ever said to me, 'You know, I see you as Jimmy Stewart. I think you're very vulnerable and funny and small town.' "
Mr. Reynolds helped recruit a cast that included Elizabeth Ashley, Ossie Davis, Charles Durning, Hal Holbrook and Marilu Henner. The show has garnered mixed reviews and modest ratings. Mr. Stringer remains enthusiastic, noting that such CBS hits as "Designing Women" and "Murphy Brown" took time to find audiences. Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason admits that "Evening Shade" needs polishing. "These characters are not yet ingrained the way, say, Barney was on 'Mayberry,' " she says.
Ms. Bloodworth-Thomason dislikes the word sitcom and says she would like her characters to be as rich and memorable as those in great novels. "If Mark Twain were alive today, he would be writing in television," she says. "I just reread 'Little Women' not too long ago. You know, it was pretty boring. Not to disparage a great American novel, but I did not think those four women were any more interesting than Mary Jo, Julia, Suzanne and Charlene."

LENGTH: 257 words

HEADLINE: 'The True and Only Heaven'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Christopher Lasch, author of "The True and Only Heaven" (review, Jan. 27), may be a literate apologist for our failure to bring more of the poor, in America and throughout the world, out of misery and into the comforts and benefits of the middle-class life that he, and I, and many readers of The Book Review enjoy. But he is not an original one.
In 1927, Charles and Mary Beard explained, in "The Rise of American Civilization," that in order for the idea of progress to develop there had to be a respect for an interest in "the common business of labor and industry." As an attorney who represents employees, I can attest to the fact that this is not the case today. Although the so-called working class has a better life today than in 1927, this is true only if there is work available. With cruel layoffs in most American cities and a recession that even an overseas war cannot cure, Mr. Lasch's book gives slight balm to those whose children will have less than they did, rather than more, as the American dream promises.
According to your reviewer, William Julius Wilson, Mr. Lasch argues that "an environmental disaster would be created if the Western standard of living were successfully exported to the poorer nations of the world." This sounds like an elaborate way of saying to those who are struggling, you don't want what we have, you want spiritual values.
Such skepticism about progress used to be written off as "you'll get pie in the sky when you die, that's a lie."
 
KAREN DE CROW
Jamesville, N.Y.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Fifth Avenue;
Retailers Place Heavy Chips on the 50's

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
INTERNATIONALISM has been on the ascendance in Fifth Avenue retailing for some years, and it is getting yet another upward thrust with a new mixed-use building for Takashimaya, the Japanese department store chain.
In Japan, the Takashimaya Group has 17 full-scale department stores. In New York City, Takashamaya has essentially been a gift shop. Its first store opened on 46th Street in 1958. Then came a move to 3,000 square feet near 43d Street in 1966. Since 1978, it has had only a second-floor gift salon. But always on Fifth Avenue. 
 It had long wanted a better avenue location, however, said Jiro Shinahara, head of Takashimaya's New York operation, "and we felt it was better to own our own building."
The new location is between 54th and 55th Streets, where the air of high fashion and expensive jewelry is purer than it is in the 40's. Takashimaya intends to appeal to a worldwide clientele with china, jewelry, leather goods and other wares sought by travelers as well as locals.
The $60 million Takashimaya project provides new reason to take notice of the upward swing in investment in high-end retailing on Fifth Avenue, particularly in the 50's. One notable expression of this was the opening of the 45,000-square-foot Bergdorf Goodman's men's store in the former F.A.O. Schwarz space on 58th Street last August. That was a $20 million project.
And just yesterday a new Henri Bendel store opened on four floors with 85,000 gross square feet of space in 712 Fifth Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets. Henri Bendel is a division of The Limited, which did not disclose the dollar investment in the store. A spokesman said that an Express store, another Limited outlet, will open in the old Bendel store on 57th Street.
All of this comes at a time when retail rents have generally declined and availabilities have increased as a consequence of the recession.
Average asking rents throughout Manhattan were down to $49 a square foot at the end of last year, according to Garrick-Aug Associates, the store-leasing firm. That is about the level that prevailed in 1983. Actual contract rents were on average 31 percent below the asking rents, the firm said.
But because of the short supply of Fifth Avenue space in the 50's, rents there are down only about 10 percent from the level of $550 a square foot a year ago, said Faith Consolo, senior vice president of Garrick-Aug.
The new investment projects confirm Fifth Avenue's long-term retailing place and underscore the importance of maintaining a street environment that will help sustain it. Blatantly garish and oversized signs and street vending of off-price merchandise work against this, although there has been some recent success in curbing the most offensive hucksterism.
The Takashimaya project is a demonstration that in specific situations it is possible to build a new structure in a high-land-value commercial street on an extremely narrow lot. Four years ago a major Brazilian development company, Gomes de Almeida, Fernandes SA, did it with an 18-story, 80,000-square-foot office building at 590 Fifth Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets.
A new building on a narrow, midblock Fifth Avenue site presents an opportunity to carry forward a distinctive Fifth Avenue look for the long term. That look is probably at its best north of 53d Street. In the 40's, a number of surprisingly ragged town houses still survive on 20-foot plots. Owners wring substantial income from first-floor tenancies, but higher floors normally earn little.
SOME yearn for the day when two or three parcels, free of long-term lessees, can be put together with enough street frontage to make a viable building lot. Such a parcel has been assembled lately by King Fook, the Chinese antiques and crafts store, which opened a 5,000-square-foot midblock store at 675 Fifth, off 53d Street, in 1979 and recently acquired the corner property formerly occupied by a Doubleday book store.
Now King Fook owns 100 feet of avenue frontage on a block where Fortunoff's and Gucci's also have property. It is a potential development site.
The 5,600-square-foot Takashimaya site has 50 feet of frontage on the avenue. A Chandler's shoe store had been the prime tenant in a small building on the site.
The Takashimaya store will occupy 20,000 gross square feet of space on the first four levels of a 20-story, 86,000-square-foot building. The fifth floor will house Takashimaya's offices. A private Japanese club will occupy three 5,000-square-foot floors above that. Then come 10 floors of 4,200 gross square feet for offices, and, at the top, a penthouse apartment. The address is 693 Fifth Avenue.
The architect, John Burgee, says the design will reflect the style of surrounding buildings -- the Elizabeth Arden Building on one side and the St. Regis Hotel on the other. Limestone is the primary building material on a facade adorned by tall black granite columns and small gilded windows in the manner of Fifth Avenue's Scribner's store. At the setback for the office floors the color of the granite turns to red.
Real-estate professionals say that the expectation of leasing space to a private club for Japanese executives may explain how the project became economically viable. Takashimaya has not reported a signed lease, but it may expect a high rent for club occupancy. Another explanation is the demonstrated interest of the Japanese in investing in Manhattan real estate, not necessarily characteristic of retailers. "If you are a retailer you had better stick to the business you know," says Kurt Barnard, a retailing consultant.
Retailers sticking to the business they know have brought what Thomas Cusick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, describes as a new wave of investment on Fifth Avenue. Not all of it is in the 50's, but what is in the 50's has a definite international tone.
A notable example is the gut renovation that Zegna's, the Italian men's store, undertook as a long-term lessee on six floors in the 10-store midblock building at 743 Fifth Avenue, next door to the Bergdorf's men's store. Zegna, based in Milan, has 87 stores worldwide.
"We felt that location was the key," said Richard Cohen, president of the American operation. To sell men's suits that start at $1,000 and sweaters that start at $600 it wanted to be in the company of other fashionable retailers, jewelers and perhaps banks. Zegna's has four 1,400-square-foot selling floors and two wholesaling floors, and the distinctive facade that strikes the proper note of Fifth Avenue glamor.
Another example is the move of Wempe's, the German jewelry and accessories firm, expanding into 2,800 square feet on two levels in the Peninsula Hotel, at 55th Street. Wempe's had been a subtenant of Chandler's the shoe store that was on the site that Takashimaya bought. Thirty percent of its sales are to overseas visitors, said Nicola Gerber, the proprietor. Despite the drop in tourism, its sales have doubled in the last two years, she said.
Between 55th and 56th Streets, Bally of Switzerland expanded its flagship store in the last year. Half a block away, Fendi's, an Italian leather goods and accessories store, opened its first American store. And last November the first Christian Dior boutique in New York City -- carrying made-in-France merchandise -- opened in 4,500 square feet on two floors of the St. Regis Hotel, at 55th Street.
Bergdorf Goodman has roughly tripled the space devoted to men's clothing in its lease at 745 Fifth. Bergdorf, part of the Neiman-Marcus division of General Cinema Corporation, took 66,000 square feet, which includes one floor for offices.
Bergdorf is hoping to achieve sales of $1,000 a square foot in the new store, said Peter Farwell, spokesman for the company, which is about what the men's store in the old building did. It is too early to evaluate the new store's success, he said.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Maryland;
A Regent's Seat For Frank Perdue Draws Protests

DATELINE: COLLEGE PARK, Md.

 BODY:
Frank Perdue has been a University of Maryland system regent for barely a month, but a number of student groups and faculty members on the College Park campus say they want him out.
Among his opponents are animal-rights advocates, who describe Mr. Perdue's record as a factory farmer as poor, saying he mistreats both his workers and his chickens. 
 Mr. Perdue is the chairman of the nation's fourth-largest producer of broiler chickens, Perdue Farms, in Salisbury. During the last year, about a dozen workers and Federal inspectors have filed complaints against Mr. Perdue for occupational-safety hazards, said Tom Devine, a lawyer for the Government Accountability Project, a Washington-based public interest group.
"If the goals of the university are simply to make money, he's good for the job," said Karen Davis, a campus English instructor who is faculty sponsor of the Animal Rights Coalition. "He doesn't support higher education. They chose him because he knows where to put money to make people think he's a swell guy."
 
 More Protests Vowed
 Now students say they will campaign for Mr. Perdue's resignation. About 50 students attended a protestlast month sponsored by the animal-rights group to call attention to Mr. Perdue's record.
Ms. Davis said coalition members would also attend all Board of Regents meetings to protest Mr. Perdue's appointment.
"We will be there with signs saying we want 'Perdue off the board' and, 'We don't want you, Frank Perdue,' " she said. "We definitely want the board to feel it's embarrassing to them as well as to the university." Ms. Davis said the coalition would collect signatures on a petition to be sent along with letters to Gov. William Donald Schaefer and local newspapers.
Mr. Perdue was appointed on Jan. 28 by Governor Schaefer to fill a vacancy on the 16-member board created by the death of John Webb.
 
Business School Benefactor
 Mr. Perdue has made several donations to Salisbury State University, one of the system's 11 campuses. One gift was of $2.5 million to establish a business school. William Kirwan, president of the College Park campus, said after the appointment that Mr. Perdue's business experience could benefit the system.
Mr. Kiwan said Mr. Perdue also knows the Governor and can relay concerns and needs of the system to him. Others also said that Mr. Perdue would be an effective regent.
"Frank Perdue has contributed more to the system than just money," said David Lasher, president of the system's student council. Mr. Lasher, a senior economics major from Salisbury, at Salisbury State, said Mr. Perdue's contributions are visible there. He said Mr. Perdue also attends football games and theater productions and invites students to his home each semester.
Although Mr. Perdue could not be reached for comment, a spokesman, Richard Auletta said, "Frank Perdue has a deep-rooted commitment to the state and will stand on his records of accomplishments and his records as a businessman."
 
'Bad for Our Image'
 But Mark Parascandola, the student president of the campus animal-rights group, said, "I'm embarrassed he will be associated with the university." Mr. Parascandola, a junior philosophy major from Silver Spring, added: "The Governor has a responsibility to choose someone who has concerns for the environment. Not only is it bad for our image, but it will affect his job if he is not sensitive to the issues."
Stuart Catalgo, a founder of the animal-rights group, said Mr. Perdue's factory farming is harmful to the environment, his workers and the health of consumers.
"It's one thing to claim it's natural to eat animals, but we're stepping outside the natural cycle with these big factories and treating animals like part of the machine," said Mr. Catalgo, a junior biology pre-med major.
Others have criticized the treatment of both chickens and employees at Perdue Farms, which has sales of more than $1 billion a year and a work force of about 14,000.
"Most of us treat our pets generally better than Mr. Perdue treats his workers," said Donna Bazemore, an employee in a North Carolina plant, told a Congressional subcommittee on labor management relations in testimony given in November 1989. She described conditions in Mr. Perdue's plants as "modern slavery" and said the poultry industry "has not shown any respect for consumers' health."
Ms. Bazemore was the first to win a workers compensation appeal against Mr. Perdue, totaling $1,200.

HEADLINE: About Cars;
The Ultimate BMW Takes a Step Up

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
I don't care how steady you are, it is hard to drive well when the cops are behind you.
I was having that trouble the other night on New York's West Side, and the police car trailed me for an eternity. Finally, at a light, the partners pulled up in the left lane and rolled down their window. And what they said to me was: "How much?" 
 How much? After all that careful driving? Ah. But that is what everybody wonders about this car, or at least that is what they wonder after they have given it the once-over, figured out what it is, and wondered again what sort of high-muckety person is driving it.
This is that sort of vehicle, the kind of car that causes all of the drivers you pass to crane their eyes. Traffic drops back for a glimpse at the rear. It pulls alongside. It steps on the gas to tweak your nose. And sometimes, when the traffic is officially municipal, it stops you. Just for a look and to ask: How much?
In this case, with paint that looks much like run-of-the-mill Ferrari and is called "brilliant red" by the factory, the how-much is $77,600, including $1,000 for the optional forged alloy wheels and the gas-guzzler tax of $3,000. That's a lot, but it is almost reasonable when you compare it to some of the competition.
Of course, you know what car we're talking about because you've seen the headline and the picture. But just to put the record straight, the paint and the hefty sticker adorned an 850i from Bayerische Motoren Werke AG in Munich, Germany, BMW's newest and flashiest offering.
And the latest version of the company's V12 automobile takes us back to 1988. That was the year in which the company put the gigantic engine into its new and lovely 750iL sedan, and I confessed at the time that I was smitten. The 750, I said, was probably the best car on the road, and I couldn't wait for its sporty incarnation.
For 1991, that version is here as a pillarless hardtop coupe, and it takes its place with the Mercedes 300 SL, Acura's NSX and Corvette's ZR1 as one of the truly great fun machines. Like them, it bristles with technological wonders. But unlike them it is a quasi sedan, and it can carry four adults -- handily, if the two in the rear are midgets.
The car is the successor to BMW's 635 CSi, but it is more than an inch shorter and five inches wider than its predecessor. Its unit body wears blackout trim, and there is a lot of flush glass. And the new design is as aerodynamic as anything on the road, with a coefficient of drag of only .29.
There is a long hood, a short deck, and a passenger cabin that is placed rearward to create a shape that not only balances front and rear aerodynamic forces at high speeds but improves crosswind stability. The windshield and rear-window pillars also provide mounting points for arches that serve as horizontal "rollbars" and allow new rigidity in a hardtop coupe.
In addition, the car is a platform for state-of- the-art electronics. They control the 5-liter engine, which puts out 296 horsepower and can be had with an electronically controlled automatic transmission or a six-speed manual. Like the 750, the new car is a rocket, and it accelerates from zero to 60 in less than seven seconds. Top speed is 155 m.p.h., and that is only because an electronic governor prevents the car from going faster.
Electronics abound elsewhere, too. The standard cellular phone, for instance, is complimented by voice-activated dialing, and the 850 has a nerve system of multiplexed wiring, which transmits several messages along each channel, simplifying the electrical connections and allowing new functions that were not possible with conventional wiring.
Among the more noticeable effects are the power-window functions, which include one-touch up and down operation and an automatic lowering of the front windows when the doors are opened. The purpose here is to protect the window seals when the doors are slammed shut, and you spot the feature right away. When you get in, there is that surprising slither as the windows close.
The chunk of the door also tells you that the 850 is as solid as a vault, but the slightly opened windows allow the doors to shut easily, and their seals keep the windows from pulling away from the body at high speed.
Once inside, you notice some of the other neat thoughts of the designers, also made possible by the multiplex wiring. A twitch of the windshield washer wand, for instance, yields an automatic three swipes by the wipers, then a pause, then another final swipe to get rid of drips.
The seats, eminently adjustable, have memory positions for three drivers. The memory includes the electrochromatic rearview mirror, the heated side mirrors and the tilt-and-telescope steering wheel, and puts them all back just the way you like them. And, of course, the passenger-side mirror flicks down to show you the curb whenever you shift the transmission into reverse.
Leather is standard in the 850, and the car smells as good as it feels. Controls for the windows, the central locking and the mirrors are in the driver's armrest, and all of the adjustments and doodads are right where they ought to be. Beyond the leather-wrapped wheel with an air bag in its hub, there is an instrument panel that holds a 185-m.p.h. speedometer and a 7,000-r.p.m. tachometer, and the dash has a computerized information display to tell you things such as outside temperature and range on fuel in the tank.
The dual-level glovebox has two doors so you can get yourself properly organized. And there are separate automatic climate controls for driver and front-seat passenger.
The sunroof tilts and slides, and the sound system is stupendous, probably owing to its 12 speakers. A standard compact-disk changer hides from thieves in the trunk, and the radio has two FM bands.
And here we come to one of the few quibbles. The radio antenna is embedded in the rear window, and like all such antennas it is less than satisfactory when you are tuning the AM band. Window-antenna technology is improving, but it isn't perfect.
A second fault in this otherwise wondrous chariot has to do with fuel economy, which is pretty much a misnomer. In a time of serious energy consciousness, a four-seater that posts a rating of 12 miles per gallon, city, and 18, highway, is a luxury indeed.
On the other hand, there won't be that many of these cars gobbling up the oil supply. And when you own one of the best, that knowledge can be one more small comfort.

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
The war in the Persian Gulf is the first in 45 years in which American soldiers are not being paid with a special military currency. Because of the relative wealth of Saudi Arabia, the stability of its economy and the ubiquity of the American dollar in the region, military authorities apparently felt that an alternative currency was not needed.
During most of World War II, soldiers stationed overseas were paid in the local currencies, but in 1946 the United States found itself holding nearly half a billion dollars of unwanted foreign currency. The Government began printing a special Allied Military Currency that was issued to all allied occupation soldiers, including Russians. This common currency facilitated a booming black market among the allied soldiers and, to a lesser extent, among German civilians. Soviet soldiers heading home knew that their Allied Military Currency would be confiscated so they paid inflated prices for articles difficult to purchase in the Soviet Union. Cameras and watches could be sold for small fortunes by the G.I.'s. 
 In the summer of 1946, the United States had nearly five million troops stationed overseas and was paying them in some 40 different foreign currencies as well as in special military notes. The deficit problem continued. But in July the military began issuing the A series of the Yen Allied Military Currency to be used by all United States soldiers in Japan for purchases in military commissaries and post exchanges. In September the new currency was printed for the troops in Europe and soon was being used from Iceland to Iwo Jima.
The wartime currency most familiar to Americans was the Military Payment Certificates issued in Vietnam. Four different issues were printed by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing from August 31, 1965 until March 15, 1973.
The different issues were produced because a huge market for the conversion of MPC's into dollars developed. Anyone possessing greenbacks could almost double his money by trading them illegally for MPC's. The MPC's could then be taken to huge military exchanges in Saigon to buy stereos, washing machines, cameras or other high-priced items. Goods in military exhanges are sold cheaply and untaxed, so anyone who had doubled his money by illegal conversion could buy many items and sell them to the Vietnamese who were forbidden to shop in military exchanges. Thus small fortunes were made. Legends abounded in Vietnam of soldiers who had returned to the United States with hundreds of thousands of dollars hidden in their personal gear.
To counter this activity, the military would declare a Conversion Day, kept secret until the last moment. At dawn on C-Day military bases were locked, civilian workers told to stay home and every soldier required to change his stock of Military Payment Certificates for a new and different issue. Anyone trying to change large amounts was taken aside and questioned. The old issue was declared worthless, and all notes collected were burned. Of course, the new issues played havoc with the black market, but also with the incomes of the myriads of Vietnamese casual workers -- the maids, barbers, bar girls, tailors and shoeshine boys that worked on and around the bases. C-Days could wipe out their small savings, and any rumor of an impending C-Day caused panic as workers tried to get rid of their own MPC's.
The last issue of 1970 was finally withdrawn in 1973 and MPC's have not been reissued since. All soldiers are now paid in United States dollars. But anyone who has held onto Vietnam-era MPC's is in for a pleasant surprise. The scrip, called "funny money" among the troops, has increased in value. Some notes in fine or extra-fine condition are now selling for as much as twice their face value. But an uncirculated $10 MPC note issued from late 1968 until the summer of 1969 is worth nearly $600.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
On Main Street, The Bulls Are Stampeding

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The public is back in the market, and the speculative stocks are soaring. The money managers, suddenly bullish, are searching for laggards, afraid to stay on the sidelines. All told, it is certainly enough to make a contrarian investor nervous.
It is individual investors who are pushing up prices now. "A lot of buyers came into the market," exulted Larry Armstrong, executive vice president of Fidelity Investment's discount brokerage operations, after peace hopes brought a buying panic on Monday, with volume soaring and more than two buy orders for every sell. Even on Jan. 17, when prices leaped after the air war began, that ratio was just three to two. 
 Those buyers want action, not safety. The Russell 2,000 index of small stocks rose 2.4 percent last week. The Dow Jones industrial average added only 20.54 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,909.90.
Investors are also pouring money into all kinds of mutual funds, especially those that buy junk bonds. Merrill Lynch's junk index leaped 8.7 percent last month. Marty Fridson, who runs junk research at Merrill, says second-tier bonds led the rally, as buyers passed up the highest-quality junk, which was already trading close to face value.
It isn't only the retail investors who are eager. In early February, the so-called professionals were about as bullish as they were in September 1987, just before the crash, reports Dick Hoey, the chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. Last September, when prices were far lower, they were more bearish than at any time since Mr. Hoey began his surveys of investment decision-makers in 1983.
Anyone looking for evidence of speculation need only check out LTV, the long-bankrupt steel and aerospace company. After leaping 150 percent last week, its common shares are at $2.50 each, or about $300 million for the whole company. The cause for the glee is that LTV may be on the verge of settling its pension problems, on undisclosed terms that have not been completely worked out.
When it finishes that deal, LTV will have to come up with a way to satisfy creditors who are owed $2.5 billion. Chances are that they will be offered packages of securities including gobs of common shares, badly diluting the stake of current holders.
LTV's junk bonds are rising, but not as rapidly as the shares. The best secured of the bonds still trade for 60 cents or less on the dollar, while the worst fetch a dime. Even those bonds have priority over the common holders, so it is puzzling what the stock buyers think they see. Or maybe it just proves that, when the speculative juices are flowing, a lot of people buy first and ask questions later.
Since Jan. 17, the Dow is up 16 percent, and the Russell 2,000 has soared 29 percent. Meanwhile, interest rates have stopped falling and started to edge up, on suspicions that the Federal Reserve will delay further easing while waiting to see if the recession is going to end soon.
Few wars have been as joyful for investors. Now they are betting that with peace will come prosperity, and a lot of it.

HEADLINE: Tougher Tactics to Keep Out Unions

BYLINE: By BARRY SCHIFFMAN

 BODY:
When nearly 300 workers who sew shirts for Farris Fashions in Brinkley, Ark., threatened to form a union, the owner of the factory, union organizers say, vowed to close the factory and turn it into a chicken coop if they did. It was not surprising, then, when the workers voted 202 to 60 last December against having the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Union try to negotiate a contract for them.
It was yet another setback for organized labor. Workers across the country have been steadily spurning unions over the last decade, and the tough, sophisticated tactics adopted by employers like Farris, now as a matter of routine, are a big reason. 
 The hired guns called upon by companies to help fight these battles is another. Well-versed in the complexities of labor laws and the art of persuasion, these armies of consultants, mostly law firms, are honing strategies to deter unions. The strategies range from plans to prevent workers from becoming disgruntled to using supervisors to dissuade workers from organizing.
Labor officials say they encounter these consultants at every pass and admit that their advice can be crucial. "We'll win 80 percent of the time in a moderate campaign," said Bob Callahan, an organizer with the Health Care and Social Service Union in Columbus, Ohio. "They win most of the aggressive campaigns."
One reason for employers' heightened interest in keeping unions out: As unions have weakened, companies are concerned with staying competitive with increasingly unionless rivals. That has also tempted companies to eliminate existing unions by replacing striking workers, a tactic that has led to high-visibility fights at the Daily News in New York, Eastern Airlines and Greyhound bus lines.
The upshot is that today only 16.4 percent of American workers belong to unions, less than half as many as at the end of World War II, when unions peaked. France is now the only industrialized nation less unionized than the United States, said Charles R. Perry, a professor of management and industrial relations at the Wharton School of Business in Philadelphia. "This is not a matter of philosophy," he said. "Businesses are driven and are trying to survive."
Labor's strength could continue to wane. These vigorous campaigns have increased unions' cost of soliciting prospective members to $300 to $400 each, far more than they once paid. The increased cost has forced them to concentrate organizing efforts on small shops with limited resources and steer away from units with more than a few hundred people, said Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the AFL-CIO.
Besides the money, unions say employers have better access to workers through supervisors. Unions also object to companies' increasing reliance on threats of closure, which they claim violate laws giving workers the right to organize.
"It's incredibly hard to vote for a union when employers threaten to close down," said Duane Stillwell, the director of organizing for the Southwest Region of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Union.
In the Farris campaign, he said, "Folks weren't voting on the union. They were voting to keep their jobs. I've never seen consultants say plants will be closed so bluntly."
With relatively low pay and poor benefits, Farris had seemed a ripe target for a union, Mr. Stillwell said. About 70 percent of the workers had signed the cards required to hold a National Labor Relations Board election to form a union.
But he said the company played so rough that the support dwindled. He said 35 workers, including key union supporters, were laid off, without any decline in work. And the company, he said, played a radio report in the factory saying that the owner, Farris Burroughs, would close the plant if employees formed a union.
Dan Kennett, a lawyer with Eichenbaum, Scott, Miller, Liles & Heister of Little Rock, Ark., which advised Farris in the campaign, said, "It is my practice not to comment on an on-going case. But of course we deny we made any threat to close the plant."
The union has filed a formal objection with the N.L.R.B. to avoid what it sees as a dangerous precedent of allowing closure threats. It is also asking the board to order Farris to recognize the union without a new election. Still, unions say, even if an employer is found to have violated the law, penalties are often so slight and remedies so long in coming that they do little to deter employers.
In these fights, management often counters that the unions are blaming employers and labor laws for their own failure to keep up with the changing American industrial landscape. "Unions claim that companies break the law," said Martin F. Payson of Jackson, Lewis, Schnitzler & Krupman of New York, one of the biggest labor relations firms. "That's not true. We have a right to show drivers being shot at; trucks being firebombed. Unions view the discussion of facts as a climate of fear."
Labor lawyers are reluctant to discuss the strategies they use to keep unions from forming, but some flaunt impressive records. Ogletree, Deakins, Nash, Smoak & Stewart in Greenville, S.C., frequently cited by the AFL-CIO as a top union buster, says it has been defeated only five times in 108 N.L.R.B. elections on new union formation in the last five years. Jimmy Stewart, a partner, says the firm now has 87 lawyers in six offices, up from 16 lawyers in two offices when it opened it 1977.
Mr. Stewart says much of the firm's work is preventive. It advises hundreds of clients on how to avoid becoming union targets. Keeping employees content, he said, is key. "Negotiation and campaigning is the tip of the iceberg," he said. "We try to establish a positive morale. We assist in policy development, in such things as employee involvement programs, peer grievance reviews. We've got clients who have employees interview and hire people. Other clients have employees participate in the selection of supervisors."
In one of its most noteworthy cases, the firm helped turn away the United Auto Workers at the Nissan plant in Smyrna, Tenn., in July 1989. Nissan uses Ogletree, Deakins to review its campaign, which Gail Neuman, Nissan's general counsel and vice president of human resources, said is based on treating workers fairly. "We involve them in decisions that affect their lives, and we believe that allowed the employees to believe the union could do nothing for them," said Ms. Neuman. She noted that Nissan uses 120 video monitors in the plant to communicate with workers.
The fringe benefits of this approach are substantial, says Mr. Payson of Jackson, Lewis. "Turnover can go down, productivity up, accidents down, errors down."
But once workers call in union organizers, the consultants often set up other programs for employers, through which they tap the help of supervisors to keep unions out.
In a bitter fight in late 1989, the Montgomery County Health Department in Dayton, Ohio, defeated an organizing drive by the Health Care Union, part of the Service Employees International Union. It was a stinging defeat, since one bright spot in labor's retreat has been public employment. Public employers cannot threaten to close and are vulnerable to pressure from voting blocks.
The union filed a complaint that the agency, assisted by Employee Relations Consultants Inc. of Dayton, misused its 70 supervisors to campaign employees for a no vote. Ohio law mandates that both sides have equal access to employees, a weapon union organizers do not have in the private sector, which is under the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Act.
 Consultants commonly try to scare supervisors, said Mr. Callahan of the Health Care and Social Service Union. "They tell them that unions will destroy the company; they say employees will be able to defy them," he said. "They hone each supervisor into a maniacal anti-union campaigner. They emphasize a loss of controlin the workplace. They talk about a family relationship."
The agency says it was simply trying to counter the union and felt that any problems could be resolved without one, said Ken Dahms, the agency's supervisor for legal services. He added that neither the county health board nor top agency officials ever officially urged rejecting the union.
The Ohio Labor Relations Board ruled that the union could conduct a new election, a decision appealed by the employer. The union responded by renewing its unsuccessful attempt for an order forcing the employer to recognize it without an election.
If there is a new election, the union says, time favors the employer. The organizing drive began in July 1989, and an election was not held until December of that year. The issue is still unresolved. Even with restrictions on the county, the outcome of the election is unpredictable.
 
 
 
NEW TACKS BY UNIONS, TOO
 After years of setbacks, organized labor is searching for a way to reverse its decline. The AFL-CIO has spent millions of dollars on its Union Yes television advertising campaign. Rather than wait for workers to call, it has hunted targets for organizing unions in several areas, including Orlando, Fla., Fort Smith, Ark., and Orange County in California.
Several unions, mostly in the fast-growing service industries, have greatly stepped up organizing. Their success rate in National Labor Relations Board elections has risen to 49 percent, from a low of 45 percent in the mid-1980's. The renewal is not lost on management. Said Martin F. Payson of Jackson, Lewis, Schnizler & Krupman of New York, a big labor relations firm, "Starting in 1988, unions are on the march."
The Service Employees International Union's three-year effort to organize 6,000 janitors in Washington, called Justice for Janitors, barely resembles a traditional campaign.
Organizing janitors is difficult, because high turnover makes it tough to get a fix on the work force, and because the real bosses are building owners who contract the cleaning services that hire janitors, said Steve Lerner, who directs the union's effort to organize the services.
"It's a question of what you do with a striker's time," said Lerner. Rather than pressure the cleaning services, the union has held demonstrations at office buildings and tried to meet with their tenants and investors. It has also carried its demonstrations to the building owners' homes.
In the political arena, it has tried to link the organizing drive to issues like homelessness and is pushing for increases in property taxes. "We appeal to the conscience of the tenants," Mr. Lerner said. "The issue isn't whether the building gets cleaned but what kind of city are we going to have."
Through these means, the union has won areawide contracts for janitors in many big cities, but it has had limited success in Washington, where only 500 janitors in the private sector are under contract, Mr. Lerner said.
Margaret O. Jeffers, executive director of the Apartment and Office Building Association, dismissed the union's approach as harassment and said its members have no business becoming involved. Some owners have tried to ban anyone connected with the union from their buildings. The union won a preliminary ruling against the association for its role in the ban, which is being challenged in the District of Columbia courts.
One of the union's more unusual tactics is personal. "We'll try to embarrass an individual building owner," Mr. Lerner said. "We try to point out the contradiction in the public persona and what happens to the people who clean their buildings."
For example, the union compared janitors' pay at buildings owned by real estate developer Mortimer Zuckerman with editorials in U.S. News and World Report, which he owns, calling for a raise in the minimum wage. In 1988 the union carried its message about Mr. Zuckerman to the Artists vs. Writers softball game in the Hamptons on Long Island.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Thai Stocks: Unharmed by a Coup

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The stock market in Thailand is rumbling along, barely jolted by the military coup a week ago that deposed the first directly elected Prime Minister since 1976. Many analysts also seem unfazed by the bloodless takeover and still see Thailand as one of the most attractive markets in Asia, even though it has already rallied 25.5 percent this year.
Thailand continues to draw investors, even after the coup, because of its large potential for economic growth. In addition, it offers good values in light of the sharp fall in the stock exchange after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last August. The quick rise in oil prices to more than $40 a barrel sent the Thai market tumbling 52.4 percent, a reflection of the country's deep dependence on imported oil. The subsequent fall in oil prices, and the quick prosecution of the war, sparked the rally this year, putting the emphasis for further gains on fundamentals. 
 The coup deposed the Government of Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan and installed a temporary Government headed by the supreme military commander, Gen. Sunthorn Kongsompong. The leaders of the coup cited rampant corruption as a reason for the takeover. But the military was also very worried about the meddling of the civilian Government in its affairs.
A temporary Prime Minister is supposed to be named soon, and a new Constitution is supposed to be written making elections possible by the end of the year.
But the coup leaders seem to be having trouble finding someone to serve as the interim Prime Minister, and its difficulties could portend a period of intense volatility for the stock market.
There have been ups and downs already. The market fell 7.3 percent on Monday, the first trading day after the Saturday coup. But it stabilized quickly, partly because Thailand is a country used to coups and military intervention; there have been 17 coup attempts since the end of the nation's absolute monarchy in 1932.
As the shock of the latest coup wore off a bit on Tuesday and the temporary Government sought to ease concerns of local and foreign investors, the market rose 5.7 percent. It fell a bit on Wednesday, took a holiday breather on Thursday and then rallied 2.8 percent Friday. The market's main index ended the week at 790.46, just below the pre-coup level of 791.60.
The two closed-end Thailand country funds traded on the New York Stock Exchange -- the Thai Fund and the Thai Capital Fund -- mirrored the seesaw pattern. The funds both fell on Monday and rebounded by Friday. At week's end, the Thai Fund was up 12.5 cents, to $20.25, while Thai Capital was off just 25 cents, to $10.25.
For many Americans, these funds provide an easier and cheaper way to get into the Thai market than buying stocks directly. Although foreigners are allowed to buy Thai stocks, they have to purchase special shares that often cost more than the same local shares. By contrast, the two funds, which invest in many of the same stocks, can buy the local shares themselves. Reflecting the strong interest in the Thai market, the Thai Fund is priced at a 20 percent premium to its net asset value, while Thai Capital has a 5 percent premium.
John Janesch of Crosby Securities in New York is attracted by the price-to-earnings ratios in Thailand, among the lowest in Asia. The coup does not worry him. "These guys will work to make it look positive," he said.
Barton Biggs of Morgan Stanley & Company, which is the portfolio manager of the Thai Fund, said that Thailand is probably a little better off with a military Government as it moves ahead to develop its economy.
"The coup is bullish," Mr. Biggs said. "A developing country that is bootstrapping itself has a lot of tough decisions to make, and the democratic process may not be the best way to do it."
Mr. Biggs also feels that the sharp fall in stock prices after the invasion of Kuwait has given the market "the cold bath it needed." The drop in tourism in the country is also helping cool the economy, although inflation is still expected to rise this year.
A warning word, however, comes from Ron Napier, a strategist at Salomon Brothers in London. Even before the coup, he had put Thailand on his neutral list. He is troubled by the country's burgeoning trade deficit, which is now close to 12 percent of total economic output. He is also concerned about the fast pace of growth in the economy, although it is slowing.
And he is worried that the military might not hold to the policies that could cool the economy and the deficit, like the rise in interest rates of 250 basis points at the end of November. The military Government may have given some inkling of this bent at the end of the week when it announced a drop in gasoline prices, a cut in the top tax rate and an increase in tax deductions for a majority of the country's workers.
"After the runup this year, you probably should be taking profits," Mr. Napier said. But with a mind to the longer term, he added: "We are not saying that the market will fall apart. We are just saying it will not go up very much."

HEADLINE: The Big Spoils From a Bargain War

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Could paying for the Persian Gulf war prove as easy a ride for Americans as fighting it? Economists take a perverse pride in supplying the rain for every parade. But even the most cautious are showing signs of being swept up in the euphoria of victory.
The war has been fought on the cheap, economists argue, and largely at the expense of Washington's allies. "The costs to America aren't zero," said Charles Schulze of the Brookings Institution, "but they aren't large." And while the spike in oil prices that followed the imposition of sanctions against Iraq apparently tipped the American economy into recession last fall, there is reason to believe that the quick defeat of the Iraqi Army will help tip it out. 
 The long-term economic consequences are harder to reckon because they turn on who rules the Middle East, and what they have in mind for oil consumers. Here, too, though, optimism seems to be bursting out all over.
Increased demand for capital for the reconstruction of Kuwait may raise interest rates, trimming investment in the rest of the world. And the burden of playing cop to the New World Order could conceivably slow the planned decline in American military outlays, leaving less to spend on everything from preschool education to potholes. But in the view of many analysts, these potential drags on growth will be more than offset by victory's salutary effect on energy prices.
"The countries with capacity will have a tremendous need to pump oil," notes Robert Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office. As a consequence, energy prices are likely to be depressed for years to come, boosting the growth prospects of the oil-importing economies.
Equally important, Saudi Arabia will be under pressure to work harder to stabilize oil prices, reducing the prospect of shocks to the industrialized economies. "If the gulf states acknowledge their obligation," concludes Benjamin Friedman, a Harvard economist, "we are talking about a big impact."
Ordinarily, a large part of the price of war must be figured in terms of weapons expended. But as Mr. Reischauer points out, this is no ordinary war. For one thing it comes on the heels of the Soviet collapse, leaving NATO equipped to fight Communist hordes who are now too busy scrounging for food to think about breaching the Fulda Gap.
According to the Defense Budget Project, a Washington-based research group, the American arsenal still contains some 5,000 Patriot missiles. Congress might think twice before replacing the few hundred launched against Saddam Hussein's Scuds. It might also wonder about the need to buy more TOW anti-tank missiles, which numbered 267,000 on the eve of the gulf war. At the very most, coalition forces expended a few thousand of them on the race to the Euphrates, leaving enough to destroy every tank left in the world and then some.
Of course, the war has not been fought entirely out of inventory: a half-million soldiers and their equipment require lots of care and feeding. But by the Bush Administration's own accounting, cash and in-kind contributions from the allies will cover these costs. Most likely, the Pentagon will be left with a profit.
 
The Bottom Line
 Had Saddam Hussein called it quits the day before the ground invasion, the Administration estimates that the bill for the war would have come to $45 billion. If the invasion had proved to be an equipment-consuming slugfest lasting through March, the total would have been $60 billion. And in light of the easy victory, it's likely that the final official reckoning will be a lot closer to $45 billion than to $60 billion.
On the other side of the ledger, the allies are pledged to deliver $53.9 billion to Washington. Although just $14.9 billion of that total has been received thus far, only the Japanese have shown signs of balking -- and only on a portion of their $9 billion pledge.
The small surplus implied by these figures may, on closer inspection, prove quite substantial. Mr. Reischauer diplomatically suggested in his testimony to the House Budget Committee last Wednesday that some Administration estimates of the cost of the war may be "overstated." Among other things, he cited two oil-related items:
* The Pentagon included higher fuel bills for American forces operating outside the Persian Gulf as a cost of the war. Possible padding: $2.8 billion.
* The Administration also assumed that oil prices would average far more for the rest of the year than they are today. If it is assumed instead that today's price of about $19 a barrel will hold for the rest of 1991, the bill for war-related fuel would be halved.
There are numerous other figures that have raised eyebrows. Ships and planes by the hundreds will be needed to bring home the soldiers and their equipment. One must wonder, though, whether the Pentagon bothered to check the Yellow Pages for cheaper charters: it is budgeting $5.2 billion -- roughly $10,000 per person.
Then there is the pesky issue of accounting for the loss of weapons that may be redundant, now that the Warsaw Pact has given up the ghost.
Mr. Schulze worries that the Pentagon is lumping unrelated costs into the Desert Storm estimates as a subterfuge for raising total military spending -- a worry that seems credible since the Administration is asking Congress to replace more Patriots, Tomahawks and TOW's than it fired at Iraqi targets.
But experts with more sympathy for the Administration see another motive for fudging war costs: nobody wants to give the allies an excuse to renege on the $39 billion still owed. If, as Mr. Schulze suggests, the actual cost of mauling the Iraqi Army runs to less than $30 billion, Uncle Sam will end up pocketing a nice piece of change.
 
Big Losses in Output
 This war ledger does not, however, represent the last word on the economic cost of squashing Saddam Hussein. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, thinks a combination of war jitters and higher oil prices triggered the recession last fall. Even if it ends soon, tens of billions of dollars in output will have been lost.
This explanation for the recession must be taken with a dash of skepticism. Economists ranging from Harvard's Mr. Friedman (a Keynesian) to Carnegie-Mellon's Alan Meltzer (a monetarist) think the Fed's failure to ease credit sufficiently last year had a lot to do with the onset of the recession. Still, the circumstantial evidence for the war-shock theory is impressive.
Mr. Reischauer estimates that oil prices averaged about $12 a barrel above normal from late August through mid-December. The $12 hike acted like an excise tax, draining away purchasing power at an annualized rate of $20 billion. And in September consumer confidence, as measured by the Conference Board's index, took the largest one-month dive ever recorded.
Philip Verleger, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, holds the Bush Administration responsible for the oil price spike. Once the President decided to send troops to the Persian Gulf, a jump in prices may have been inevitable. Mr. Verleger says, however, that the price spike could have been blunted with sales from the Government's 600 million barrel oil reserve. "If we had used the strategic reserve in August," he insists, "we would have cut the economic dip in half."
 
Adding to the Woes
 One way or another, though, the war did add to the nation's economic woes. At the very least, says John Taylor of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, "it was icing on the cake."
If the war did indeed nudge the economy into the recession, will its quick and decisive conclusion pull the economy out? Oil prices returned to pre-conflict levels with the start of the air campaign in January, but shoppers have been slow to return to the malls. Auto sales are still depressed; airlines and related travel industries are still sputtering on one engine. Nonetheless, some experts believe the auguries for recovery are positive:
* Consumer confidence rose a tad in February, a number of surveys showed, and might be expected to rise more on news of the smashing success of the ground war.
* Military orders already in the pipeline are spurring demand. These purchases can be expected to have more than the usual impact on economic output because they are being financed with foreign cash rather than domestic borrowing. Demand created by deficit spending, notes Mr. Reischauer, would have raised interest rates a bit, partly offsetting the stimulative effect of Government spending.
* The economy will soon reap the benefits of another dive in oil prices, Mr. Verleger predicts. Inventories of oil are exceptionally high for a season in which demand is certain to ebb. And the pressure exerted by this oil overhang could be reinforced by expectations of a glut. Nobody, after all, wants to be caught with excess supplies when Kuwait and Iraq struggle back to the export market.
With luck, the war will help as much coming out of the recession as it hurt going in. But what about the consequences of the gulf war thereafter?
One thoroughly unpleasing prospect is higher interest rates, as Kuwait goes on a buying spree to rebuild from the sand up. While no one really knows how much it will cost to repair the war damage, numbers as high as $100 billion have been tossed around. Much of the money will no doubt come from Kuwait's hoard of cash. But whether the money is borrowed or drawn from bank accounts, it represents a drain on world savings and will thus increase the cost of capital for everyone from I.B.M. to the U.S. Treasury to Joe Homebuyer.
 
Bad Timing
 The timing could hardly have been worse. Mr. Friedman of Harvard notes that real interest rates -- interest less expected inflation -- are already high by historical standards. And even without help from the Kuwaitis, rates might have gone higher.
The Japanese, who have supplied much of the world's savings over the last decade, are finally beginning to take our advice and spend more on themselves. The Germans, who supplied most of the rest, will need every pfennig they can muster to bring East Germany up to Western living standards.
But Kuwait's demand for capital is not entirely bad news for the home team: the foreign companies who supply the goodies will mostly be American. Kuwait has traditionally looked to America for everything from drill bits to fried chicken franchises. And now that the U.S. Marines have retaken Kuwait City, Kuwaiti officials are making no secret of their wish to look even harder.
Caterpillar, Raytheon, Motorola, American Telephone and Telegraph, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler have already bagged contracts. The rest of the Fortune 500 are no doubt in line.
Another nagging worry is the cost of defense. Before the gulf war, the Bush Administration proposed to reduce military expenditures by 20 percent over five years, winding down the arms surge of the Reagan era. Might the sweet taste of success in the gulf lead the President to change his mind?
That prospect worries Mr. Friedman, who fears that military spending will crowd out both public and private investment. And President Bush's request last week for money to replace more missiles than he lost in the gulf is hardly reassuring. But Mr. Reischauer argues that the political constraints on military outlays are still likely to bind.
Under last year's budget agreement, Washington is committed to a cap on military spending through 1993. Thereafter, Congress and the President could increase outlays -- but only at the expense of non-military programs. And Mr. Reischauer scoffs at the idea that anything less than a resurrection of the Soviet threat could break a deal that was so painfully wrought. "What happens in the U.S.S.R.," he concludes, "is going to determine the pace of defense spending."
In any case, the gulf war's impact on interest rates or military outlays pales beside the war's likely impact on oil prices. And here the tea leaves are coming up roses.
The key conflict within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is between hawks (like Libya and Iran), who are desperate for every oil dollar they can earn, and doves (like Saudi Arabia), who want to make sure there is a market for their oil 20 years down the road. Breaking Saddam Hussein's power to intimidate the gulf producers, argues Daniel Yergin, author of "The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money and Power," should put the doves firmly in control. "The people who will be dominating oil prices," he says, "will want to be long-term secure suppliers."
 
Falling Lower?
 Before his invasion of Kuwait, Saddam Hussein was pressing for $25-a-barrel oil -- the price he needed to pay the interest on loans from the West without cutting back on weapons purchases or imports of consumer goods. Now, oil prices are already under $20, and in Mr. Verleger's view could soon fall by another $4 to $5.
What is more, Mr. Verleger believes the price is likely to remain below $20 for many years. Iraq and Kuwait will surely pump all the oil they can for the foreseeable future. And Saudi Arabia, which ran its cash reserves down to nothing during the war, will be in no position to offset the depressing effect on prices by turning down its oil taps.
Lower oil prices mean fewer dollars going abroad, raising Americans' domestic purchasing power. It also means less investment in domestic energy, Mr. Friedman notes, freeing capital for more productive uses (while also making the United States more dependent on foreign energy sources).
Over a decade, the difference between $15 oil and $25 oil is one to 1.5 percentage points in economic growth, Mr. Verleger reckons. And from such little acorns do mighty oaks grow: a gain of one percentage point in G.N.P. translates as $60 billion a year, year after year after year.
Good news for oil importers, of course, is bad news for oil exporters -- among them our friends, Mexico and Venezuela. And low oil prices could put a spanner in Mexico's good work to reform its inward-looking, interest group-ridden economy.
But Mr. Verleger is not impressed. "Mexico," he says, "could offset the effect of lower prices by opening the market to technically savvy foreign producers." And Venezuela, he argues, could seize the opportunity to diversify its oil-dependent economy.
Nobody, it seems -- not even the dismal scientists -- is ready to spoil the victory celebration.
 
 
 
PROBLEMS THAT WON'T DISAPPEAR
 Victory in the gulf should provide a welcome boost to the American economy in the form of lower oil prices and, perhaps, a surge in consumer spending. But few analysts believe that the recession will succumb as rapidly to Washington's will as the Republican Guard. Consider the problems dogging economic policy makers:
The credit crunch. Battered by losses on commercial loans and under the gun to increase their capital reserves, big "money center" banks are reluctant to make any but the safest loans to business. Insurance companies, traditionally a major source of capital for corporations and developers, are also pulling in their horns.
The money markets aren't dead; resourceful borrowers are turning to smaller banks or raising money through sales of short-term securities. But the banks' problems have surely complicated the Federal Reserve's cautious effort to ease credit in the last few months.
The S.& L. overhang. The fact that hundreds of savings and loans are dead or dying has no direct effect on the availability of credit. But these institutions have dumped tens of billions of dollars worth of real estate on Uncle Sam's doorstep -- real estate that sooner or later must be sold. And this overhang is depressing property values, impoverishing the balance sheets of solvent mortgage lenders and hurting the construction industry.
The looming capital shortage. Through most of the 1980's, Americans spent beyond their collective means, looking to Germany and Japan to make up the difference. Now our thrifty allies have decided they have better ways of investing their money at home. The result: higher interest rates on securities denominated in yen and marks.
The Federal Reserve can still keep a lid on American interest rates -- but only at the risk of further depressing the exchange value of the dollar. And some policy makers are reluctant to see the dollar fall because it would raise the cost of imports and kick up inflation.
The demise of fiscal policy. The budget deal struck last summer offers some hope that the deficit gap will be closed by 1995. But one price of the deal was the effective abandonment of spending increases and tax cuts as a means of stimulating the economy.
Under the agreement, Washington has the discretion to declare an economic emergency and spend beyond the deficit reduction targets. But both the White House and Congress are deeply reluctant to revisit the scene of the budget crime. It would probably take a long and much deeper recession to change many minds.
