SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1489 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/February 24-March 1

 BODY:

AFTER THE WAR
 
In 1930, when pearl-diving was the largest industry in Kuwait, Japan's development of cultured pearls wrecked Kuwait's economy. Now one of the world's wealthiest nations, Kuwait has seen its livelihood ruined again, its power and desalting plants destroyed, its oil wells feeding fires that blacken the skies. But few such devastated nations have ever had such gleaming prospects. With an estimated $100 billion in investments abroad, and most of its oil still securely in the ground, Kuwait has the cash and the credit for rebuilding. The Kuwaitis say the allies who fought the hardest will benefit the most; American companies have won about 70 percent of the 200 contracts signed so far. Kuwait has asked the Bechtel Group to manage the reconstruction of its oil industry, potentially a $10 billion task. Caterpillar Inc. is selling diesel engines to provide emergency power; Motorola Inc., portable telephones, and the Raytheon Company, air traffic control gear. Kuwait plans to not only rebuild but also modernize, promoting private enterprise and taking the nation another step beyond reliance on diving for pearls or drilling for oil. Kuwait would just as soon have an economy efficient enough to manage without the hundreds of thousands of Palestinian and Jordanian guest workers, whose political leanings are suspect.
 
The War Payment Plan
 
Even as American companies gain contracts, the United States is likely to continue paying some costs of its Persian Gulf mission. With rebuilding expenses of $50 billion to $100 billion -- in the same range as the post-World War II Marshall Plan -- Kuwaiti borrowing could squeeze credit around the world. Many analysts suggest that payments from allies will more than cover American military expense. But Hermann F. Eilts, a former Ambassador to Egypt and Saudi Arabia who now directs the Boston University Center for International Relations, said that some nations might have second thoughts. Germany is burdened by reunification costs, he noted, and Japanese legislators are likely to renege on the Government's promises to the United States. "When the shooting is over, they find reasons to limit their payments," he said. "That means you and I are going to pay."
 
Return of the Oil Jitters
 
The war ended, but the oil jitters resumed. A barrel of crude, down sharply since the allied assault began Jan. 17, eased back up by $1.47 a barrel to $19.38 last week. Some oil traders voiced fears that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would soon agree to cut back production. And Kuwait is unlikely to resume shipping oil for several months. Iraq, who knows when? But several energy analysts said that the world has already shown it can survive a winter without Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil; the longer run worries them much more. Christopher Flavin, an energy specialist at the Worldwatch Institute, said that with worldwide consumption growing and Soviet production falling, the real squeeze could come in the mid-1990's.
 
G.N.P. Hints at Rebound
 
A revised estimate of the nation's output for the fourth quarter last year provided some evidence that the economy is poised for a rebound in the coming months. The Commerce Department said the the gross national product fell at an annual rate of 2 percent, compared to an initial estimate of 2.1 percent. But inventories were revised down, meaning that manufacturers would have to increase production to meet any stronger demand after the the victory in the Persian Gulf.
 
Economists Turn Upbeat
 
Economists had a mind last week to emphasize the favorable aspects of statistics that still tell of a recession. Consumer confidence remained at depressing levels last month, according to the Conference Board's survey, but analysts noted that it rose for the first time since September. Purchasing managers, responding to another survey, also remained downcast, but again, not as dismal as the month before. The government's index of leading indicators fell four-tenths of 1 percent for January, the sixth straight decline, but economists tended to say that the end of the war, an expanding money supply and a rising stock market in February virtually guarantee that the next report will be more favorable. "You are forming a bottom," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at First Boston. "There is no question about that." She said that growth is likely to resume in mid-year.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Revlon on the Block?
 
Strip away the makeup, the multibillion-dollar estimates of his worth, and underneath, Ronald O. Perelman is a man facing a possible cash squeeze. Revlon Inc., his giant cosmetics company, is holding sales talks with Procter & Gamble, L'Oreal and Unilever, at prices estimated in the billions. Analysts say that Revlon cannot continue to pay off its heavy debts without selling assets.
 
Selling The Daily News
 
The survival of the Tribune Company's Daily News now depends on finding a buyer. Talks to settle a strike collapsed last week and The News is trying to negotiate a sale to Robert Maxwell, the British publisher.
 
The Wallenbergs Reach Out
 
The Wallenbergs of Sweden offered $2.27 billion last week for the portion of Saab-Scania A.B. that they do not already own. The family, which already controls Swedish companies with a market value of between $31 billion and $36 billion, is apparently preparing for Sweden's entry into the European Community and the easing of restrictions on foreign investment.
 
Choosing an Indy Pace Car
 
The Chrysler Corporation's manner of demonstrating patriotic fervor entails as many swerves and scrapes as a 60-mile-an-hour drive though rush-hour traffic. On Monday, Chrysler scrapped plans for its Japanese two-seater, the Dodge Stealth, to be the pace car in the Indianapolis 500. To take its place, the company is rushing out a prototype of the sinuous Dodge Viper. "The Viper is a symbol of the can-do attitude and the technical innovation of the American auto industry," a Chrysler executive proclaimed. It also demonstrates the prowess of the Italian auto industry, where Lamborghini, a Chrysler subsidiary, aided in the Viper's development. Or maybe it really is an apt American symbol. One prototype developed a cracked engine block, and Chrysler only trusts the pace car to manage a single ceremonial lap. If another car is needed during the race, Chrysler will send in the Japanese Stealth.
 
A Looser Accounting Rein?
 
The four agencies that oversee the nation's banks and savings and loans recommended looser accounting standards on Friday to ease a credit crunch. Critics questioned whether the Government should weaken the rules when so many banks are in trouble.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY


Banks and Insurance
 
It's not exactly a bailout for banks. Maybe more of a siphoning operation, keeping the banking system afloat with the help of as much as $25 billion in Federal loans. Last Thursday, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, proposed a $64.4 billion, five-year plan to keep the insurance deposit fund solvent. Annual bank insurance premiums, now 19.5 cents per $100, would increase by at least 3.5 cents, or more depending on how much the fund borrows. Some features of his plan require Congressional approval, while others need only the backing of the F.D.I.C. The insurance fund, at $8.4 billion, stands at its lowest ratio to deposits since it was created during the Depression.
 
Verdict on the Keating Five
 
The Senate Ethics Committee said their doings reflected "poor judgement" at the least, but most of the Keating Five are claiming that they have been cleared. In a statement last Wednesday, the committee accused Senator Alan Cranston of misconduct in taking contributions from Charles H. Keating Jr., an executive of a failing savings and loan. Actions by Senators Dennis DeConcini and Donald W. Riegle Jr. appeared improper, the committee said, and Senators John Glenn and John McCain had failings of judgement. "I am, of course, relieved that I have been exonerated," said Senator McCain. It remains to be seen whether voters, who have been outraged over the costs of rescuing Mr. Keating's institution and hundreds of others, are equally relieved.
 
A Lag in the Mag Trade
 
There's Crochet Celebrations and Girls of Outlaw Biker. Kansas City Live! and Kamikaze! and Missouri Wine Country Journal. A choice of Metal Party, Metal Explosion, Metal Revolution, Future Metal or Heavy Metal Mania Pinups. Space Monsters and Monster Truck Spectacular, too. All among 536 entries in Samir Husni's Guide to New Magazines for 1990. Dr. Husni recorded a decline in new titles last year, from 599 in 1989, for the first time since he started the guide six years ago. Sex again accounts for the most new titles, with 62, followed by life style and service, then sports.

HEADLINE: The Fine Art of Coping With Taxes

BYLINE: By TOM SAWYER; Tom Sawyer is a freelance writer based in Brooklyn who covers tax issues.

 BODY:
Gregory Russell, a Manhattan artist who works in a youth program through the day so he can paint through the night, is attacking the conflict between finding time to paint and earning enough to pay the rent, by taking a close look at his taxes.
"If I save $500 in taxes, that's $500 I can keep," he said. 
 After paying his income taxes last year, he asked himself: "How can I maximize what I'm making and keep what I am bringing in? How can I work with these taxes?"
He now keeps careful records of the expenses involved in producing his art so he can take the deductions allowed a self-employed person, instead of filing the short form, as he always had.
Mr. Russell, who is unmarried and 35 years old, became deeply frustrated last year about how much he had needlessly paid in taxes. Working at a daytime job to make ends meet often left him drained by the time he could approach his canvas.
"What I was doing, by not doing, was making it difficult for me to create images," he said. "I'm looking to be more independent and self-sufficient in terms of my art, so I'll have to invest less of my time in supplementing my income with a job."
Mr. Russell said he became angry last year when he was filing his taxes and realized that for years he had been throwing deductions away. He also felt the sting of turning 35 without having made painting his career, despite his dedication to it, and despite a proven market for his work in sales, honors and gallery shows.
Mr. Russell said he would probably be much closer to his dream of supporting himself with his art if he had treated his painting as a business for tax purposes and deducting expenses.
"If I think of all the money I've given away, it makes me angry," he said. "Rather than being closer to financial security, I'm further away. I did myself a disservice by not seeking information in regard to taxes."
He said his tax filing this year is an important first step. In addition to reporting his "meager" salary from a his 35-hour-a-week job as a program director in a youth organization in Brooklyn, he will report his art sales as self-employment income on Schedule C. He used to report it as "other income" on his 1040 form. That change will allow him to deduct thousands of dollars in expenses from his gross receipts before determining how much tax he has to pay.
"I ask for a receipt for everything, and I make a note on the back of it," he said. "If I rent a car to go to Washington to take paintings, I keep receipts. I'm going to the Middle West to be a visiting artist in the latter part of February. I'll get receipts."
He hopes to buy a half-interest in a loft by the end of the year instead of renting an apartment and working in a makeshift studio in his dining room. As a buyer, he could deduct his mortgage interest and could build equity.
"I would like to invest with a friend in buying a living- and working-space," he said. "It's ridiculous to pay close to $1,000 a month, when, for a small amount more, you can own and have an investment."
Despite his lack of any appreciable savings, he thinks he can make his share of the downpayment through painting sales this year, and can qualify for a loan on the basis of his job income, his stock of finished paintings, his record of sales and a body of work he is creating. He is now working on large triptychs about AIDS.
"If I were to tell anything to a young artist just starting out and setting up, it would be to put his taxes in order," he said. "It's been a painful learning experience."
 
 
 
Midlife, Middle Bracket
Defending Income Against the Bite
 Ron and Anne Sinico, both 40-year-old teachers, would seem to be the sort of middle-income people Congress had in mind when it overhauled the tax laws with the goal of making them simpler and fairer. But Mr. Sinico says bluntly, "Tax reform didn't do me any favors whatsoever."
Indeed, taxes take a bigger bite from the couple's income now than they did before the Tax Reform Act of 1986, he said, adding that the percentage of their income that actually goes to pay taxes has risen about five points. He blames lost deductions and higher rates -- the Sinicos are now in the 28 percent bracket.
Mr. Sinico supplements his salary from a small private school near Albany, by serving as zoning officer for West Sand Lake, N.Y., a town of 8,000 where he lives, and by working part-time as a tax preparer.
He is also trying to use his tax knowledge to reduce his family's tax burden. Much of his tax strategy centers on renovating the family home, a lakeside summer cottage that is almost 100 years old, so they can convert it to a rental property and take deductions for maintaining it and for depreciation.
The couple and their daughters, Katie, 10, and Elizabeth, 7, now live in the house. They expect to complete the project in late summer and to buy another house for themselves. If they do not convert their present home to a rental, they will sell it.
Two-and-a-half years ago, because of the phasing out of deductions for interest on consumer debt, the Sinicos consolidated their debts with a home equity loan, so their interest payments would continue to be fully deductible. The loan also financed the renovation.
"For middle-income people like ourselves, rental property is a way of saving money toward retirement or college costs," Mr. Sinico said. He anticipates depreciating the rental house and deducting operating costs from the income while building equity. He says he will eventually sell, perhaps when his income is lower or when capital gains are treated more favorably, or, alternatively, will borrow against the property.
Even if it is necessary to take out a loan for the girls' college costs, he said, if they "take an equity loan or a second mortgage on the rental property, those expenses can be taken as expenses against the rental income."
 Mr. Sinico is studying for a master's degree, which he hopes will not only lead to a higher income and possibly tenure, but also will make him eligible for an administrative job. He says that as a teacher without a master's degree, his age and experience are starting to work against him. Mrs. Sinico already has her master's degree.
"I've got quite a few years' experience, and I'm quite expensive for the position I have now," he said. "I'm competing against recent college graduates." In 1989 he spent four months at the end of the year without a teaching job and drew unemployment benefits, from which no tax was withheld. With his last quarter income down sharply, it was difficult to find the money to pay the taxes when they came came due.
"I didn't set anything aside," he said. "When you are used to getting a regular teacher's salary, and then start getting $265 a week, it's hard."
 They have been trying to invest $100 a month as a college reserve. The money is in a mutual fund where the dividends are routinely reinvested. But Mr. Sinico is disappointed with the returns and says he may shift the money to Series EE savings bonds. Under tax laws that became effective last year, the interest on Series EE bonds used for college expenses would be tax free in their case.

 
 
In Retirement
Facing Taxes Counterintuitively
 Beginning retirement with a 30-year mortgage on a new home while buying stocks and bonds with the proceeds from the sale of an old one may seem an unlikely strategy for a couple from the historically debt-shy Depression generation. But after studying recent changes in the tax laws, that is what Ellen and Jim Biggs, of Brevard, N.C., have done.
"There are very few tax shelters left," said Mrs. Biggs, 60 years old. "That's why we elected, instead of paying off our house, to have a mortgage, because the interest is a deduction. Mortgage interest and property taxes are about the only deductions left."
Over the years, she became the family bill payer and financial researcher. "I sort of like it," said Mrs. Biggs, who recently began using a personal financial program, Andrew Tobias's Managing Your Money, on her home computer to track income, investments and expenses in greater detail.
Five years ago she was half-owner of a bookstore and gift shop in their long-time home of Hickory, N.C. Her husband, then 59, had a one-man architectural practice. With their three children well-established in life, they began to study their retirement options. One of the first moves was to sell Mrs. Biggs's interest in the bookstore. "We were thinking about moving, and I had to clear the decks a little," she said.
They found a financial adviser at Legg, Mason, Wood, Walker, Inc., the Baltimore-based brokerage firm, who suggested they diversify their assets and move from growth-oriented stocks they had held many years to income-oriented investments.
Mrs. Biggs said they continue to rely on his advice, meeting with him in July and December to review everything, and now they have a regulated income and a comfortable level of contingency resources.
"We are constantly monitoring where we are," she said. "The approach is that we try to look at the tax benefits and get as much taxable income as we can and stay within the 15 percent bracket. We look to see how much we can earn and how much we can offset."
Selling their 70-year-old "barn of a house" in Hickory, as well as an adjacent piece of real estate, was a key move. They took the one-time capital gains tax exemption and invested the proceeds from the sale in a diverse portfolio, which includes high-yield stocks and tax-free bonds.
When they sold their house, they took a mortgage on a new home, a condominium in a retirement village in the southern Blue Ridge Mountains.
"Most of the people of my generation don't want a mortgage," said Mrs. Biggs. "They don't want debt. They want to own their home. Well, this is much better for us, we think."
 To prepare for retirement, Mr. Biggs reduced the level of his architectural practice substantially, but he keeps his professional credentials active and does some work from home. He is careful to avoid earnings that will cut into his Social Security benefits or move them out of the 15-percent tax bracket.
His Social Security check is used to pay the mortgage. The Biggs use credit cards sparingly and pay balances promptly to avoid consumer-interest debt. Their contingency fund includes a five-year annuity and their I.R.A.'s, which they haven't touched. Mrs. Biggs said those assets are for travel, home improvement or expenses in case of serious illness.
Like many people over 60, the Biggs are concerned about possible increases in the cost of living and about future health care expenses, but Mrs. Biggs said they feel fairly well protected. She researched nursing home insurance extensively, and even took out a policy on a 30-day trial basis, but she rejected it for the time being. She said they may look into it again in about 10 years. In the meantime, they consult their financial adviser and keep a sharp focus on their tax picture.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Turn Mideast Money Into U.S. Deposits

BYLINE: By LES DINKIN; Les Dinkin is managing partner of Les Dinkin & Associates, a financial services consulting firm in Westport, Conn.

 BODY:
The joke that has been going around since the war in the gulf began goes like this: Kuwait is a banking system without a country being defended by the United States, a country without a banking system. In large part, this is true. But together Kuwait and Saudi Arabia can help fix our banking and savings and loan mess.
Kuwait has an investment portfolio in excess of $100 billion. Add to this Saudi Arabia, with its own vast investments and cash reserves. In the United States, meanwhile, there is a savings and loan crisis that will cost taxpayers as much as $500 billion and a badly damaged banking system that could possibly drive the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's Bank Insurance Fund into the red. 
 This situation brings to mind a not too immodest proposal. In exchange for cleaning up the current mess in the Middle East, let's have Saudi Arabia and Kuwait help us clean up our mess: our banking and savings and loan institutions.
The way they could do this is straightforward. Our banking and savings and loans institutions suffer from what some economists call a capital and liquidity crunch. So why not ask Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to deposit some of their billions in our banks and savings and loans? Why not ask them to help capitalize the F.D.I.C. or take a minority nonvoting equity positions in selected institutions, as Saudi Arabian Prince al-Waleed bin Talal said last week he would do with Citibank. These funds would be insured and safe and would earn them interest. But they would also provide us with mid- to longer-term stable funding sources.
Big deposits and new equity investment in the United States by these countries would take pressure off the F.D.I.C.'s insurance fund and encourage increased lending. With enough new capital in the system, interest rates might come down since there would be no need for shaky institutions to offer premium rates to win risk-averse depositors.
We don't have to ask Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to deposit all their money in the United States. My back-of-the-envelope calculation says we only need $200 billion to $300 billion to take the pressure off the American taxpayer and the F.D.I.C. Is that too much to ask? I don't think so.
Since President Bush has been passing the hat to get funding support for the war, why not pass some deposit slips as well? Come to think of it, why not pass some slips to the Japanese and Germans?
Given the aggressive promotions banks and savings and loans run to attract deposits, think of all the toasters, appliances and televisions the new depositors would receive.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Giving the Environment Teeth

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Last summer, the International Business Machines Corporation took a giant step backward -- on purpose.
Years earlier, it had decentralized responsibility for environmental matters. Then, on July 1, it appointed Arthur J. Hedge Jr., a corporate officer who had run the real estate and construction departments, to the new job of vice president of environmental health and safety. It gave him a staff of roughly 30 people culled from such disparate departments as real estate, personnel, legal and energy. And it charged the new group, which is based at I.B.M.'s Armonk, N.Y., headquarters, with insuring that corporate environmental policy is carried out. 
 "We needed one high-level group to focus our environmental efforts, and to send a clear signal that management cares about the environment," Mr. Hedge said.
I.B.M. is one of many companies that are upgrading the size, scope and status of their headquarters' environmental staffs. "Companies want people who can find the common thrust between technological, legal and public relations needs," said Bruce Piasecki, associate professor of environmental management at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y.
They also want people who won't be cowed by plant managers who are more concerned with production than pollution. "Environmental people who report to someone above the plant manager are immune to politics," said William Alford, a New York recruiter who specializes in environmental jobs.
There are many reasons this is happening now. Companies still want to push decision-making as far down the line as possible. But they also want corporate-wide pollution control programs. They want environmental monitoring mechanisms that insurance underwriters will buy into. And they want to be sure that in a weak economy, headquarter's hands-off policies are not interpreted by plant managers as a go-ahead to press for profits instead of environmental compliance -- something particularly onerous at a time of nationwide environmental activism.
"The public has upped the ante, so we've upped the environmental function's clout," said Bruce W. Karrh, the Du Pont Company's vice president of safety, health and environmental affairs. Indeed, since 1987, Du Pont has increased the number of environmental jobs at Wilmington, Del., headquarters to 11 from 3, installed a more formal environmental audit process and tightened the criteria for joining the environmental staff.
Environment has a higher profile around the Polaroid Corporation's Cambridge, Mass., headquarters, too. Four years ago, Polaroid added a senior manager in manufacturing to control generation of toxic waste, and another in research, to see that new processes are environmentally sound. A few months ago, it added a senior marketing person to see that Polaroid products and packages do not cause a solid-waste problem.
 "What we are doing is incorporating environmental issues into the management system," said Harry Fatkin, Polaroid's director of health, safety and environmental affairs. Polaroid now is installing a complex auditing system that will check not only that plants are in compliance with environmental policies, but also that their management systems promote environmental and safety concerns.
Auditing certainly is getting special attention at the Ciba-Geigy Corporation's Ardsley, N.Y., headquarters. Two years ago, Ciba-Geigy put all of its environmental auditors into a stand-alone group that reports to the chief executive. "Just like you don't want financial auditors to audit their own bookkeeping, you don't want environmental auditors to judge their own technical decisions," said Joseph T. Sullivan, the senior vice president who oversees the group that helps the plant managers comply with environmental policies.
Apparently, the separation makes a difference. At one plant, the plant managers, the lawyers and the engineers all agreed on a particular solvent's safety. The environmental auditors disagreed -- and the plant people redesigned a process to eliminate the solvent.
"They figured if the internal auditors weren't satisfied, the external auditors probably wouldn't be -- and neither would the C.E.O.," Mr. Sullivan said.

 
 
WHEN THE BOSS GETS INVOLVED
 Sometimes, one word from the chairman can be worth a thousand words from the next level down.
Just ask Bruce W. Karrh, the Du Pont Company's vice president of safety, health and environmental affairs. As a Du Pont officer, Mr. Karrh, who has run the company's environmental operations since 1984, is a honcho in his own right. Even so, plant managers often balked when he advised them to commit resources to environmental projects.
Then, in May 1989, Du Pont's chairman, Edgar S. Woolard Jr., called for "corporate environmentalism" and dubbed himself Du Pont's "chief environmentalist." All of a sudden, plant people were begging Mr. Kharr for environmental advice.
"I used to have to do a real selling job to the line people," Mr. Karrh said. "Then suddenly it wasn't just me trying to get the organization to do things, it was Ed. Now they call all the time."
Ciba-Geigy, too, is putting a visible, top-level imprimatur on environmentalism. In January, it established a "governance committee" of the board of directors, responsible for overseeing any issue that affects the company's reputation. The committee, led by Ciba's chairman, Richard Barth, is looking at environmental issues first.
"We want to insure a common understanding of our expectations throughout the company," said Joseph T. Sullivan, a senior vice president and a committee member.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Indivisibility of Ethics

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. MYERS; There is a sharp division within the nation's business schools about how ethics should be taught. In a Dec. 23 article on the Forum page, Edward J. Conry, a professor in the College of Business Administration, argued that special courses in business law and ethics should be required of all business students. In the following article, Robert J. Myers, president of the Carnegie Council on Ethics and International Affairs, argues there is no separate set of ethics for business.

 BODY:
 In 1981, Peter F. Drucker wrote "What Is 'Business Ethics?' " In that article, he said: "There is only one ethics, one set of rules of morality, one code: that of individual behavior in which the same rules apply to everyone alike." Mr. Drucker attributed this conclusion to a long tradition of Western and Eastern philosophers. That should have laid the question to rest. It did not.
The debate over business ethics seems particularly relevant as one looks over some of the recent literature on the subject. First, there is Research Report No. 900 from the Conference Board on "Corporate Ethics," an international survey and collection of interviews that examine how 200 companies "define ethical issues, respond to ethical dilemmas, develop and communicate codes of ethics, design ethics training programs."
Another Conference Board publication starts out: "Unless ethical considerations are a part of every manager's thought process, both the corporation and individual executives will fail to exercise the level of responsibility which good business represents and the law demands." It is the phrase "both the corporation and individual executives" that highlights the so-far perennial problem for "business ethics," opening as it does a dual standard of ethics.
Executives need to know that they are not alone in an uncharted ethical jungle. Nor do they single-handedly have to invent ethics. Further, they are not required to build a unique ethical system, applicable only to their own business. Yet this is what one senses when looking through the popular "codes of conduct" that hundreds of American companies have felt compelled to establish as modern, concerned corporate citizens.
The claim that there is a separate set of standards for the action of a responsible executive in his or her corporate capacity, as opposed to personal capacity, has been discussed in different ways over the centuries. This notion first surfaces in the concept of a dual standard between one's actions as an individual and in a public or state role. An early example is seen in "The Prince," in which Machiavelli advocated no restraint on the part of the ruler, although cautioning the Prince to conceal this side of his character from the public. In the last century, the Italian statesman Conte Camillo Benso di Cavour, considering his role and those of his colleagues in the unification of Italy, put the matter succinctly: "If we had done for ourselves what we have done for Italy, what scoundrels we would have been."
The pernicious contemporary result of this thinking is the acceptance by the corporate community that the corporate code is inferior to the private code. This unnecessary burden can be happily abandoned by following Mr. Drucker's "one code" idea. Otherwise, criticism of corporations on ethical grounds will continue.
While change is a given in our society, and ethics is not immune from that process, the locus of ethics remains in the individual. No amount of economic or sociological hocus-pocus will alter that. Corporations and other institutions will not be relieved of their clear-eyed responsibility to hew to a single ethical standard. Executives can try to operate behind legal and other fig leaves, but in the end, they are still Adam and Eve standing blushingly before judgment.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Operating Systems for PC's Grow More Confusing

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Reports that the OS/2 operating system is dead are greatly exaggerated, officials of the Microsoft Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation say. Yet there appears to be a great deal of confusion about the future of OS/2 -- and about the future of personal computer operating systems in general.
The confusion stems in part from the decision late last year by Microsoft and I.B.M., which had collaborated to develop the industry-standard DOS operating system, to part company on the developmental responsibilities for operating systems. 
 The two companies have long agreed that the original DOS system they rode to fortune is about ready for pasture. DOS is a decade old, and advances in computer technology and software applications have rendered it too feeble to meet the needs of today's complex business computing systems. OS/2 can run several programs at once (a process called multitasking) and it breaks the 640-kilobyte memory limit of DOS.
 I.B.M. and Microsoft still see OS/2, or something very much like it, as the eventual successor to DOS. But if they are heading toward a similar destination, they have chosen different paths to get there. And they may each come up with a slightly different form of OS/2, one with the "look and feel" of Microsoft's Windows, the other with I.B.M.'s preferred interface called Presentation Manager. "There would be just enough incompatilities to confuse users and cause them to pull their hair out," said John McCarthy, a senior analyst with Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass.
Presentation Manager, like Windows, is a graphical shell that hides the complexities of the operating system behind a control panel of symbols, scroll bars, menus and windows. Although Windows and P.M. are very similar, someone running OS/2 with Presentation Manager would not be able to use Windows-based software, and vice versa.
I.B.M. officials rather lamely say the divergence reflects a logistical problem -- that it was hard to collaborate when Microsoft's programmers were in Redmond, Wash., while I.B.M.'s were in Boca Raton, Fla., and England. Microsoft was somewhat more candid: "Microsoft systems strategy has changed over time," the company said, implying that "I.B.M.'s has not." What changed Microsoft's strategy was the phenomenal and apparently unexpected success of Windows, its graphical front-end to DOS.
 OS/2 was announced with fanfare nearly four years ago as the eventual replacement for DOS. I.B.M. was so keen on OS/2 that it named its entire family of personal computers PS/2, in a clear effort to make customers think that the hardware and software went hand in hand. Microsoft obviously believed that OS/2 was the future, too.
To say that I.B.M. and Microsoft overestimated the OS/2 market is an enormous understatement. Total sales of OS/2 to date are about 300,000 copies, and Microsoft says it is selling 150,000 copies a year. In contrast, Microsoft said last month that it will sell 15 million copies of DOS this year -- outselling OS/2 by a neat 100-to-1 margin -- on top of an installed base of 60 million DOS computers.
But the coup de grace for OS/2 as a desktop operating system -- rather than a network server system, where it has been been successful -- has come from Windows 3.0. That program has sold three million copies between its introduction in May 1990 and the end of the year. Microsoft expects to sell six million copies of Windows in 1991, company officials say.
"Try as it might, and as big as it is, Microsoft does not control events in the computer industry," said Marshall L. Moseley, software analyst for Dataquest Inc., a market research company in San Jose, Calif. "It moves with the economy and with events that no one can predict."
Business customers are saying loud and clear that they want Windows on their desktop computers, not OS/2, and Microsoft shifted its strategy accordingly, much to I.B.M.'s consternation. I.B.M. had promised its customers that OS/2 and its Windows-like Presentation Manager would prevail. Without Microsoft's full support, that promise now sounds hollow.
I.B.M. continues to put its broad shoulders behind OS/2 and Presentation Manager. Microsoft is throwing its developmental weight behind DOS and Windows, including a so-called Win32 that will take full advantage of the Intel Corporation's 80386 and 80486 microprocessors, which process data in chunks of 32 bits. (The current Windows is a 16-bit system, designed to run on the 16-bit Intel 80286 chip.)
At the same time, Microsoft disclosed plans for an intriguing operating system called NTOS, for New Technology Operating System, which includes a core operating code that analysts say is what Microsoft used to call OS/2 3.0. Like OS/2, the NT kernel described by Microsoft is envisioned for high-end personal computers.
First, it is "portable," meaning it can work on virtually any computer. Second, the NT kernel will have the ability to work with a variety of software application interfaces, including Windows and Presentation Manager. Third, the NT operating system is said to incorporate advanced data security features, multitasking, the ability to work with multiple processors and a technique called disk mirroring, which means the system automatically backs itself up.
Microsoft said NT would be released to software developers by year-end. I.B.M. continues to work on its own versions of OS/2, including the first 32-bit OS/2, called OS/2 2.0, which is also expected late this year.
 Just to complicate things, reports are surfacing that the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation and MIPS Computer Systems Inc., among others, are plotting to support a new processor standard for advanced computers, based on the MIPS R4000 RISC processor. Santa Cruz Operations Inc. would develop a version of the Unix operating system for such computers, but -- surprise -- it could also run Microsoft's NTOS.
 The Go Corporation of Foster City, Calif., meanwhile, is working on an operating system for computers that use pens instead of keyboards. And Apple Computer Inc. is preparing to release its long-awaited System 7.0 Macintosh operating system.
"For most users, a lot of this is meaningless," said Mr. McCarthy of Forrester. "The standalone PC users will be more than content with Windows 3.0 and the extensions Microsoft has done there. Where DOS is ultimately going to fall on its face is in network-intensive applications where you have a lot of communications going on between the desktop and multiple servers, the high-end, mission-critical systems where you need real multitasking. Those are the people who are most affected by all this waffling and battling between I.B.M. and Microsoft."

HEADLINE: Furor in Japan Over U.S. Funding Program

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 2

 BODY:
At the height of frictions with the United States last year, Japan created an ambitious new $375 million Government-financed endowment to support scholarly, political and cultural exchanges between the two countries.
But now as the new venture is about to begin, an unusual controversy has arisen, with warnings by American foundation executives and scholars that the fund might backfire by being seen as a costly attempt to improve Japan's public relations reputation in the United States. To Japanese and Americans alike, the controversy reflects the tense state of relations these days, aggravated by endless trade disputes and American resentments over Japanese investments and what many officials see as Tokyo's half-hearted response to the war against Iraq. 
 "Apparently the Japanese Government has become a kind of leper, with everything it approaches being seen as smeared," said an irritated former Japanese diplomat involved in the creation of the new fund. "Why can't the Government of Japan be seen as sincerely wanting to do good deeds?"
Japanese officials praise the fund as a brilliant idea that won high-level political backing when it was proposed by Shintaro Abe, an influential former Foreign Minister who is now ailing.
The fund endowment is to generate about $30 million annually for a variety of exchanges between Japanese and American scholars, particularly "grass roots" officials, journalists and other specialists who would explore common problems in the two countries. Among the subjects to be examined are the environment, economic tensions, politics and social problems.
In a recent symposium to discuss the establishment of the fund, American scholars and foundation representatives expressed enthusiasm, saying it could supplement much of the support for scholarly research on Japan and United States-Japan relations.
But they also warned Foreign Ministry officials that because of the current climate in the United States, such studies would be seen as tainted if they were sponsored by a unit dominated by the Government. These Americans urged that the new Global Partnership Center be freed of all Government ties.
One of the strongest warnings came from a vice president of the Ford Foundation, Susan V. Berresford, who said in a speech at the symposium that "many knowledgeable people" were concerned that the fund would "set U.S.-Japanese relations back rather than advance them."
"I will be very candid," she went on. "They fear that it will be set up and run with the express purpose of polishing the Japanese image rather than being a legitimate philanthropy in the U.S. tradition."
The suggestion, echoed by several others, has in turn irked Japanese officials, who argue that because the new fund is backed by taxpayers' money, it would be accountable to some degree.
"The fund will be very independent," said Kazuo Ogura, director general of cultural affairs at the Foreign Ministry. "We want it to do new things, and to be imaginative, creative and perhaps even controversial."
But he added that an overly independent fund might "strike out a certain independent, individualistic, unorthodox or controversial policy" unacceptable to the Government. "The fund will have to strike a balance," he said.
Others involved with the fund said that a "tug of war" was under way in the Foreign Ministry, with various consuls general of Japan in the United States seeking authority to give grants to groups in their communities to improve Japanese relations.
"Much of Japanese corporate money and Government money is, bluntly speaking, P.R. oriented," said Tadashi Yamamoto, president of the Japan Center for International Exchange. "There's very little money on the Japanese side for substantive policy-oriented intellectual joint studies."
Another Japanese official promised that the fund would have an "advisory council" to insure that "we can have American ideas and American suggestions for our activities." But he said that the power of the advisory council had not yet been determined.

HEADLINE: Applications to Medical Schools Rise Steeply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The number of applications for admission to medical schools, which declined steadily through most of the 1980's, is up sharply this year. The increase is apparently a result of students' search for safe careers in the midst of recession, aggressive recruiting by medical colleges and the schools' efforts to make themselves appear less forbidding to liberal arts majors.
More than 33,600 students have applied for 16,000 spots in the nation's 126 accredited medical schools next fall, according to a memorandum sent to medical college admissions officers in February by the Association of American Medical Colleges. 
 That number of applicants is still more than 3,000 below the number recorded in 1981, when the decline began. But it is 15 percent above the 29,243 of last year and marks the third straight year in which there has been at least some increase.
The number fell to 26,721 in 1988 from 36,727 in 1981. It increased in 1989 and again in 1990, but by nothing approaching the large gains being witnessed at many schools for next fall.
Applications are up more than 28 percent at the University of Michigan and Ohio State University, 27 percent at Northwestern University, 24 percent at the University of Southern California, 23 percent at Baylor University, 22 percent at Vanderbilt University and 17 percent at Johns Hopkins University.
 
Reasons for Upturn

Admissions officers at the medical schools see a number of reasons for the sharp upturn. One is the economy.
During the 1980's, highly qualified students flocked in record numbers to law schools and business schools, lured in part by visions of quick fortunes on Wall Street.
The images associated with medical colleges were more negative: many years of study, tens of thousands of dollars in student debt, and malpractice lawsuits.
The negatives remain. Eighty-one percent of medical students incur debt, averaging more than $42,000 a student. And it still takes 7 to 10 years of study and clinical training to enter the profession.
But some admissions deans now say as Leibert Morris of Ohio State University's School of Medicine put it, that "the negatives are losing their shock value." With illness an inherent part of the human condition, some top students tend to view the medical field as a safer bet than business or law in a recession, several deans said.
Dr. Norman Anderson, dean of admissions at Johns Hopkins, said he was seeing unusually large numbers of older applicants and people changing careers. "This year," he said, "there were a large number of people released from jobs in investment banking and business. I've had more lawyers apply now than I've ever seen. My guesstimate is we have 20 this year."
Others point to recent efforts to make medical schools less forbidding to liberal arts majors.
"Medical colleges are stressing that science is no longer the end-all," said Dr. Louis J. Kettel, vice president for academic affairs at the Association of American Medical Colleges. "There's lots of room for the humanist."
In one sign of such openness, prospective medical students in April will take a drastically revised Medical College Admissions Test, which for the first time will emphasize problem solving more than pure science.
Aggressive recruiting is also paying off for some schools.
Zen Camacho, Baylor's dean of admissions, said he and other medical school officials were doing more traveling than ever to colleges and high schools to persuade students that medicine was worth the hard work.
And the American Medical Association has been campaigning to get doctors to be less negative when asked whether they would recommend careers in medicine.
"There's no question that you can't just sweep the negatives away," said Dr. Kettel. "But we ask students in questionnaires if they understand the problems, and they seem to be saying, 'Yes, but we're here anyway.' "

HEADLINE: A Cautionary Note on Africa

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a black African I was more than delighted to see that an article about the future of the continent was given space ("Afterward, Make Africa a Priority," Feb. 3).
In the piece, Salim Lone, a Kenyan, argues that after the current American engagement in the Persian Gulf is over, the industrialized Western countries must help Africa cope with its economic problems by offering massive "debt relief and easier terms for receiving aid." Furthermore, Mr. Lone advises the West not to spend more of its expertise and resources on Eastern Europe where the collapse of Communism paved the way for private investment.
With all due respect, I strongly disagree on both accounts. First, while Africa was busy getting close to $230 billion in loans and credit in the past 30 years, which marked the rise of the new African states from the era of European colonialism, the Eastern European countries that were forced into the Warsaw Pact by the Red Army weren't getting any sort of significant assistance from the West. "In the 1980's," writes Jennifer Whitaker in her book "How Can Africa Survive," "Africans, who are about 12 percent of the developing world's population, were receiving about 22 percent of the total aid and the share per person was higher than anywhere else in the third world."
Now that there has been democratic change in Eastern European nations, it is in the interest of the West that massive assistance, both private and public, be given to them so they can develop a free market economy with a stable middle class.
Africans, like yesteryear's East Europeans, need to get rid of their corrupted dictators who more often than not run the state for the benefit of one man, his family and his tribe. The West should not fall for the eloquent speeches delivered by Africa's 40-plus dictators who all of a sudden celebrate the virtue of free-market capitalism and the failure of centrally planned economic systems. They hadn't read Karl Marx's "Das Kapital" when they were with the Soviets and their new conversion to the market is not based on an understanding of Adam Smith's "Wealth of Nations." They say whatever the donor countries with the most funds wish to hear.
Unless Africa experiences an Easternn European-style revolution, no amount of debt relief and aid will be enough to solve its economic misery.
 
ABDUL RAHMAN ABDI
Greenbelt, Md., Feb. 10

HEADLINE: Account of Failure: Talks at The News

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
While management of The Daily News and its striking unions share blame for the failure of their negotiations, that failure was from the beginning a likely, if not inevitable, outcome of the strategy of the paper's owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago.
 The fact that the Tribune Company could afford to let the talks fail, indeed could benefit overall as a company by letting The News go out of business after 71 years of publication, was its underlying strength in extended bargaining with the paper's nine unions. 
 But if the company thought this strength would bring the unions around to accepting drastic changes that News management said were necessary to continue operation of the paper, it miscalculated in a large and repeated way.
In a bruising but often subtle duel extending nearly two years, both sides thrust and parried, until Thursday evening when negotiations were declared effectively ended. The News has said that a buyer must be found by March 20 or the paper will be closed.
 
Profit or Loss
 There were about a dozen moments during the negotiations that proved particularly significant.
The first and most important was the policy decision made sometime in 1989 by Charles T. Brumback, the combative man who had become president of the Tribune Company on that Jan. 1, to shed The News unless it could quickly be turned into a money maker.
Mr. Brumback began telling associates he was determined to "win back the franchise" from wasteful and abusive union control by negotiating a radically different contract to replace the one that was to expire on March 30, 1990. Tribune executives say The News lost $115 million in the 1980's.
From the start, the Tribune Company's stated objective was to establish "management rights," which the company said were essential to stop feather-bedding and unnecessary overtime so that the paper, could be made profitable. For instance, with a management rights contract, management would have been able to decide how many people should operate a press in all situations, even though such issues had been previously controlled by staffing levels negotiated with unions.
 
No Ground Surrendered
 Union leaders regarded the management rights concept as unconditional surrender of their power at The News and tantamount to union busting. While union leaders said they were willing to reduce the work force and make other economic concessions, they resolved to do so only within the framework of a traditional contract that would preserve union power in the work place.
Neither side ever gave any significant ground.
The great power of the Tribune Company throughout the negotiations has been that, while the unions had everything to lose, the Tribune Company had nothing to lose except incurring the onus of closing one of the nation's best-known newspapers.
Since The News became unprofitable in the early 1980's, the paper has been a drag on the company's corporate earnings, which include profits from The Chicago Tribune and other papers and broadcast properties.
With its bargaining approach, The Tribune Company stood to gain a profitable paper operated with the efficiencies of management rights, or by closing or selling the paper, to improve corporate profits in a different manner.
To the unions, the Tribune Company effectively took the paper hostage.
 
'Reform Is the Word'
 "If they couldn't beat up the unions, they'd shut it down," George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council which includes all of the striking unions, said on Friday.
"Reform is the word I like to use," said James Hoge, publisher of The News, characterizing what the paper had sought from its unions. "I don't think we created the confrontation."
In the summer of 1989, the decision having been made to revolutionize The News's work place or abandon the franchise, Mr. Hoge began to execute the company's public relations strategy.
One significant element of the plan was to win the hearts and minds of New Yorkers by exposing abusive union work practices, especially in the two unions considered the worst offenders: the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York and New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2 -- the drivers and the pressmen.
Mr. Hoge made his case in an interview in Vanity Fair magazine that fall, but the article had the additional effect of alerting unions to the company's strategy, which was to isolate the drivers and the pressmen from the other unions and break union solidarity.
Forewarned, the unions began planning a strategy of their own, whose cornerstone was maintaining solidarity.
 
Lawyer's Significance
 Later that fall, with actual negotiations about to start, Mr. Hoge announced that Robert Ballow would represent the company in the talks. To the unions, that was comparable to declaring that there would be no quarter. Mr. Ballow, a lawyer based in Nashville, is known within the newspaper industry for his very aggressive bargaining, which often has gained dramatic union concessions.
The Tribune Company fully understood the significance of hiring Mr. Ballow. In 1982, when the company had tried to sell the paper, the publisher W. Dean Singleton, who represented a prospective buyer, Joe L. Allbritton, said he wanted Mr. Ballow to represent Mr. Allbritton in negotiations with unions. But Mr. Singleton said the Tribune Company forbade it. The reason the company gave, he said: the unions would consider hiring Mr. Ballow "inflammatory."
The significant moment came when the contract expired last March 30. Negotiations had gone nowhere, and executives at The News, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the company hoped -- and expected -- all or part of the 2,300 union members to strike.
 
Trying to Avoid a Strike
 The News wanted a strike because it would allow the paper to hire permanent replacements for striking workers, and the new employees would work under a management rights arrangement.
But union leaders, who were now being counseled by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., decided that it was in their best interest not to strike and their members continued to work as negotiations ground on.
The next significant moment came in late March when The News offered to raise salaries of its largest union, the Newspaper Guild, by about 30 percent over three years. Executives involved with the management strategy who spoke on the basis of anonymity said The News considered such an offer all but irresistible and expected the Guild to break with the other unions.
But it was another miscalculation. The offer would have stripped Guild members of the job security that they valued even more highly than the salary increase, and the union's leaders rejected the proposal without significant dissent from members.
 
Dispute in Mail Room
 By June, the unions were engaged in a strategy of prolonging negotiations in an effort to prevent The News from declaring an impasse, which would be followed by imposing the new managment rights policy, something that they expected would prompt a strike and open the door to permanent replacements.
News executives who spoke on condition of anonymity said that, throughout the spring, some members of the management team who had questioned the wisdom of Mr. Ballow's confrontational style of negotiating were quietly pushed out. They were replaced, in many cases, by executives from other Tribune papers who had been through other strikes and shared the tough, can-do attitude that now permeated the paper's top ranks.
In late October, a group of drivers left their posts in a dispute in the mail room. The News quickly replaced them and said the next day that they had been permanently replaced. The drivers union then walked out, and the other unions struck in sympathy.
The News's careful preparation made it possible to print the paper with replacement workers, and a cadre of replacement drivers and security workers successfully got trucks loaded with The News from the plants to the street.
But once again, News management had badly miscalculated by assuming that news dealers would support the paper in such a situation.
 
Absence of Advertisers
 Faced with a combination pro-union sentiment, outright violence and threats of additional violence, most newsstands in New York refused to sell The News. Circulation dropped precipitously, which made the paper less attractive to advertisers, who were under pressure from unions to withdraw their ads.
In mid-November, the paper's advertisers abandoned it in a rush, and The News was left almost without revenue.
The News filed several lawsuits, including ones charging union racketeering, and the unions filed countersuits. The News also tried selling the paper through street hawkers.
But the unions had shut it down as a business.
By Jan. 1, the paper said it was losing $750,000 a day.
On Jan. 16, Mr. Hoge announced that such losses could not be sustained and that the Tribune Company would close the paper or sell it by March 20 if no settlement could be reached with unions.
Unhappily for the paper's unions, the stock market reacted to the news that the paper might be closed with an 8 percent increase in the price of Tribune Company stock on that day. Last Friday, Tribune stock closed at $42 a share, 21 percent higher than the price before the Jan. 16 announcement.
There was a brief flicker of hope among union officials that the Tribune Company might soften its position when Bill Usery Jr., a former Secretary of Labor who is respected by unions, was brought in by The News to try to mediate.
 
Ballow Continues
 In the first face-to-face meeting during the negotiations between Mr. Hoge and Mr. Brumback and the union leaders, the company's message was that it wanted to save the situation.
But Mr. McDonald said that, had The News been serious, it would have replaced Mr. Ballow as the chief negotiator. Instead, Mr. Ballow continued to direct the negotiations, though Mr. Hoge was present. Though there were some changes and a relaxation of some of the management rights language, union leaders considered such maneuvers merely an effort to build a record to help the company in existing and future lawsuits after the paper was closed.
In turn, Mr. Hoge said the changes were from a sincere effort to reach agreement. In negotiations with the pressmen's union, which had been selected as the lead union in the mediation, The News offered to negotiate the number of people needed to operate presses in the traditional fashion. But The News demanded a 50 percent work force reduction and a 45 percent pay cut for most of the remaining workers. The offer was rejected, with the president of the Newspaper Guild, Barry F. Lipton, calling it a "suicide proposal" that "was made to be rejected."
On Thursday, at a final mediation session, The News and the pressmen once again failed to come to terms, and Mr. Usery announced that further negotiations were a waste of time.
Mr. McDonald said one of the few silver linings for unions in the current situation is their expectation that Mr. Ballow's reputation would suffer because his confrontational approachdid not win the concessions that the Tribune Company expected and cost it a small fortune.
Mr. Hoge said that, from the beginning of 1990 to the present, the paper's losses have been over $130 million, much of it related to the labor conflict. He added that he considered Mr. Ballow's work to have been excellent.
"I don't cast blame on anyone," he said.

HEADLINE: Record $4.4 Million Raised for Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
Despite war and a declining economy, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund last week completed its most successful campaign in its 79-year history.
While the 1990-91 appeal opened in November to dire predictions of "compassion fatigue" among New Yorkers, the drive ended with thousands of contributors' sending money to help the sick and the poor. Many did so even in the face of salary cuts, job layoffs and the city's fiscal crisis. 
 Some fund-raising experts say that the campaign's achievements reflect a general trend in charitable giving: Hard times lead to an increase in the number of donors.
The 1990-91 appeal for the Neediest Cases raised $4,439,093.47 from at least 15,580 people and organizations. The fund's total is up $66,810.25 from last year, and it received about 1,300 more gifts than in the previous drive.
 
Annual Testimony to Generosity
 The 1990-91 appeal ended on Thursday, though donations will continue to be accepted throughout the year and be recorded in the next campaign, beginning in late November. All the money goes to seven charities that aid the needy, as The New York Times pays for the fund's administrative costs.
Since it was established in 1912 by The Times's publisher, Adolph S. Ochs, the fund has provided annual testimony to the generosity of New Yorkers. Over the years, it has has grown steadily from its initial appeal, which received 117 gifts totaling $3,630.88. The $1 million mark was passed in the 1970-71 campaign, the fund's annual total broke $2 million in the 1983-84 campaign and the proceeds increased for much of the 1980's.
Though the fund's amount had increased in the five previous campaigns, fund administrators had not been hopeful about the chances for a record this time around.
 
'Appreciate the Compassion'
 "When the fund started its annual appeal last November, no one connected with the drive held any hope of matching last season's solid record," said Arthur Gelb, the president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund. "The fact that we ended ahead of last year despite such difficult times is a tribute to the loyal, caring readers of The Times.
"All of us at the fund and those at its benefiting charities appreciate the compassion and generosity of everyone who gave."
This generosity, however, was not restricted to the Neediest Cases. Similar charities sponsored by newspapers, including those of The Washington Post, The San Francisco Chronicle and New York Newsday, reported increases in their holiday appeals. In New York, a number of other charities reported that their latest fund-raising efforts had come out ahead of their previous ones in both the amount and number of donations. And several fund-raising experts said that the percentage of people giving to charities had increased over the last few years.
"Even though some people are hard pressed because of the recession, a lot more people are giving," said Jimmie R. Alford, the chairman of the Trust for Philanthropy of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. "More and more people are aware of the different charities out there, and although times are tough, they're finding ways to support them -- especially the ones that serve the basic human needs."
 
Expert Doubts General Increase
 But Lester Salamon, an expert on philanthropic giving and the director of the Johns Hopkins Institute for Policy Studies, disagreed. He said that there was no evidence of a significant increase in giving this year and that past trends suggested a recession would hurt donations. He noted that the increase in this year's total for the Neediest Cases was substantially less than the growth in previous years.
As in previous campaigns, the 1990-91 Neediest Cases drive continued to attract a wide variety of donors: millionaire movie stars, elderly people on Social Security and children who received a weekly allowance of 50 cents. Contributions came from as far as Hong Kong, Israel, Switzerland and France as well as from Connecticut, New Jersey and New York. The donations' amounts ranged from two checks for $150,000 each from the Starr Foundation in Manhattan and Paul Newman's food company to a $1 bill sent anonymously.
But this year seemed different in the number of contributors who wrote that they were giving to the fund despite losing their jobs or or suffering a drop in their income.
Judith S. Hull, a 42-year-old architectural history scholar in Oak Park, Ill., has been unemployed for several years because of an illness. But this year, she and her husband felt it was important to send a donation to the fund, their first in many years.
"We are not yet out of the woods and hesitate to send the check as the banking crisis continues," she wrote. "But where will we all be if conditions in our greatest city decline further? Perhaps for me, this is some kind of investment in a place where I studied and learned so much."
Another donor, who did not want her name published, sent $1,250 and wrote: "Economic adversity has caused a significant drop in my income this year. Nevertheless, I am privileged compared to many New Yorkers, so once again I am increasing my contribution."
The $500 gift from Robert and Lynn Mueller of Manhattan came with a brief note: "While the amount is not as much as it has been in recent years, we feel that it is important to continue to give. It is an unfortunate irony that in the years when people need the most help, there may be less to give."

HEADLINE: Scraping By, Illegally, Mining Kentucky Coal

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARBOURVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
This part of southeastern Kentucky is so poor with so few ways to make an honest living, that many people do not even try. The last time state officials counted they found that fewer than half the adults in Knox County were working.
"We're a mailbox economy," said Phillip Connley, the Mayor of Barbourville, referring to the monthly arrival of welfare and pension checks. "Everybody gets checks." 
 But one thing that Knox County has in abundance is people who know coal mining. Many worked for coal companies until mechanization put them out of their jobs, and some still earn a living as "wildcatters," by mining illegally. Because of a glittering seam of uncommonly rich coal known as the Blue Gem -- coal that is hard for the big mining companies to get at -- the Cumberland Mountain land around Barbourville is the nation's center of wildcat mining.
Concerned about the risk of deaths and goaded by lawful operators, the United Mine Workers of America and environmentalists, Federal and state regulators have stepped up pursuit of these miners.
Edward Hugler, deputy administrator of the Mine Safety and Health Administration in Washington and chief of the agency's two-year-old study group on illegal mining, said regulators had cut down the activity. But he added that new wildcat mines had opened and that if depressed coal prices rebounded, there would probably be more.
Wildcat miners fatten their profits by skirting safety and land use regulations, taxes and other government-imposed constraints. Because of this, they infuriate unions and law-abiding mining companies. But that type of lawlessness also evokes romance and admiration in Appalachia.
"Like moonshiners, these people are trying to make a living," said Tom Duncan, who retired in December as president of the Kentucky Coal Association, an industry group.
"Some of them are thieves," who pillage coal from others' land, he said. "But some mine the coal because it's theirs, it's on their territory."
 
A Bankrupt Wildcatter
 One wildcatter who got caught is Ray Phipps, who lives in a rundown trailer in a hollow near Barbourville, a town of about 3,000 people and the seat of Knox County.
In the last decade Mr. Phipps, now 45 years old, became a big wildcatter, burrowing into the hills on hundreds of acres that his father had bought over the years. With a crew of up to 17 miners who shared in the profits, he mined 90 tons of Blue Gem coal a day and made a comfortable living.
But Mr. Phipps caught the eye of the Kentucky Department of Surface Mining by operating without permits and leaving the area around his mines in a chaos of slate and shale that he had dragged out with the coal.
He said he was ordered to restore the land he had defaced or pay a fine of $250,000. He could not afford either, he said, so he closed the business and filed for bankruptcy. Mr. Phipps said he planned to leave the Cumberlands and go to Georgia to look for a factory job.
"You realize the country you live in is not hardly free," he said. "They're running me out. If you want, you can take a bulldozer and tear these mountains all to hell -- just so you don't take any coal."
Like Mr. Phipps, many people here look for illegal ways to make money because the government, the economy and the business establishment have provided few alternatives.
Southeastern Kentucky has had little success in luring new industry or in teaching the young new skills. And the big coal companies here have found they can dig more coal faster by replacing people with machines.
Last year an average of 9,959 Knox County residents received food stamps each month, in a population of 29,643. And, in the depths of the recession, crimes like shoplifting and drunken driving are soaring.
 
'Theft Is Up the Most'
 "Theft is up the most," said Officer Bill D. Swafford of the Barbourville police. "We've got people who, if they knew there was a nickel on the table in your house, they would break in to get it."
Kentucky, the nation's second largest coal producer after Wyoming, enjoyed a period of relative prosperity in the late 1970's, when coal prices rose with oil prices and many utilities converted their power plants from oil to coal.
But with the mechanization of mining, the jobs withered away even as production soared. In Knox County, the number of jobs in legitimate mining plunged to 242 last year from 717 in 1985. Jobs in businesses that cater to mining have disappeared with them.
"In the 70's you saw new ranch-style homes, new trailers and satellite dishes, those metal ears in the ground," said John Stephenson, president of Berea College, a private liberal arts college just north of the coal country. "Now you see peeling paint and people moving."
After growing in the 1970's, the population of Knox County declined by 2 percent in the 1980's. Among the people who stay, many work in low-wage fast-food and discount stores. But others, and the people they hire, find richer rewards outside the law.
Some grow marijuana. Robert Trevey, an Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky, in Lexington, called Kentucky the nation's third largest marijuana producer, after California and Hawaii. And both of those states have year-round growing seasons.
"Marijuana wiped out moonshine," said Lowell W. Lundy, a Barbourville lawyer. "It's much more profitable."
But in dry counties like Knox, people continue to bootleg. "It's usually a family business," Officer Swafford said. "It passes from father to son."
And they wildcat. Joseph Garcia, manager of the Mine Safety and Health Administration's office in Barbourville, which oversees mining in Kentucky, Tennessee and Alabama, said 43 active unlawful mines, defined as those working without official sanction, were uncovered in the three states over the last two years. Eleven were in Knox County, he said, and 10 were in neighboring Whitley County.
 
Few Convictions, Fewer Jailed
 The mine safety agency, which is part of the Federal Department of Labor, wants to close wildcat mines because of the danger they pose to workers. But people who sympathize with the wildcatters say fatal accidents are rare because most wildcatters are cautious, even if they skirt regulations. They themselves work in the mines, unlike the managers of big coal companies, and the crews are often made up of family members.
Convictions are hard to obtain because of sympathetic juries. Of 66 wildcat mines found nationwide over the last two years, Mr. Hugler said, in only one case have people been sent to prison -- two Kentucky men for four months.
Officials of the mine safety agency say they have no way of knowing how many mines are starting up until they see the signs of one -- a new dirt road up a remote hill or coal being hauled along back roads.
On a recent day in February, Federal investigators near Barbourville saw two trucks loaded with coal that aroused their suspicion. Mining inspectors have no authority to stop vehicles on public roads, so they hurried to the office shack of a nearby mine, where the tiny, legitimate Gideon Coal Company is working the Blue Gem Seam.
Vernon Morris, the manager of the mine, said the investigators asked if the trucks had come from his mine. Only one, he said he told them, and he knew of no other mines along the road. But with more coal leaving the area than Gideon is producing, it appeared that a wildcatter had taken another hill.
 
A Shallow Shelf of Wealth
 The Blue Gem Seam, a shelf of coal that cuts through the hills and hollows of Knox and Whitley counties, is favored by wildcatters as well as by small legitimate operators because it is too shallow, at 18 to 30 inches thick, to accommodate the heavy machinery used by big coal companies.
Because Blue Gem coal contains little sulfur, it creates little pollution. Big mining companies and coal brokers pay about $32 a ton for it, $8 of $10 more than for most coal. It is illegal to buy wildcat coal, but miners can disguise its origin.
For an illegal operator, wildcat mining is a fairly cheap business to enter. He borrows or rents a bulldozer to prepare the face of the mine, and he usually buys a tractor and scoop.
And wildcatters avoid many other costs. Lawful operators spend about $10,000 for engineering studies, and thousands of dollars more for special bolts to secure the roof of a mine. They also have to put a lot of money in escrow with the state, money that they get back only after they have closed the mine and reclaimed the land.
Legitimate operators find that Federal and state regulators are intrusive, and contend that the authorities spend as much effort going after those among them who disregard regulations as it does pursuing wildcatters.
Regulators say lawful operators' concerns are exaggerated. "The egregious ones get our attention," Mr. Hugler said. "If you have a small operation, only a small number of rules apply to you. These rules are to protect you from killing yourself."
 
A Fear of the Future
 Competition for the Blue Gem Seam is increasing, and competition from wildcatters could drive down prices and wages and eventually exhaust the accessible approaches to the seam.
Dannie Lewis, 32, who is working the Gideon mine and is the son and grandson of coal miners, said he feared that when the mine closed another job might be hard to find.
"It worries me very much," he said. "I think that by the time I turn 40 there might not be mines in this county. The only thing I can do, being a Christian, is pray the good Lord will make a way for me and my family to survive."
He said he hoped his two sons, one 13 years old and the other just born, would find a different job. "I would like for them to do something that wouldn't be as physically strenuous and do better in life than I have," he said.
