HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: A Reconstruction
The Path to War -- Bush's Crucial Decisions -- A special report.;
From the First, U.S. Resolve to Fight

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN and PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The Bush Administration began planning an offensive campaign to dislodge Iraqi forces from Kuwait early last fall even as Administration officials insisted in public that the only mission of United States forces was to defend Saudi Arabia and enforce United Nations sanctions.
According to a reconstruction of major internal deliberations and decisions by President Bush and his senior advisers during the seven-month Persian Gulf crisis, offensive military planning began in earnest in September. 
 On Oct. 30, a week before Congressional elections, the President secretly approved a timetable for launching an air war against Iraq in mid-January and a large-scale ground offensive in February that would strike deep into Iraqi territory to outflank and encircle President Saddam Hussein's army.
This war-planning process went forward in conjunction with American diplomatic and economic pressure on Iraq to leave Kuwait, and senior officials indicated that Mr. Bush all along hoped -- at times even believed -- that sanctions coupled with the threat of war would be enough to dislodge the Iraqis.
The planning steps that the President approved in October were those carried out when the air war began on Jan. 17. The only element of the plan made public was the announcement by Mr. Bush on Nov. 8, two days after the election, that he had ordered a major reinforcement of American forces in the Persian Gulf to give them an offensive capability. That critical decision increased American troops from 230,000 to more than 500,000 and provided the allies the troop strength for the decisive flanking action carried out in February in the Iraqi desert.
Another plan submitted to the Pentagon early in October by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of United States forces in the Persian Gulf, had been rejected because it envisioned a ground offensive directly into the heart of Iraqi forces and fortifications in Kuwait.
In addition to the timetable for offensive military action, the Administration's reconstruction of events shows that while the gulf crisis ended on the high note of military victory, earlier officials had been short of insight into President Hussein's intentions and bereft of military options to stop his invasion of Kuwait last summer.
It also shows that despite the Administration's carefully maintained image of unanimity on major decisions, there were debates at the White House and the Pentagon over how to respond to the Iraqi aggression.
A briefly contentious point was whether and how to keep Israel from striking back in response to Iraqi Scud missile attacks. At one stage, the President's advisers seriously debated letting the Israelis unleash their Jericho missiles on Iraqi territory. When this was rejected, the White House arranged for the Israelis to receive intelligence information on American military progress against the Scuds.
The reconstruction also provides an insight into a central mystery of the gulf crisis -- why Mr. Hussein ignored all warnings that his army would be destroyed and his country crippled. According to top officials, Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at the end of their meeting in Geneva on Jan. 9:
"Your Arab allies will desert you. They will not kill other Arabs. Your alliance will crumble and you will be left lost in the desert. You don't know the desert because you have never ridden on a horse or a camel."
 
Sending Troops
The Allies Debate How Soon to Help
 At 2 A.M. on Aug. 2, 80,000 troops from Iraq's Republican Guard pushed across the Kuwaiti border and headed south toward Kuwait City, the capital. The first intelligence reports reached Washington around 6:30 P.M. Aug. 1, Eastern daylight time, as the invasion was occurring. At 9:15 P.M., Kuwait's Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, telephoned the American Embassy asking for immediate military help to stop the invasion, but, worried about how this would be seen in the Arab world, he insisted that the request "not be made public or treated as official."
At 10:30 P.M. Washington time, the embassy got a second telephone call from Sheik Saad. Ignore the first request, the desperate Kuwaiti said. Now the Government was "officially requesting help" and was willing to make this public. But before an answer could be conveyed back to Sheik Saad, he had dashed to Dasman Palace to pick up the Emir, the country's ruler, and was heading south in the royal limousine to Saudi Arabia.
"We had told them all along, 'You can't ask us for help when your enemies are knocking on the palace door,' " a senior Administration official said. "We just did not have the military assets in place."
Indeed, the nearest significant American military help, the aircraft carrier Independence, was far away in the Indian Ocean.
The view in Washington was that for the time being "Kuwait was a goner," as a senior official said. The whole focus of thinking was: How far south would the Iraqis move?
The first official contact with Saudi Arabia was made through the United States Embassy in Riyadh, where a senior diplomat asked what the kingdom wanted from the United States.
"The Saudis were a little flustered, a little scared," a senior official recalled. "They didn't know what they wanted." The Pentagon offered to send a squadron of tactical fighter planes.
"We'll get back to you," a Saudi official replied.
The President awoke the next morning to a crisis unforeseen in the post-cold-war era. At 5 A.M., Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, presented him the draft of orders to freeze all Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States. Later, his senior advisers gathered in the Cabinet Room. During a brief photo session, Mr. Bush was asked whether the United States was prepared to intervene militarily. "We're not discussing intervention," he said.
When the cameras left, the atmosphere was one of shock and frustration. The President wanted options, but there appeared to be few that could immediately reverse the Iraqi push into Kuwait.
Nevertheless, when Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady began to lay out how the United States might adapt to expected higher oil prices, Mr. Bush interjected, according to a senior official: "Let's be clear about one thing: We are not here to talk about adapting. We are not going to plan how to live with this."
If Mr. Bush was frustrated and angry, it was because he had personally invested in the notion that Mr. Hussein's behavior could be moderated. Only a few days earlier, King Hussein of Jordan, whom Mr. Bush had regarded as a friend, had told him "absolutely not," when asked if Iraq would invade Kuwait, an official said.
When the National Security Council reconvened on Friday, Aug. 3, Mr. Scowcroft opened the meeting with a strong admonition that the discussion of options would be based on the recognition that Iraq's invasion was unacceptable and if allowed to stand, would fundamentally alter the balance of power in a vital part of the world.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, initially annoyed by a reticence among uniformed officers to provide concrete choices, brought General Schwarzkopf to explain the Pentagon's updated plan to use troops in a crisis in the Persian Gulf.
"I remember the body language when Norm talked about the 140,000 troops," a senior official said. "Good God, that's a lot of people" was the expression on some faces, he said.
Mr. Bush, however, focused on the principal obstacle to such a troop movement -- the Saudis. He had telephoned King Fahd and assured him that the United States would stand by Saudi Arabia, and he directed Mr. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to brief the Saudi Ambassador, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, on the threat and on the troop plan.
Convinced that the sending of troops was the right course, Prince Bandar recommended that a high-level envoy fly to Saudi Arabia to convince King Fahd, who would have to make a quick decision. The deliberations moved to Camp David on Saturday. General Schwarzkopf took the President and his aides through a series of charts depicting the full plan to move troops to the gulf.
"This is what it will take to defend Saudi Arabia," the general said. Then, flipping to a final chart depicting an even larger use of troops, he added, "And if you want to liberate Kuwait, this is what it will take."
Although the group was focused on the immediate problem of defense, General Schwarzkopf had introduced the concept of offense from the very beginning.
Mr. Bush and his advisers debated who should go to Jidda, site of King Fahd's palace, and whether a high-level mission would run the risk of disastrous recriminations if the Saudis could not make up their minds. In the midst of the talks, Mr. Bush received a telephone call from Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, who said he had an authoritative report that the Saudis had decided not to accept American forces.
Mr. Bush telephoned King Fahd to sound him out, without mentioning the Mubarak call. The King delayed in accepting a visit from Mr. Cheney. He wondered whether a delegation of technical experts might not be better. Mr. Bush offered General Schwarzkopf, but continued to push Mr. Cheney as the head of the mission, because if the King decided to receive an envoy of his level, it would be difficult for him to say no.
King Fahd delayed 14 hours before agreeing to see Mr. Cheney. In the ornate palace at Jidda, Mr. Cheney delivered his brief and then watched as the King and his brother spoke in Arabic to express some of their ambivalent feelings about the Kuwaitis.
"We have to do this; what will happen to Kuwait?" King Fahd said to Crown Prince Abdullah, according to one of the Arabic-speaking Westerners present.
"There is still a Kuwait," Prince Abdullah responded.
"Yes, but the entire population is living in our hotel rooms," the King shot back. Saudi Arabia was on board, as long as the Americans agreed in writing to leave when the threat passed and to get Saudi approval before initiating any offensive military action.
The dimensions of the planned military buildup were closely held by Mr. Bush and his inner circle. A senior White House aide scoffed at a published report in mid-August that the American force strength could reach 200,000.
 
Doubling the Force
When a Buildup Becomes Political
 The public outrage that spurred support for the sending of troops in August eroded when the President and Congress bogged down in a bruising budget fight during September and October. An intense Israeli-Palestinian clash in Jerusalem drew attention away from Kuwait, and the Central Intelligence Agency began reporting there were no signs that Mr. Hussein could be pressed by sanctions alone to leave Kuwait.
Reports of atrocities in Kuwait and Iraq's mistreatment of Western hostages, including their use as human shields at military and industrial installations, created tension among policy makers -- between a strategy of waiting out the Iraqis and taking the initiative to eject them.
"There was a sense of drift," a senior Administration official said. "Saddam seemed to have the initiative. We felt we had to do something to get it back."
Mr. Bush pressed the Pentagon to develop the offensive military options, but General Schwarzkopf protested that he did not have his defensive forces in place yet and the Iraqis were still pouring more troops into Kuwait.
Rushed as it was, the first offensive plan -- presented early in October to Mr. Cheney, General Powell and the Joint Chiefs of Staff in a Pentagon conference room known as "the tank" -- was an unimaginative "up the middle" through the Iraqi front lines "right smack into his strength," as a senior official put it.
Over the next few weeks, General Schwarzkopf sent back a plan to conduct a flanking attack around Iraq's front line, a more imaginative approach, but Mr. Cheney and General Powell agreed with the commander's assessment that there were not enough allied forces to conduct such an attack while also preventing the Iraqi Army from coming south.
American officials said their initial dispatch of 180,000 troops would have given them both defensive and offensive options if the level of Iraqi forces in the region remained at 100,000. But as the Iraqi force climbed to 430,000 by the end of October, the United States had to match this to maintain a credible offensive option.
General Powell told General Schwarzkopf to state his full military requirements to drive the Iraqi Army out of Kuwait, and he flew to Saudi Arabia on Oct. 21 to discuss the plan and its timetable and brought it back to Mr. Cheney. When the Pentagon leaders took the plan to the White House on Oct. 30, it called for a timetable to begin a large-scale bombing campaign against Iraq in mid-January, followed by a ground campaign late in February.
The plan required almost doubling the 200,000 American forces in the gulf in little over three months, with a major call-up of the reserves.
In the two-hour meeting, Mr. Bush made two fundamental decisions: first, to set in motion the machinery for a mid-winter war against the Iraqi Army and, second, to win a United Nations mandate for that war. To that end, he dispatched Secretary of State Baker on a round-the-world tour to round up support for a Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force.
General Powell, Mr. Cheney, Mr. Scowcroft, Mr. Baker and the President all felt there was a reasonable chance that the enormous mobilization of American military power, combined with the setting of a deadline, might be enough to scare Mr. Hussein into leaving Kuwait, officials said. Mr. Cheney's nightmare was that Mr. Hussein would find more troops to send to the front to force another round of escalation.
The President showed no hesitation in making the controversial decision to increase troop strength, but decided to keep it secret until Nov. 8. Why?
"Nov. 8 was a very important date because it was after Nov. 6," a White House official said, referring to the election.
The troop increase sent a shudder through both the alliance and among many Americans. A senior White House official said: "Shortly after we announced the increase in troop strength, we got a sharp reaction from Capitol Hill, and the press was saying that nobody knows why we are there, and it looked like we had a big domestic problem."
It was during this period, aides say, that the President began thinking about "going the extra mile to avert a war" by sending Mr. Baker to Baghdad and inviting Foreign Minister Aziz to Washington -- a move he announced immediately after the United Nations Security Council vote on Nov. 29 sanctioning the use of force if Iraqi troops were not out of Kuwait by Jan. 15.
 
The Air War
Bush Becomes 'A Different Man'
 On Dec. 16, President Bush, in an interview with the British broadcaster David Frost, said of Mr. Hussein, "It's my view that he doesn't know what he is up against and that he doesn't believe the willpower of the United States. He is still unconvinced."
Yet two days later, speaking to Time magazine, Mr. Bush stated, "My gut says he will get out of there."
The contradictory instincts expressed in these two interviews reflected the President's mood swings in the weeks leading right up to the Jan. 16 decision to launch the air war. Some described this as a toughening of mood.
If there was a last chance to avert war, it was on Jan. 9, when Mr. Baker met Mr. Aziz in Geneva. The long session recessed after two hours and Mr. Baker reported by telephone to Mr. Bush that the Iraqi minister's tone was very reasonable.
At the time, Mr. Bush was meeting with a group of 15 members of Congress, and those present say that as the Geneva meeting resumed and then stretched to six hours, Mr. Bush seemed cautiously optimistic that a deal might be in the works. Then came a final call from Mr. Baker.
"The President excused himself to take the call and was gone for about eight minutes," said Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California. "When he came back, our conversation stopped. The President's whole demeanor had changed. He was somber and grim. You could see it all over his face. He looked at us and said two words: 'No progress.' I felt it was a defining moment. He was a different man. When we asked why the meeting in Geneva had lasted so long, he simply said: 'History.' "
This was apparently a reference to Mr. Aziz's long recitation of Iraqi and Arab grievances with the United States. It was not the Iraqi's official's only complaint, though. He also laid into the Soviet Union.
"We don't have a patron anymore," Mr. Aziz complained to Mr. Baker. "If we still had the Soviets as our patron, none of this would have happened. They would have vetoed every U.N. resolution."
Mr. Baker warned Mr. Aziz during their session that a war with the United States would not be like Iraq's war with Iran.
Mr. Aziz riposted with a prediction that the Arab allies would abandon the United States and that in any event the desert would defeat the Western armies.
After the Baker-Aziz meeting, all of the President's advisers agreed that war was now inevitable. On Tuesday morning, Jan. 15, Mr. Bush sat in a wingbacked chair by the fireplace in the Oval Office and signed a national security directive for war against Iraq.
 
The Israelis
Need to Placate A Worried Ally
 As early as September, President Bush and Secretary Baker began sounding out the Arab allies about how they would respond if the Iraqis launched missiles against Israel to bring it into the war.
The answers that came back over the next few months were generally positive: Provided that the Israelis did not attack Iraq first and that any Israeli retaliation was "proportionate," none of America's Arab allies would have a problem, they indicated.
On Dec. 11, Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, came to Washington and met with President Bush in the Oval Office -- the first time the two men had spoken since the gulf crisis began. The President, officials said, told the Israeli that in the event of war, the United States had specific plans to destroy fixed Iraqi missile-launching sites in western Iraq, as well as all the mobile launchers in the area.
But Mr. Bush also told Mr. Shamir that since Washington was doing all it could to avoid any linkage between the gulf crisis and the Arab-Israel dispute, so the Israelis had to avoid linking them by retaliating for any Iraqi attacks. Mr. Shamir, eager to patch up strained relations with Mr. Bush, promised that Israel would not launch a pre-emptive strike and that he would consult with the President before responding to an attack by Iraq.
The Administration reciprocated by establishing a secure hot line -- code-named "Hammer Rick" -- between the Pentagon's crisis center and the Israeli Defense Ministry in Tel Aviv, so that the Israelis could be given instant warning of missile launches detected by American satellites.
Minutes after the first Iraqi Scud missiles slammed into Tel Aviv on the evening of Jan. 17, Mr. Cheney used the hot line to talk to an agitated Defense Minister Moshe Arens, while in Mr. Scowcroft's office at the White House, Mr. Baker telephoned Mr. Shamir, as did Mr. Bush later.
The message from Washington, a senior official said, was simple and clear: "We are going after western Iraq, full bore. There is nothing that your Air Force can do that we are not doing. If there is, tell us and we will do it. We appreciate your restraint, but please don't play into Saddam's hands. We also told them that night that we would give them more Patriots with American crews."
At one point during that tense evening, the President's most senior Cabinet and foreign policy advisers and Vice President Dan Quayle were sitting in Mr. Scowcroft's office and a top Administration official -- no one will identify him -- suggested that since it was inevitable that the Israelis were going to retaliate at some point, why not let them go now, using their arsenal of Jericho missiles instead of planes. After a discussion among the President's men -- unbeknownst to the Israelis -- the majority view was that the Israelis had to be, and could be, talked out of retaliating.
Mr. Shamir, a senior official said, was "very cool" and never insisted on retaliating, even though he was under pressure: Israel's Air Force chief, Maj. Gen. Avihu Binun, kept arguing that his pilots could do a better job than the Americans, and that the Patriot missile batteries would not protect Israel, American officials said.
Mr. Arens was not so cool. He told Mr. Cheney and Mr. Baker that Israel would have to retaliate at some time and asked Mr. Cheney again that night for access to the electronic identity codes that Israeli fighter planes would need to distinguish between American and Iraqi jets. In turning down these requests, Mr. Cheney helped to ease the Israelis' anxiety by ordering more intelligence sharing to show the Israelis exactly what targets the allies were hitting in western Iraq.
Essentially, the conversations of that night -- both the American appeals and the Israeli responses -- were repeated with every Scud attack. Mr. Arens would ask for the codes, and later for an air corridor through Saudi Arabia so that Israeli planes could retaliate without going through Jordan. Mr. Cheney would refuse all requests, Mr. Bush would say how much the Israeli restraint was appreciated and Mr. Shamir would weigh it all and sit tight.
Mr. Bush knew he had a secret ally: The Israeli public, which was overwhelmingly against retaliating and whose feelings highly influenced Mr. Shamir. When Mr. Arens came to see Mr. Bush on Feb. 11 to tell him again that Israel had to do something, the President came armed with the latest Israeli public opinion polls tucked into his breast pocket.
 
The Soviet Mission
Gorbachev Envoy Makes a Last Try
 On Monday night, Feb. 11, Mr. Cheney visited the White House to tell the President that General Schwarzkopf had asked for a "window" of dates to begin the ground war,, with the earliest date being Feb. 21.
The President agreed that would be the planning date. Within a day or two, General Schwarzkopf refined his H-Hour as 4 A.M. on Feb. 24 (8 P..M. Feb. 23, Eastern time).
Once the military timing was set, a new factor came into play when the Soviet Union initiated its eleventh-hour attempt to mediate a face-saving withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
Administration officials said the first inkling came on Thursday, Feb. 14, in a cable sent by Mr. Gorbachev to Mr. Bush reporting on the discussions that his envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, had held in Baghdad the previous day with Mr. Hussein.
In his cable, Mr. Gorbachev said that Mr. Hussein displayed "some change in attitude" when pressed for an unconditional Iraqi pullout from Kuwait in accordance with the United Nations resolutions. This, he said, merited exploration.
Mr. Gorbachev, apparently under pressure from his military to show more independence from the United States and protect Iraq, a longtime client, from destruction, added in his cable that given the possibility for a peaceful solution, "it might be desirable" if the United States did not launch a ground war until talks with Mr. Aziz were completed.
In Washington, this was not received with enthusiasm.
"The initial feeling was that at the final moment of decision-making, this old ghost from the past got up to haunt us," a senior Administration official said. "We were well aware of the wreckage potential. From the start, the President took the view that Gorbachev, for domestic reasons, obviously needed to be seen to be playing a role. We had to reject that role, but not dismiss it in a way that would embarrass him."
Essentially from Monday night until noon on Saturday, President Bush and his advisers engaged in a dizzying series of phone calls and cables with Moscow to administer a mercy killing to the Soviet peace initiatve. Each day, Mr. Gorbachev would say he had brought the Iraqis a little closer to an unconditional withdrawal, and each day Mr. Bush would point out the conditional fine print that the Iraqis were adding -- particularly their insistence right up to the end that once they withdrew, all sanctions, reparations and other demands in the United Nations resolutions would have to be dropped.
The turning point came on Thursday night, when the President, having concluded that the Soviet diplomacy was getting out of hand, decided he wanted to put out a statement with his own terms for an Iraqi withdrawal in compliance with all the United Nations resolutions. During the White House deliberations, General Powell suggested to the President, "Why not just set a deadline?" on Friday for noon Saturday because a date would be helpful for his forces who were poised to attack at the already appointed hour of 8 P.M. Eastern Time, on Saturday.
Nevertheless, even Saturday morning the Soviets floated a new, "improved" plan at the United Nations Security Council, but when pressed by Washington, Moscow could not confirm that the Iraqis were on board. The Soviets were so unsure of where the Iraqis stood that they did not press the Security Council to vote on their plan, which Washington would have vetoed.
Summing up the whole experience with Mr. Gorbachev, a senior Administration official said: "He was acting to assert the interests of his various bureaucracies, but at the end of the day he was not ready to put his relationship with the United States on the line for those interests."
At noon Saturday, when the American ultimatum for Iraqi forces to be out of Kuwait expired, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker called Mr. Gorbachev.
They thanked him again for his efforts, reiterated why they were still considered insufficient, and told him that if he was in contact with the Iraqis, he should tell them "that they didn't believe it when we said that the air war would start right after Jan. 15 so they should believe this deadline," and get out while they still had a chance to save something.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations;
U.N. Approves Measure Bolstering Allies' Rights

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 2

 BODY:
The Security Council easily approved a resolution tonight that effectively endorses President Bush's call for allied troops to remain in the Persian Gulf until Iraq has complied with his peace terms.
The measure, approved in an 11-1 vote, also denies Baghdad an immediate formal cease-fire, and affirms the allies' right to attack again if their conditions are not met at the meeting on Sunday between military commanders of the allied coalition and of Iraq. 
 Of the Council's 15 members, only Cuba voted against the measure. China, India and Yemen abstained. The resolution came to a vote only after the Council rejected 18 Cuban amendments designed to change the measure to a simple call for a cease-fire.
The United States had been anxious for the Security Council to approve the resolution before the meeting on Sunday near the Iraq-Kuwait border, in which commanders from the two sides are to discuss the conditions set by Mr. Bush on a permanent end to hostilities. The resolution effectively approves those conditions.
 
13th Vote on Gulf Crisis
 The resolution was the 13th approved by the Security Council to address the gulf crisis since Iraq invaded Kuwait last August. The vote tonight suggested that international support for the United States' handling of the war is considerable, though somewhat diminished from a few weeks ago.
The 11 votes cast in favor of the resolution represented the smallest majority mustered by the United States on any of the gulf resolutions, though it was comfortably above the minimum of 9 needed for the measure to pass.
Many countries welcomed the new resolution as the first step toward a permanent settlement of the war and the resolution of wider Middle East problems, including the Palestinian issue and Israel's disputes with its Arab neighbors.
The United States representative at the United Nations, Thomas R Pickering, welcomed the vote. He said the resolution "turns our attention from a war we never wanted, from the tragedy precipitated by Iraq to the greatest challenge of all: building lasting peace and security."
He spoke indirectly of the need to address the region's other long-term problems, noting that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would soon depart for the Middle East to see what needs to be done "to insure the peace we have secured is a lasting one."
The Soviet representative, Yuri M. Vorontsov, was more explicit, declaring that the time had come for all countries to begin focusing on resolving the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait and other issues troubling the Middle East.
 
Text Preserves Option of Force
 The resolution affirms that the coalition allies have suspended fighting only to give Iraq a chance to comply with Mr. Bush's demands. It makes it clear that the allies retain the right to attack again if Iraq refuses to do so.
After listing the allies' demands, the resolution specifically recognizes that, during the time Iraq needs to comply with these terms, the provisions of paragraph 2 of Resolution 678 remain valid. That paragraph authorized the allies "to use all necessary means" to evict Iraq from Kuwait, including force.
Under the resolution, the principal conditions Iraq must meet before the allies will agree to a "definitive end to the hostilities" include the return of all P.O.W's and about 17,000 Kuwaiti civilian detainees, the repeal of all Iraqi laws annexing Kuwait, acceptance by Baghdad of its liability for war losses and damages and an end to Scud missile attacks and other provocations against Israel or any other countries in the region.
 
Sanctions Remain for Now
 In addition, Iraq is required to return war dead and to help in locating mines and booby traps and to reveal the sites of chemical and biological weapons. It must also send its commanders to discuss these and other matters with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the allied commander.
The text makes it clear that the economic and trade sanctions imposed by the Council on Iraq remain in effect. It sets no conditions or date for lifting them.

HEADLINE: Man Held in Forest Hills Sex Attacks

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
A 25-year-old Manhattan man was charged last night in a series of six sex attacks and robberies that had cast a pall of fear over Forest Hills, Queens, since September.
The police identified the suspect as Roy Hickman, of 252 West 149th Street in Manhattan. He was picked up at 9 P.M. Friday on a street in the exclusive Forest Hills Garden section, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Edward J. Burns. Two patrolman assigned to the 112th Precinct thought he fit the general description of the assailant, who often ended his attacks by slashing his victims. 
 The officers, Steven Haynes and Eric Crumbly, noticed a bulge in Mr. Hickman's clothing and found a knife with a 12-inch blade, the police said.
"We feel comfortable that we have the right individual, through the physical evidence that we have and statements that have been made by this individual," said Capt. Barry Noxon, commanding officer of the 17th Division.
 
Apartment Searched
 Members of the Queens Sex Crimes Squad and the Queens Homicide Task Force obtained a search warrant and went to Mr. Hickman's Harlem apartment, where he lives with his mother and stepfather, Sergeant Burns said.
The police said they found two knives in the apartment that they believe might be connected to the crimes. They also found property that belonged to two victims, Sergeant Burns said.
Captain Noxon would not explain what the property was, saying only that it was a "significant find."
At least five lineups had been conducted by last night, Captain Noxon said. "We had good results," he said.
Late last night, Mr. Hickman's stepfather, Green Dasher, 77, dressed in pajamas and bathrobe and moving around their fourth-floor tenement apartment with the aid of a cane, said he could not believe Mr. Hickman could commit the crimes with which he was charged.
"It's hard to believe," Mr. Dasher, a retired clothes presser, said. "He just don't seem like that kind of boy. I just hope he's not the one."
Mr. Dasher said Mr. Hickman was unemployed but had been a street peddler at one point.
Mr. Hickman had lived with his father, who died several years ago of a stroke. He then moved in with his mother, Lila Merchant, also a retired presser, and Mr. Dasher about a year ago.
Mr. Dasher said his stepson had few friends in the neighborhood but had a girlfriend somewhere in New Jersey.
 
Other Links Sought

In the first of the series of attacks, Mr. Hickman was charged with sexual abuse and robbery for an incident on Sept. 16. He is also charged with sexual abuse and robbery on Oct. 29, rape and robbery on Feb. 6, robbery on Feb. 11, rape and robbery on Feb. 21 and sexual abuse and robbery on Feb. 26.
Captain Noxon said the police were investigating to see whether Mr. Hickman might be linked to other sex crimes.
Most of the attacks took place in the Forest Hills Gardens neighborhood, a wealthy enclave within Forest Hills, of stately Tudor homes around the West Side Tennis Club. It is considered a relatively safe area, but after the attacks, the fear of many residents intensified.
The Sex Crimes Squad and Homicide Task Force tried to trace a pattern and a "script" for the rapist by interviewing the victims and scores of residents and merchants in the area, said Captain Noxon. The description and pattern that emerged were given to police officers before they began patrol each shift. He said Officers Haynes and Crumbley zeroed in on the subject and then felt he was evasive in answering their questions when asked what he was doing in the neighborhood.
 
Police Cite 'Viciousness'

Some of the women were accosted near the subway station at Continental Avenue and 71st Street. In the most recent assault last Tuesday night, a man forced a teen-age girl at knifepoint into a yard he tried to rape her.
What marked the attacks was what Captain Noxon called the "viciousness" of the slashing.
"The slashing after the incident, the cutting of the throat areas, that was his trademark," said Captain Noxon. "That seemed to be the thing that stood out, that made it espcially vicious."
He added, "It appeared he escalated his viciousness, escalated his daring as we studied the assaults."
Mr. Hickman was charged with two counts of rape and robbery, three counts of sexual abuse and robbery, one count of robbery, and in each case, criminal psossesion of deadly weapon, Sergeant Burns said.
Mr. Hickman had been picked up by the transit police on two occasions for fare-beating in the subway: in 1986 and again on Feb. 13, both times in Manhattan, said Sergeant Burns.
Mr. Dasher, the stepfather, said Mr. Hickman would stay around the apartment "for a week at a time."
"Sometimes he would go out at 6 and come back at 3 or 4 in the morning," Mr. Dasher said.
"Nobody around here knows him," Mr. Dasher said. "When he leaves here, he goes downtown -- at least that's what he says."
Asked why a suspect who lived in Manhattan might choose Queens for victims, Captain Noxon said, "It will be something that as the investigation continues, we'll find out -- why he was attracted to this area."

HEADLINE: Yachting;
Japan's Plan for a Major Effort

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
The day starts out simply enough for the 30 crewmen of Japan's America's Cup challenge team.
There is an hour of exercise: running, swimming or working out on weight machines at the team's compound, a sprawling apartment complex close to where the boats are docked at Mission Bay. Then there is breakfast. 
 Bowls of miso soup and seaweed, pan-fried fish, rice and green tea set a hearty oriental table. But how to explain the miniature boxes of breakfast cereals, the toast, yogurt, fried eggs, hot dogs and coffee?
Hikaru Shiraishi eats frankfurters by skewering them with the tips of his chopsticks. And Yoshiya Sasaki is adept at folding a fried egg in half and eating it with one gulp. But the Western dishes have other palates to please, those of the five New Zealand yachtsmen who form the sailing backbone of Japan's first effort in history to win the America's Cup.
Few question the Nippon's potential successes in the computer-driven aspects of boat design. But finding experienced crewmen in Japan's fledgling yachting community was like spotting a buoy in fog-shrouded Sagami Bay near Tokyo.
Kaoru Ogimi, vice commodore of Japan's cup sponsor, the Nippon Ocean Racing Club, said recently in San Diego that his team was forced to look outside Japan for a crew.
"The big question mark is, of course, the people, the software side," said Ogimi. The syndicate's answer was to hire Chris Dickson of New Zealand, the top-ranked match-racing skipper in the world.
"What we've been doing around the clock with him in our own camp is trying to reach out and go beyond Chris," said Ogimi.
To make the best use of Dickson's expertise, the Nippon group in 1987 bought two former America's Cup yachts to use as training vessels. The boats happened to be the same 12-Meters, KZ 3 and KZ 5, that Dickson and his teammates sailed to a near victory four years ago in cup trial races in Australia.
The purchase was designed to help Japanese sailors prepare for even bigger boats: the new 76- to 78-foot International America's Cup Class yachts that will be sailed in the 1992 cup races here.
"None of us have ever sailed in boats in any size approximating these," said Ogimi of the $2 million racing craft. The America's Cup class boats are 10 feet longer than most 12-Meters, and one-third lighter. They carry far more sail area, and are faster downwind by 6 or 7 knots.
Even Dickson, who has sailed on everything from a seven-foot dinghy to an 80-foot maxi-boat, is impressed with the new class.
"These boats portray power," he said, while standing on the deck of JPN 6, the second of the syndicate's two identical new America's Cup class yachts. "When you look up, you see a cloud of sail. Suddenly it feels like a tiny little boat with a huge amount of sail area."
A budget of six billion yen, about $40 million, has fueled the syndicate's extensive costs of research and development. From a country rich in naval architecture through its commercial shipbuilding, Japanese experts have turned their attention to sailboats.
At Nippon's 45,000-square-foot compound on Mission Bay, a new sail loft is taking shape. Four trailers and 12 shipping containers -- a combination of 20- and 40-footers -- serve as space for offices, a machine shop, computer center and storage space.
The promise of competition looms large. Syndicates from Italy, New Zealand and France are also in San Diego. By year's end, 12 challenge teams and two defenders are expected be sailing.
Dickson had his first crack at sailing one of Japan's freshly built cup boats last April. He and his crew launched the new breed of yachts in Gamagori City, Nippon's training camp 200 miles southwest of Tokyo. The boats were shipped to San Diego in mid-January.
For starters, the 29-year-old Dickson and the 40-year-old Makoto Namba, his Japanese team captain, had to teach many on the crew how to sail. The first recruits answered newspaper advertisements placed by the syndicate. The ads called for individuals at least 175 centimeters tall (6 feet) and weighing at least 82 kilograms (170 pounds).
Nearly 300 people, most with weak sailing skills but strong athletic backgrounds, responded. One man thought he was trying out for a golf tournament. Ten were chosen after a battery of physical and psychological testing. Known within the syndicate as the green crew, the novice sailors have put in more than 8,000 hours on the water since then.
Takashi Kawahara, a Nippon sail trimmer, was working in Japan as a pig farmer when he read the ad. Jin Matsubara was a young businessman in Tokyo who sailed for a hobby. He was inspired to answer the crew ad by a video he had once seen of the 1983 cup races.
Shiraishi, a professional diver, remembers being overwhelmed the first time he joined the Nippon sailing team.
"I didn't know the winch name," he said last week. "I didn't know anything. Someone told me to ease something, but I didn't know what ease meant."
Others confess to falling overboard now and again, and embarrassment unbecoming to a seasoned yachtsman.
Language was a barrier at first, and to some degree, still is. There were reports that friction had developed on the boat during the early days because of communication problems. Dickson and Namba insist that those days are gone.
"Big-boat sailing is very systematic," said Namba at the docks last week. "Once we have established the system, there are not many opportunities to express yourself any other way."
Namba, who commented through an interpreter, speaks limited English. But at crew meetings, he speaks in English.
The team returned two weeks ago from a three-week vacation. The prospect of a world championship May 4-11 here for the new cup boats -- a kind of dress rehearsal for the America's Cup trials next winter -- has thrown training into high gear six days a week.
Plans to sail last week were stopped short by an unusual turn of events in drought-ravaged California: rain and wind in San Diego. Dickson, who is known for keeping his crew on a short leash, gave them free rein in deciding whether to sail on Thursday.
"We took a vote," said Dickson, "and we feel this isn't a good day to go out." Dickson, whose boyish looks belie a voice of authority, left no room for second-guessing.
Rain deluged the boat yard minutes later. Wind instruments on the boats measured the velocity at 25 knots and higher. In a yacht where a new mast made of carbon fiber costs $250,000, chance is not part of the game.
Thirty well-heeled Japanese companies are behind the Nippon effort. Each has donated about $650,000 to join, a roster that organizers say hinges more on national pride than economic returns.
Tatsumitsu Yamasaki, a wealthy entrepreneur and avid yachtsman who founded the syndicate, has spoken of the America's Cup as an "irrational passion" and a "noble goal."
But the Japanese propensity for achieving also drives the syndicate.
"Japan is trying to catch up with the rest of the world," said Emili Miuri, a Nippon spokeswoman. "They have achieved in many other ways, and even moved forward. But in sport and culture, they have not caught up."

A member of the kitchen staff preparing breakfast, Japanese style. (Photographs by Nippon Challenge, top, Robert Burroughs for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: When Bigger Trucks Get on the Road

 BODY:
The article on triple trailers in New Jersey raises a very distasteful argument that says a measure of highway safety should be sacrificed for the benefit of greater profits of trucking and trucking-dependent industries.
That argument should not be allowed to sway Federal legislators who are considering amending the Federal Highway Reauthorization Act to permit carrying weights of trucks to increase, from 80,000 pounds to 137,000 pounds. To carry that much weight would require trucking companies to use triple trailers.
The trucking industry claims it needs the bigger trucks to increase productivity, but productivity should not be attained at the cost of safety. I am all for increased productivity, but trucks are now involved in a disproportionate amount of fatal accidents and are responsible for about 5,000 deaths in New Jersey each year. Allowing bigger trucks to carry more weight on our highways is to invite disaster for motorists.
New Jersey is too densely populated and its highways too heavily traveled to accommodate triple trailers. We also have a disproportionate number of elderly drivers who could easily be unnerved by the highway competition offered by huge triple trailers.
I am not unsympathetic to the argument from the trucking industry that increases in fuel costs have cut into profits. However, fuel price increases are not the fault of New Jersey motorists, and they should not be exposed to increased risk of death because of the failure of the Reagan and Bush Administrations to develop an energy policy that would hold down the cost of fuel.
As we have recently witnessed, the major oil companies have racked up obscene profits in 1990, indicating that truck fuel price increases are not warranted and should be rolled back, which will do a great deal to help truckers and consumers.
A more pertinent economic argument to be considered is who will pay for the damage to New Jersey roads caused by triple trailers. That damage, either through wear and tear from trucks or through the increased accidents they cause, will have to be paid by New Jersey taxpayers.
The Federal Government, under President Bush, has backed away from its long-held responsibility to finance highway repair. Greater stress on New Jersey's infrastructure caused by giant trucks will mean higher taxes for our taxpayers.
I am uncompromisingly opposed to allowing triple trailers on our highways, and I have petitioned our state's Congressional representatives to oppose any Federal legislation that would allow such monsters on our highways.
 
WILLIAM J. PASCRELL JR.
Assemblyman, District 35
Passaic-Bergen

HEADLINE: Phases of War: Politics;
Did Someone Say 'Domestic Policy'?

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was a familiar political tableau: A Republican President confidently striding across the center stage of foreign policy, while a chorus of Democrats stood in the wings, saying, "Yes, but...."
What about the economy, Democrats began to ask last week. What about education, the environment, health care, civil rights? Where is President Bush's domestic agenda? Their voices, however, barely broke through the cheers as the war in the Persian Gulf wound down. 
 Mr. Bush's approval rating was at 86 percent, while Republican strategists charted a surge of national optimism in the public opinion polls. "It's morning again in America," said Richard Reed, a Republican polltaker, referring to the triumphant slogan of Ronald Reagan's 1984 re-election campaign.
Assuming that Mr. Bush's successes in foreign policy hold, a key dynamic of the 1992 Presidential campaign may have already emerged: Democrats arguing that the nation must address an array of domestic problems, while Mr. Bush offers himself as a tested, seasoned Commander in Chief.
Mr. Bush may need an aggressive new domestic policy for the judgment of history, but does he need one for re-election? He obviously must worry about the economy, but must he match the Democrats, program for program, on all the other domestic problems that register in the public opinion polls? These questions seem minor compared to the challenge the Democrats face in finding a nominee who could compete against a President who has just won a popular war.
"Voters view national security as the single most important quality in a President, and they have always been unwilling to take risks with it," said Robert Teeter, a top political adviser to Mr. Bush. "Voters have concluded that the one time they did that over the past 20 years, it was a mistake." He was referring to the Carter Presidency, a favorite point of reference last week for some of the more partisan Republicans as they basked in victory.
Democratic analysts, by and large, did not minimize their predicament. "Being Commander in Chief became larger in the Presidential job description because of the war in the gulf, and it will be harder for Democrats, for Democratic candidates, to prove that they're up to that part of the job," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker. "The historical reality is, this is exactly the reason voters elect a George Bush rather than a Michael Dukakis."
 
Changing the Subject
 Yet some Democrats privately worry that their nominating system is likely to produce yet another outsider in 1992, with views on national security closer to those of the party's liberal wing than those of the general electorate. In the meantime, even as Democrats made the first gentle attempts to turn the discussion to domestic policy, they were careful to hail the President and the allied victory.
"The country deserves and needs to appreciate the fullness of this success," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader and potential Presidential candidate. "Clearly, the President gets and deserves credit for sticking with his policy, putting the coalition together, and skillfully leading the military to a very positive conclusion." Such deference was the norm among Democrats last week.
This was no Panama or Grenada, events that held the public's attention for a matter of days or weeks and then vanished from the television screens. The gulf crisis dominated the nation's psyche for seven months -- week after week of People Magazine stories on the troops in the desert, song dedications on the radio to spouses and lovers "in Saudi," yellow ribbons everywhere and local blood drives.
As a result, Operation Desert Storm will probably produce more than a short-term spike in the President's popularity, said John Mueller, a professor of political science at the University of Rochester and the author of "War, Presidents and Public Opinion."
"I think it's likely to linger for a substantial period of time," he said. "The best analogy is probably Maggie Thatcher and the Falklands. She was able to ride the crest of that for quite a while."
Many analysts say the war was also a remarkable confidence-builder for a generation that was bred on bitter memories of Vietnam. These were the powerful chords that Mr. Bush was striking last week. "It's a proud day for America and, by God, we've kicked the Vietnam syndrome once and for all," the President said.
Depending on how long the afterglow lasts, and how much the economy begins to improve, the Democrats could face a strategic dilemma as the 1992 campaign begins: How to make the case for change without leaving themselves open to the charge of being "gloom and doom Democrats," as the Republicans put it so often.
"When Americans love themselves and their country and feel good about themselves, I don't think the Democratic platform is very appealing," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee and one of the most partisan voices in Washington.
Some Democrats sought comfort in the case of Winston Churchill, a revered wartime leader who saw his Conservative Party defeated at the polls three months after the surrender of Germany, as British voters turned to domestic needs and wants. A foreign-policy Presidency is not enough, they suggest; Americans will want something more. This argument, however, overlooks the fact that this is not a parliamentary system and Americans choose a President, not a party.
The White House recognizes that it cannot seem indifferent to domestic concerns. The President paused last week to give a domestic policy address, although it revolved around proposals previously advanced, such as tougher crime laws and greater opportunities for parents to choose the schools their children can attend.
Two days later, the Administration turned its attention to civil rights and protection against job discrimination, a subject that prompted a lengthy fight with Congress last year. But the measure the Administration proposed late Friday night ---- not the most opportune time to release new initiatives ---- was largely a rehash of the proposals Congress had spurned last year.
The President's critics say his domestic agenda has been a combination of rhetoric, political positioning, and change around the margins. Many cited the Administration's recently released energy policy as an example of Mr. Bush's lackluster interest in domestic affairs. Many of his fellow Republicans are urging the President to use his newly enhanced popularity -- as Mrs. Thatcher used hers -- to push through new domestic programs.
But if the economy improves, Mr. Bush may be able to pursue his passion at little political cost and be, essentially, a foreign-policy President. Until Democrats produce a nominee with credibility as a potential Commander in Chief, they will continue to plead the case for domestic problems -- but from Capitol Hill.

HEADLINE: Done.;
A Short, Persuasive Lesson In Warfare

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
THE 42-day war in the Persian Gulf Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf's hit-hard, hurry-up, high-tech, hyper-successful campaign to savage Iraq's military and oust it from Kuwait -- was a study in lessons learned.
In a political, military and especially a psychological sense, it drew a line beneath the hauntingly inconclusive Vietnam tragedy. The United States will not soon forget its sins and humiliations in Southeast Asia a generation ago, but it has learned from them, and as President Bush exulted on Friday, "By God, we've kicked the Vietnam syndrome once and for all." 
 The list of lessons is long, but start with this trio.
* Never go to war before insuring domestic consensus and establishing international support. Lyndon B. Johnson never managed to do either; George Bush did both, with a master's touch. The President coaxed Congress to the point of backing a war -- not by much, but by enough to carry him through a few weeks or a few months -- and he and his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, built and maintained an international coalition that cut across lines of economic, religious, political, ideological, regional and even personal conflict. They said it couldn't last, but it did.
 
The First Principle
 * Never go to war without a clear objective. Lieut. Gen. Thomas Kelly, the avuncular oracle of the Pentagon these past weeks, called it "the first principle of war" -- a target, clearly designated and steadfastly lit by the politicians, that the generals and admirals could take a bead on. Mr. Bush must have said five times a day for six months that Saddam Hussein had to leave Kuwait, without conditions, to satisy the United States. No such goal was ever convincingly articulated for the Vietnam adventure.
* Take no half measures. Mr. Bush gave his commanders the troops they said they needed, right away, instead of feeding them in slowly. He granted no sanctuaries to the enemy. He resisted the inevitable calls for a cease-fire until he judged the job done, lest he give the Iraqis a chance to catch their breath, rearm and fight again. Those three decisions enabled General Schwarzkopf to develop and execute a strategy that placed the heaviest fighting squarely on President Saddam Hussein's own territory, brought American firepower to bear all at once and kept it there to do the job. The result was clearest, perhaps, in the casualty figures -- the staggering gap between the 89 Americans known to have been killed and the tens of thousands of Iraqis dead on the battlefield, as well as even vaster numbers taken prisoner.
There were old lessons, too, left over from other wars in other decades, other centuries, but no less apt for that. Here are seven:
* Deception can be worth a dozen divisions. General Schwarzkopf assembled all the paraphernalia and manpower for amphibious operations, practiced amphibious operations and talked about amphibious operations. But they were never part of his basic plan. He fooled his foe into wasting thousands of men and guns. On an elaborate battle model of Kuwait City discovered in a school on Thursday, every Iraqi gun and troop unit in the region of the capital faced the sea, like the guns of Singapore during World War II. They were of little use in combating invaders coming from other directions.
* Without air cover, tanks are tin gasoline cans, just waiting to blow up. When the Luftwaffe could no longer protect him, Rommel lost in North Africa; when the clouds that had protected him finally parted, von Rundstedt lost the Battle of the Bulge; with his air force destroyed or dispersed and his attack helicopters -- Soviet, French and German -- mysteriously uninvolved, Mr. Hussein could do nothing to protect his T-72's and T-62's from American tanks and, especially, the terrifying Hellfire missiles fired by the army's Apache helicopters and the equally deadly Mavericks fired by A-10 Warthog attack planes flown by the Air Force.
* In the desert, supply is everything. Armies can live off the land, to a degree, in many parts of the world, but not in the sands of Arabia, where nature is an implacable enemy. Again, air supremacy made the difference. It meant American logistics specialists, under a tough general from Pennsylvania named Gus Pagonis, could move mountains, and allied forces had 10 of everything, thousands of miles from home; it meant many front-line Iraqi troops had so little they ate grass and hoarded cups of rainwater.
* Modern weapons become obsolete terrifyingly quickly, which is why maintaining modern armed forces costs so much. For all the oil wealth he squandered on arms, Saddam Hussein went to war against the United States -- cruise missiles, Stealth bombers, electronic countermeasures and all -- with an air-defense system that was a generation or two out of date.
* Men matter as much as machines, and there the Iraqi forces were outclassed in two ways. One was training, skill, sheer ability. "Not everything depends on the quality of the technology," said Nikolai Kutsenko, a ranking military planner in the Soviet Union, which supplied so much of Iraq's best equipment. "More depends on the professional training of those who use and service it, and both, in the Iraqi Army, left much to be desired."
So did the troops' morale, a second key area of deficiency. For that, General Schwarzkopf blamed a leadership "so uncaring that in the end they could keep them there only at the point of a gun."
* If you can't communicate, you can't command. Battlefield evidence collected by Marines showed chemical weapons ready for use, but orders never came from the top. And the total lack of coordination between squadrons of tanks and between tanks and artillery in the big battle that ended the war convinced American armored commanders that their adversaries were operating with nothing approaching adequate radio links between units.
* Get around him, if you can, and hit him from the flank or the rear, rather than marching into his strength. Talking military history long before he launched last week's ground offensive, General Schwarzkopf often dwelt on Cannae, the epic battle in the heel of the Italian boot in which Hannibal perfected the double envelopment. The American commander used a single envelopment to equally good effect, forcing the Republican Guards, potential battle-winners, to fight on his ground at a time of his choosing.
In Vietnam, the United States overestimated its own power and prowess and underestimated that of the enemy. Here, it was just the opposite.
Saddam Hussein proved to be as full of folly on the battlefield as in the halls of diplomacy, relying on a Maginot line as easily flankable as the original, making his tanks vulnerable by digging them into the sand and robbing them of their mobility.
It proved impossible for a nation with the population of the Netherlands and the gross domestic product of Portugal even to dent a coalition that included the United States, Europe and two of the main Arab military powers.
On the other side of the line, the new, all-volunteer American military, with its new, smart weapons, proved formidable. Especially the Air Force, Naval air and Army air, which severed the enemy's logistical lifelines, scrambled his communications, blinded his reconnaissance eyes and finally killed his advanced tanks, his last best hope of averting disaster.
As Col. Hal Hornburg, a top Air Force pilot, said, it took the grunts to apply the coup de grace. It always does. But air power decided it.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Budget Chief: Disarming Critics With a New Tact And Good Behavior

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FEW public servants have ever commanded a process as complex as the Federal budget more completely than Richard A. Darman.
Nor have many unelected officials ever commanded so much attention and intermittent controversy as has Mr. Darman, President Bush's Director of the Office of Management and Budget. 
 When he writes a budget message, it makes interesting reading. When he testifies, intellectual sparks fly. But more spectators at those hearings come for entertainment than enlightenment, waiting to see whether questions that he regards as stupid or mean or baiting get his goat.
So when Congress and the Bush Administration get down to the business of proving whether they can keep the budget agreement they made last fall -- the first tests come this week on supplemental appropriations in the House -- Mr. Darman is likely to be one major flash point.
The tests this week will not come over paying for Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm, but over what other expenditures can justly be deemed "emergency" spending (the agreement allowed for emergencies). Many lawmakers want to recompense Israel and Turkey, but especially Israel, for the costs the war imposed on their military and civil defense forces.
Mr. Darman testified firmly on Tuesday against Senators pressing an Israeli request for $1 billion to cover the costs of air force alerts, gas masks and other items. He said "emergency" meant, in effect, "Is this needed yesterday, today, or tomorrow?" The Israeli request did not meet that test, he said.
"It's not an immediate emergency the way coming up with the funds and the legal authorization to allow certain kinds of security expenses and equipment to be installed at certain airports here right away or covering the extra costs of security at the Capitol immediately for the overtime and so on -- those are immediate needs."
He spoke bluntly, avoiding the bureaucratese that had led him to say "if indeed the war does suddenly clarify favorably in the next some number of days" (in English: if the war ends soon).
But by Thursday James A. Baker 3d was telling House leaders that the Administration had not decided whether to support "emergency" aid for Israel and Turkey, and leaving them with the impression that it would decide in favor.
For someone whose every word is scrutinized for hidden, political, even Machiavellian motives, this was probably a case where Mr. Darman was trying to be unpolitical and loyal to the literal meaning of the budget agreement. He appeared to have no agenda more subtle than trying to hold down Federal spending by putting the Israeli request into a nonemergency category. Under the terms of the budget deal, meeting the request would require cutting somewhere else. One "emergency" could lead to another; aid to Israel could lead to grants to hire unemployment compensation workers, or new aid for veterans.
This is really the closest thing to a controversy Mr. Darman has got into this year on the Hill, a far cry from his experiences in 1989 and 1990. In 1989 the Democrats were furious at him because they felt he was using budget talks they had counted on to face the deficits of the Reagan years to do nothing more than push for a capital gains tax cut.
That problem largely solved itself in 1990, when he supported tax increases, but that infuriated most House Republicans.
This year he has gone out of his way to court his House G.O.P. critics. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the G.O.P. leader and a target of some of the same wrath Mr. Darman felt, praised the director for spending time giving House Republicans an unusually thorough advance look at the budget. "He's tried to level with them," Mr. Michel said.
And Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgian who revolted at the budget deals even though he serves as House G.O.P. whip, credited Mr. Darman with "moving toward a more conservative position."
The budget message, Mr. Gingrich said, "had everything a reform-oriented Republican could ask for," with its themes of turning some Federal programs over to the states, encouraging ownership in public housing, and limiting Federal aid, in a few programs, for those with high incomes.
Those same ideas drew some very hostile questioning early last month from two House Democrats who share Mr. Darman's reputation for a high I.Q.: Representatives Barney Frank of Massachusetts and Jim Cooper of Tennessee.
Each had only five minutes for interrogation. Mr. Frank insisted that the Federal aid cuts accomplished little and were not really focused on the rich, and kept interrupting Mr. Darman's replies to get more questions in. Mr. Darman didn't like it and was hardly mollified when the committee chairman, Leon V. Panetta of California, tried to explain that "whoever discusses things with Mr. Frank only gets one word in for every four words he says."
Then came Mr. Cooper, with suspicions that Mr. Darman, by suggesting that some programs not pay the well-off, "would be undercutting the national consensus that has built and preserved these programs." Mr. Darman said that wasn't his purpose, but Mr. Cooper pressed on, asking why there were no means tests for tax breaks that helped the rich. That was too much for the director. Mr. Darman allowed that "a lot of times it takes me a lot of energy to keep my natural tendencies under proper control at the witness table." He said he did not respect Mr. Cooper's challenge to his purposes and lectured him, as he had Mr. Frank, telling him to check with people who had been on the committee longer than they had to learn more of his good motives.
In some ways it was a classic performance. He did answer the substantive questions, among the most thoughtful in a hearing where a lot of members were concerned about how the budget affected much narrower constituencies, but he also showed a thin skin and demanded acknowledgments of respect.
Has he mellowed? Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who chairs the Senate Budget Committee and says he likes Mr. Darman, coyly responds, "I find Dick Darman just as charming this year as he has been in the past."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Where Have All the Jobs Gone? Follow the Crab Grass

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
ENCASED in the millions of statistics the Census Bureau is releasing on what America looked like in 1990 are a few big mysteries about this decade.
What the data show is that the United States is becoming ever more a suburban nation. For the first time a majority of Americans lives within 39 metropolitan areas of a million residents or more. There is unparalleled growth in jobs and population away from the confines of the old central cities. 
 Among the things that this shift seems to portend is a national labor gap, in which the employers have distanced themselves from the employable, the poor minority group population that will comprise the largest pool of new workers in the coming decade.
When the next census is taken in the year 2000, some of the key questions will be: Did the minorities move to the suburbs? Did the jobs move back to the cities? Or did American society find some other solution to the dilemma it created for itself in the 1980's?
Starting in the mid-1970's and then at an ever faster pace in the 1980's, former bedroom communities were converted into major economic centers. The results are clearly evident in the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area, where there are now five suburbs with populations greater than 100,000.
"Cheaper land available in large tracts and easy access to a Dallas-Fort Worth airport has meant that some suburbs have been steadily expanding their employment base in manufacturing by 17 or 18 percent over the past 20 years while the city of Dallas has lost more than a quarter of its manufacturing jobs," said Bernard Weinstein, director of the Center for Economic Development and Research at the University of North Texas.
The same has happened in the San Francisco Bay area, Orange County, Calif., and the environs of Atlanta, but it is not just a Sunbelt phenomenon. Gleaming new plants to produce high-tech gizmos sprouted in a broad crescent around Boston and in some of New York City's suburbs.
"What this is about is families," said Florence Shapiro, Mayor of Plano, Tex., a Dallas suburb that is among the fastest growing cities in the nation.
"We have a lot of young couples who were go-getters in the 1980's," she said, "and they wanted to raise their children with others who enjoyed the same life style and the same values and they wanted good schools and they didn't want to worry about crime. After they started coming here, the jobs followed."
The nation's new suburban cities are products of the same impetus that has led the white middle class away from the cities since the 1950's. Despite the arrival of some blacks and Hispanic residents, the suburbs remain far whiter than the urban cores. They continue to offer better schools, less crime and usually a lighter tax burden. Their appeal continues to be that they are a world apart.
As a second generation of Americans, the children of the baby boomers, is reared in the suburbs, challenges arise from the changing geography. The suburbs have developed as a separate culture in America. In the 1980's they captured political power as a main constituency for the political shift to conservatism, and they began to amass economic power by becoming employment centers. But they are not self-sufficient.
Entrenched in the suburbs, the baby boomers in the 1980's grabbed the lion's share of new jobs as white women joined the labor force. But the baby boom is peaking as a contributor of new workers. In the 1990's, it will be the large, poor minority groups that will have to start filling the ranks.
A growing number of city politicians, business and minority group leaders and labor market experts find that an unbridgeable gulf is developing between work places in predominately white suburbs and the inner-city neighborhoods.
"For the disadvantaged in America the three great symbols of social opportunity have been the Statue of Liberty, the Underground Railroad and the covered wagon," said John D. Kasarda, director of the Center for Competitiveness and Employment Growth at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
Professor Kasarda argues that the genius of the ever changing American economy has been its ability to move workers, including those in the lowest wage categories, to where new jobs were being created. This has been true, he says, whether it was immigrants crossing the Atlantic, blacks streaming from the rural South to the urban North or settlers heading West.
"Throughout our history spatial mobility and economic mobility have gone hand in hand," he said. "Now for the first time that connection has been broken."
He argues that inner-city residents, already beset with disadvantages, are now further separated from the best economic opportunities by the logistical and financial burdens of traveling to suburban work places. Also playing a role, he says, are discrimination and social welfare programs, like public housing projects, which have anchored the poor to core areas.
Some experts who have rejected this emphasis on geography in the past now view it more favorably given what happened in the 1980's. For example, David Ellwood, a prominent Harvard economist, coined a much-cited phrase in a paper he wrote in 1986: "It doesn't seem to be space; it's race." He now says: "I am starting to see some real disadvantages coming from the movement of jobs to the suburbs. There is no question that in the 1980's it aggravated the problems of the urban poor."
Professor Ellwood views geography as one factor in the isolation of the most disadvantaged in society.
"There's a structural change and the location of jobs is part of it," he says, "but so is the location of good school systems and the location of people who work and can share information about jobs. Living in the ghetto is detrimental not just because there are no jobs down the street but because there are no people down the street with jobs."
When all the census results are in, it will be possible to make precise measurements of the distance between declining urban neighborhoods and new suburban factories. But, in the 1990's the distance will be measured not just in miles but also in skills that go untransmitted, in knowledge of opportunities that go unshared and in a labor force that grows only with great effort.

HEADLINE: The World;
On the Edge, In the Lands That Wrote The Book

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN addition to good wines and cheeses, rousing folk music and rich poetry, the Balkans have given the world the term "Balkanization" -- for the breakup of countries along ethnic lines into antagonistic fragments.
Employed originally a century ago to describe what was happening to the moribund Ottoman Empire's possessions in southeastern Europe, with its 70 million people and bewildering quilt of nationalities and religions, the term has acquired new currency in recent weeks as parts of the region threaten to go over the brink. 
 The most extreme case is Yugoslavia, a federation of six republics that started life at the end of World War II as a centrally controlled Communist state. It is now a fragile shell displaying numerous cracks, with two northern republics talking of breaking away.
 Late last month, Slovenia's democratically elected parliament adopted legislation permitting it to "disassociate" from Yugoslavia. Within hours, Croatia's parliament approved legislation giving its own laws supremacy over the laws of the federation.
Some politicians in these republics are floating the idea of "two Yugoslavias," while a third variant might simply be no Yugoslavia at all -- with the country replaced by a gaggle of Balkanized entities locked in mutual hostility.
On Friday, leaders of five of the six republics convened in Belgrade in an attempt to solidify a consensus on basic finance and banking measures needed to extricate a whole Yugoslavia from its Communist economic heritage. Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, boycotted the meeting, while Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, stubbornly continued to pursue the chauvinistic policies that set off the Balkanization threat in the first place.
Another uncertainty is the role of the Yugoslav National Army, recruited from all republics but dominated by officers from Serbia. Would they stand idle if the federation collapsed?
New strains have appeared in other Balkan countries, most notably Albania, the poorest nation of Europe. After 46 years under the twin shadows of Stalinist rule and self-imposed isolation, Albania is now staggering -- with incidents of bloodshed -- toward democracy. Multiparty elections are scheduled for March 31.
Were it a matter alone for the 3.5 million citizens under the Tirana regime, the current tumult in Albania would not matter so much for the rest of the region. But in neighboring Yugoslavia there are close to 3 million ethnic Albanians, most subjected to severe political repression in Serbia. A breakup of federal Yugoslavia would automatically heighten aspirations of these 6 million ethnic brothers to join hands across the mountain-ringed borders.
As if to underline that old Albanian ideal, Ibrahim Rugova, head of the Kosovo Democratic Alliance, the largest political formation of Albanians in Yugoslavia, visited Tirana last week. His meetings with President Ramiz Alia, the Communist chief, and with leaders of the new democratic opposition parties represented the first time in almost half a century that top-level officials from the two separate regions inhabited by Albanians encountered one another.
The fragility of the infant post-Communist governments of Romania and Bulgaria, both beset by economic misery, must also be included in any accounting of the security situation of the Balkans.
Ethnic minority problems also persist in Romania, with its 1.5 million Hungarians, and in Bulgaria, with its 1 million Turks. Even Greece, the only country in the region that is a member of the European Community, has barely disguised minority problems.
Balkan derives from the Turkish word for mountain; in 1808, a German geographer, believing that Bulgaria's Balkan Mountains stretched across the whole region, coined the term Balkan Peninsula. In the shortened form, "the Balkans," it stuck.
Nationality conflicts gave rise early in the century to the phrase "Balkan powder keg." The region was, after all, the site of the first and second Balkan Wars and, with the assassination in Sarajevo of the Austrian Archduke in 1914, was the place where World War I was ignited.
The difference between then and now is that at the beginning of the century, the great powers of the day -- all European -- were engaged in keen rivalry over the Balkans. That wrestling over spheres of interest had a softer echo in the cold war contest between the Western powers and the Soviet Union, whose influence and empire include much of the Balkans.
Today, the Soviet Union is so preoccupied with its own internal threat of Balkanization that it seemed almost relieved to sign off last week on the end of the Warsaw Pact, the military alliance that also had its Balkan components. Nor does any other great power covet parts or the whole of the Balkans.
Still, the possibility of Yugoslavia's collapse is deeply troubling not only for its seven immediate neighbors (four in the Balkans), but for the entire continent and for the United States, which is deeply committed to the integrity of Yugoslavia.
It would be the first breakup of a European state since the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1918, setting a poor precedent at a time when all of Europe is supposed to be coming together.
Optimists may take comfort in the fact that nobody outside Yugoslavia is prepared to welcome its separate parts into the European family. Besides, as Vice President Zivko Pregl noted in Washington last week, it would take years to terminate or renegotiate federal Yugoslavia's 8,000 international agreements.
