HEADLINE: Campus Life: Swarthmore;
Phi Sigma Kappa Loses Its Chapter Over $100,000 Debt

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
The Phi Kappa Sigma fraternity at Swarthmore College has been abolished. College officials expressed doubt about its contribution to the campus after the fraternity ran up about $15,000 in debt for heating and utility services and $85,000 in charges for structural maintenance.
 Even if the fraternity, known officially as the Phi Chapter, could raise the money, it would not be reinstated because it had already missed the Dec. 10 deadline, said Swarthmore's president, David W. Fraser.
 The college changed the locks to the fraternity's house during winter break last month, essentially disbanding the chapter. College policy prohibits fraternities from operating without a house.
 
Two Fraternities Left
 "As far as I'm concerned, the deadline has passed, and the fraternity is no longer a recognized college organization," Mr. Fraser said.
 He added that the fraternity "probably would have been given more time to work out its financial problems" had it contributed more positively to life on campus.
 Phi Sig's demise leaves the college with only two fraternities. Nevertheless some of Phi Sig's 13 members have continued to meet, although a few concede that the fraternity is essentially dispersed. The entire fraternity met last week, but reached no decision on whether to continue functioning.
 The fraternity would have to petition the college for reconsideration as a new organization, Mr. Fraser said.
 Thomas E. Recker, executive vice president of the fraternity's national organization in Indianapolis, said the national group had taken no formal action to close the chapter. "We want to keep the group alive," Mr. Recker said. The chapter, founded in 1906, is one of the fraternity's oldest.
 Tedd Goundie, assistant dean, said the college told the chapter in May that it owed about $15,000 on bills incurred in the last six to 10 years. In addition to the debt, the fraternity would also have to pay about $85,000 to repair decades of structural damages to its house on campus, Mr. Goundie said.
 The college became aware of the debt only after recently hired administrators reviewed old financial records, Mr. Goundie said.
 Bernard M. Berman, the lawyer for the national organization and a 1962 alumnus of Swarthmore's Phi Sig., said the chapter's Alumni Association has paid the bills in the past. However, payment on some portions of the bills stopped yeaars ago, because of disputes over the amounts charged for heating, he said.
 "As individuals, it's not our fault," said one Phi Sig member, Jason Morton. "As an organization, we do owe the money."
 Mr. Morton, a senior English major from Phoenix, MD, conceded that "they've given us numerous second changes, and we didn't make good on any of them."
 John Curran, the chapter's president, said Phi Sig had not known of the accumulating debt until the college told it last year.
 "No one notified us, so we assumed everything was all right," said Mr. Curran, a senior economics major from Wyckoff, N.J. "It was partly our fault, since we should have been closer in touch with the alumni and the school."
 But while the debt might be legitimate, Mr. Curran said, the school had been uncooperative in helping Phi Sig meet its obligations. He said the fraternity had asked for a breakdown of how the debt was incurred but had received no information until well after the deadline.
College officials acknowledged that they failed to see Phi Sig as serving any positive role, except as an organizer of parties.
 Mr. Curran said, however, that the fraternity sponsored a canned food drive last semester and was planning other ventures this semester, before learning of its closing.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Dear Mr. President . . .

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
I didn't try to telephone because I knew you'd be busy. So here's a public communication where candor may be easier than in private conversation with a President, especially one who has actually succeeded at something.
 If you're only reading short adulatory messages, this paragraph constitutes an executive summary: You, your advisers and the fighting men and women of the United States brought great honor to our country in the Persian Gulf. After the celebrations, however, don't expect any deference from Democrats on domestic issues (they'll be righter than ever for having been wrong on the gulf), cooperation from those nations you helped save (they said thank you on Thursday) and further compliments from journalists (we're not in that business). 
 On the war, I was with you 87 percent. The other 13 percent was constructive criticism, most of which you fortunately ignored.
Everybody else, as you now know, was with you 103 percent. Some experts and colleagues would have been with you 105 percent had you been a little tougher and used maybe one very small nuclear weapon, just to make sure they work.
 You have every right to feel like Superman. No President since Truman ended World War II has brought such uncluttered success to America. You have our undying admiration. That and $1 trillion will help you close the deficit.
 Here are some test cases of what's to come in Congress. Say instead of reducing the Pentagon budget, as you promised, you now want increases. Maybe you'll get 20 new Democratic votes, but not enough to win. Say you want a big jump in spending on Star Wars. Perhaps Democrats will give you a few extra million, simply to cover their retreat; no more.
On domestic issues like energy, education, child care and the economy, Democrats will have to be even more rambunctious than before the war. Your dominance in foreign affairs will make it more important for them to distinguish themselves in areas where you haven't done very well and don't seem to care very much.
 It's fair for you to unleash Republican pit bulls to chew up Democrats for being soft on the gulf. It's your party's only chance to gain control of Congress. But you should retain your credibility and never gainsay that the Democrats backed you after they lost the vote to stop you from warring on Iraq. Republicans, when they disagreed with the way the Korean and Vietnam Wars were being fought, abandoned Democratic Presidents.
 Besides Americans, the deepest debt to you is owed by the Kuwaitis, the Saudis, the Israelis and our allies from Egypt to Europe to Japan. Expect even less generosity than from the Democrats.
 The Saudis probably will give you a year's worth of oil at low prices, to show where their hearts are. After that it will be all wallets, once again. Just ask them to sit down at the peace table with Israel.
 Nor will Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir feel he owes you much for dispatching the Patriot missiles to defend Israel against the Scuds. Instead, he is likely to remind you about Palestinians cheering on the Scuds and present his bill for the destruction.
As for the Kuwaitis, don't count on enlightenment. A senior Kuwaiti cabinet minister acknowledged to "60 Minutes," the CBS news program, that the war "has made us know that what we used to do was wrong." For example, he offered, "I had four maids, or three maids in my house; you can have two maids. Why should you have four maids in the house? Why doesn't your wife do some of the work?"
 Yes, indeed, women's liberation comes to Kuwait. Will it be said of these royal gentlemen what was remarked about the Bourbons returning to rule France after the defeat of Napoleon -- that they learned nothing, and forgot nothing?
 Also, our loyal allies still owe us about $40 billion for their share of war expenses. They've paid only a fraction of their pledges, which were far too low to begin with. Yes, it's unbecoming for a world hero to travel hat in hand, but also make sure they don't pay off, as before, in used Sony tape recorders and East German military uniforms. Cash, preferably in Deutsche marks and yen, will do fine.
 Probably the threat to your re-election ended when the cease-fire began last week. But all heroic leaders of democracies should keep in view the fate of Winston Churchill, whom the British loved for leading them toward victory in World War II but whom they voted out of office before war's end for his inattention to Britain. Democracies love their war heroes, but they love their country even more.

HEADLINE: For the Neediest: A New Record

 BODY:
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received record-breaking contributions for the sixth consecutive year. Generous even in the midst of recession, Americans have responded to the needs of the impoverished and the homeless by donating $4,439,093 to the 79th annual campaign, just ended. This exceeds last year's total by more than $66,000.
It is reassuring that this record was achieved in tough times. Clearly, Americans from many walks of life have responded to the growing desperation of less fortunate citizens. This is generosity and civic responsibility at its most timely. Seldom has the need been greater. 
 Those who contributed to the fund during this campaign, more than 15,500 people in all, deserve thanks. Although the official drive has ended, the needs of the impoverished continue to grow. As in previous years, the fund will continue to operate throughout the year.
Bequests and contributions received from this date forward will be credited to the 80th appeal campaign, which begins officially in December. Contributions will go entirely to those served, with nothing held back for solicitation or administrative purposes.
Contributions are deductible to the extent permitted by law. Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to Post Office Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087

HEADLINE: From War to Peace

 BODY:
Think of the Middle East as a jigsaw puzzle on a wobbly card table. Saddam Hussein knocked over the table. Now, after the thrillingly quick allied triumph, the pieces are back on the table, leaving the U.S. and its allies with a breathtaking opportunity. But the puzzle needs to be put back together just as quickly.
There's neither time nor reason to reshape the individual puzzle pieces. The gulf war was fought, after all, to uphold sovereign borders, not revise them. What is of transcendent importance, however, as Secretary of State James Baker heads for Middle East meetings this week, is to rebuild the card table. 
 Four sturdy new legs would protect against future shocks. The first need is regional arms limitation, starting with Iraq. The next requirement is a web of peace treaties, explicitly including Israel. Meanwhile, the international community needs to build on the first successful collective security operation in decades. Finally, Mideast governments need to distribute political and economic power more widely.
Curbing the regional arms race. The first concern is to contain Iraq, which until last week had the Middle East's largest and most dangerous army. Most of its offensive capacity seems to have been destroyed, but the continued pressure of U.N. embargoes is needed until Iraq accepts strict, verifiable arms limits.
Regional stability would not be enhanced if a weakened Iraq tempted adventurist neighbors. Regional security guarantees should be buttressed by commitments from arms suppliers like the U.S., the Soviet Union, France, China and Brazil to restrain reckless transfers.
Undefeated Arab states may reasonably resist any arms limitation plan that excludes Israel. But the Shamir Government recently signaled willingness to talk about regional arms control. Such talks could promote wider Arab recognition of Israel.
Fashioning a regional web of treaties. The Kuwait crisis revolutionized Arab political thought, drew Iran back into contact with the world and scrambled Palestinian politics. Arab states resolutely resisted Saddam Hussein's efforts to split the coalition with pro-Palestinian rhetoric and a rain of Scuds. Israel won grudging admiration by refraining from retaliation against Iraq.
The best way to build on this progress is to fashion a regional web of mutual security agreements. It needs to include Israel and be guaranteed by major outside powers. Some Arab states might now be willing to follow Egypt's example and recognize Israel. In return, Israel might offer credible formulas for the exercise of Palestinian political rights and for implementing Security Council resolutions that ordain trading land for peace.
Consolidating and refining collective security. The Kuwait crisis brought the Security Council back to life after 40 years of deadlock. It gave substance to post-cold-war cooperation between Washington and Moscow. But no satisfactory formulas were found for sharing the financial and military burdens of enforcing international law. And in the decisive military phases of the crisis, the U.N. was all but bypassed. The gains now need to be built on, the shortcomings remedied.
Expanding access to political and economic power. Saddam Hussein was able to sacrifice hundreds of thousands of Iraqis in two disastrous wars only by maintaining a fiercely repressive dictatorship. The Arab world is divided, furthermore, between rich gulf monarchies and poorer relations in countries like Jordan, Yemen and Tunisia.
It's not Washington's role to redesign the internal politics of Middle East states. But America has every reason to proclaim and promote democratic values. Where appropriate, it might condition U.S. aid on respect for basic rights.
The U.S. and its allies have achieved much with their bold performance in the gulf war. They have protected Saudi Arabia, liberated Kuwait, created a prototype for collective action and sent a reverberating warning to potential aggressors.
Now, by capitalizing on the diplomatic opportunities, the allies have the chance to transform a famous victory into a historic triumph.

HEADLINE: All About/Medical Supplies;
Removing the Warehouse from Cost-Conscious Hospitals

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
In the palmy years before the nationwide squeeze on health-care costs, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston kept a hoard of expensive medical supplies in its 20,000-square-foot warehouse. Like all hospitals, St. Luke's cannot afford to run short of vital items -- least of all in the operating rooms. At St. Luke's, Dr. Denton A. Cooley's teams perform open heart surgery on 3,000 patients each year, using prodigious quantities of supplies.
But to achieve economies as the pressure to control costs intensified, St. Luke's shut its warehouse and sold the inventory to Baxter International, a major hospital supplier. Baxter is becoming a full-time partner with this 950-bed hospital in managing, ordering and delivering Baxter's wares as well as the products of 400 other companies. Baxter's daily "just-in-time" deliveries to the hospital loading dock were only the first step. In an innovative system that hospitals call stockless inventory, Baxter fills orders in exact, sometimes small, quantities and delivers directly to departments, including the operating rooms and nursing floors, inside St. Luke's.
At least 50 hospitals buy stockless services from Baxter and a handful of smaller distributors. Converts to the concept are multiplying. About 250 more hospitals will go stockless in at least some departments in the next two years, said Pat Dolan, a partner in Chicago with Arthur Andersen & Company. Dolan recently studied stockless systems for the Health Industry Distributors Association.
 
 
Industry Leaders
Competitors in a $15 Billion Market
The nation's 6,700 hospitals spent $15 billion last year on products like disposable gloves and gowns, sutures and therapeutic solutions. Baxter International, Johnson & Johnson and Abbott Laboratories dominate the market. Baxter is the largest manufacturer of hospital supplies, with 29 percent of the market, said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. J. & J.'s share is 11 percent, and Abbott Laboratories has about 10 percent.
Baxter is also the leading distributor, with 28 percent of that market. The company says it makes 70 percent of the products it sells. But Baxter is also a middleman for many of its manufacturing rivals; it is Johnson & Johnson's largest customer for hospital supplies. J. & J.'s hospital products unit makes one-third of its sales directly to hospitals but, unlike Baxter, does not distribute supplies for other companies. Other major suppliers include Owens & Minor Inc. in Glen Allen, Va., with $1.2 billion in 1990 sales; the A. Stuart Company in Greensburg, Pa., with $600 million, and the General Medical Corporation in Richmond, with $340 million, said Mr. Abramowitz.
 
 
Multiple Benefits
'Just-in-Time' Means Less Handling
 Hospital supply expenses only begin with the $15 billion in purchases. "For every dollar spent to buy a product, hospitals spend another dollar moving that product through the system," said David Cassak, hospitals editor with In Vivo Business and Medicine Report, a trade magazine.
Stockless systems lower hospitals' holding and handling costs. "We think we've saved $1.5 million a year since 1988" from just-in-time deliveries alone, said Randy Jackson, a St. Luke's vice president, with another $500,000 likely once the stockless system is fully implemented. Annual savings already have included $350,000 from reducing staff and $162,500 from eliminating inventory. The hospital has converted storeroomsto patient care and other money-generating uses.
Vernon R. Loucks Jr., Baxter's chairman, said the company is introducing the stockless service, which it calls Valuelink, at 17 large hospitals. "We walk very carefully and slowly, because we can't afford a glitch," he said. "The first morning that an operating room doesn't open, we've got a problem."
The distributors profit from stockless services because they impose extra charges, raise prices more readily and often become a hospital's sole source of medical supplies. They typically add 3 percent to 5 percent service fees. "Our price might be slightly higher than what the hospital used to pay us, but their total cost is reduced," said Glenn Dozier, the chief financial officer with Owens & Minor, whose major stockless client is the huge medical center of the University of California at Los Angeles.
By helping hospitals reduce costs through computerized ordering, just-in-time deliveries and stockless services, suppliers have been able to raise their prices by at least 5 percent per year. They have withstood pressure from Government and private insurers and the buying clout of groups like Volunteer Hospitals, which has 600 member hospitals and 190 affiliates. Mr. Abramowitz said the hospital supply market is growing by about 8 percent a year; Baxter's sales growth in 1991 will be about 11 percent. "Stockless is Baxter's most exciting growth opportunity," he said.
Mr. Loucks said stockless services benefit both sides. "We generally take about 30 percent of whatever is saved," he said. "The hospital is picking up 70 percent."
A medical supply company does not have to be Baxter's size to exploit these opportunities. Even before Baxter jumped in, smaller suppliers like the privately held Koley's Medical Supply Inc. in Omaha were providing stockless service to a handful of customers beginning in the mid-1980's. Michael P. Gittings, Koley's president, said 18 hospitals, mostly small and all within 200 miles of Omaha, buy the service. He said Koley's sales rose to $38 million this year, compared with $6 million in 1984, before it introduced the service. Being near at hand and relatively small helped Koley's make the service work. "The hospitals have a very strong trust relationship with us," Mr. Gittings said.
 
 
Concern Over Conflicts
Most Hospitals Remain Skeptical
 The overwhelming majority of the nation's hospitals still shun stockless services. Some administrators fear that suppliers would write themselves larger orders than the hospitals needed. Administrators say group buying organizations already give them deep discounts. "Some hospitals would not want non-employees working in sensitive areas like ordering supplies," said Dwight Winstead, president of the VHA Supply Company, the buying unit of Voluntary Hospitals of America. Administrators of hospitals that belong to the VHA are wary of becoming hens opening the door to an eager fox, he said. "They feel there could be a conflict between supplying and servicing stockless and a corporate strategy to move products," he explained.
Some suppliers say hospitals must be on guard to realize the potential savings. "Hospitals that don't have the internal systems and controls to manage it will be in trouble," said Frank J. Ryan, president of Johnson & Johnson Hospital Services, a unit of J.& J.
Hospitals also need to see whether the savings from going stockless are greater than the extra charges. "You have to find the happy medium where the price of the product doesn't exceed the need for the service," said Jerome L. Stracke, an assistant vice president at the Evanston Hospital in Illinois.
One hospital may have found a way to realize many of the benefits from new delivery systems without the risks. The independent St. Paul-Ramsey Medical Center in St. Paul, Minn., requires Baxter and two other suppliers to bid against each other. All three provide just-in-time deliveries to the loading dock, but the hospital takes charge of internal distribution. Michael I. Kerr, St. Paul-Ramsey's support services director, said this system keeps prices and inventory costs low, with the hospital staying in control of its supplies. Last year, as the cost of medical supplies rose nationally by 4 percent to 6 percent, his hospital's costs increased only 3 percent.
 
 
 
'PARTNERS' IN INVENTORY CONTROL
 Steve Seide, a general manager in Houston with Baxter International, and Dave Render, his operations manager, meet every day with nurses and executives in two local hospitals. "We talk about everything from a request to stock the new Diet Dr. Pepper to a complaint that a pest control truck is taking too long at the loading dock," Mr. Render said.
Mr. Seide and Mr. Render run a service that Baxter calls Valuelink at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital and Hermann Hospital. Under this stockless system, Baxter fills precise orders for supplies and delivers them just as they are needed, directly to the departments that place the orders.
"We have become their warehouse, their central supply -- we're it," Mr. Seide said. As the hospitals phase in the stockless system, he said, "all they will have left is two to three days of supplies. Then it's all up to us."
Among other economies, stockless service has enabled Hermann Hospital to eliminate a 68,000-square-foot warehouse and St. Luke's to get rid of a 20,000-square-foot warehouse. Baxter keeps enough supplies for both institutions in an automated warehouse with only 44,000 square feet.
Baxter has used the stockless system to become a virtual partner with St. Luke's and Hermann in managing their supply flow. "We formed teams in the hospital units, with leaders and steering committees to deal with problems," Mr. Render said.
Mr. Seide said Baxter can tailor its services according to the wishes of a hospital's staff. "Seventy percent of it is good communications," he said. Based on a suggestion from the operating rooms, Baxter became part of the telephone voice mail system at St. Luke's. Anyone in an operating room can dial the letters RSVP to reach the company.
A suggestion by an operating room nurse at St. Luke's has helped Baxter prevent surgical mix-ups. Mr. Seide said she had noticed that Baxter's blue labels on pentalyte liquid, used to moisten and clean surgical incisions, closely resembled the blue labels on sterile water. Baxter, which says it was already planning to remedy the problem, promptly started putting black labels on pentalyte.
Mr. Seide and Mr. Render have good reasons for boasting of their progress at Hermann and St. Luke's. They are hoping to attract other Houston hospitals to their service. Analysts say that the more hospitals join, the greater the economies for Baxter.

HEADLINE: New York Area Grows Fastest At Its Fringes

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Until about five years ago, the John Deere dealership in Goshen, N.Y., sold mostly farm equipment. But as some barns and silos gave way to offices and shopping plazas and wooded ridges sprouted subdivisions, it has been selling fewer hay balers -- and more lawn mowers and snow blowers.
For N. Daniel Dunitz, the dealership's vice president and general manager, it is one more bittersweet sign that the landscape, though still largely undeveloped, is changing. 
 Mr. Dunitz, whose family has been supplying farms in the area for decades, says he sometimes has to go out of his way these days just to pass a working farm. But at least that way he can also avoid the traffic, another symptom of the encroaching suburbanism that some regard as if it were an infectious disease.
In Orange County and the other counties in the outer ring of the New York metropolitan region, the 1980's were a decade of growth and growth pains, a time when the balance between open spaces and the desire of people to fill them became harder to strike.
In the 80's, the Census Bureau reports, 13 of these outer counties, from Litchfield in northwestern Connecticut to Ulster and Sullivan in New York to Monmouth and Ocean in central New Jersey, added a total of 332,434 people, an increase of 13 percent.
In contrast, the metropolitan region's other 18 counties, which have more than 80 percent of its population, added 319,766 people, an increase of just 2 percent. The metropolitan region overall grew 3.4 percent, to 19.8 million people, the Census found.
Many counties in the inner ring of suburbs, including Nassau and Bergen, lost population in the 1980's, the Census Bureau found. New York City, which had a surge of foreign immigration, grew by 3.5 percent, though city officials and others contend that the Federal count missed many residents.
Planners and economists say the surge of growth at the fringe is evidence of the region's continuing decentralization -- of jobs as well as people.
"It's a relentless process," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association, an independent research organization.
 
At a Price?
 Though Nassau and Bergen Counties lost 54,000 people in the last decade, they still added nearly 275,000 new jobs, an indication of their transition from bedroom communities to employment centers in their own right.
Many of the new suburban jobs are being filled by commuters from the outer ring. But counties like Orange are attracting more jobs now, too, and even developing their own business centers, complete with services from consulting firms to hotels to copying shops.
Mr. Anderson and other planners worry that decentralization will mean a sprawl gobbling up forests and overwhelming highways.
And if, as seems likely, the outer counties continue to grow, some planners are also concerned that their prosperity could come at the expense of New York City, with which these counties will increasingly compete. As more and more of the region's housing and jobs are located along its edge, the gulf between the urban poor and well-to-do suburbanites is also likely to widen.
Still, Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said she believed that the dispersion of people from urban areas will continue, although it will not necessarily mean that urban areas will not grow.
"I think there'll be a flight to smaller cities and counties all across the country, " she said. "People are just moving, getting away."
 
$1,000 a Mile
 If Orange County, which begins 40 miles north of the George Washington Bridg, is typical, the new residents of New York's outer ring are much like the last generation of suburbanites: married, with children, they are leaving behind crowds, crime and questionable schools for extra bedrooms and backyards. But, priced out of the inner ring of suburbs, they are moving farther and farther out.
The rule of thumb, said Christopher J. Dunleavy, executive director of the Orange County Chamber of Commerce, is that housing prices rise roughly $1,000 for every mile one moves southeasterly toward the Rockland border. And comparable houses in Orange County cost half of what they would in Westchester and Bergen Counties, he added.
When a county's population rises, jobs and development follow, though the process is complicated and often lags. Some outer counties are already showing evidence of labor shortages, particularly Somerset and Hunterdon in New Jersey, where in December the unemployment rates were 3.2 percent and 3.1 percent respectively, and Rockland, Putnam and Dutchess in New York, with unemployment rates of 3.6 percent, 3.7 percent and 3.8 percent in December, the last month for which statistics were available. This shortage could dampen future job growth.
Parts of the outer ring seem so vibrant that the economic recession that is so visible in the city and the inner suburbs is not much in evidence.
"A lot of the surrounding counties see themselves as much more independent of New York than they once did," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"That perception has some reality to it," he added, "but I think they tend to underestimate the amount of continuing economic ties that they have to New York City."
Still, while parts of the city, and much of the region, are glutted with vacant offices, Mr. Dunleavy said Orange County may actually run out of space this year.
Toward the north end of the county is Stewart Airport, where commercial flights began about a year ago and a handful of airlines now operate. Nearby office and industrial parks are filling.
In the county's south is Sterling Forest, where there are plans for what Mr. Dunleavy said is the largest development project in the works in the Northeast -- 14,000 houses and more than 5 million square feet of commercial and industrial space -- on the largest single piece of developable land in the metropolitan region.
In the center of the county, Empire Blue Cross-Blue Shield is moving into what Mr. Dunleavy says is the biggest commercial office building between the Bronx and Montreal, though the sprawling brick structure has been designed in a way that does not call attention to its size.
 
'Needs to Be Slowed'
 But prosperity has its price. Mr. Dunitz of Gor-Dun's Inc., the John Deere dealership in Goshen, said Orange County has lost perhaps 30,000 of the 145,000 acres of farmland it had 15 years ago, along with many of the people who tilled them. Fortunately for him, John Deere has expanded its line of consumer products.
"For some reason we have to have growth," he said. "That seems to be the position. But I think it needs to be controlled. I think it needs to be slowed."
The vast majority of the county's land is still undeveloped. But Mr. Dunleavy worries that Orange County will repeat what he regards as the mistakes of Westchester and Bergen, either by forcing developers to put each new home on several acres, which would consume precious fields, or by clustering row houses too densely and in the wrong places, without adequate visual or environmental buffers.
 
'Seen as a Negative'
 "What we fear most is the kind of suburban sprawl that we see in more immediate parts of the metropolitan region," he said.
"There is literally not a single soul on the political spectrum who wants us to become a bedroom community," he said. "That's universally seen as a negative."
More families mean more children mean more schools mean higher taxes. That has been a problem for Warwick, in the southeast corner of the county, and other towns where residential has outpaced commercial development.
Some towns have water supply problems, and the entire county is projected to be 20 million gallons a day short of water by 2010, Mr. Dunleavy said. Sewage treatment is another concern.
Orange County is served by three major highways -- the New York State Thruway, Route 17 and Route 84 -- that are helping to make it a distribution center. Similarly, in Hunterdon County, corporations have opened research and office centers along Interstate 78.
But the surge of growth in parts of the outer ring is already causing backups that are bound to get worse. Transportation experts say the number of trips in and between these counties will grow at a faster rate than commutes to and from New York City, and the new patterns of travel do not lend themselves to new mass transit lines, assuming that money were available to build them.
 
A New Los Angeles?
 "The historical settlement pattern was fairly compact -- villages, towns and cities organized around rail lines," said Robert D. Yaro, senior vice president of the Regional Plan Association. "But for the last couple of generations, we've been building a Los Angeles-type region. A lot of the problems are being driven by that."
Mr. Yaro is now at work on a new regional plan, the third vision of the future his organization has devised in 60 years. Like a martial arts expert, he is seeking not to meet development head on but to deflect it, guiding it into patterns that conserve resources.
To make his point, Mr. Yaro has prepared a series of aerial views of typical suburban locations comparing what would happen if growth and development continue to sprawl, and what would happen if they were shaped according to the association's principles.
One image, based on a Connecticut town, shows a downtown filled with shopping malls and blotches of half-filled parking lots that stretch to the horizon. The companion view shows a town with even more buildings, but clustered together and separated by tree-lined streets -- a modern suburban village.
"The goal is to have more effective planning in all three states," Mr. Yaro said. "With 900 municipalities, we just can't expect all of them to be headed in the right direction."
The renderings will be unveiled next month, at a regional assembly the organization is holding. After that, Mr. Yaro said, "we'll be taking these images on the road."

HEADLINE: ART;
On Edward Hopper, Loneliness and Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT COLES; Robert Coles is a child psychiatrist who teaches at Harvard University. His most recent book is "The Spiritual Life of Children" (Houghton Mifflin).

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Three years ago I began teaching a fourth-grade class in a Cambridge, Mass., elementary school. I noticed, right off, that on the playground or in the halls, or even in the classroom itself, the children were often marvelously forceful and vigorous storytellers. But when they were asked to write, they commonly became inarticulate, even fearfully so. "I can't write," was their refrain, and I decided not to take them up directly on that claim.
 Instead, I turned the English class into an informal art seminar. I brought in slides, fed them into a projector, and we all looked at Picassos and Pissarros, Remingtons and Renoirs, and nearer home, John Sloans and Edward Hoppers. I noticed that Hopper's paintings, especially, both excited and puzzled the children. I also noticed that they wanted to connect what they saw to stories, which they constructed as I flashed one Hopper slide after another against the wall. It was almost as if this 20th-century American realist painter (who died only 23 years ago) somehow addressed these children, prompted in them a desire to respond to his pictures by telling of their various experiences. 
 I remember, especially, some personal tales told by those children in response to the more familiar Hopper paintings. I remember the girl who said of the "folks" who figure in "Nighthawks" (three customers at a food counter in the middle of the night, being served by a waiter): "They have a different day -- I mean, night. Night is their day. Maybe something is on their minds, and they can't sleep -- but maybe they just work at night, like my mom does." Her mother runs a Dunkin Donuts shop on the 11-to-7 shift. "She says she has a good time talking with some of the people, and they have a good time talking with her. She says people talk more at night -- or maybe it's that night people talk more. It's easier then."
 Other Hopper paintings prompted an almost universal chorus of perplexity or apprehension. Pictures like "Sunday," in which a man sits, arms folded, in front of stores that seem empty, abandoned, or "Approaching a City," in which tenement buildings hover over subway tracks that head underground, stirred the children to anxious questions, to gloomy statements about not only the content of the slides but their own lives as well.
"That's a funny one," said one girl. "It's weird -- it's spooky." The emphasis on that last word said it all for the whole class -- nods, several "yeah's," and the fidgeting that is more telling, at times, than any words. In their own way, these children may have been circling around the thoughts I was entertaining -- the grim, sinister, dangerous side of urban life, maybe even that aspect of our psychological life: the electric third rail, the dark underground that looms before the viewer.
 In "Approaching a City," a mood of stark stillness dominates; in the better-known "Early Sunday Morning," with its storefronts, and above them, tenement apartments, with its street hydrant and old-fashioned barber pole, a serene stillness is offered -- the city sleeps, as it should on the morning of the week's seventh day. Such pictures prompt the children to ask about people: where are they or, better, why are they left out?
 At that point, I was ready with some pictures in which human beings are given a more intimate kind of attention: "Office at Night," or "Hotel Room," or "Hotel by a Railroad," or "Sunlight in a Cafeteria" or "Automat," or "The Barber Shop." The result, however, is often further unease. A boy tells me: "The people don't seem happy. Their heads seem bent. Either they're alone, or if they're with someone, they don't look at each other. No one is smiling." A chorus of agreement -- though a girl demurs: "Just because they're not smiling doesn't mean they're unhappy. I think they're thinking."
 That line of reasoning evoked much discussion. Some children pointed out that in several pictures Hopper's women look "sexy" but his men seem cold, buttoned up, self-preoccupied -- or, as in the dramatic "Excursion Into Philosophy," of a man seated on a bed, introspectively tied to reading matter rather than connected to a woman who is lying nearby, her back (with its exposed bottom) to him. Others expressed indirectly their sense of the confinement of those urban rooms and offices, the frustrations of the people who inhabit them, through urgently stated therapeutic recommendations: "Those people should get out and go take a long walk in the country; then they could unwind."
 This high-strung, tense, self-preoccupied side to certain of Hopper's American city dwellers, office workers, travelers, doesn't yield, unfortunately, to the remedy suggested by that 9-year-old child. I follow her advice, in a way -- we move to Hopper's suburban and rural world.
If anything, things get worse away from the downtown streets. In "East Wind Over Weehawken," no one is in sight, but a large "For Sale" sign tells of a collapsed economy. (The picture was painted in 1934.) In "Ryder House," a field of grass is overgrown near a house whose windows are boarded up -- a forlorn, abandoned farm.
In "Cape Cod Evening," overgrown grass again surrounds a house whose two occupants, a man and a woman, are outside, grimly stoic, their dog turned away from them. Even more threatening, a dark cluster of nearby trees seems on the march, ready to overwhelm a rural scene already stifled, uncompromising. The woman's crossed arms, her dark blue dress, the man's T-shirt -- this is a bedraggled, woebegone couple, as the children recognize.
Again, rather than analyzing and explicating, they suggest action: "Let's go back to the city -- that restaurant, where there was the food, or to the movie one." The boy who said that was referring to "Tables for Ladies," which features a couple eating, a cashier, and a worker arranging a display of fruit, and to "New York Movie," which emphasizes not a film or its audience, but a pensive usherette who stands aside under some light.
 In the former, however, the viewer is outside the restaurant, maybe hungry (the picture was painted in 1930, as the Great Depression deepened), and in the latter the viewer is asked to think of someone who is, literally, outside a particular mainstream: others lose themselves in a few hours of film distraction, while the one who has helped them get to their seats, who has been, in a way, an instrument of their subsequent pleasure, is left to stand apart -- left to her own, isolated, personal resources.
 To return to the city, we need gas, I remind the children by showing them Hopper's "Four Lane Road" and "Gas" -- but again, a couple in the former, running a gas station, seem out of touch with each other, and without customers, big as the road is, whereas the latter poses yet another of those dark, encroaching forests next to a Mobil station tended by a man who is alone as evening settles upon a carless road, this one narrow and headed obliquely into the dark. No wonder these children have become restless -- and, finally, have resigned themselves to the realization that all does not go well in Hopper's America: an alienation of individuals, one from the other, and too, a good deal of social and economic dislocation, distress.
 When I use Hopper's slides with Harvard college students, only a few blocks away, a different emphasis can often be heard. I teach a seminar titled "American Light," named after a wonderful poem written by E. L. Sissman. It is meant to honor Hopper's shrewd eye for much of what takes place in our country, as well as his extraordinary way with light and darkness -- a cold, even supernatural glow, often given intensity and prominence by a nearby stretch of darkness in the form of shadows cast by buildings or by trees.
 We look at the same slides the elementary school children do, but we also read and discuss Raymond Carver's fiction, his brilliantly constructed, emotionally piercing stories, in so many of which a failure of communication, of human understanding, figures so prominently. The loneliness of his characters, their down-and-out state becomes transfigured by the genius of this writer into the greatness of one compelling, dramatic moment after another. The students respond with feeling as well as intellectually to Carver -- examine his texts, but also let themselves personally enter and walk their way, open-eyed, through his narratives.
 Yet, with respect to Hopper, they are wont to favor analysis of his pictures: shapes, sizes, forms, arrangements of objects, nature of pigment, contrasts of color -- all noted with big-deal words like chiaroscuro coming up now and then. Yes, I think, this is important, to learn "critical skills," but we sometimes go further, hasten to question common truths entertained outside the academy: "Too much is made of the loneliness and alienation in Hopper," a student announced. Maybe so, I think.
 In Hopper, we begin to realize, there is a 20th-century sensibility at work: his often explicit interest in a documentary art that tells of a nation not at ease with itself, and individuals not at ease with one another.
 To be sure, Hopper's paintings lend themselves especially well to the viewer's inclinations -- in the tradition of Rorschach cards or, better, Henry Murray's "Thematic Apperception" pictures, they tell about us viewers, as opposed to an American "them." The elusive ambiguities of those paintings are fodder for our conflicts and worries, for the constant complexities of feeling within us that struggle for expression and find it in our dreams (our own private, nightly art) as well as in the pictures to which we become attached, and to which we make our various personal attributions. Still, Hopper remarked, in connection with "Nighthawks," that he "simplified the scene a great deal and made the restaurant bigger" than the one in Greenwich Village in New York City that he used as a model of sorts. He went on to say: "Unconsciously, probably, I was painting the loneliness of a large city." In our university sanctuary, we read those words, look again at his various railroad tracks slicing through the land, his empty drugstores and bleak bridges, his eerie country houses or massive tenement blocks, his hotel lobbies and roadside gas pumps, and begin to realize that this was an artist whose unconscious knew well not only how to supply energy to a wonderfully gifted talent, but also knew well how many Americans, at least some of the time, both live and feel.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Nighthawks"--Children had therapeutic recommendations for the people who inhabit Hopper's pictures: "Those people should get out and go take a long walk in the country," one suggested (pg. 33); Edward Hopper's "Automat"--The elusive ambiguities of these paintings are fodder for our dreams, our own private, nightly art. (pg. 35)

HEADLINE: FILM;
Daniel Pyne Did It: 'The Hard Way'

BYLINE: By BETSY SHARKEY; Betsy Sharkey is an editor of Adweek and an entertainment columnist for the magazine M Inc.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
What first intrigued the writer Daniel Pyne about "The Hard Way," a comedy thriller that is as much a sendup of the way Hollywood perceives the real world as it is a story of cops and bad guys, was the idea of trying to fashion a parody with some depth, rather than a predictable cliche.
The movie, starring Michael J. Fox and James Woods and opening on Friday, is a collision of characters built around a simple "what if" premise. In this case, what if an intensely driven New York cop (Mr. Woods) hot on the trail of a serial killer is forced to baby-sit a pampered Hollywood movie star (Mr. Fox), who is out to research a role? 
 The result is a clash of the ultimate reality with the ultimate illusion, played on a verbal tightrope of dialogue that works a bit like a Robin Williams comedy routine -- breathlessly, relentlessly and rarely without purpose.
"The toughest problem was figuring out a fresh way to portray an actor who wasn't a Hollywood in-joke," says the 35-year-old Mr. Pyne, whose open Lincolnesque face and quietly intelligent discomfort with conventional wisdom make him seem an embodiment of naivete and insight -- a "Mr. Smith Goes to Hollywood," instead of Washington.
"I wanted to create an actor as a real person, not an actor as some writer's simplistic, stripped-down version," he says. "The Preston Sturges film 'Sullivan's Travels' was an inspiration in that regard, because the character had a bit more depth than the typical Hollywood producer-director. The cop was easy, because I'd been writing cops and had a definite opinion of the difference between what a movie cop was and what a real cop is like."
Indeed, Mr. Pyne's first real paying job in Hollywood was "writing cops," when, in the early 80's, he was hired as a story editor on the first season of the NBC network series "Miami Vice." There he rewrote and wrote original scripts about two undercover detectives who are remembered as much for the way they dressed as the way they solved crimes.
Mr. Pyne went on to conceive and write "Hard Copy," a short-lived CBS drama about journalists. That was followed by an experimental, pseudodocumentary series, "The Street," which he describes as being "all about deconstructing, going against the traditional narrative, going against the traditional cop show and yet finding something that would hook people to watch it at 12:30 at night." The show, syndicated by MCA, lasted for 40 episodes.
But it is his work on "The Hard Way" that has turned Mr. Pyne into one of Hollywood's busiest writers. For Mr. Fox, he has since rewritten "Doc Hollywood," a comedy currently in production. He recently completed an adaptation of Akira Kurosawa's classic 1954 film, "The Seven Samurai," for Brian De Palma. "White Sands," a political thriller and an original screenplay, is set to go into production later this year for Morgan Creek, which also produced another of Mr. Pyne's scripts, the 1990 film "Pacific Heights."
His comedy about American football in Italy, "Winning Ugly," is in development at M-G-M-Pathe. And he is the writer and executive producer of "The Antagonist," a pilot for CBS whose style is reminiscent of Mr. Kurosawa's "Rashomon" in its exploration of different truths. "The Antagonist" will be televised this spring.
When Mr. Pyne discusses his film and television work, he tends to do so in literary terms. When he talks about how his fascination with the American legal system led him to create "The Antagonist," he likens his interest to "the way that Kafka was fascinated with the legal system."
"I write a lot about certain themes," he says, as he balances his 9-month-old daughter, Katie, on his knee, in the living room of his home in Los Angeles. "Moral man in an amoral world, relationships between people and how culture and society impact upon them, and identity, characters in search of themselves."
Even his method of writing tends to more closely parallel that of a novelist rather than a screenwriter. He does not structure his scripts initially. If a particular structure is there, it is not by design. The scenes are highly detailed rather than skeletal and, at least at first, don't conform to a screenplay's world of interiors and exteriors. "I think of characters and of beginnings," he says. "But generally I imagine the character in the broadest outline. Then, when I start to write them, they become defined. I know that I'm on the right track when the character begins to take over the story and I'm following the character rather than pushing the character around on the page."
On his own, Mr. Pyne believes that he never would have come up with a movie like "The Hard Way." "I'm not a high-concept writer," he says. Left to his own devices, he prefers darker, more complex themes that explore a more cynical side of life. He says he loves living in Los Angeles because it is a "multicultural, teeming, ugly cesspool" that provides an unending supply of good characters.
He and his wife, Joan, a musician, take road trips to soak up and absorb reality. He'll come away from a trip with an idea, write 10 pages, then pack it away for a year to see how well it wears, as he did in the case of "White Sands." "White Sands," the first original movie script he tried to sell, was widely turned down.
"There were complaints that it was too hard to read," he says. "It took two hours, and a lot of people in town don't want to spend two hours reading anything." The initial reaction to "White Sands" encouraged him to write "Pacific Heights," set in San Francisco, where he and his wife have another home they escape to on occasion. "I wanted to prove to myself that I could do something very lean and readable," says Mr. Pyne. "I thought it would make a nice, small movie. When I finished it, I gave it to my agent, and he thought it was a little dark but that he might be able to sell it. It sold in a day."
While Mr. Pyne seems to have a penchant for drama rather than comedy, the producer William Sackheim, who worked with Mr. Pyne on "Hard Copy," was convinced that "The Hard Way" could be Daniel Pyne's kind of story. He first brought Mr. Pyne into the project in 1986 with an assignment to rewrite a script by Lem Dobbs (who shares the screenwriting credit with Mr. Pyne). "Dan has a wonderful way with dialogue, and one of the best ears I've ever encountered," Mr. Sackheim says of Mr. Pyne. "And he also knows it is the characters who really drive a movie."
Mr. Pyne spent portions of the next four years working through various rewrites as the project moved between different directors and different actors. The script finally settled with the director John Badham, who worked through several more rewrites with Mr. Pyne.
By the time filming was ready to begin, Mr. Pyne was absorbed by other projects and left the production. Mr. Badham brought in yet another team of writers. Still, it was Mr. Pyne who "nailed it," says Mr. Badham. "It was his script that we got Michael and James to commit to. Dan brought a particular kind of humor and wackiness and sort of an unexpected quality to it."
 Mr. Badham cites one scene, a particularly dramatic explosion in which Mr. Woods tries to explain why Mr. Fox will never in 100 lifetimes understand what it's like to be a cop; it dissolves from drama into comedy when a stunned Mr. Fox pulls out a tape recorder and says, "That was great . . . I'm serious, I can use that . . . Could you do it once more?"
 However, Mr. Pyne remains tentative about how much of "The Hard Way" as he wrote it survives in the final movie. "I was more interested in the relationships between the two characters and doing a spin on the buddy film," says Mr. Pyne. "Lem had a bigger comic plot, more complicated, more action, which is ironically what they've gone back to -- bigger, more physical comedy."
 Mr. Pyne can't remember a time in his life when he didn't want to be a writer. He grew up in Littleton, Colo., a green-grass suburb of Denver, where he worried about living a life that was too bland to provide the foundation for the fiction writer he wanted to become.
He credits writings by Larry McMurtry ("Terms of Endearment" and the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Lonesome Dove") with giving him a sense that he could do more.
"Growing up in Denver," Mr. Pyne says, "not even Denver, but a suburb, I was fearful that I had a point of view and a perspective that would limit me, because all of the books I was reading were coming from New York. Then Larry McMurtry came along and wrote these elegant novels that I could not only identify with, but that inspired me because they were so specific to what he knew and what he had experienced in Texas. It made me think that I could someday do something that had some deeper meaning."
Nevertheless, when Mr. Pyne went to Stanford University in 1973, he majored in economics, in part to assuage his father, a sculptor who had struggled and wanted Mr. Pyne to have a more practical career, and in part because he loved economics. "It was sort of a religion," he says.
Still, he always found himself drawn back to writing. He wedged creative writing courses in between his economics studies and worked on the college newspaper. For about six months, he wrote for The Menlo-Atherton Recorder, which Mr. Pyne describes as "a man-bites-dog" weekly in northern California. He did a brief stint as a copywriter at a small San Francisco advertising agency that did "political advertising in that kind of snobby San Francisco way."
In 1978, Mr. Pyne decided to move to Los Angeles to see if he could make enough money writing for film and television to support himself while he worked on his short stories. Success did not come easily. There were four lean years before "Miami Vice" when he lived in a cheap, two-room apartment near the beach with his two dogs, two cats, his wife and his typewriter. His short stories went unpublished; he took screenwriting courses at the University of California in Los Angeles, and his first marriage began to dissolve.
"It was tough," he says. "I thought about giving up. I thought about doing a lot of different things -- going back into advertising, going back into journalism, going to Washington, D.C., and working as an economist." It was his father, who had hoped for an economist, who helped him remain a writer. "He has always struggled as a sculptor," says Mr. Pyne. "He worked at home, so I was very familiar with what he had to go through. If anything, it helped. He gave me the ability to persevere."
Mr. Pyne has yet to see the finished version of "The Hard Way," choosing to wait until he can slip unnoticed into a neighborhood theater and see it with ordinary people and watch how they respond to the portions that are his. "A movie becomes a collaborative effort when you start working with a director," says Mr. Pyne. "Maybe this goes back to the fact that I like to write fiction. In a sense, the finished first-draft screenplay is my movie and my story. From that point on it becomes everyone else's. So I like to have that moment when it's all mine."

HEADLINE: Food Supplier Opens Warehouse Outlet

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL

 BODY:
BINGING in the 1980's has given way to belt-tightening in the 90's, and no one is more aware of the sharp contrasts between the decades than those in the food industry.
Restaurants, particularly the higher-priced ones, are struggling to survive and when the restaurant business is down, so is the business of those who supply restaurants. To keep profits from sagging, some suppliers have diversified. 
 When one purveyor of fine foods to restaurants, Poritzky's Meat Company and Food Service here, saw its sales drop 20 percent last year from $12 million in 1989, its president, Sander Poritzky, sought additional ways to generate income. Last June, he opened a warehouse outlet that is a cash-and-carry operation open to the public.
 
'A Business Strategist'
 Mr. Poritzky, 51 years old, who is known as Sandy, said adaptability has always been one of his company's strongest assets.
"My father, who started the business in 1925 as a kosher butcher shop,would be surprised to learn he was a business strategist," Mr. Poritzky said.
"But in current parlance, that's exactly what he was; he had the ability and the flexibility to shift the focus of his business to take advantage of changing conditions."
Before his father, Benjamin, came to the United States in 1923, he had been in the family's cattle business in Poland, Mr. Poritzky said.
"When he got here, he went to Peekskill, where his brother Sam had a butcher shop called the Eagle Market," Mr. Poritsky said. "A few years later, my Dad, who saw a need for it, opened Poritzky's Kosher Butcher Shop. He contracted with several of the small farmers who were around Peekskill then, who supplied him with cattle, calves and lambs.
 
Some Satellite Shops
 "Since kosher meat is only taken from the front quarter of the animal, he sold the hind quarters to other butchers. And when Jewish summer colonies, such as Pine Lake Park, began to spring up around Peekskill, my Dad saw another opportunity. He opened a couple of satellite kosher butcher shops to serve the summer people."
By 1946, the Poritzky business shifted gears again, Mr. Poritzky said. "That's when my Dad bought what had once been a blacksmith's shop for $4,500. He renovated it, and he went into the wholesale business. He started by delivering meat, then eggs, cheese and margarine, to customers like the Forest House -- which was then a top hotel in Mahopac -- and restaurants and schools in the area."
Mr. Poritzky grew up working in the family business, where his mother was the bookkeeper. His first job when he was 9 or 10, he said, was sweeping the floor and putting down the fresh sawdust in the butcher shop.
 
Truck Driver at 16
 "Even as a kid, I knew I'd always work in the company," he said. "When I was 16 and got my driver's license, I started making our deliveries before school and after school in our truck.
"Then I went off to Hobart College, but I left after two years to go into the business with my Dad. We had a very unusual relationship. When I was 19, he gave me complete authority to run the business, which included doing the hiring and firing."
In 1964, when the Poritzkys bought their first industrial freezer, they were able to add french fries to their list.
"Then we went into cooking oil," Mr. Poritzky said. "It was a logical merchandising step."
 
A Move Into Fish and Poultry
 And when, as one of the largest purveyors of fresh meat in the area, the family saw their business threatened by changing eating habits, they increased the amount of fish and poultry.
"This has always been an extremely competitive business and one that is subject to constant government inspection," Mr. Poritsky said.
"Under the Wholesome Meat Act, which applies to anyone in business who processes $33,000 worth of meat a year, a Federal inspector from the U.S. Department of Agriculture is here inspecting us daily, to make sure that we are operating under stringent sanitary conditions."
But he said that retail outlets for fresh meat are under county jurisdiction like the Westchester Department of Health, which makes inspections once or twice a year.
 
Bargains Represent Business
 As the recession deepens, Mr. Poritzky said he expected to find an increase in business from cost-conscious customers seeking premium foods at discounts.
"Economists have been saying that the retailer who offers the customer the greatest bargain will do well during a recession," he said.
"I've taken that advice literally. We send out a catalogue and with that and word-of-mouth referrals, we've already had a turnaround in business. Even during a recession, people have to eat; if they can feast for the same price, I'm betting they will do it. Our cash flow has already improved."
In the new 23,000-square-foot warehouse in the Charles Point Industrial Park in Peekskill, more than 1,500 food items are stocked. They include the same quality meats, poultry, hors d'oeuvres and specialty desserts served at the best area restaurants, Mr. Poritzky said.
"The finest dining establishments in Westchester and Fairfield County are customers of ours," he said. "They include Auberge Maxime's, the Arch, the Inn at Ridgefield and Stouffer Westchester Inn."
Warehouse customers include working women, small party-givers and good-sized caterers. Deliveries are made on orders of more than $300.
 
Popular Items
 Among some of the most popular food items, Mr. Poritzky said, are three-pound imported hams at $2.59 a pound, strip loins of beef shells, which come fully trimmed and boneless without the tail, averaging 12 pounds, custom cut into steaks or roasts at $3.98 a pound.
"That compares with retail market prices of $5.69 to $5.99 a pound," he said. "And premium Italian salami sells for $4.25 at our place compared to $7.99 a pound elsewhere."
One hundred handmade hors d'ouevres from Wilton Foods are priced at $23.95 and deluxe desserts from places like David Glass and Sweet Street Desserts are about half the price they sell for in specialty food shops, Mr. Poritsky said.
"David Glass's famous chocolate mousse cake sells for about $30 at Nieman Marcus," he said. "We sell it for $16."

HEADLINE: Small Banks Resist Trend On Profits

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DURING the 1980's, when many commercial banks were reporting fantastic rates of return from real estate ventures, managers at New Haven Savings Bank considered getting into those areas, too. "But we have learned from the past that prosperity does not last forever," said New Haven's vice president, David R. Rice. "So even when it's most tempting, we do not participate."
As banks in the state were completing their accounting for 1990, Mr. Rice and others at his bank said they were glad that they did not succumb to the allure of quick and easy money. 
 While other banks are going out of business or posting record losses, New Haven Savings earned $7.5 million in 1990, becoming one of several banks around the state that bucked the trend and posted a profit. Typically, the profitable institutions are small savings banks in suburbs or small cities, like Union Savings in Danbury, American Savings in New Britain and Stafford Savings Bank in Stafford.
By contrast, Olde Windsor Bancorp, which operates New England Bank and Trust, had a profit of $120,000 for 1990, on assets of $200 million, with deposits up only 0.007 percent.
 
'Everything Has Changed'
 "You never thought anyone would be satisfied with that kind of growth and profits," said Olde Windsor's marketing director, Sophia B. Bernier. "But this year, everything has changed."
Ms. Bernier said the bank never got into the high-risk, high-yield investments that were popular in the 1980's, which included commercial real estate and brokered funds.
"That works both ways," she said. "You don't grow phenomenally in the good years, but we're protected in a year like we're having now."
The 149-year-old Willimantic Savings Institute posted a $1 million profit in 1990, up from $600,000 a year earlier, for the third best year on record, despite having taken over the failed Brooklyn Savings Bank.
"The rule in banking is, if a deal looks too good to be true, it probably is," said William R. Wilcox, the president of Willimantic Savings. "We followed basic banking principles. We know our market, and we didn't get involved in commercial real estate."
The Brooklyn Savings Bank did. Its participation in a condominium complex has been called the reason for its downfall.
 
'Just Too Risky'
 Mr. Wilcox said many banks ran into trouble when they financed cars on revolving credit lines for automobile dealers. When times are good and car sales are high, such deals can be lucrative; when times are bad and sales plummet, banks can lose huge sums.
"There were times we saw banks around us going into these things, and you have to say, 'It's something we should consider,' " Mr. Wilcox said. "And I guess we did consider it. But some of the deals the banks went into were just too risky."
Several Connecticut banks have announced preliminary results from 1990, and most will be announcing their final numbers over the next few weeks. The results are not expected to be good in most cases.
Dozens of Connecticut banks and thrift institutions converted to stock corporations in the 1980's as a way to raise money for investments. But investors demand higher returns than depositors, and many banks chased high-risk, high-yield investments. Banks also were competing with mutual funds and other investment vehicles that were providing high rates of return, further spurring the search for lucrative investments.
But as the 1980's ended, so did the rapid economic expansion of the Connecticut economy. Instead of the yield, banks started to realize the risk.
In the last two years, 10 Connecticut banks have been taken over by government agencies or declared insolvent, one of the highest failure rates in the Northeast. Among the failures was Connecticut Bank and Trust, once considered among the most secure banks in the state.
 
Happy With Any Profit
 Many of those that have not failed have had problems. Shawmut National Corporation, the parent company of Connecticut National Bank, reported large losses in 1989 and eliminated its stock dividend.
"In this environment, if a bank is still showing any profit, you're happy," said Dr. Lewis Mandell, a professor of finance at the University of Connecticut.
Tracey J. Stangle, a bank analyst in the Hartford office of First Albany Corporation, said many of the losses taken by banks in 1990 were paper losses, as banks shuffled massive amounts of capital into loan-loss reserves. Those loans might go bad, but if the economy improves, they might not, he said; and in any event, they are covered.
"Hopefully, the last quarter was the low-water mark for bank earnings in Connecticut," Mr. Stangle said. But if the economy continues to sour, he said, the turnaround might not occur.
"I think 1991 is going to be the worst year for banks since the Depression," said John C. Shortell, president of Dime Financial Corporation, the holding company that operates Dime Bank in Wallingford and the City Savings Bank of Meriden. "Even if the recession gets better in 1991, the commercial real estate market is probably not going to recover. The most you can hope for, as a bank, is to stabilize your loan losses."
 
Conservative Philosophy
 Dime Financial earned $4.4 million in 1990, down from $7.3 million a year earlier, Mr. Shortell said. He said 4.2 percent of the bank's loans went bad in 1990, compared with a regional average of 7.5 percent.
"We have our problem loans, and we're working night and day with some of them," he said. "But overall, we have a very conservative lending philosophy.
"We do most of our lending in New Haven County, for instance, while other banks were interested in loaning money anywhere in the state. And they might not have had as good a feel for the values in the areas where they were loaning money."
James P. Cronin, president of Dime Savings Bank in Norwich, which posted a record $905,762 profit for 1990, on assets of about $96 million, said his company never converted to a stock institution because it is so small.
"We are a community bank, and we've always had the philosophy that growth for growth's sake is not beneficial," Mr. Cronin said. "We didn't think we could serve our market any better as a $200 million bank than we can as a $100 million bank. We never expected to compete with the big regionals."
Mr. Cronin said the bank's core depositors come to Dime for service. "And they don't leave us because they can make a half-percent more interest somewhere else," he said, so there was no reason to scramble for deposits.
 
'$2 Million Is Chicken Feed'
 But Dr. Mandell said many of the banks posting profits for 1990 did so because they were too small to interest commercial real estate developers. A bank can only loan an amount equivalent to 1 percent of its assets to any single customer, so banks between $100 million and $200 million never got into that risky business.
"The fact is, $2 million is chicken feed to a developer, so they're not going to get involved with a bank that small," Dr. Mandell said. "Those smaller banks invested heavily in Treasury notes and municipal bonds, and in the good times, they were getting a terrible return. But those are very secure investments, and they look pretty good now."
But even New Haven Savings, a bank that is approaching $2 billion in size and could have participated in some of the commercial real estate projects of the last several years, is profitable. Mr. Rice said that is because the bank abstained from those risks. More than 70 percent of the bank's loan portfolio is in single- to four-family houses, he said, and it never formed a mutual holding company to issue stock and raise money for investing.
"It may sound very conservative and old fashioned, but that is the way we operate," Mr. Rice said.
Mr. Cronin of Dime Savings Bank in Norwich said: "When we were going into the 1980's, people told us we were an anachronism, that there was no place left for a community bank. But we're still here, and we're still profitable."
