HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
The Fires of Patriotism And Cold Necessity Put 13 in Harm's Way

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Don Terry, Sam Howe Verhovek and Mary B. W. Tabor and was written by Mr. Terry.

DATELINE: GREENSBURG, Pa., March 3

 BODY:
Sorrow rushes over the hills and swoops into the valleys across western Pennsylvania like a bitter wind these days because soon the funerals will start.
Thirteen Army reservists from this close-knit region of small cities and farm towns in the foothills of the Alleghenies were killed last Monday in one of the final Scud attacks of the Persian Gulf war. 
 The loss has shaken and stunned this land of tough but friendly people who despite the rugged terrain that separates their communities are tied together by immigrant backgrounds, a love of high school sports and a faith in country as strong as the steel they produced before the mills began to close and the hard times set in.
Most of the reservists lived within a two-hour drive of the Greensburg Army Reserve Center, a low-slung brick building at the top of a winding road, where they gathered one weekend a month to train, listen to lectures and socialize.
 
 
 
Who They Were
 They were 11 men and 2 women. They were black and they were white. They were laborers and they were college students. "They were us," Gov. Robert Casey said in a memorial service here Saturday. "The roll reads like a list of the family next door."
They came from places called Latrobe and Monongahela and Monessen, where a quarter will buy five hours on the parking meters downtown.
"The towns are so close together around here that everyone knows someone from another town and everyone certainly feels this," said Jim Steeley, a teacher at a local high school. "I don't know of any geographic part of the country that was hit as hard as this immediate area was by the war."
President Bush agreed. "For the Greensburg community, I know the cost of freedom has been particulary high," he said in a letter that was read at the memorial service, which was attended by more than 1,000 people.
 
Kindness From Strangers
 Other services are planned or have already been held throughout the area. But not all the expressions of grief have come in the form of organized services.
In Monessen, where the parents of one of the reservists, Specialist Anthony Madison, live, an old man climbed the steep porch steps and knocked on the door. The man had tears in his eyes as he presented the family with a card and a $20 bill.
The old man was a stranger.
Counseling teams are being assembled to help family and friends deal with the grief. That will not be easy.
"We are still stunned by the suddenness of the tragedy," Governor Casey said at the memorial. "The shock is worse because we believed they were out of harm's way."
The 13 reservists were members of the 14th Quartermaster Detachment, a 69-member water purification unit housed in Saudi Arabia with several other reserve units miles from the front. They had arrived in Saudi Arabia only a few days before the attack and were staying in a barracks in Dhahran.
Their deaths, and the deaths of 15 other reservists living in the barracks, are the largest concentration of United States casualties in a war that killed 95 Americans. And the fact that they all died so far from the front during a ground war that had been expected to produce many front line casualties is one of the cruelest ironies of the conflict.
Patriotism was a major reason most of them had joined the Reserves. Many were the sons and daughters of soldiers and grew up waving flags on the Fourth of July and listening to war stories around the dinner table.
But they were also pushed through the recruitment office door by the need to earn money for college or to learn a new skill for a job market that threatened to leave them standing in front of a closed steel mill.
 
Ordinary and Extraordinary
 Reading the roll of the victims, Governor Casey called them "salt of the earth people, who were extraordinary Americans." People like Specialist Beverly S. Clark, 23 years old, of Armagh, a secretary and member of the Future Business Leaders of America; Specialist Steven E. Atherton, 26, a forklift operator who lived with his wife, Brenda, and 6-month-old son Aaron in Nu Mine, and dreamed of the day they could buy a house;
Specialist Frank S. Keough, 22, of North Huntingdon, who wanted to become a reading teacher and who joined the Reserves to earn money for college; Specialist Frank J. Walls, 20, of Hawthorn, a college student who like thousands of young people in a region that produced football greats like Joe Montana was a devoted athlete; Specialist John A. Boliver Jr. of Monongahela, who followed his grandfather and father into the military;
Sgt. Allan B. Craver, 32, of Penn Hills, who felt that the water purification mission was socially responsible work; Specialist Richard V. Wolverton, 24, who was born into a military family and settled in Latrobe 10 years ago; Stephen Siko, 24, of Lloydsville, a 1984 graduate of Greater Latrobe High School who was divorced and had a 5-year-old son named Stephen Jacob; Specialist Thomas G. Stone, 20, of Jamestown, N.Y., a star on his high school wrestling team and the father of a 17-month-old girl.
 
The Student
A Steady March Toward a Dream
Early in the morning of Memorial Day in 1987, Donald Reed sat on his porch swing in Hickory, Pa., when a pickup truck rumbled past and pulled up at the cemetery just down the road.
A young man in jeans got out and slowly walked amid the tombstones, a trumpet under his arm. Raising it, he played taps, so softly that Mr. Reed had to strain to hear the notes. Then he got in the truck and rumbled up the street in a cloud of dust.
The solitary figure was Joseph P. Bongiorni 3d, then a high school junior, more recently a specialist with the 14th Army Reserve Quartermaster Detachment.
A quiet, earnest boy who loved to play music and to hike and fish in the Allegheny Mountains here in Western Pennsylvania, Mr. Bongiorni had another passion in life: the military. "Ever since he was a little boy, Joey wanted to be a soldier," said his mother, Rita Bongiorni.
 
Promise to Parents
 That young Joey came to be in the Reserves was not of his own choice. He had wanted to join the Army full time right out of high school, but Mrs. Bongiorni and her husband, Joseph 2d, made him promise to go to college first. So at the age of 17, he enrolled at West Virginia University in Morgantown as a civil engineering major. The call for active duty came in January; within a month he was in the Middle East.
"He wanted to go," said Mr. Bongiorni's 24-year-old sister, Jody. "Joey was a little scared, like any normal person would be, but he wanted to go."
His eagerness was so great that he was a bit frustrated to learn that his main duties would be with a water purification unit in Saudi Arabia, far from the front lines.
"Hey Bro," he had written in a rambling letter to Timothy Gilbert, one of his best friends, just days before he left for the gulf. "Who wants to be a water boy, anyway?"
Mr. Bongiorni was an honor student who graduated from Fort Cherry High School in 1989. He played defensive end for the Fort Cherry Rangers football team and played trumpet in the school band. At half time, when the other members marched out in red uniforms, there was Mr. Bongiorni marching in his muddy jersey and shoulder pads.
The school's principal, Jess King, recalled that he "never gave less than 110 percent in everything he did." His music teacher, Dick Burns, said that Mr. Bongiorni "used to have a little trouble with the high notes," but would practice for hours at a time in the band room.
"I think he liked music for the same reason he liked the military," Mr. Burns said. "It was the discipline of the thing."
About 150 people turned out in a rattling wind on Thursday afternoon for a brief memorial service at the high school. At the family's request, the service concluded with Mr. Burns stepping to the school marquee and playing taps.
 
The Athlete
Talent Wasted In a Dying Town
When Specialist Anthony Madison was a boy growing up in Monessen, he dreamed of becoming a professional boxer. He hoped to dance and slug his way to the top and away from a life in the mills where his father had earned a decent living but had also lost a leg.
Specialist Madison was 9 years old when his father, Norman, took his son into the basement of the Taylor Funeral Home, where he worked part-time. There in the dimness, Mr. Madison, a former Marine Corps boxing champion, began teaching the skinny boy how to fight.
"He caught on real quick," Mr. Madison, 54, said last week. "But sometimes he got a little hard headed. He'd drop his hands and I'd have to pop him one. He thought he could box better than me. I said, 'Hey, I taught you what I know, but not all I know.' Those were some good times. Real good times." He fell silent as if the memory had stolen his voice.
A few minutes later the telephone rang in Mr. Madison's two-story house. It was Taylor's calling to discuss arrangements for his son's funeral.
Anthony Madison was born in Monessen 27 years ago and graduated from Monessen High School in 1983. A gifted athlete, he struggled in school, especially after his parents' divorce and then his mother's death in 1982. He spent a year in the job corps learning bricklaying, and loved playing music as a disk jockey around town.
Specialist Madison played on the football team at Monessen and dated the girl he later married, Leeann. They had two children, Dacarra, 3, and Anthony Jr., 5.
In this part of the country where football is both king and queen, Specialist Madison could have been a prince if he had stuck with the sport and his studies, said his former coach and counselor, Jack Scarvel. He played both defensive end and running back.
"He was an impact player," Mr. Scarvel said. "He was a wiry, hard-hitting football player. I asked one of the coaches about him once and he said, 'Tony is the kind of kid that you want in the foxhole with you.' He'd do anything you asked of him. He was quiet, loyal. He made this town proud."
 
Nothing Else But to Join
 Like countless other communities in this part of Pennsylvania, time has not been kind to Monessen or its young.
When Specialist Madison was a boy, jobs in the steel mills were almost as plentiful as apples in an orchard. But as he grew into manhood, the mills began to disappear and by the time he finished a three-year enlistment in the Army he could not find work.
Less than a year ago, he joined the Reserves. "There was nothing else for him to do," said his stepmother, Darla.
Shortly before shipping out to the desert, Specialist Madison pulled up a chair and tried to reassure his father.
"He said, 'Don't worry about me,' " Mr. Madison recalled. "He said, 'I know you will, but don't. I'm not going to be nowhere near the war. I'll be back.' "
 
The Sergeant
Faith in Army And Himself
John T. Boxler was one of the thousands of people in Western Pennsylvania who lost their jobs in the 1970's when the steel mills were closing because of competition overseas. But unlike many who gave up on the region and moved away, he hung on, looked for work and eventually found it with the Postal Service in Johnstown.
Such was the nature of Sergeant Boxler, a Vietnam veteran and Johnstown native who at 44 years was the oldest member of the 14th Detachment to die in the Scud attack.
Sergeant Boxler's family and friends described him as a gregarious man who had "a zest to pitch in," as one colleague said, whether he was in the kitchen, at the postal garage or at the Westmont Volunteer Fire Department in his neighborhood.
"He wasn't the most polished guy in the world, but he'd give you the shirt off his back," said his mother-in-law, Jane Crowley. "He must have given gallons and gallons of blood to the Red Cross. Every eight weeks, he'd go down there."
 
Town Is a Shadow of Itself
 Johnstown is a factory town, a place that literally grew up around steel and iron and coal. While perhaps most famous as the scene of the calamitous flood in 1889 that killed more than 2,000 people in the Conemaugh Valley, Johnstown has suffered quieter devastation in more recent times. There are 2,000 factory jobs left, barely one-tenth the number here during World War I.
Sergeant Boxler lost his job in 1977, when Bethlehem Steel "downsized." He struggled for a few years, but finally with the help of his experience as a helicopter mechanic in Vietnam he landed a job with the post office as a vehicle maintenance worker.
Although they both grew up in Johnstown, Elaine Boxler did not meet her future husband until the day he came home from Vietnam, in July 1970. She said he was proud to be in the Reserves, and when the call came to go to Saudi Arabia, he was "raring to go."
Because of Sergeant Boxler's military experience, the Boxlers were not unduly worried when he left. John Jr. told his mother, "Don't worry at all; Dad was in Vietnam and he knows how to take care of himself." Mrs. Boxler remembered thinking, "A water purification unit -- what could sound like a safer thing to be a part of."
At 6 A.M. Wednesday, an official car pulled up with two Army reservists to the Boxlers' tidy, two-story colonial house. One of the reservists could not stop himself from crying when he stood at the doorway and read a statement of condolence from the Army.
Now the Johnstown post office is draped with black bunting. But the Boxler home is still hung with American flags and bright yellow ribbons. That was one thing, Mrs. Boxler said with a sad smile as she walked a visitor through the house the other night -- it had not occurred to her to take the ribbons down.
 
The Shy One
Seeing the World And Growing Up
For Specialist Christine L. Mayes, military service marked a coming of age.
As a teen-ager in this Pennsylvania's coal country, Ms. Mayes spent long afternoons walking with friends down the lone street here, playing high school softball or picking corn for spending money. She was "a good girl, but a shy one," said neighbors and school friends. So shy that even in Rochester Mills, a rural community of 65 families where most everyone is related by blood or marriage, Ms. Mayes kept mostly to herself.
Until she joined the military. Like many other young people in this economically depressed region, Ms. Mayes saw the Army as a way to help pay for the college education that her father, a construction worker, could not afford. She enlisted right after graduating from Marion Center Area High School in 1986 and was shipped to Germany, where she served as a cook for three years.
When Specialist Mayes was discharged and arrived home last summer, the honey-colored curls of a girl who had once belonged to the Future Homemakers of America had given way to a bleached blond coiffure, triple-pierced ears and a penchant for rap music.
"I didn't even know what rap music was," said Linda Winebark, a childhood friend who said she did not recognize Specialist Mayes upon her return. "She went from T-shirts and blue jeans to skirts and heels," she said. "Chris had really grown up and become outgoing. It was like when she left here she was Christine. When she came back, she was Chris."
 
Getting Ready to Settle Down
 But the transition back to small-town living had been a good one, friends and neighbors said. In June 1990, Specialist Mayes began dating David Fairbanks, of nearby Punxsutawney, Pa., a drilling assistant whose father, Arnold, was an Army reservist.
That fall, Specialist Mayes, her younger sister Pamela and her father, Franklin, now unemployed, began courses at the Punxsutawney campus of Indiana University of Pennsylvania. In October, hoping to pull in some extra family income, Specialist Mayes joined the Reserves in Greensburg.
"She liked the service and she wanted to help Mom and Dad out," said Pamela, 19.
The weekend before she left for Saudi Arabia, Specialist Mayes, 22, and Mr. Fairbanks became engaged, but she did not take her ring with her for fear she would lose it.
The loss now, however, has been to Rochester Mills. Since last Wednesday, when news of her death came, visitors loaded with food and gifts have worn a mud path outside the modest one-story home, where a lone birch tied with tiny yellow ribbons stands sentinel.
Pamela Mayes said the family had received cards or calls from everyone in town. "We have even had calls from people on the answering machine who just say, 'God bless you,' and then hang up," she said.
Sandy Pardee, the Mayeses' next door neighbor, said community members were trying to build a memorial to Christine that would go in the village post office.
"I'm sure this is hard for the Mayeses in their grieving, but Chris is part of history now," said Mrs. Pardee, who offers $5 haircuts in her garage-turned-beauty shop. "This is kind of a tribute. If Chris could look out of the window, I know she would think it is such a gas that all of this could be going on in such a tiny little place like Rochester Mills."

HEADLINE: Defying Recession With Exports

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
In an aging brown-brick factory here, hunched over tool-littered workbenches, men and women are coaxing tiny wires into circuit boards as they put together the computer controls that are the brains of machine tools.
Once finished, the Hurco Companies' control consoles and the assembled machine tools that cut, bend and mold metal parts are heading overseas. They are going to Germany, France, Britain, Singapore, South Korea and two dozen other countries -- part of the wave of American manufactured exports that has been a surprising source of strength amid the nation's economic recession. 
 The surge in exports of not just machine tools -- a building-block industry often seen as a barometer of a nation's industrial health -- but of everything from aircraft engines to power generators to nuts and bolts has helped make this recession very different from the one in 1981-82.
 
A Remarkable Resilience
 Last time, manufacturing companies and the industrial Midwest suffered most. Now, leaner, smarter and more competitive internationally, the manufacturing sector has shown a remarkable resilience.
Last year, American manufactured exports rose nearly 10 percent, to $316 billion, adding to a comeback that has seen such exports jump more than 80 percent since 1985, according to the Commerce Department. To be sure, the United States still runs a sizable, though declining, trade deficit. And slower economic growth abroad may cut into exports. Yet so far, shipments of manufactured goods overseas have held up.
The fall in the dollar's value, roughly 50 percent since 1985, has played a big part in selling American goods overseas, making them cheaper to foreign buyers. But beyond the change in the terms of trade, executives and analysts agree that the attitudes and competitiveness of many American companies have sharply improved.
As proof of the broad-based change, they point out that while a handful of big corporations, like Boeing and General Electric, have helped, most of the recent gains on America's export ledger have come from the numerous ranks of middle-sized companies, like Hurco, based here in Indianapolis. Such companies typically have annual sales of $50 million to less than $1 billion.
These companies, analysts say, have made big strides in improving the technological performance and the quality of their goods, straining to match efficient rivals in Japan, Germany and elsewhere. And by the thousands, executives from the industrial heartland have flown to places where the language, the food and the customs are strange, shedding traditional American parochialism in search of business.
"There's still a way to go, but we're beginning to do a lot of the right things in corporate America," said Kent Hughes, president of the Council on Competitiveness, a nonprofit research and policy organization in Washington.
 
Research Pays Off
 Hurco is a classic example of a midsized company that has clawed its way back from deep troubles to global competitiveness. It has improved its products and invested heavily in research and development, changes that have enabled the company to increase its share of the United States market and sharply expand sales abroad, cushioning Hurco somewhat from the cycles of American business.
Hurco sells machine tools to the "workhorse" end of the market, the small-batch manufacturing processes, for $40,000 to $150,000 apiece. Its customers include big companies like Boeing, General Motors and I.B.M., but Hurco's main market is the thousands of small subcontractors that supply larger companies with parts and components, and typically employ 50 people or fewer.
Hurco was a small but innovative builder of machine tools that ran into deep troubles in the 1980's when it tried to expand as the American manufacturing sector was being squeezed. It lost money for four straight years, through 1985, while debts mounted and quality-control problems proliferated, from oil leaks to bugs in computer software. To try to cope, management cut the work force of more than 600 people in 1984 to 360 by 1986, when Hurco returned to profitability.
Also in 1986, Brynwood Partners Ltd. bought much of its current 27 percent stake in Hurco. Brynwood, an investment firm based in Greenwich, Conn., has championed Hurco's spending programs as prudent bets on the future that will pay off for the shareholders, said Richard Niner, a general partner of Brynwood. In 1987, Brian McLaughlin, a young executive from the Ransberg Corporation, which makes factory automation equipment, was recruited as Hurco's president and chief executive.
 
Overseas Business Rebuilt
 Mr. McLaughlin set about building Hurco's fledgling global business, reducing debt, improving service and focusing research efforts on upgrading the technology of the company's greatest competitive strength -- computerized controls for machine tools.
To date, the strategy seems to be working in an industry littered with American casualties. Japanese companies like Fanuc, Mazak and Okuma have been the big winners in the American market, both by exporting and direct investment, despite a 1986 export restraint agreement with Tokyo.
Between 1987 and the fiscal year that ended last October, Hurco's revenues doubled and profits tripled, to $94 million and $6.9 million. The work force is back up to 530 employees, and more are being hired. Today, roughly half of Hurco's revenues come from sales in 28 foreign markets. Most of the company's overseas sales are in Europe, and about 20 percent of Hurco's revenues come in the highly competitive German machine tool market.
Like many internationally minded American companies, Hurco has moved beyond simple exports. The key component of its machine tools -- the computerized controls -- are all made in the United States. But most of the machines sold in Europe, for example, are assembled at its plant in High Wycombe, England, west of London. There, the controllers from the United States are put together with housings, fittings and screws from Germany, Spain, Taiwan or wherever they are produced most efficiently.
So exports alone represent less than half of Hurco's foreign sales, even though the company's exports are growing quickly and the components shipped from the United States are the heart of its machines. "Our computer control technology is what allows us to get orders," Mr. McLaughlin, 48 years old, said in a recent interview.
In Germany, the company bought out its Swiss partner in 1988 to establish Hurco G.m.b.H., and expand its sales and technical support staff in that market. The Germans expect service calls on machine tools to be made within 24 hours, a high standard that Hurco now provides to its American customers as well. Over all, more than 20 percent of the company's employees are now stationed abroad.
 
Shipping to Affiliates Overseas
 "We've found that exporting alone is too distant a relationship to really develop an international business," Mr. McLaughlin said.
Other American companies have learned the same lesson. Indeed, about a third of American manufactured exports to Europe are shipments by United States companies to their European affiliates, just as Hurco does, said Stephen Cooney, an international specialist at the National Association of Manufacturers, the Washington-based trade group.
Hurco's East Asian business, recently begun, is starting to take off with encouraging orders from South Korea, Singapore and Malaysia. The Commerce Department recently chose Hurco as one of several American companies to participate in a five-year program to crack the Japanese market, the Everest of the machine-tool industry.
"Hurco is selling good-quality basic machines all over the world," said Edward Miller, president of the National Center of Manufacturing Sciences, a research group in Ann Arbor, Mich. "If you can succeed in that part of the machine-tool market, you can compete anywhere."
Thanks to changes in product design and manufacturing, Hurco's cost for repairing machines on warranty is just 8 percent of the level in 1984. The training of machinists, which the company started as a "necessary evil" to sell machine tools, became so professional that it was set up as a separate business, generating revenues of $1 million a year.
Still, Hurco is not immune to the recession. The price discounting in the United States and Britain, which trimmed earnings last year, is expected to continue.
 
Tough Year Expected
 "Make no mistake, 1991 is going to be a tough year for us," Mr. McLaughlin said. "But this company is now in a position to be able to go ahead in this difficult period with a sizable investment program."
Hurco will spend more than $4 million this year on research and development, several times the industry average of seven-tenths of 1 percent of revenues. The company plans to move into a new $6 million, 175,000-square-foot plant in June, housing both production and administrative operations. That building, which will have an exercise room for employees, overlooks a lake with a running path. All Hurco employees are eligible for profit-sharing bonuses.
The research budget is going mainly toward developing specialized computer software for machine tools. Already, Hurco executives say they have an edge over their rivals in computer software, which gives the company two advantages: Its machines are easier to use, and the vital process of converting a customer's blueprint into a finished part is faster and often more accurate.
 
Speeding to Next Task
 The so-called print-to-part process takes about 24 minutes, compared with roughly 90 minutes on most competing machines, said Michael Seall, Hurco's vice president for marketing. In the flexible, small-batch production that is increasingly replacing mass production even at large companies, the speed with which machines can be set up for the next task is crucial to productivity.
To build on that advantage, Hurco engineers are working on further advances in software to offset the edge enjoyed by bigger foreign rivals in efficiently producing machine tools in volume.
"The hardware is becoming more and more a commodity," said David Platts, vice president for research and development. "The challenge for us is to bring state-of-the-art software and computing ability to the machine-tool industry. And it's the only way to get at the strategic problems of the American industry."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations;
U.N. Compromise Plan To Widen Relief to Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 3

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council pledged tonight to exempt more food and humanitarian aid from its trade embargo against Iraq and speed authorization for delivering the supplies to needy people there.
The decision, announced by Austria, this month's Council president, represented a compromise between the United States and its gulf war allies and a group of members who wanted trade sanctions lifted altogether on goods needed to preserve public health in Iraq. 
 The gulf allies say they are ready to send Iraq more humanitarian supplies to relieve suffering and stem the danger of epidemics resulting from polluted water and poor medical services. But they plan to do so on an exceptional basis without changing the Council's decision to ban all trade with Iraq except medicines.
The coalition partners say they are opposed to any formal weakening of the Security Council's economic embargo aganst Iraq at this stage because they are still pressing Baghdad to comply fully with their terms for a formal cease-fire.
 
Cease-Fire Resolution Approved
 Saturday night the Council approved a new resolution endorsing the conditions for a cease-fire and reaffirming the trade sanctions against Iraq as well as the allies' right to attack Iraq again if it does not make peace on their terms.
In a letter to the Council today, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said the Iraqi Government had accepted the resolution and "will fulfill its obligations under the said resolution."
He asked the Security Council to declare a formal cease-fire and to lift all sanctions against Baghdad.
As a result of the compromise tonight, five Council members, India, Cuba, Yemen, Ecuador and Zimbabwe, withdrew a resolution they had circulated that would have formally lifted the Security Council's trade embargo on food as well as on machinery and supplies used for purifying water and generating electricity.
 
Health Reports Prompt Appeal
 The five countries introduced this resolution after the World Health Organization and Unicef reported last week that Iraqi children are short of food and that hospitals and water treatment plants, operating without public electricity, desperately need portable generators and fuel.
The Council wants a special committee empowered to approve humanitarian exceptions to the embargo to speed up its work and take a more generous approach, allowing shipment of a wider range of supplies.
Today the committee examined the W.H.O.-Unicef report and asked for more details on what equipment Iraq needs to improve health standards. Diplomats said W.H.O. and Unicef will supply this information in the next few days when the committee is likely to give the green light for these supplies to be sent in.
 
Resolution Gets 11 Votes
 At today's meeting the committee also approved requests by the Danish and Belgian Red Cross to send in food for children. Last week it allowed Iran to send in some 700 tons of food.
The new resolution endorsing President Bush's cease-fire terms was supported by 11 of the Council's 15 members. Only Cuba voted against it while China, India and Yemen abstained.

HEADLINE: U.S. Balks at Easing Export Curbs

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Fearful of the political and economic tension in the Soviet Union and arms proliferation in the third world, the Bush Administration has begun taking a harder line on how to restrict exports of technology with military applications.
The more cautious approach led to the postponement last week of a long-scheduled meeting in Paris in which the United States and 16 allies were to consider a drastic reduction in the number of technologies subject to export restrictions. 
 The meeting of the group, known as the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom, was put off for 30 to 45 days, a significant sign that the Bush Administration is quietly slowing, and in some cases reversing, a relaxation process announced with fanfare last spring, as the cold war was abating.
 
At Odds With Allies
 That puts it at odds with many European allies who want the benefits of greater trade.
At the same time, the Administration is expected to publish soon in the Federal Register stiffer regulations against the spread of chemical and biological weapons.
This is a "difficult period in U.S.-Soviet relations," said Robert Zoellick, a State Department counselor, saying it required a "flexible approach" by the United States on all fronts.
Paul Freedenberg, the top export-control official during most of the Reagan Administration, said that what is occurring now is a "drawing back from the feeling that the cold war is over and that security concerns are finished." He added, 'It's all related to what happens in the U.S.S.R. and in the third world after Saddam Hussein."
The Administraton's caution is causing flutters among corporate executives, who had counted on broad decontrol of technology to all destinations to perk up revenues.
 
Concern Among Corporations
 "What makes business most nervous is the unilateral application of our controls," said William T. Archey, international vice president at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "History shows that other people don't necessarily follow our leadership, and so they get the sales that we don't make."
Cocom consists of the member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, except for Iceland, and Australia and Japan.
Under a plan worked out by the allies in June, controls would have been maintained in telecommunications, computers, software, lasers, turbines, navigation, avionics and propulsion systems and other "core" categories, but only at the most sophisticated end of the technology spectrum.
Then, with a core list in hand, there would be large reductions, as much as 25 percent, in the overall range of technology exports subject to export licenses.
 
Accord in Doubt
 The gulf between Washington and Europe is so wide that many analysts wonder whether Cocom will be able to reach agreement at its next meeting. Under the schedule announced in June, the allies were to agree on the core technologies by the end of last year.
The United States and Germany are especially at odds over telecommunications. The Germans want to decontrol such technology as high-transmission fiber-optic cables that carry more telephone traffic and the signaling switches used in large Western cities to route calls faster.
 
Far-Reaching Controls
 The new chemical, biological and nuclear weapons controls are described as unusually far reaching. For the first time, all exports of manufacturing, plant designs and processing equipment associated with the manufacture of weapons would require special licenses.
In trying to draft the regulations on chemicals, United States agencies are still fighting among themselves over which countries the rules would be directed at.
The State Department, worried about offending Syria and other nations, resists identifying countries as special targets. It would prefer to list regions like the Middle East where exports would be restricted.
To control chemical weapons, 20 nations have joined under the leadership of Australia.
Known as the Australia Group, they share intelligence on suspected chemical weapons development. While the State Department objects to identifying specific countries, the Australia Group has already singled out Iran, Iraq, Libya and Syria as official targets for export controls.
Similar bodies -- the 12-nation Missile Technology Control Regime and the 14-nation Nuclear Suppliers Group -- have been formed in recent years to seek to control proliferation in those areas.

HEADLINE: California Readies for Political Brawl Over Both of Its Senate Seats in 1992

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., March 3

 BODY:
California politics is erupting into a full-scale, $70 million brawl with more than a dozen contenders maneuvering for two of the state's top political prizes: the United States Senate seats, which will both be open next year. Democrats and Republicans both have reason to hope for a sweep, making the election a potential bonanza as the parties push for dominance in the Senate.
State party conventions last weekend and this are the starting blocks for the 20-month campaign, when candidates must distingusih themselves in a crowded field. The next hurdle comes on June 30, when the first campaign finance reports are filed and the cast is likely to thin to those candidates, perhaps seven in all, who are capable of raising $4 million for a primary and $10 million for a general election, which is what experts believe those races will cost. 
 The last time there were two Senate seats open in a state at once was in 1978, in both Alabama and Minnesota.
The two Senate races in the same year, a first here, came about because of Pete Wilson's election as Governor in November, after the Republican former Senator's battle with Dianne Feinstein, and the decision of Senator Alan Cranston, a Democrat, not to seek re-election because of prostate cancer and the political damage he suffered from the savings and loan scandal.
Mr. Wilson appointed John Seymour to fill his Senate seat, which will be contested again in 1994. Now Mr. Seymour is seeking to be elected to the remainder of Mr. Wilson's term, but first faces a nettlesome primary challenge from Representative William E. Dannemeyer of Fullerton, who has built a career opposing homosexual rights. The primary, while costly, is thought by some analysts to be an opportunity for Mr. Seymour, a rather bland former state legislator, to establish his identity as a moderate in the mold of his benefactor, Mr. Wilson.
 
Running Twice in 2 Years
 Ms. Feinstein, a Democrat, announced that she would run against Mr. Seymour for this "short seat" in the hope of avoiding a bruising primary, despite the cost of running three statewide campaigns in four years. So far the strategy has been successful, although some analysts here suspect that Gray Davis, the Democratic state controller, may enter the race, which could comlicate Ms. Feinstein's plans.
The second seat, jokingly referred to as a multicar collision, involves five or six Democrats and a similar number of Republicans. While four Democrats have formally declared their candidacies, one who has not, Representative Mel Levine of Los Angeles, already stands out as the only Democrat seeking either of the Senate seats who supported President Bush on going to war against Iraq rather than continuing economic sanctions.
The Democrats who have announced for the six-year seat are Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., the iconoclastic former Governor; Lieut. Gov. Leo T. McCarthy; Representative Robert T. Matsui of Sacramento and Representative Barbara Boxer of San Francisco.
Mr. Brown is considered the early favorite, because he is the best known and has a cadre of supporters, albeit dwindling in size, that could be enough to secure victory in a large field.
The races come in a Presidential year and coincide with contests for seven new Congressional seats to be created by reapportionment and will surely produce a cacaphony of high-priced political advertising in this vast state where campaigns consistently set national spending records.
"There are already reports of donor burnout," said Don Sipple, a Republican political consultant. Paul Maslin, a Democratic poll taker, agreed. "This may be a rich state," he said, "but it's not that rich."
The competition for money will be less intense for Republicans, who can ride the coattails of a President whose popularity has soared with the swift victory in the Persian Gulf. The National Republican Senatorial Committee says it is "unfortunate" that Mr. Seymour is being challenged in the primary, the sort of messy battle that is common among Democrats but that Republicans managed to avoid when Mr. Wilson ran for governor. But party officials say there is plenty of money to cover the cost.
The Democrats, however, will be scrambling for money.
While Ms. Feinstein struggled to raise nearly $20 million in her bid to be governor, eventually relying on a $3 million gift from her husband, an investment banker, she emerged from the race with a donor list of more than 60,000. She is also the best known candidate, familiar to 86 percent of the electorate, a recent California Poll found.
 
Well-Known Names
 Some other candidates also start out with the advantage of being well known and thus need less money. In that category are Mr. Brown, who resigned Saturday midway through a stormy tenure as state Democratic chairman; Mr. McCarthy, who lost a Senate race to Mr. Wilson in 1988, and Mr. Davis.
Mr. Brown hopes to pattern a grassroots campaign on the successful race for Governor by Lawton Chiles last year in Florida. Mr. Brown may be the favorite in the primary, but many analysts say he would be weakest Democrat in a general election if the Republicans chose a mainstream candidate, like Ed Zschau, a former Representative, or Representative Tom Campbell of Palo Alto, rather than someone from the far right wing of the party, like Representative Robert K. Dornan of Garden Grove or Bruce Herschenson, a television personality.
"Jerry has the potential to be real destructive to the Democrats," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a politcal analyst at Claremont Graduate School.
The richest Democratic candidate, undeclared although actively raising money, is Mr. Levine, who relies for financial support on the powerful Los Angeles political organization run by Representatives Howard L. Berman and Henry A. Waxman. Mr. Davis also depends on the the Berman-Waxman organization and is thus considered likely to chose the other seat.
Mr. Levine stayed away from the state Democratic convention, which ended here today, thus avoiding taking heat from party liberals for his vote on the war, a vote that could reap a rich harvest from Jewish donors.
 
Asians Seen as a Factor
 Also in good shape financially is Representative Matsui of Sacramento, a member of the House Ways and Means Committee and thus a beneficiary of contributions from those eager to influence Federal tax policy. He will also tap California's Asians, who now represent 10 percent of the state's population, double the proportion of a decade ago, and have yet to emerge as voting bloc, but have wealth to share with a Japanese-American candidate.
The candidate thought to be weakest on fund raising is Ms. Boxer. She has attracted attention lately, however, with high-visibility stands, like her authorship of a bill to prohibit sending two parents to the Persian Gulf.
"The most important thing is that Barbara is different," said Tony Coehlo, the former House Democratic whip. "She sparkles. Her eyes dance."
Republicans are already using the national euphoria about the war as a weapon, as Senator Seymour did at last weekend's Republican convention when he said the Democrats "would have cut our President off at the knees."
Still, Democrats are not giving up. "If the election were tomorrow, sure a Republican would win," said Ed McGovern, Ms. Boxer's campaign manager. "But it's not. It's 20 months from now. The economy may totally go into to the tank. Things are fluid and 20 months is a long time."

HEADLINE: U.S. Slump Hurts Japan Car Sales

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 3

 BODY:
The recession in the United States and an unusual burst of frugality among Japanese consumers -- is finally beginning to hurt Japan's largest car makers, forcing them to cut production and rethink plans for constant expansion in North America.
While the Japanese are selling fewer cars, just about everybody in the industry agrees that they are likely to emerge from the recession with a significantly larger share of the American market, at Detroit's expense. Yet for political reasons, Japan's big automobile makers have been portraying the slump as more dire than it may be. 
 "There is a strong feeling among the leaders of the industry that we have to be seen to be suffering as much as General Motors or Ford or Chrysler," one senior executive of the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest car company, after Toyota, said recently.
 
Honda Sales Down 22%
 Without question, the manufacturers that seemed invincible are hurting. The Honda Motor Company's sales in the United States are down by 22 percent, and the executives who talked last year about ways to expand the company's huge manufacturing operations in Ohio are scrambling for ways to keep all of their American workers employed.
The Toyota Motor Corporation, which two months ago waved aside most concerns about an approaching downturn, has now revised its predictions for the fiscal year that will end on June 30, saying profits could drop by 18 percent from a year earlier. The decline would be Toyota's first in four years.
In January, sales of Japanese models in the United States were down by about 10 percent, a big decline but less than half that of the American auto makers. More surprising, perhaps, is that in Japan, where the automobile market has been booming for four years, new-car sales have declined by about 2 percent in recent months. But those drops are based on a comparison with a record level of Japanese sales -- a level so high that most Japanese makers could not fill demand a year earlier.
"The companies will tell you that they are hurting, and by their measures they are," said Kenny Hyman, the automobile analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. in Tokyo. "But the fact is that most factories here are still running at full capacity."
But many people here are beginning to question openly whether that will remain true in the next two months, especially if Japan's stock market remains stagnant.
If the downturn in Japan is manageable, the decline in the United States is fraught with political problems. This is the first severe recession since Toyota, Nissan, Honda and the Mazda Motor Corporation each built large assembly operations on American soil. Last year, they built 1.3 million cars in the United States, and Japanese autos now command more than 30 percent of the market, if Japanese-engineered cars sold under American badges are included.
While each car maker says it does not want to gain ground at Detroit's expense, that appears to be what is happening. Even if overall sales are down, executives here say, a rise in Japan's market share during a recession could cause a backlash in Congress.
 
Honda Is Most Affected
 At the same time, so could a bigger downturn. One selling point of Japanese factories in the United States has been Japan's postwar practice of lifetime employment, even in difficult times, though no one knows how well the practice will extend to operations in the United States.
Indeed, the prospect of steady employment has helped Japanese companies to keep unions out of most plants. Should the downturn worsen, no Japanese maker will want to be the first to lay off American workers.
The most severe troubles so far appear to be afflicting Honda, long the Japanese champion of the American market. Its sales in the United States were down by 22 percent in recent months, to 45,375 vehicles, about half of them produced in the United States. The other half are imported from Japan.
Honda said last month that over the next three months, it would cut production by about 20,000 vehicles, including 5,000 a month in the United States.
"For Honda, it is a quite serious reduction, and we had to make a quick judgment to keep things from getting worse," said Shin Tanaka, a spokesman. "What is happening is that every market is declining." On Feb. 22, Honda announced results for its fiscal third quarter, showing a 50 percent decline in operating profits.
Analysts note that Honda is particularly hard hit because it has a much weaker base in Japan, where it is still, remarkably, considered a newcomer. When Honda's production cutback figures were announced, some Japanese newspapers scoffed, noting that cuts of that size often occur unannounced in Japanese auto factories.
But Japan's other big car makers felt obliged to match Honda's announcement, telling reporters that they did not want to appear to be pushing forward in the United States while American car makers were in retreat.
Then Toyota executives quickly said the company would reduce exports to the United States by 10,000 vehicles over two months. That is a tiny fraction of the 325,000 cars Toyota produces every month, and the figure is even smaller because Toyota said it would divert some American-bound cars to other destinations, particularly to Southeast Asia.
Nissan reported much the same when its president, Yutaka Kume, said it would cut back exports to the United States by 4,000 to 5,000 vehicles. Many of the cars will be diverted to Europe.

HEADLINE: Vermont Development Laws May Have Saved Its Banks

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Vermont is the only New England state that has not had a bank failure in the current economic downturn, and its strict environmental laws -- not shrewd Yankee banking -- are widely credited with saving the state from the worst excesses of the Northeast's real estate boom.
"There are still problems here, but nowhere like those in New Hampshire, Maine and Massachusetts," said Thomas Menson, a former chief operating officer of the Bank of Vermont. Mr. Menson also spent the last five years as the top banking and financial adviser to Madeleine M. Kunin, who recently stepped down as Governor. 
 The environmental laws, known as Act 250, required such a long review process that they discouraged poorly capitalized developers. Mr. Menson said the act "weeded out the poorer projects, and you only get well-capitalized developers," and added, "You don't get someone who made a profit on one house suddenly trying to put in a whole development."
The sharpest contrast, bank analysts say, is to the situation in New Hampshire, which has long been the New England state with the most laissez-faire attitude toward development.
"I think all five of the largest banks in New Hampshire will require Federal assistance unless the economy turns around," said Gerard Cassidy, who follows New England banks in the Portland, Me., office of the Tucker, Anthony brokerage firm.
Act 250, enacted 21 years ago, has some of the nation's toughest and most time-consuming environmental rules and procedures. It applies to all commercial and public developments as well as residential projects of 10 units or more. Projects are reviewed by regional boards that consider 10 criteria: conformance to local plans, water use, sewage disposal, energy efficiency, soil erosion, effect on traffic and municipal services, preservation of wildlife habitats, historic sites, agricultural soil and esthetics.
The reviews serve as an umbrella for other state and local permits. Vermont also has a stiff capital gains tax on short-term land speculation that has helped to slow development.
Fewer than 2 percent of the projects presented to the Act 250 regional review boards are ultimately denied permits, but many are modified. For major developments, getting through the entire local and state review process can take several years and several million dollars. This comparatively strict regulatory climate has occasionally crimped profits at Vermont banks, said William Bruette Jr., the chief executive of the Chittenden Bank from 1984 until last year, when he moved to New Jersey to head Paine Webber Inc.'s national banking operations.
 
Cash-Flow Problems
 "Some projects that would have been economically viable got halted in their later phases, putting the developers into cash-flow problems that they wouldn't have had if they had been allowed to go forward," Mr. Bruette said.
But Mr. Bruette is one of many bankers who are convinced that Vermont benefited, on balance, from the regulations. Not only were fewer buildings constructed but those that came on the market ended up being more marketable because they were more environmentally attractive.
"A good loan depends on many of the criteria in Act 250," said John Ewing, president of the Bank of Vermont in Burlington. "There are plenty of cases where developments fail for lack of a good infrastructure, including things that banks don't normally take into account." Mr. Ewing is also a former chairman of the regional board that reviewed Act 250 applications in Chittenden County, which includes Burlington and is the state's most urbanized county.
Of course, Vermont's banks have not escaped New England's downturn unscathed. All of the state's leading banks have recently reported sharp declines in profits and have set aside more money to cover bad loans. Banknorth Group Inc., the largest commercial bank, last month suspended its quarterly dividend. And the Chittenden Bank, the state's largest until Banknorth was formed in a 1989 merger, reported a $1.5 million loss for 1990.
But over all, the Vermont banks remain strong by most historical measures, like the ratio of capital assets to loans or the percentage of loans that cause problems.
New Hampshire bankers doubt, however, that differences in environmental regulations have anything to do with their situation's being more precarious. They contend that the biggest factor is that New Hampshire -- and southern Maine -- are so close to Boston that they have been swamped by growth stemming from the rapid expansion of the high-technology and military contracting businesses in eastern Massachusetts.
 
Close to 'Ground Zero'
 When the Massachusetts economy crashed, New Hampshire inevitably crashed with it, they said. Vermont was too far from "ground zero," as the bankers now call Boston, to feel the brunt of the boom or the bust.
"I think market forces created our situation," said Marcel Veilleux, director of the New Hampshire Bankers Association in Concord. "I don't think stricter permitting would have slowed us enough for us to be in as good shape as Vermont."
Some Vermont developers also doubt that Act 250 has had much effect on the financial health of banks. "It certainly limits overbuilding, but not necessarily by weeding out the worst projects," said Peter Judge, owner of Judge Construction in Burlington. "It's basically a political process that has supplanted zoning."
Edwin Granai, a State Senator and real estate developer, has introduced legislation to "streamline" Act 250. One provision would exempt government-mandated projects, like new sewer systems and prisons, from review under the act. Others are intended to cut the number of occasions when developers must re-argue issues like traffic impact before state, regional and local agencies with overlapping concerns.
"I hear constant horror stories about delays and cost increments in projects that aren't bad," Mr. Granai said. "There are some desirable businesses that go right by Vermont, which hurts in tough economic times like these."

HEADLINE: Foes of Trump Compromise On His 'City'

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump has agreed to shrink his long-stalled plans for a huge development on the Upper West Side nearly in half and to give New York City land to reroute the West Side Highway to allow for a waterfront park -- if the Dinkins administration backs the compromise Mr. Trump reached with civic groups that had fought the project.
The agreement would break a logjam on Trump City, one of the most criticized real-estate proposals in the city, at a time when both the city and the developer, who has had recent financial setbacks, could use the economic benefits it would provide. In turn, the agreement would give civic groups the open space they have fought for, would allow for the rerouting of the West Side Highway to make way for the park and would leave Mr. Trump's plan for a 150-story tower no more than a dream abandoned. 
 Under the tentative compromise, Mr. Trump would reduce his project from 14.5 million square feet, including a huge shopping mall, to 8.3 million square feet, 6.2 million of it residential, with 1.8 million square feet of motion picture and television studios and the rest office space.
 
Announcement Expected Soon
 No representative for any of the parties would say yesterday that they had a final agreement, but they made it clear they expected to announce one soon. Participants in the negotiations on the project said Mr. Trump wanted public assurances from the Dinkins administration that it would support his scaled-down plan and not seek further compromises.
And the civic groups, participants say, want a strong commitment from the city that it intends to build a new highway eventually, farther inland at ground level, and tear down the existing elevated stretch of the road along the Hudson River from 59th to 72d Streets.
But the big catch is that the existing road is so badly deteriorated that officials say it might have to be closed at any time, sending 90,000 vehicles a day onto surface streets in Manhattan. The state and city intend to award a $62 million contract, perhaps today, to reconstruct it, using mostly Federal highway funds, rather than try to shore up the highway for the several years that would be needed before the inland road could be built.
Late yesterday, participants in the talks said they were still negotiating just what language the city would use to convince the civic groups that it would be willing to tear down the rebuilt highway, which could last 50 years. But in doing so, the city risks jeopardizing the Federal money it would need for either project.
Barbara J. Fife, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, speaking for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said yesterday: "The city is aware of the agreement, and we have encouraged that agreement. We are looking forward to making a statement in the next few days. We're pleased that there's a possibility that an important development can go forward without the contention that so often accompanies these projects."
Mr. Trump, in a telephone interview from Atlantic City, said: "I'm delighted that the community, the state and city and civic groups could come together in support of something. Not only will the job be a great job, but the cooperation means the process can work."
 
Civic Agreement Tied to City's
 Richard A. Kahan, an unpaid adviser to six civic groups, including the Municipal Art Society and the Parks Council, that had opposed Mr. Trump's original plan and offered an alternative that set the framework for a compromise, declined to comment on the negotiations last night. But others said the civic groups' agreement with the developer was contingent on the city's agreement.
Even if the Dinkins administration backed the plan, whose original version was first proposed in 1984, there is no guarantee that the revised project would be built as proposed. Mr. Trump would have to resubmit his application for a zoning change and undergo a long review by the City Planning Commission and City Council.
Negotiations on a compromise, which began in late December, intensified in the last few days, participants said, as the state approached a deadline of today for awarding a contract to rebuild the elevated highway. Also last week, the civic groups' suit seeking a restraining order to delay the contract was dismissed.
The groups have long wanted the road shored up temporarily, then rebuilt at ground level and moved east to allow easy access to a waterfront park.
 
Trump Owns Land Under Road
 But Mr. Trump and the city had contended that that idea was too costly and impractical, and the developer's original plan placed buildings where an inland road might go. The city does not own the land under the existing highway, or along the proposed alternative route; Mr. Trump owns both, and the city said it could not afford to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to buy the right of way. Mr. Trump's willingness to give the city the land would remove that hurdle.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, whose support could be critical for any Trump City plan and who opposed the old one, said the compromise was the first step in a long approval.
"As long as everyone keeps that in mind," Ms. Messinger added, "we are on the verge of moving away from an appallingly bad plan toward a concept for this site that makes a great deal of sense for everybody."
Mr. Trump, who has had several serious financial setbacks in the last year, acknowledged that the city's economic slump made it an opportune time for him to seek a compromise that would allow his plan to go forward. Obtaining new zoning for the site would make it possible for him to build on it himself or make it more attractive to a buyer. He said he intended to develop some buildings himself and sell other parcels to other developers.
The precise configuration and number of buildings allowed in the compromise is yet to be determined. Some would be 35 to 40 stories, instead of the far larger towers orginally proposed for a Trump City, including a plan for the world's tallest.
One participant in the talks who was not on Mr. Trump's negotiating team said, "I believe he is now down as low as he can go without jeopardizing the economic viability of it."
Under the compromise with the civic groups, Mr. Trump would no longer be required to make improvements in neighborhood subway stations that had been part of his original proposal. Nor would he have to maintain the riverfront park after it was built. The city would do that. And Mr. Trump would not have to finish the park until the highway was moved inland and his project was producing income.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Why can't a nation that produces high-tech weapons make a compact disk player? Experts say the weapons are not necessarily sophisticated and the effort of making them does not automatically translate into commercial success. [Page A1.] 
 A surge in exports has helped make this recession very different from the one in 1981-82. [D1.]
The next few months are beginning to look like a difficult time to form a national policy for becoming less dependent on imported oil. News Analysis. [D1.]
Vermont has not had a bank failure in the current economic downturn, unlike its New England neighbors, and its strict environmental laws may be a reason why. [D1.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 2166 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: National Mood;
War Heals Wounds at Home, but Not All

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
On the battlefield and at home, it was a victory of stunning decisiveness, like a thunderbolt that had the potential to obliterate the two decades of doubt and drift that began with Vietnam.
But with the fighting over, the real lessons and the long-term impact of the Persian Gulf war -- what it says about Vietnam and about the nation itself -- are far less certain than the surge of exhilaration now surrounding it. 
 For the short term, the war has had a profound impact on the nation's psyche and political landscape. To some, it culminated a struggle in which the cultural and political ideology of the Ronald Reagan era routed its liberal critics as decisively as the Allied forces routed Iraq's Republican Guard.
 
'End of the Decline'
 "This is the end of the decline," said Michael Novak, director of social and political studies for the conservative American Enterprise Institute. "This is the decline of the declinists. The mother of all battles turned into the daughter of disasters for the declinists. For years, people are going to cite the lessons of the Persian Gulf."
In a radio address Saturday praising the American troops, President Bush said, "The specter of Vietnam has been buried forever in the desert sands of the Arabian Peninsula."
But amid such euphoria, there were warnings that a military victory, no matter how overwhelming, against a country with an economic output the size of Kentucky's and a population less than a third of Vietnam's does not necessarily herald a new day.
 
Signs of Intolerance
 There were some suggestions that the combination of jubilation over the war and some signs of intolerance for dissent at home said as much about the frustrations and divisions that preceded the war as the sense of power and unity that came out of it.
"People in this country have been feeling profoundly demoralized and ovewhelmed and if somebody presents something to them in a way that suggests this is managable, we can do it, we can do it quick, it's a boost," said June Jordan, a poet and professor of African-American studies at the University of California at Berkeley. "I suggest to you it's a hit the same way that crack is, and it doesn't last long,"
H. Ross Perot, the billionaire Texas electronics entrepreneur and investor, said it would be tragic if the nation's pride in the success overseas diverted it from the enormous problems at home.
"Let's put a turbine under all this euphoria and use it to clean up our problems over here," Mr. Perot said.
"One success will not carry anybody very far," he added. "We need to put it behind us and press forward. If we just sit around and high-five one another over the fact that we blew the bejesus out of the Arab world, nothing but arrogance can come out of it."
 
Vietnam's Lessons
How Much Might Is Right?
From the beginning of the military buildup, the confrontation in the gulf was shadowed at every step by the ghosts of Vietnam.
For many Americans, the war banished the ghosts to a degree few people could have hoped for. Instead of the television images of terrified American diplomats fleeing as Saigon fell, the United States saw tearful Kuwaitis hailing Americans as liberators.
Instead of ending in doubt and shame, this war finished with flags, yellow ribbons and swaggering expressions of pride. The New York Post, for instance, published a picture of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq at prayer and the headline "ON HIS KNEES!" And radio station WRAL-FM in Raleigh, N.C., began identifying itself as "broadcasting from the most powerful nation in the world."
For many Vietnam veterans, there was particular pride.
"A lot of people see this as a chance to right old wrongs," said Adrian Cronauer, a communications lawyer in Washington who, as an Armed Forces Radio announcer in Vietnam, provided the model for the Robin Williams character in the movie "Good Morning, Vietnam."
"A lot of people are feeling vindicated," he said. "I think this will put all the negative results of Vietnam behind us."
 
Which Lesson Is Right?
 To Mr. Cronauer and others, the lesson of Iraq is that the nation must be prepared to unleash whatever resources are available when it decides to take military action.
But many experts wonder if that is the right lesson.
Gerald Linderman, a University of Michigan historian who specializes in the effects of American wars at home, said Iraq may have shredded the mythology of Vietnam more than the substance of Vietnam. The idea that the United States lost in Vietnam because of a lack of will or undue restraint is simply false, he said.
"It wasn't that power wasn't exerted in Vietnam, it was that it was unavailing, in part because it was misdirected in that kind of war," he said. "I suspect that no human power could have prevailed in that situation any more than it could have prevailed in Afghanistan. To think this success renders unimportant a previous failure, when in fact they're two entirely different species, could lead us into serious mischief."
Many historians, including John Shy, a University of Michigan military historian, said the peril in the war euphoria is that it could make the United States more likely to use force again.
"Put together with Grenada, with Libya, with Panama, it seems to be the triumphal culmination of a series of episodes in which military power was used as an instrument of foreign policy," Professor Shy said. "I hope it does not induce an arrogance or bully boy behavior in American foreign policy."
 
The World's Policeman
 Others, however, say the success against Iraq will make wars less likely by deterring aggession by others.
"When you carry a big stick, you can talk awfully quietly," said Mr. Novak. "You can even smile."
But it is clear that if the lesson of Vietnam was a sense of the limits of United States power, the lesson of this war is the opposite: that there are few limits to the nation's military might. To war critics, and even to some backers of this war, that is worrisome.
But especially after what most Americans saw as a moral war against a dangerous despot, many are again talking about being the global enforcer.
"I'm not one of those people who believe the cliche we can't be the world's policeman," said Richard Viguerie, the conservative direct-mail specialist. "Well, somebody has to be the world's policeman, or else a lot of people are going to be hurt."
 
Persian Gulf's Lessons
Unity Masks Deep Problems
Basking in victory, many conservatives see a transformed America, newly united and with a new sense of confidence and resolve.
"Who can mount Desert Storm should be able to police Central Park, and who created the Patriots should be able to handle Sony and Mercedes," said the conservative columnist William F. Buckley Jr.
Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, added: "We've just seen a 21st-century army beat a 20th-century army, and I think the challenge to us is to say, 'Let's get the rest of America into the 21st century.' "
But aside from the most ardent conservatives, there is little consensus that victory over Iraq necessarily means improvement at home, in a country that before the war was convulsed with self doubt, disgusted with its politicians and unable to address gaping domestic needs.
"It's going to take more than good will to deal with our problems in education, homelessesness, poverty, declining productivity, and we've never seen George Bush much interested in domestic issues," said Barbara Ehrenreich, a liberal writer and essayist. "Ticker tape isn't going to feed families. Yellow ribbons aren't going to hold bridges up. You can't keep warm under a tent of flags."
 
Darker Side of Patriotism
 And if the war produced expressions of unity and pride, it produced darker undertones as well.
War opponents in many cities said they were subjected to harassment ranging from threatening phone calls to physical abuse. Peg Mullen of Brownsville, Tex., whose search for the truth about her son's death in Vietnam was the subject of the book and movie "Friendly Fire," said she received warnings her house would burn down when she organized a busload of mothers protest in Washington. "I didn't go through any of that in Vietnam," she said. "Then I was allowed to say what I thought."
Others had similar experiences. The actress Margot Kidder was branded a "Baghdad Betty" and subjected to abuse for remarks questioning the war. A Seton Hall University basketball player, Marco Lokar, decided to return home to Italy after being criticized for refusing to wear an American flag on his uniform.
Some say this undercurrent of unease and the still-sagging economy could short-circuit a national celebration of the war.
Kevin Phillips, a political analyst who predicted the Republican surge over the past two decades and who has recently begun predicting its decline, said that without a genuine economic surge, the war euphoria may soon fade. "It's highly unlikely you can have a genuine feel-good era coexisting with this degree of economic concern," he said.
"If we get something else that churns up all those bad feelings again, after all this hype, you could have some very frustrated people out there," he added. "I think they'd be prey for politicians using some form of scapegoating. I can imagine you could get some cultural form of that from the right and some economic version of that from the left."
But for now, more people are struck by the political implications of the positive mood.
The war has left President Bush with approval ratings hovering near 90 percent. That gives him extraordinary leverage with Congress and makes him an overwhelming re-election favorite.
 
Parties Gauge Their Chances
 An economic reversal could alter the mood, but for now Republicans also see the possibility of gains in the House and retaking control of the Senate.
"There's going to be a lot of Democrats, liberals, that are going to rue the day they voted against the war and the Patriot missile," Mr. Viguerie said. "These are recorded votes, and there are going to be a lot of 60-second commercials out there."
Democrats see the risks too. "I think that this is the biggest event in post-Vietnam America, and therefore we have to expect it will have a major effect on the 1992 elections" said Michael Donilon, a poll taker for Democrats.
 
History's Lessons
Perils Facing The Powerful
If Vietnam was the emotional backdrop for judging the war, one book is playing much the same role on an intellectual level.
It is "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers" (Random House, 1987), the sweeping study of international powers since 1500, by the Yale University historian Paul Kennedy.
Its thesis is that throughout history, imperial powers have accelerated their decline by diverting too much energy to military entanglements rather than activities that are more productive economically.
In a short section at the close of the book, Professor Kennedy found the potential for such a decline and what he termed "imperial overstretch" at work in the United States.
 
Using the Wrong Measure
 He said that historically, nations whose economic strength was ebbing have used military victories, often against lesser foes, as misguided signs their power was intact.
People who measure America's strength by the Persian Gulf War are "measuring the wrong measure and shooting at the wrong target," he said in a telephone interview.
"The U.S. has been pouring $300 billion a year into defense throughout the 80's, so it was never a question of there being inadequate military power," he said. "The argument was they were concentrating too much of their energy and resources on defense and neglecting the state of American technical education, infrastructure, indebtedness, high-tech competitiveness, erosion of the social fabric and other problems. To say a swift battlefield victory proves the declinists wrong is a total misinterpreation."
 
The Positive Signs
 Mr. Novak and others argue that Professor Kennedy's thesis fails because he underestimates the nation's economic strength and the broader signs of American pre-eminence, like the collapse of Communism.
Mr. Gingrich said the military and domestic situations are not different at all; rather, the Persian Gulf experience shows that the nation's domestic needs require the same dramatic overhaul the military has received.
Mr. Perot, once thought of as a military hawk, now more of an iconoclast, hopes there is humility as well as pride in the lessons of the war.
"We need to be very, very careful in how we use our power, and not get swept up in going off to war every chance we get," he said. "We could end up with the mind-set that says, 'Gee, we're going to see more Nintendo games on television.' But don't count on that ever happening twice. The next one is going to be just as much of a bloody mess as war always is close up."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Up Slightly

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, March 4

 BODY:
Stocks in Tokyo were slightly higher today in light trading. Brokers said the market was treading water, uncertain about the prospects for United States economic recovery and interest-rate cuts.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished up 94.45 points, or less than 1 percent, to 25,976.02. At midday, the Nikkei was up 57.65 points, to 25,939.22, with 200 million shares traded. On Friday, the index lost 527.65 points, a 2 percent decline. 
 "Both sellers and buyers are holding back," a senior trader at Merrill Lynch Japan, said after the morning session.
Other traders said uncertainty about interest rates and the weakness of the yen made trading difficult, with large-capitalization, interest-rate sensitive and financial issues all moving sluggishly.
Wall Street gained on Friday on optimism that the United States economy may recover faster than expected. But brokers here said that if the Federal Reserve delayed a further easing of interest rates, an American recovery would be just as much bearish as bullish for Tokyo.
Midday volume was light compared with 400 million shares traded by midday on Friday. Declining issues led gainers by 7 to 4.
