HEADLINE: Meadow Star Wins Races and Hearts

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

DATELINE: HALLANDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
TO the stable people tending her at Barn 15 at Gulfstream Park, she is "little sister." To the groom pampering her in Stall 16, she is "BooBoo." To the clockers, trainers, jockeys and other insiders in the world of thoroughbred racing, she is "the filly."
She is The Filly, indeed. She is Meadow Star, the undefeated and almost unchallenged filly, the winner of all seven races she ever ran, including six stakes races in a row, including even the Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies, which she polished off by five lengths. And that was three weeks after she won the Frizette by 14 lengths. And that was three weeks after she won the Matron by six lengths. 
 She is chestnut in color with a white patch on her face, she isn't imposing in size, and she is portrayed by her entourage as kind, gentle and intelligent, and by her trainer as "the model of a race horse." She was the reigning filly in America as a 2-year-old in 1990, and she's even-money to continue reigning as a 3-year-old in 1991.
She hasn't raced yet this year, but she will probably make her debut here at Gulfstream within the week. And, in the months ahead, she may capture the public's fancy to a melodramatic degree, perhaps more so than any race horse since Secretariat and more so than any filly since Ruffian.
One reason for the drama is that her owner, Carl Icahn, is donating all her prize money to the Children's Rescue Fund, a charity that he established to provide homes and scholarships for the poor. Icahn, the international financier and owner of Trans World Airlines, is matching gifts to the fund. But Meadow Star, meanwhile, has won $992,830 and figures to become a millionaire philanthropist the next time she races.
"There is something heroic to children about a horse's image, and especially a champion," Icahn said the other day. "We want children to know about her. And if she wins even bigger races, the image may grow and the Rescue Fund will certainly grow."
Another reason for melodrama is that her trainer, Leroy Jolley, is nearing a classic decision: Meadow Star dominated the racing fillies last year, but has never raced against a colt. So, has the time come to race the little filly against the big colts this year? Has the time come to shoot for the ultimate prizes in racing, starting with the Kentucky Derby?
"We're all tantalized with the Triple Crown races," Jolley said. "I don't think anybody in racing doesn't think that way. You're always tempted. But you don't race an average filly against an average colt. Size and strength and other factors have something to do with it."
He paused, and said, "The only time a filly does it is if she's an exceptional filly."
Jolley stood in the rain at 7 o'clock in the morning last Tuesday at Gulfstream Park and watched his exceptional filly take her first formal workout of the year. She did it after resting on her laurels all winter, and after taking life easy with only light work for the last month at the Payson Training Center about 75 miles north of here. She breezed seven-eighths of a mile in 1:27, ran around two turns for the first time in her career and came back to Barn 15 for some walking and caressing.
The trainer, who is a trim man of 53 with piercing blue eyes and a coiled bearing, watched Karen Ross walking his superstar under the shed row for a few turns around the barn. So, he was asked, what's the big decision?
"My mind hasn't been made up yet," he said. "No, not even privately. It depends on, No. 1, how she responds to her training and racing in the next few weeks. No. 2, how the colts are doing, and how many of them there are, and how tough they are. You have to see how the colts look."
Then, as though arguing both sides of the same issue, he said:
"She's not big, but she's the model of a race horse. Beautifully put together. All business when she races. She's better in her races than in her training.
"But you have to be conservative. You can't bite off more than you can chew."
Finally, he confronted his own warning that only an exceptional filly should tackle colts, and he said:
"She's a very exceptional filly. She does everything right. I'm excited about her. I may not look it, but you never know the fires burning inside. Early in her career, she was a good-looking filly but nobody in the stable went out and hocked their car.
"But she went around two turns very well the first time we asked her to do it. She had plenty of rest up at Payson, but she needed to get back to a racing atmosphere. Funny thing, she's almost turned on by it. She's a creature of racing.
"She's had a nice long vacation, and now she needs the stimulation of racing. She's just about ready to run. We'll probably put her in a race here later in the week, then take her to New York and maybe put her in the Comely on March 30. It's a mile, and it's the only race we more or less have carved in stone."
"After that," Jolley said, "the decision will be made."
He paused, and added: "Probably by that time, the decision will make itself. It'll be obvious to everybody."
"The decision," Icahn agreed, "will make itself."
But, speaking by telephone from his office in Mount Kisco, N.Y., he seemed to cast a vote for turning Meadow Star toward the classics.
"We hope she'll go that route," he said.
If she goes that route, she will be adding drama to the growing image of the noble filly, starting with Ruffian in the 1970's and continuing through Genuine Risk and Winning Colors in the 1980's.
The image was enhanced tragically in 1990 when the champion Go for Wand broke down in the final yards of a stirring duel against Bayakoa in the Breeders' Cup Distaff. Then, before a shocked crowd at Belmont Park and a national television audience, the courageous filly struggled to her feet and tried to finish the race, only to collapse for good -- a few yards from where Ruffian lies buried at the finish line.
On the same afternoon, Meadow Star raced to her seventh straight victory in a season of success. But Jolley has raced with fillies and against fillies, and he has no illusions.
"With a filly," he said, "it's the luck of the draw. If the owner's interested in breeding, you have fillies. But the economics of the business has changed. Until three years ago, the emphasis was on breeding a filly. But the bloodstock market is down now, and the emphasis is on racing. There are more big races for fillies, more big purses for fillies in racing.
"But the exceptional ones can cross the line and compete with colts. In Europe, they compete very successfully with colts. Look at the Arc."
In the Arc de Triomphe, which is run in the fall, when fillies have matured more, fillies won eight times in 11 years before 1983. They haven't won since then, but they have run second or third every year.
In the Kentucky Derby, only 35 fillies have even been entered in 115 years and only three have won: Regret in 1915, Genuine Risk in 1980 and Winning Colors in 1988. In fact, only four fillies have tried the Derby in the decade since Genuine Risk, but Meadow Star is standing in the wings.
This isn't the first time Jolley has wrestled with the problem of fillies and colts. He knows the rewards, and he knows the risks.
In 1980, he was the trainer of Genuine Risk, who crossed the line and won the Kentucky Derby. And five years before that, he was the trainer of the colt Foolish Pleasure, who won the Kentucky Derby and then ran the storied match race at Belmont Park against Ruffian, the filly champion. They sizzled for half a mile, stride for stride, and then Ruffian snapped her right foreleg and did not survive.
The jockey on Ruffian was Jacinto Vasquez, who had also been the regular rider on Foolish Pleasure. When the horses were paired in the match race, Vasquez had to make a difficult decision. He elected to ride the filly, whom he later mourned as "a gorgeous beast."
Five years later, he was riding for Jolley again and this time his mount was Genuine Risk, who became only the second filly to win the Kentucky Derby. The general feeling in racing seems to be that Meadow Star will try to be the fourth.
It's not clear, though, who will be on her back. Her regular rider, Jose Santos, also rides the champion colt Fly So Free, who has won twice in two starts this year and seven times in nine starts in his career. He is already the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, and Santos has said he will ride the colt.
So, who will ride the filly? Probably Chris Antley, who rode her once last August at Saratoga when Santos was sitting out a suspension. Antley also went to the Payson complex twice (once by helicopter) in Indiantown to guide Meadow Star through workouts, and he was aboard when she stepped onto the track at Gulfstream last Tuesday morning.
"She's all business," he said later. "She knows her job. When you step on the gas pedal, she responds."
Vasquez, wrapped in a floor-length terrycloth bathrobe, stood on the porch of the jockeys' quarters the other day and peered back through the years and the memories of his "gorgeous beast."
"Fillies are special," he said. "You don't always know how they'll respond to hard training or hard racing. Ruffian and Genuine Risk were able to handle it. They could beat colts. They could beat anybody. Some can do it; some can't.
"I have respect for Leroy Jolley. But he'll have to be careful with Meadow Star. To me, Ruffian was very special. It would be hard to find a race horse like her. When Genuine Risk came along, I didn't think she'd run in the Derby. I told Leroy Jolley: 'Let me get on her a few days after she runs in the Wood and see how she comes back. If she's O.K., then let's go for it.'
"Right now, Meadow Star looks unbeatable. She's very impressive. But there are a lot of colts around. And I don't think you should mix them. Fillies can fall apart."
Icahn, one of the heavy hitters in the investment world, invested $90,000 in the pretty little filly when she was a yearling two years ago at the Keeneland sales in Kentucky.
"I like to breed horses," he said. "But we were lucky buying her. We went to the sales that September and bought four yearlings. I told Rob Whiteley she's worth more, but don't go higher than 90. We just got her at 90."
Whiteley, the director of operations for Icahn's breeding, racing and selling of thoroughbreds, remembered that the yearling's sire, Meadowlake, had been an unproven stallion.
"But he was big and fast," he said. "An exceptionally fast 17-hands horse who had great potential before he was injured. Her mother, Inreality Star, was a daughter of In Reality. And his mares are known for their toughness.
"Before we bought Meadow Star, I went back to see her three times at the sales. She was alert and unflappable. Very professional. The consummate professional.
"She's also very kind and very honest, and that's the most endearing thing I can say about her. It's hard to believe such a gentle filly can be so tough once the gates open."
The gates will open for her in a few days. And, in about one month, Jolley will decide whether to enter her in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct and two weeks later in the Kentucky Derby, male bastions where only an "exceptional filly" dare enter.

HEADLINE: Rangers Face Major Choices

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
As his second season as a hockey executive comes to an end, Neil Smith of the Rangers finds himself entering what may be the most pivotal two days of his front-office career.
The team's 37-year-old general manager, Smith commands a team that holds first place in the Patrick Division and may take the division title for the second consecutive season. 
 Smith, his players and the hockey public at large know that such a small honor will not satisfy the deep needs and wants at Madison Square Garden, where the Stanley Cup championship was last won in 1940.
The four-round playoffs begin in four weeks and the Rangers must pursue the trophy with the team they have when the trading deadline passes tomorrow.
 
Astute Transactions
 In Smith's brief tenure with the team, his initial trades have proven to be astute. Regular contributors like Bernie Nicholls, Mike Gartner and Kris King were acquired from other teams.
As presently constituted, the Rangers appear to be a good-but-not-great team with a good chance of surviving the first round, a fair chance of winning the second, a possibility of success in the third and a distant hope of prevailing in the final.
To improve upon those chances, Smith plans to be on the telephone this morning with his peers around the league.
There is no clear Stanley Cup favorite this season, although Chicago, St. Louis, Boston, Calgary and Los Angeles seem to be reasonable possibilities. To move into that group, the Rangers may need to make one or two significant trades.
It is much like playing poker: Do you throw away a pair of 10's in the hope of drawing the ace or the king that will fill a straight flush?
In both poker and hockey trades, the operative word is "deal." In the case of the Rangers, that might mean trading one of their rotating goalies, John Vanbiesbrouck or Mike Richter.
 
Seeking a Hot Commodity
 "We are willing to part with anybody, but certainly our strength is in our depth of goaltending," Smith said over the weekend in Toronto, where the Rangers beat the Maple Leafs by 5-2 Saturday.
"It would have to be a lucrative deal," he said. "I feel we have the best two goaltenders in the league and I wouldn't want to give up one unless it was for a hot commodity."
Such a commodity might be a winger who can give the forward lines more aggressiveness. Before joining the Rangers as general manager in 1989, Smith was the chief scout for Detroit. He has long admired Joe Kocur, the Detroit forward whose scarred knuckles attest to his reputation as one of hockey's premier fighters. But Smith isn't sure that one man would solve all the Rangers needs.
"We need a general upgrading of size and strength at the forward positions," Smith said. "It's not something you can do with one move. You can't get a general size change. Our needs are probably not completely satisfiable through a trade."
But a trade this week can affect a team's championship possibilities this spring. It might also change the perception of the top hockey team in the league's largest market.
 
Few Sellouts
 Despite their relative success this season, the Rangers seldom sell out all of their seats. The radio talk shows seem more interested in the failings of the Knicks than the success or failure of the area's three hockey teams. The newspapers are more concerned about the success of the football Giants and the rebuilding of the Mets without Darryl Strawberry.
For a man who grew up in Toronto and learned his skills in Detroit, New York's lack of hockey passion is new to Smith.
"I'm disappointed we're not selling out," Smith said. "We should be; we've got a good product. Some of it probably has to do with the renovation of the interior of the Garden and with the current economic climate.
"Also, Roger Neilson and I have run it at a low profile for the last two years. We don't get the exposure a high-profile management team might bring. I guess that's the price you pay.
"We're all business. We're interested more in winning that in having posters for sale. I think it's time the New York Rangers had less celebrity status and more winning percentage. People in New York don't really get interested in hockey until the playoffs anyway. Until then, it's more like just another show. Should we go see 'Cats' or the Rangers?"
 
No Ripple Effect
 Smith said last week's shakeup of top Garden management would have little effect on him. Jack Diller no longer oversees the Knicks, only the Rangers. Smith said this could only increase communication and access between the two.
But the Garden authorities have been known to be impatient with slow building programs. As the New York sports world gives hockey its turn this spring, the fans, the news media and maybe even Smith's bosses will be asking the familiar question: Is this the year?
"It could be," Smith said. "We certainly want it to be. We also are aware that we intend to be in this contending position for the next few years. We hope that this year we can reach for the brass ring and grab it. We certainly intend to win."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
New U.S. Hint on Hussein

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d hinted today that Iraq might be accorded a lighter reparations bill for rebuilding Kuwait if President Saddam Hussein were overthrown.
"The degree to which the coalition and other countries would actively prosecute their claims I think might be affected to some degree by whether or not that regime is still in power," Mr. Baker said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." 
 His comments came only hours after the United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution on terms for ending hostilities that called on Iraq to accept liability for damages caused by its invasion and occupation of Kuwait. Preliminary estimates of damages have reached tens of billions of dollars.
Mr. Baker said talks during his forthcoming tour of the Middle East would deal with creating new regional security arrangements, arms control and economic cooperation. Cautioning that "we can't impose peace," he said he would not carry a specific Arab-Israeli peace plan with him.
He said that a United States peace plan "would be shot up like a Scud missile with a couple of Patriots."
Mr. Baker expressed mild optimism for the prospects of reducing tensions in following the Gulf war, although he added that the conflict between Israel and its Arab neighbors "is so intractable, and it has been there for so long, and the issues are so deep that divide."
He said all Washington could do was serve as a "catalyst" to bring Israelis and Arabs together. "We have got to find a way for Arab states and Israel to make peace; and we have got to find a way for Israel and Palestinians to begin a dialogue," Mr. Baker said.
Even though Jordan gave verbal support and apparently some weapons to Iraq during the crisis, Mr. Baker expressed a positive attitude toward King Hussein. "It may very well be," Mr. Baker said, that as we move forward here, Jordan and King Hussein himself personally may become a very important player in this."

HEADLINE: Don't Skimp on Treatment for Addiction

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Doctors Press States to Curb Reviews of Procedures' Costs" (front page, Feb. 13), you report on the battle between insurance companies and physicians over medical review companies, which attempt to limit health-care costs. It didn't surprise me that, to put a human face on the issue, you use the case of a California man whose death may have resulted from his premature release from a drug-treatment program. 
 According to a survey released last December by the benefits consulting firm of Foster Higgins & Company, nearly 9 in 10 employers limit benefits for alcoholism, other drug dependence and mental disorders, although 52 percent of the survey participants could not say how much it cost them to provide any kind of treatment for these diseases.
But we do know the price society pays for leaving them untreated. The Department of Health and Human Services estimates that alcoholism and drug dependence cost the country at least $144 billion in 1988. Treatment-related expenditures account for just 11 percent of that figure; lost or reduced productivity, mortality and other costs that are not related to health, such as crime, law enforcement and property destruction, make up the rest.
While the long-range economic folly of cuts in benefits for alcohol treatment and drug treatment is obvious in light of these estimates -- which are rock bottom according to the Government -- specialists in addiction medicine are even more troubled by a system that has begun increasingly to discriminate against alcoholics and other drug-dependent people.
The review companies who have been mandated to control costs are less likely to second-guess the hospitalization needs of a patient who has been diagnosed with heart disease than one with a life-threatening addiction because their decisions are more often informed by their moral beliefs than by any medical expertise or professional standards.
Specialists in addiction medicine and organizations such as the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence will continue to fight for access to treatment that meets the needs of individuals, but it appears that in this environment, we will have to rely on economic arguments as much as compassion and understanding.
 
NICHOLAS A. PACE, M.D.
Board Member, National Council
on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence
New York, Feb. 21, 1991

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations;
U.N. Compromise Plan To Widen Relief to Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 3

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council pledged tonight to exempt more food and humanitarian aid from its trade embargo against Iraq and speed authorization for delivering the supplies to needy people there.
The decision, announced by Austria, this month's Council president, represented a compromise between the United States and its gulf war allies and a group of members who wanted trade sanctions lifted altogether on goods needed to preserve public health in Iraq. 
 The gulf allies say they are ready to send Iraq more humanitarian supplies to relieve suffering and stem the danger of epidemics resulting from polluted water and poor medical services. But they plan to do so on an exceptional basis without changing the Council's decision to ban all trade with Iraq except medicines.
The coalition partners say they are opposed to any formal weakening of the Security Council's economic embargo aganst Iraq at this stage because they are still pressing Baghdad to comply fully with their terms for a formal cease-fire.
 
Cease-Fire Resolution Approved
 Saturday night the Council approved a new resolution endorsing the conditions for a cease-fire and reaffirming the trade sanctions against Iraq as well as the allies' right to attack Iraq again if it does not make peace on their terms.
In a letter to the Council today, Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said the Iraqi Government had accepted the resolution and "will fulfill its obligations under the said resolution."
He asked the Security Council to declare a formal cease-fire and to lift all sanctions against Baghdad.
As a result of the compromise tonight, five Council members, India, Cuba, Yemen, Ecuador and Zimbabwe, withdrew a resolution they had circulated that would have formally lifted the Security Council's trade embargo on food as well as on machinery and supplies used for purifying water and generating electricity.
 
Health Reports Prompt Appeal
 The five countries introduced this resolution after the World Health Organization and Unicef reported last week that Iraqi children are short of food and that hospitals and water treatment plants, operating without public electricity, desperately need portable generators and fuel.
The Council wants a special committee empowered to approve humanitarian exceptions to the embargo to speed up its work and take a more generous approach, allowing shipment of a wider range of supplies.
Today the committee examined the W.H.O.-Unicef report and asked for more details on what equipment Iraq needs to improve health standards. Diplomats said W.H.O. and Unicef will supply this information in the next few days when the committee is likely to give the green light for these supplies to be sent in.
 
Resolution Gets 11 Votes
 At today's meeting the committee also approved requests by the Danish and Belgian Red Cross to send in food for children. Last week it allowed Iran to send in some 700 tons of food.
The new resolution endorsing President Bush's cease-fire terms was supported by 11 of the Council's 15 members. Only Cuba voted against it while China, India and Yemen abstained.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 5, 1991, Tuesday

HEADLINE: Big Developments Stalled in New York's Real-Estate Slump

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
At Columbus Circle, where the gigantic Columbus Center complex was supposed to be, there is a modern "Hooverville" outside the vacant New York Coliseum, an encampment of homeless people in crudely built shelters who warm themselves at night over fires in open drums.
Not far away, in the deserted railroad yards along the Hudson River where Donald J. Trump has dreamed of building his own city since 1984, the only thing that has gone up is vegetation. Mr. Trump is close to an agreement with civic groups and the city on a scaled-down version of his plans. 
 The yawning vaults under the Queensboro Bridge, where the Bridgemarket food center was to have been, will stay empty indefinitely. No 60-story South Ferry Plaza office tower will rise at Manhattan's tip, and no one lives at 108 East 96th Street, an empty unfinished shell of an apartment building.
 
Emblems of Both a Boom and Distress
 Each of these projects, in its own way, was emblematic of the building boom that transformed and transfixed New York City in the 1980's. Now each, in its own peculiar limbo, is emblematic of the city's distress.
In a city where construction cranes are as much a part of the local topography as hills or shoreline, the entire civic character seems out of kilter when development slackens -- even if it means that there might be time to plan more rationally for the future.
In all, more than 40 developments that began to take form in the last decade are now dead, delayed or mired. Many have been scuttled, or at least hobbled, by the worst real-estate market since the 1970's. And while many others seem to be victims more of legal maneuvers or bureaucracy than market forces, their developers would probably have moved much faster a few years ago to settle the suits or obtain permits.
This slowdown has left gaping holes not only in the streetscape but in the private and public economies. Thousands of jobs have been lost in the building and real-estate fields, and with them, much money that had been spent on high-priced dwellings, goods and services. At the same time, the municipal budget is missing millions in real-estate tax revenues.
 
Plenty of Space for Tenants to Choose From
 No change is in immediate sight, particularly because banks, stuck with many loans that are unlikely to be repaid, have turned their backs on construction lending. Moreover, what tenants there might be for new office space have plenty to choose from: whole skyscrapers sitting freshly built and nearly empty.
Perhaps the greatest obstacle to big projects at the moment, besides the lack of tenants and financing, is a court decision.
In November, Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court overturned two amended zoning rules -- one applying to large-scale developments, the other to developments on rail yards -- under which several projects had been approved by the city, thereby effectively blocking the projects themselves. Justice Gammerman found a "failure" on the part of city officials "to identify and assess the reasonably foreseeable environmental consequences" of the zoning changes. The city is appealing.
Even with construction at its quietest in years, several office towers and hotels are going up. The revised Trump City plan that appears to be moving forward again, even at 57 percent of its former size, would be a huge enterprise. And officials insist that construction will begin on such ambitious and long-delayed efforts as the four-tower Times Square Center and two Federal buildings around Foley Square.
Still, what follows is a profile of development at a standstill.

HEADLINE: Yanks Hope Sanderson Has Good Start

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 3

 BODY:
Even with all their woeful offensive problems last season, the Yankees began their winter by continuing their never-ending search for pitching.
What they found was a starter, Scott Sanderson, and a reliever, Steve Farr, who probably make them better but don't necessarily solve what has become an annual puzzle. 
 Sanderson could possibly be their best catch of the off season. But can he?
Last season, with the Oakland A's, he had a career-high 17 victories, pitched 206 innings and did not miss a starting assignment, working 34 times. But that was Oakland; this is the Yankees.
 
Winning Isn't Easy
 "If it was as easy as throwing your glove on the mound, then I say ask Mike Moore how easy it was for him last season," Sanderson said. "You don't win unless you pitch well. Everybody talks about the A's offense, but they might have been in the middle of the pack in runs scored."
The Athletics were actually third in runs, but they were 12th in team batting average. Moore may have suffered most from the dropoff, going from a 19-11 record in 1989 to 13-15 last season.
Sanderson, who is 34 years old, assumed that his durability and his 17-11 record would earn him a new contract with Oakland. He accepted Oakland's offer of arbitration, then 36 hours later found that he had been traded to the Yankees. He signed a two-year deal valued at $4.5 million.
The A's later conceded that the economic climate had left them with little chance to win in arbitration, and it would have probably cost them well over $1 million to keep Sanderson, who made $850,000 in 1990. Instead, they acquired cheaper talent: just as Sanderson had replaced Storm Davis in the A's rotation the season before, Eric Show will replace Sanderson.
"It doesn't remain a complete mystery to me," Sanderson said, "but there are some unanswered questions. I have no resentment toward the A's, though. I only have good memories."
 
Reliable Starter
 The Yankees are hoping they have good memories of Sanderson when the season ends. Like others in the rotation -- Tim Leary, Mike Witt, Chuck Cary and either Andy Hawkins or Dave Eiland -- he is reliable without being exceptional.
"Whoever our fifth starter is," said the Yankee pitching coach, Mark Connor, "we have four guys who are capable of winning 15 games or more. With the exception of Chuck, they've all done it."
Sanderson doesn't give the Yankees what they need most of all -- a No. 1 pitcher -- but he insists that the term is overused and misunderstood.
"How important is a No. 1, an ace, the day after he pitches and the next three days after that?" he said. "Whoever is the starter that day is No. 1. I don't care if you're talking about Roger Clemens, Dwight Gooden or Dave Stewart."
Sanderson is none of those, but he is dependable, having won 28 games over the last two seasons (he spent 1989 with the Chicago Cubs) and made 57 starts during that span.
Last season, he added a forkball to his fastball and curve, which he hopes will induce more ground-ball outs.
"I'm hoping it won't go as far," Sanderson said, smiling. "It should be a ground-ball and strikeout pitch."
Last season, Sanderson gave up 27 home runs. Only Dave Johnson of the Baltimore Orioles (30) and Dennis Rasmussen of the San Diego Padres (28) gave up more in the majors.
"I like what I've seen so far of it, and it's not even there yet," Connor said. "It's a pitch that starts in the strike zone and ends up out of it. It's not a pitch everybody can throw."
Now, Sanderson needs to translate it into victories, which clearly won't come as easily as they did with the A's.
"I'm going to try and do the same things I did with Oakland," he said. "That was to show them they made the right choice in signing me."

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: The Gulf War's Aftermath
Is the Vietnam Syndrome Dead?;
No, Hussein Was One of a Kind

BYLINE: By Eric Alterman; Eric Alterman, a senior fellow at the World Policy Institute, is writing a book about political pundits.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
All right, so the peaceniks were wrong about one thing. There will be no tens of thousands of body bags coming home and thus no popular reaction of revulsion and horror against the Persian Gulf war. President Bush's popularity ratings are off the charts and even the most hawkish of "pro-sanctions" Democrats are running for cover, musing about 1996. Politically and militarily, Operation Desert Storm is a rout.
But does this mean, as many try to claim, that America has finally exorcised the ghost of Vietnam? The question itself implies a misunderstanding of the underlying factors that created the Vietnam syndrome. 
 Although neo-conservatives sneered at the "culture of appeasement" it allegedly bespoke, the nation's reluctance to involve itself directly in the wars of the 1980's represented a lasting and significant confluence of thinking between military leaders and the American citizenry.
Following Vietnam, the military saw itself nearly destroyed by fighting an inconclusive, unpopular and probably illegal war. That trauma instilled in it an unshakable respect for the Clausewitzian dictums that wars should be undertaken only on behalf of what former Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger called "clearly defined objectives" and only "with the reasonable assurance" that they would enjoy "the support of the American people and their elected representatives in Congress."
Our brass learned to read polling data as effectively as they did battlefield intelligence. They were hardly eager to see their precious resources, military or political, squandered in a war that lacked overwhelming support, had no clear definition of victory and offered plenty of jungles and mountains conducive to a long drawn-out guerrilla campaign.
From Vietnam, Americans learned the cost of blind obeisance to their leaders. Though "Nicaragua" may not be a perfect Spanish translation for "Vietnam," it sounded sufficiently similar to American ears to prevent a rerun of our tragic sideshow in that decidedly unvital part of the world. Ronald Reagan used every trick in his great communicator's bag to convince Americans that the conflicts in Central America merited a direct U.S. military response. But the opinion polls always came back, "No thanks."
So, are we really ready to get back into the war fighting business?
To answer in the affirmative, one must be confident that the U.S. is likely to find a villain as convincingly evil as Saddam Hussein; victims as unarguably aggrieved as the Kuwaitis; threatened resources as "vital" to our way of life as petroleum; an enemy as vulnerable to U.S. military doctrine as was the Iraqi Army.
None of these conditions is likely to be reproduced anytime soon. It's not that Saddam Hussein, as President Bush has tried to argue, is uniquely evil. Our erstwhile gulf ally, Hafez al-Assad of Syria, gives him more than a run for his money on that score. It's that Mr. Hussein provided a unique combination of evil and stupidity.
He not only invaded a country that supplies oil to the entire Western world but he threatened our regional allies as well. Moreover, he did so on a terrain that left his soldiers no place to hide in exactly the kind of orthodox land war that NATO has been planning for 40 years.
Is there anybody out there nasty and stupid enough to try that again?
In the Philippines, the New Peoples Army may be unpleasant fellows, but they are smart enough to conduct their war on an island archipelago. In Peru, the Shining Path guerrillas have jungles and mountains on their side. Neither one sits on any oil. In China, Deng Xiaoping had the good sense to bond with George Bush before conducting his terror campaign.
Most of the world's potential military conflicts, from Slovenia to East Jerusalem, have their roots in ancient ethnic, political and economic legacies. These are exactly the kinds of morally and militarily complicated interventions that the nation has forsworn as unwinnable and unworth it.
The cold war is history, with the Soviets fighting exclusively among themselves. The new world order is a pipe dream. So given all these caveats, just who is it that Americans should prepare to fight? Vanessa Redgrave?
Despite the cheerleading of our armchair infantrymen, the Vietnam syndrome remains in place. Saddam Hussein is a one-of-a-kind bad guy. Now, if only our real long-term threats -- weakening productivity, a deteriorating environment, collapsing infrastructure and third-rate education system -- provided such spectacular television visuals.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: California Jobless Rate Soars After Cold Ravages Oranges

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: FRESNO, Calif., March 4

 BODY:
The freeze that ravaged California's navel orange crop sent unemployment rates soaring, with nearly one of every five workers unemployed in one hard-hit county, the state reported today.
Tulare County, in the heart of the citrus groves, had a jobless rate of 19.7 percent in January, the State Department of Employment reported. That was up 5 percent from December as 5,500 people were added to the unemployment rolls.
Neighboring Fresno and Kern Counties also are agricultural but fared slightly better. January's unemployment reached 13.7 percent in Fresno and 12.7 percent in Kern.
The severity of the layoffs in Tulare County is illustrated by Food Link, a private, nonprofit food bank.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: Gulf Victory May Raise U.S. Influence in OPEC

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
By virtue of its military victory, the United States is likely to have more influence in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries than any industrial nation has ever exercised. But in the short term, the Administration may not try to exercise this influence.
American officials say they are just beginning to discuss how they might use their new franchise. The first opportunity would arise if crude oil prices plunged from the current level of nearly $20 a barrel. In that event, Washington might lean on a reluctant Saudi Arabia to cut production and push prices back up to a range of $18 to $22. 
 Many economists consider that a suitable level for the American economy, since it is high enough to encourage conservation and allow American energy companies to make profits but low enough that gasoline and heating oil remain affordable, encouraging economic growth.
 
An Unseen Presence at Talks
 When representatives of the 13 OPEC nations gather in Geneva next week, Administration officials will not attend, even as observers. But they will be sitting figuratively at the elbow of Saudi Arabia and the other oil-producing states of the Arabian peninsula.
"I think we are going to see a closer relationship between the gulf oil producers and ourselves," said John J. Easton Jr., Assistant Secretary of Energy for international affairs and energy emergencies. "We had been laying the foundation for some time, and the house was built very quickly when the war came."
The peninsula's two biggest oil producers now, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, account for 18 percent of the world's production. When Kuwait eventually regains its prewar output, roughly 22 percent of the world's oil will come from those three nations, all of which sought American help after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
It is through Saudi Arabia that the Administration will have its greatest influence, American officials and oil specialists say. Because that country produces 14 percent of the world's output -- and exports nearly all of it -- it can influence prices more than any other country by raising or lowering its production.
 
Saudis 'Know What to Do'
 "If prices rose substantially and the Saudis had spare production capacity, they would be asked by the United States to increase production," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "But they would not have to be asked, because they would know what to do."
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and officials of his Government have said their policy is to keep oil prices at about $21 a barrel. The Saudis say, in fact, that they may have to raise production this year to counter pressure for higher prices as demand rises in Europe, Asia and perhaps the United States.
The test of the Bush Administration's new leverage will come if the Saudis are wrong. If higher demand failed to materialize, oil inventories could build up, causing prices to plunge. Some analysts expect this to happen by late summer. The White House might then lean on the Saudis to cut production. And the Saudis might resist.
 
Precedent of 1986
 That is what happened in 1986, the last time oil prices fell sharply, to as low as $7 a barrel. The Saudis caused the plunge by flooding the world market with oil, to punish OPEC partners that were pumping more than their agreed-upon quotas and to demonstrate their power over pricing.
Mr. Bush, then the Vice President, traveled to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to argue for restoring an $18 price level, an effort that brought public criticism from American advocates of cheap oil. In those days, the United States did not have the influence over the Saudis that it presumably has today, and it was seven months before prices began to rise as the Saudis finally relented and cut production.
Saudi Arabia is now producing nearly 8.4 million barrels a day, having raised its output during the gulf crisis to help offset the loss of supplies from Iraq and Kuwait. Now the Saudis say they need all the oil revenue they can obtain to pay war costs. That raises the possibility that they will balk again at any American request to cut production to, say, the level of 5.3 million barrels a day that prevailed in July.
 
Goal of Mutual Benefit
 Would the Administration drop such a request for lower production and forgo exercising its influence? Perhaps, the experts say. "Some in Government may disagree," said Mr. Easton of the Energy Department, "but I for one don't believe that we can wave a wand at the Saudis and they'll automatically respond. The challenge is to find an action beneficial to both of us."
More than a dozen Bush Administration officials and oil industry analysts suggested in interviews last week that although the Administration had new clout on oil prices, they preferred to describe the new American influence in different terms.
Some contend, for example, that the United States' goal should be obtaining easy access to an abundant supply of Middle Eastern oil. In this view, the war was fought in part to prevent Iraq from using its military power to control, and to limit, the flow of oil in an effort to drive up prices.
 
Approval of Expanded Capacity
 This abundant-supply approach is reflected in frequent expressions of approval for Saudi Arabia's efforts to expand its production capacity to 10 million barrels a day or more. Oil analysts and Government officials also speak of rebuilding Kuwait's oil production centers to a capacity well above the pre-invasion level of 2.5 million barrels a day.
"Successful reconstruction policies have the potential to create substantial excess capacity, and this new ability to step up production should act as a brake on rising oil prices," said Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist of the World Bank.
Then there is President Bush's style. "Dictating prices is not his modus operandi," said a high Administration official who declined to be quoted by name. "The President would prefer that people work out prices in their own way, staying within reason."
 
$21 a Barrel a Likely Goal
 "Within reason" means OPEC's current target price of $21 a barrel, set at an OPEC meeting in July over the objections of Iraq, which sought a $25 price to raise additional revenue to pay debts from its eight-year war with Iran.
Crude oil from OPEC's various producers is now averaging $17 to $18 a barrel, but the $21 target price is likely to be affirmed in Geneva next week.
The Bush Administration also counts on oil in the $18 to $22 range. In their most recent projections for the American economy, this was the price range assumed by the Treasury Department, the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the Office of Management and Budget.
"It would be disadvantageous for the American economy if the price were to fall into the low teens," said Sidney Jones, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for economic policy.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Reshaping Laws On Insurance

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
HEALTH insurers are rushing to formulate their own plans for making coverage available to small businesses and individuals. The insurers hope to shape new laws being drafted that will crack down on practices like the blacklisting of certain occupations, red-lining of neighborhoods and price gouging.
But the commercial insurers and Blue Cross and Blue Shield groups are fighting one another on some issues. Under the commercial companies' plan, the 10 largest insurers of small groups in each state would pay for a backup reinsurance pool to help cover high-risk customers. But some Blue Cross groups already cover all applicants, albeit at high premiums. So the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association says participation in reinsurance pools should not be compulsory in every state. 
 Under both the Blue Cross and the commercial proposals, coverage would be offered to all applicants, regardless of health status, occupation or geographic location. For those labeled as high risks, premiums could still be 50 percent higher than for others. That would be progress, the insurers say, compared with 400 percent differentials charged by some companies.
The Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group for 300 commercial insurers, is pushing a package with reinsurance in New Jersey, Minnesota and Maine and says it will probably be offered soon in Ohio and Wisconsin. "These are proposals that would greatly restrict our ability to make money in the small group market," said Carl Schramm, the association president.
But in a policy called open enrollment, Blue Cross plans already accept all comers in 13 states and the District of Columbia. In most cases, they charge the same rates, regardless of occupation or health status, which is called community rating. These associations object to helping the commercial companies with the reinsurance plan.
Individuals in New York state can obtain Blue Cross coverage at any time, said Albert A. Cardone, chairman of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Although new members are not covered during the first 11 months for pre-existing conditions, they are fully covered afterward, even for AIDS. But Empire has stopped covering some professional associations, and their members must now pay the individual rates, which are higher. "Everybody has health insurance accessible to them," Mr. Cardone said. "The problem is they can't all afford it."
The reinsurance idea is being tested in Connecticut, where the pool will begin on May 1. Connecticut Blue Cross officials said the new law would actually force the association to start "medical underwriting" for the first time, to stay competitive. In medical underwriting, higher premiums are charged to those who have had expensive health problems.
Mary Nell Lehnhard, a national Blue Cross vice president, said the Connecticut law might raise the cost of all health insurance. "Twenty percent of the people enrolled tpically incur about 80 percent of the costs," she said. "If costs for the 20 percent are reduced, they will have to be raised quickly for a lot of people, which could cause political problems." The issue is being debated by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. The group is drafting a model law, to be recommended to legislatures and regulators in the 50 states.
In Congress, Pete Stark, chairman of the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, said he favored a bill that would restore tax exemption to Blue Cross plans that offer open enrollment and community rating.
Only 21 of the 73 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans might qualify for tax exemption under the bill, which is sponsored by Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan. But the national Blue Cross supports it. The measure will probably be part of the next tax package.
Mr. Stark is considering taking the Rangel approach a step further. Arguing that the industry's proposals for change would not reach enough of the 37 million uninsured Americans, Mr. Stark said he was thinking of requiring all insurers to offer open enrollment and community rating. The new rules would also apply to self-insured employers, who are exempt from many regulations under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act.
Mr. Stark's plan was criticized by insurance industry spokesmen. "Mr. Stark is in pursuit of a romantic ideal," said Mr. Schramm of the health insurance association. Health-cost inflation would "jump to over 20 percent a year," he said, if rates could not be tied to medical histories. Bernard R. Tresnowski, president of national Blue Cross and Blue Shield, said, "We've got to be able to take demographic factors into account, particularly age."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Two Growth Areas Beckon In Recession

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
BECAUSE of the recession, college students more than ever are searching for growth areas, even if they have to add a master's degree.
Prof. Lawrence K. Williams of Cornell University and Prof. Donald W. Collins of Arizona State University have two suggestions -- the so-called human resource field for liberal arts majors and waste management for science majors. 
 Professor Williams, administrator of graduate studies at Cornell's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, said retailers and financial companies were "not in the market" for liberal arts majors. "Graduates with degrees in areas where jobs are in short supply are coming to us for advanced study in human resources," he said.
Companies concerned with matching human resources with business strategy have been spending more on personnel departments to provide "a competitive edge," he explained.
Human resource departments deal with a company's employees. They handle relations with unions, executive compensation and bonuses, health and retirement benefits, discrimination and harassment charges, day care, maternity leave, part-time work and disciplinary problems, including drug abuse. Hiring M.B.A.'s and college graduates is part of the job, as well as establishing career routes.
Companies want to attract "young and vigorous people to manage these areas," Professor Williams said.
Students realize the broad scope of the field of human resources, he said. Applications for Cornell's two-year program leading to a master of industrial relations degree have jumped sharply this year. but Professor Williams said he did not expect enrollment to increase much beyond the 65 in the program, plus 60 working for doctorates.
"It allows us to be more selective," he said. "We look for balance -- good verbal and mathematics scores." Every student gets a well-paid summer internship. After receiving the master's degree, most start with big companies at $42,000 to $50,000.
He added: "Most of the Generals recruit here -- General Motors, General Foods, General Electric. This is a big year for petroleum recruiters -- Exxon, Chevron, ARCO and Amoco."
Graduates who start with big companies often move to small ones and a higher position after a few years, possibly as vice president of human resources.
In the past, managers in this field had what Professor Williams calls "low shelf skills," which means they filled a niche, like a specialty in employee benefits, and tended to stay in it. Many held M.B.A. degrees, which included a few courses in industrial relations and organizational behavior.
"Our training is more general," Professor Williams said. "We give them diagnostic skills -- law courses, economics and organizational behavior. We want them to have long-lasting research skills and a long shelf life." he explained.
Programs in human resources are not new. The interest in professional degree programs began after World War II, Professor Williams recalled.
Professor Collins, who is chairman of the department of industrial and manufacturing technology at Arizona State, acknowledges that engineers and some science majors have less difficulty in finding jobs than liberal arts students. But he says that "some of the hottest job opportunites of the decade will be in specialties like hazardous material, safety and waste management."
"Consider one agency -- the Department of Energy," he said. "The cleanup campaign for nuclear power plants required by law involves a 30-year program. It predicts the need to recruit 20,000 to 25,000 employees to do this job, and there must be managers to guide them."
The university offers a new master of technology degree in the field. "We have had courses in waste management and the environment for four years, but we have awarded the degree only in the last two," Professor Collins said. "It's a one-year program requiring 32 credit hours. Students need a strong science background, especially in chemistry. We have 36 students in the program, of which 18 are full time."
Students attend classes on Fridays and Saturdays because many are sent by their companies, Professor Collins said. "Few come from out of state because we have done no advertising, but now we are doing mailings," he said. "I would like to see the program grow to 100 a year." Salaries range widely from $28,000 to $65,000, depending on background, he said.
"The University of California has such a program and we have patterned ours on that one," Professor Collins said, adding that universities would increasingly offer courses in waste management, chiefly in civil or industrial engineering departments. He also hopes to start a doctor of technology program in the fall, he said.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Devalues Money To Stem Economic Collapse

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 4

 BODY:
Trying to satisfy Nicaragua's international creditors without setting off another round of violent strikes by Sandinista labor unions, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro began a new economic stabilization program today based on a major devaluation of the currency.
"We have already exchanged war for peace," Mrs. Chamorro told the nation in a televised address on Sunday. "Now we are going to exchange economic disaster for the stability we all want." 
 She presented the plan after several days of uncertainty that saw commerce come almost to a halt over price confusion and the nearly worthless cordoba drop from 7 million to the dollar to about 12 million in one day of street trading on Friday.
The Government intends to replace the existing cordoba over the next two months with the so-called gold cordoba -- actually a bill, too -- that it created last year on a par with the dollar. The gold cordoba has so far served mainly as a way to guarantee bank deposits and loans.
The new parities are five gold cordobas to the dollar and five million old cordobas to a gold cordoba. The old cordoba is to disappear by the end of April.
The package also includes increases in state salaries and in the wholesale prices of basic foods and fuel, in public transportation and in utilities, but generally by three or four times the existing levels, not the five times the devaluation seemed to represent.
Mrs. Chamorro also promised to push ahead with her commitment to liberalize the economy, still struggling under the weight of the heavy state structure created during nearly 11 years of rule by the Sandinistas, but offered few specifics.
Although many in Mrs. Chamorro's Government think Nicaragua deserves more economic help with fewer strings attached than what it is now receiving from the United States and other leading nations, these steps were timed to impress donors and would-be donors with the Government's economic seriousness.
Representatives of donor nations are scheduled to meet in Washington on March 25 and 26 to consider an aid package for Nicaragua that would pay off its $350 million in arrears to the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.
Trying to head off labor and other opposition that could destroy any hope of reviving Nicaragua's prostrate economy, Mrs. Chamorro's chief minister, Antonio Lacayo, spent the past week discussing elements of the plan with virtually every sector of Nicaraguan society.
The key group, the Sandinista Front, along with the labor movement affiliated with it, the National Workers Front, has been critical but did not immediately mount public protests or strikes.
The labor group met on Sunday night and announced that it was rejecting what it characterized as a "shock" treatment. The group declared that the plan violated what it said was Mr. Lacayo's promise to take gradual measures.
Seeming to take a negotiating position, the labor group demanded, among other things, that salaries be raised by about twice what Mr. Lacayo announced. It called for workers to "mobilize" in defense of these demands but said the precise steps would be discussed in meetings of individual unions starting today.
These measures are similar to stabilization attempts that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and the Sandinista Front made in the last year of their Government, with the difference, Mr. Lacayo said, that this Government counts with international support to back up the currency and make the plan work.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Lowest Since 1982

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
New-home sales plunged in January to their lowest level in eight and a half years, the Government said today, but analysts, saying buyers had become more active in recent weeks, forecast a modest improvement this year.
"January was a month of high anxiety," with spending curtailed because of concern over the Persian Gulf war and the recession, said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. 
 The Commerce Department and the Housing and Urban Development Department said sales fell 12.3 percent, to 408,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, in January. That was the lowest level since the 407,000 rate in August 1982.
 
War Anxiety Cited
 "Housing activity stalled in the first half of the month as the clock ticked away" on the deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, said David G. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.
Since then, however, "we've been getting a lot of reports that things are looking pretty good," he said, citing an increase in buyer traffic and more optimistic expectations by builders.
John A. Tuccillo, an economist at the National Association of Realtors, agreed, saying, "Continuous reports of allied successes had eased consumer anxiety by late January, and many markets reported a notable increase in home-buying traffic."
New-home sales have fallen for two years, and in January were 35 percent below January 1990.
The Government also said today that the median price of a new home fell 4 percent, to $121,800, in January. Median means half of the homes cost more, half less.
At the end of the month, the seasonally adjusted estimate of new houses for sale totaled 316,000. That represented a 9.3-month supply of unsold units, the highest level since a 9.4-month supply in April 1982.
Because builders tend to postpone construction when inventories are high, the report raised the possibility of more layoffs in the housing industry.
 
Construction Jobs Lost
 The Labor Department has reported that 155,000 construction jobs were lost in January, although it blamed unusually bad weather for some of the decrease. The overall weakness in the construction industry has caused 450,000 workers to be cut from payrolls since May.
Today's report said sales of new homes were off nationwide. In the South, sales plunged 17.5 percent, to an annual rate of 160,000, the lowest since the Government began keeping records in 1973. Sales had slipped 6.7 percent in December.
In the Midwest, sales fell 14 percent, to 74,000, after being flat the previous month. Sales were off 12.3 percent, to 57,000, in the Northeast, where sales had fallen 5.8 percent a month earlier. And they dropped 1.7 percent in the West, to 117,000, after declining 5.3 percent in December.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold End Mixed; Jobless Report Is Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mixed against the leading foreign currencies yesterday as traders took a breather after the dollar's big gains last week. Gold prices were also mixed.
After a strong rise last week, the dollar's levels were due for some adjustments, said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager of the Bank of New York. He said the market was now in the process of consolidating "before the trend resumes on the upside." 
 Analysts said the market continued to shift attention away from the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war and back to technical and economic factors. They said traders were waiting for the release of the Government's employment report, due out on Friday, for an indication of whether the economy was moving out of recession.
If the employment numbers are strong, the Federal Reserve would be under less pressure to relax interest rates. When rates are stable or moving up, the dollar tends to gain value.
In Europe, dealers said the dollar moved narrowly during the session, reflecting concerns among traders that the end of the gulf war alone would not create the demand needed to support the dollar.
 
Pound Climbs
 The British pound gained against the American currency, closing at $1.9008 in New York, up from $1.8960 late Friday. Earlier in London, the pound rose to $1.8975, from $1.8970 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Friday prices, were: 1.53265 German marks, down from 1.5385; 1.3355 Swiss francs, unchanged, 5.2185 French francs, down from 5.2415; 1,144.75 Italian lire, down from 1,150.50, and 1.15515 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15205.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with the late Friday prices, were: 1.5365 German marks, unchanged; 1.3390 Swiss francs, up from 1.3320; 5.2335 French francs, down from 5.2350; 1.7320 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7315; 1,147.50 Italian lire, down from 1,148.50, and 1.1555 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1530.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen, closing at 135.49 yen in New York, up from 134.60 on Friday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 135.35 yen, up 1.10 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 135.50 yen.
Gold closed at $367.90 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, up 90 cents an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $367.40, also up 90 cents.
Gold finished unchanged in London at a late bid price of $366 an ounce.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Expected Cut in Oil Output Pushes Crude Prices Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Petroleum futures prices jumped yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders bought contracts on the expectation of production cuts by OPEC members.
Crude oil futures settled 25 cents to 87 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in April up 87 cents at $20.25 a barrel. Home heating oil was 1.55 cents to 1.84 cents higher, with April at 56.13 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline rose 1.65 cents to 3.95 cents, with April at 69.40 cents a gallon. Natural gas was 0.6 cent lower to 1.5 cents higher, with April at $1.355 per 1,000 cubic feet. 
 Crude prices were bolstered by widespread expectations that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would agree at a meeting next week in Geneva to cut production in hopes of raising crude prices to an OPEC target of $21 a barrel, said James Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York.
 
Saudis in Command
 He said the defeat of Iraq by forces led by the United States had left Saudi Arabia in a commanding position among OPEC nations.
The Saudis "are looked at as price moderates, but even the moderate position in OPEC looks for $21 a barrel," Mr. Steel said.
Gasoline futures were further supported by reports of a fire at a Citgo Petroleum Corporation refinery in Lake Charles, La. The fire began late Sunday and burned itself out early yesterday.
Silver futures rose sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York, extending a rally that has raised the spot price by more than 29 cents an ounce, or about 8 percent, since last Tuesday. Analysts said the buying partly reflected a belief that the war's end could speed an economic recovery in the United States, stimulating silver demand from industry.
 
Strike Helps Silver
 John Jonat, metals analyst with Deak International Inc. in New York, said the market also drew support from a strike at Mexico's Penoules smelting operation.
Silver futures settled 8.2 cents to 10.5 cents higher, with March at $3.856 an ounce; gold was 90 cents to $1 higher, with April at $369.50 an ounce.
Grain and soybean futures rose modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending to three days a rally linked to poor crop weather for southern Brazilian soybeans and American winter wheat.
Wheat futures were unchanged to 3 cents higher, with March at $2.71 a bushel. Corn was 1/4 cent to 2 cents higher, with March at $2.46 a bushel Oats were 2 1/2 cents to 3 3/4 cents higher, with March at $1.19 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 2 cents to 5 3/4 cents higher, with March at $5.90 1/4 a bushel.
Livestock and meat futures ended mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting continued strength in the cash cattle market and weakness in cash hogs, combined with expectations that pork futures were due for a break after a strong rally last week.

HEADLINE: Democrats to President: Focus on Issues at Home

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
After months as bystanders while President Bush led the country to war, the Senate and House Democratic leaders struggled today to shift some attention back to Congress, domestic affairs and partisan politics.
In separate addresses before a legislative conference of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell, and the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, praised Mr. Bush for his leadership in the Persian Gulf crisis. But in the euphoria over the victory abroad, they said, it is no time to neglect pressing social problems at home. 
 The speeches were a preview of the careful balancing act facing Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Foley in the coming days: they want to show initiative among Democrats but they do not want to be accused of attacking a President whose popularity has soared to a historic high point. Conceding the wide bipartisan support for Mr. Bush's handling of the gulf crisis, the Democratic leaders have invited him to address a joint session of Congress on Wednesday night.
Mr. Foley opened his address this morning by commending the President and the American military for "a brillant military success." But after taking note of a new "national pride," the Washington Democrat turned to domestic matters.
"We have problems here at home that are dramatic in a long-term sense, are conclusive and defining in a long-term sense, though not with the intensity or the focus of this recent war," the House Speaker said. "But if we ignore our problems at home, if we ignore the failings of our own system in this country -- economic, political, educational and health -- we will be inviting a time in the next century when the United States will simply not have the capacity, will not have the power, to lead the world to an undertaking such as the Desert Storm or Desert Shield operation."
Appearing later before the same friendly audience of leading union officials, Senator Mitchell was more overtly partisan, and not as effusive in his praise for the Administration. While he said Mr. Bush and his military advisers "deserve credit for the success" in the Persian Gulf, the Maine Democrat wasted no time in reciting a litany of what he views as the Administration's domestic vulnerabilities.
"In the wake of the war, the President says he seeks a new world order," Mr. Mitchell said. "We say, Join us in putting our own house in order. Our first priority must be the American people and economic growth and jobs in the United States."
The Senator condemned Mr. Bush's energy policy as "no policy at all," and dismissed Mr. Bush's recent proposal on block grants for cities and states as "ill-advised." And he vowed to champion passage of family leave and civil rights bills. Both measures were vetoed last year.
The Democratic leaders said that while the United States should play a leading diplomatic role in seeking to resolve lingering troubles in the Middle East, they were more concerned with rebuilding American cities than with rebuilding Kuwait or Iraq.
"It is not appropriate for the United States or United States taxpayers to be called upon to pay any of the cost of rebuilding of this region," Mr. Foley said, prompting applause from union leaders.
Senator Mitchell sounded a similar theme. "But what about American cities?" he asked. "They haven't been bombed. People haven't been tortured. But in many respects, there is devastation in American cities -- economic devastation, psychological devastation, the loss of jobs, the loss of hope, the loss of opportunity. We've got to restore that."
Mr. Foley dwelled on a need for improvements in secondary and higher education so that students can lead the nation into the next century with the ability to "make a military achievement such as Desert Storm possible."
Unlike Senator Mitchell, the Speaker sought to give Congress a bit of credit for the military victory.
Neglecting to mention that he and two-thirds of the Democrats voted in January against using military force in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Foley told the group: "From the time the President made the decision to send forces to the gulf in August of 1990, there was strong bipartisan support for that decision. There was no significant opposition in the Congress or in the country to his determination to defend Saudi Arabia and to redeem Kuwait and to expell Saddam Hussein from Kuwait."

HEADLINE: Bloomfield Hills Journal;
'Recession' Means Someone Else's

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich.

 BODY:
In this wealthy enclave 20 miles from the desperate ghettos of Detroit, local celebrities live on forested estates, chic women in shearling and mink casually drop $4,000 on, say, a belt, and the word "recession" is a minor annoyance, a faint description of somebody else's world.
So while people on the coasts anguish over their faltering economies and even as a new Michigan Governor searches for ways to cut a thin budget, it is more or less spending as usual in this privileged suburb. 
 People are building their 12-bedroom mansions, buying their Ferraris and $4,600 crocodile totebags, racing to the fashion shows to order $2,800 pantsuits and flying first-class to Aspen for the weekend.
To read a recent issue of the local daily newspaper, The Eccentric, one would never know there was economic turmoil in this hemisphere. One story told readers about the latest features on a luxury cruise ship and a headline urged them to "forget winter's blahs, think summer camp."
Bloomfield Hills has never been known for its austerity. While the older, courtlier suburbs east of Detroit, the Grosse Pointes, are a picture of studied restraint, Bloomfield Hills to the north is new money and proud to show it, as perhaps best embodied by a onetime resident, John Z. DeLorean. Bloomfield Hills is now home to Lee Iacocca, Roger Smith, Aretha Franklin, Isiah Thomas and just about anybody else from Detroit who has come into money in the last quarter-century.
These are people who can buy what they want, say the jewelers and boutique owners and interior designers who make their living by catering to the new rich and famous. "The people who've had money still got money and are still spending money," said Terry Mullen, a dealer of luxury import cars in nearby Birmingham.
So despite a recession and layoffs looming in the American automobile industry, Mr. Mullen recently sold a used Ferarri Testarossa for $170,000 to a Bloomfield Hills man who found that his BMW and Mercedes-Benz were simply not enough.
This is not to say that residents here are insensitive to the times. Mr. Mullen has been noticing that some are showing a bit of pragmatism by buying a second Mercedes, a convertible, maybe, instead of a Lamborghini. "Some of them are going for the stuff they can actually drive -- Porsche 911's, Mercedeses, BMW's," he said. "Ma and pa stuff. But of course, ma and pa make $200,000 apiece."
From Bloomfield and the rest of Oakland County, a regional center for research and technology companies, the world looks rosy indeed. In December, the county's unemployment rate fell below 5 percent, to 4.9 percent, for the first time since 1978.
Michigan businesses learned bitter lessons from the devastating recession of 1982, when the unemployment rate in Oakland County reached double digits. That recession, economists say, sifted out the weaker companies.
In the past decade, Oakland County has been the source of 60 percent of all new nongovernment jobs in the state, and Bloomfield Hills and Oakland County consistently rank among the richest in the country.
"We don't bend metal," said Joseph D. Joachim, the deputy county executive. "We're becoming a brain center. We've yet to experience a recession with this kind of mix."
People here prefer not to think about the "R-word." "I won't even allow the word to be said in our company," said Janet Sparks, a Bloomfield resident who heads her own secretarial services concern. "It allows people to make excuses for not performing."
Still, in these days when thousands of auto workers are destined to spend more time on the unemployment line than the assembly line, the captains of industry are being careful not to look as if they are enjoying themselves too much.
"People are more publicly discreet," said Ed Rondina, a hair stylist who has been primping the manes of Michigan's wealthiest women for 13 years. "The automotive high executive wives are tending to repeat outfits now when otherwise they would't wear the same thing twice."
At Adaria, a newly expanded boutique where a suit could pay an average family's mortgage through August and where $2,000 alligator purses are the big movers, business is as brisk as usual, its owner, Anne Dinon, said.
If there is a recession in the auto industry, Chris Long, a Bloomfield Hills architect, says he cannot feel it. "They are absolutely still spending money." Mr. Long said. "After several good years, the auto company executives are spending the fruits of their labor."
Nor have people here lost their zeal for travel. "We're going crazy right now," said Sharon Friedman, an Oakland County travel agent. "We've got tons of people going to Aspen, and they're paying top dollar."
So it is mostly business as usual along the leafy boulevards here, where women pay Mr. Rondina $75 a day to stop by their homes to brush out their hair. "They are still conspicuous spenders," he said. "They feel confident because they know they can ride it out. After all, they rode out the last recession and became more prosperous than they were before."
