HEADLINE: Fed to Fight Part of Plan On Banks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan and other top officials of the Federal Reserve Board are strongly opposed to the part of the Bush Administration's proposed banking legislation that would remove some of the nation's largestbanks from the central bank's supervision.
The Fed's opposition is likely to doom this aspect of the legislation. Insistence by the Treasury Department that the provisions be retained could delay Congressional approval, or even reduce the likelihood of approval, of more fundamental elements of the broad package that the Administration, the Federal Reserve and many private economists say would modernize an anachronistic banking system. 
 Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and his colleagues insist that the Fed could not properly conduct monetary policy or respond adequately to crises like a crash of the financial markets without the detailed understanding of large banks that comes from direct supervision of their lending and other activities.
 
A Matter of Responsibility
 Mr. Greenspan, the other Federal Reserve governors and top staff regulators would not discuss the matter for attribution because, they said, they have not yet presented their case to Congress. But one senior official, who agreed to be interviewed on the condition that he was not identified, said: "Ultimately, the Fed is responsible for the nation's financial system. We can't have that responsibility without the input that comes from direct contact with the biggest banks."
The Administration argues, to the contrary, that the central bank must relinquish some regulatory authority in the interest of simplifying an unwieldy structure in which three Federal agencies -- the Fed, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation -- are involved in bank supervision.
"What we do now is overlapping, confusing and not responsive, and is badly in need of simplification," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in an interview today.
Another top Treasury official said, "The Fed would get all the information it needs from the other regulators."
President Bush has said the banking measure is his top domestic legislative priority for this year. The main aspects of the proposal would eliminate barriers to interstate banking and permit commercial and investment banks to merge. The plan would also allow industrial companies to own banks.
But the battle over supervisory authority is an example of how, just four weeks after Mr. Brady announced the proposal, the initiative may be foundering.
 
Formal Proposal Is Delayed
 To the disappointment of the leaders of the Banking Committees in Congress, the Treasury has still not submitted the legislation it wants considered. Mr. Brady told the lawmakers in hearings last week that the delay was a result of the difficulty of drafting such a long and complicated document.
Many lawmakers of both parties also said they were upset that the Administration had so far refused to take a position on how to replenish the bank insurance fund, which is administered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and protects bank deposits up to $100,000.
By some estimates, enough banks will fail this year to cause the fund to run dry, and officials and politicians agree that new money must be found this year. But raising that money is bound to be politically unpopular, and the Administration apparently wants to avoid as much responsibility or blame as possible.
 
A Mixed Reception
 In two days of hearings before the Senate and House Banking Committees last week, much support was heard for allowing banks to open branches nationwide. But considerable opposition was expressed to allowing banks to enter new lines of business, and there was little enthusiasm for allowing commercial companies to buy banks.
Robert D. Reischauer, who is director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief staff economist, said in an interview that he plans to testify on Tuesday that he is "sympathetic to interstate banking and lukewarm about giving banks increased powers." He also said he sees "no persuasive evidence why allowing commercial firms to own banks would improve the situation."
On the question of supervisory authority, Mr. Reischauer said that he favored simplified regulation but that it was "not at all clear that the Administration proposal represents a marked improvement over what we have now."
 
State and Federal Charters
 Under current law, the Fed regulates all bank holding companies; more than 90 percent of the nation's bank assets are in banks that are part of holding companies. The Administration proposes to continue to let the Fed supervise holding companies in which the principal bank is state-chartered, but to allow a new agency within the Treasury Department to supervise those in which the main bank is federally chartered.
Some of the largest banks owned by holding companies are federally chartered, including Citibank, Chase Manhattan, First National Bank of Chicago, Security Pacific and BankAmerica. Among those that are state-chartered are Manufacturers Hanover, Chemical, the Bank of New York, Bankers Trust and Morgan Guaranty.
Many senators and representatives view the fight over which agencies should supervise which banks to be little more than a bureaucratic turf struggle, but officials at the Fed and the Treasury say it is more important than that.
"Some might suggest that my position is motivated by nothing more than bureaucratic turf," E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said in a recent speech. "But it is not; it is my utter conviction based on my view of the very essence of central banking."
Mr. Brady, on the other hand, said, "You're supposed to say and do what you think is right for the country regardless of the turf fights." He added that he thought it was crucial to have bank regulation "in the political realm" rather than largely at the Fed, which is independent.

HEADLINE: A County With Much at Stake Is Wary of Weicker Tax Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn.

 BODY:
The anxiety and uncertainty that has gripped much of Connecticut since Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced his plan to tax wages has found its focal point here in Fairfield County, the seat of the state's greatest wealth.
From the horse paddocks of back-country Greenwich to the corporate office parks of Stamford, Fairfield and Danbury -- home to more Fortune 500 corporations than any place in the United States after New York and Chicago -- Mr. Weicker's plan has raised questions about the region's future and its identity. There is widespread concern over how the tax plan would affect individuals here, and whether the changes would disrupt the economy and make the area less desirable for corporations. 
 Among the mysteries is the question of just how much wealth would be tapped by Mr. Weicker's proposed 6 percent tax on family income over $25,000. Because Connecticut has had no income tax except on dividends, interest and capital gains, and because the Internal Revenue Service only compiles statewide figures, no one is really sure how rich the rich here really are, or even how much they pay in taxes now.
Connecticut, one of only 10 states with no broad-based personal income tax, has financed state government mainly through sales and corporation taxes. The Weicker plan would lower those in an effort to stimulate the economy and would make up the gap with the new income tax.
 
Pockets of High Income
 There are only glimmers of information about what might turn up on the new tax form: New York State officials, for example, say that the average commuter from Connecticut was paid about $63,000 in 1987, or three times as much as the average commuter from Pennsylvania.
A study several years ago found that 40 percent of the taxes on stock dividends and capital-gains earnings in Connecticut were collected in just eight lower Fairfield County towns. When one Greenwich millionaire, whose name remains a mystery, died last year, the inheritance tax paid to Connecticut was $52.7 million.
The United States Department of Commerce ranked Fairfield as the ninth wealthiest county in the nation in 1988, with a per capita income of $29,084. Connecticut's statewide average was $23,033, highest in the nation.
But residents and politicians here, some of whom report an almost hysterical reaction against the income tax, say the implications of Mr. Weicker's plan go far beyond the pocketbook.
"Upstate the income tax is opposed, but it's recognized as a meaningful option," said Senator George Jepsen, a Democrat from Stamford, who said he intended to oppose the plan. "Downstate it's just absolute, and frequently emotional, opposition."
 
A Separate Identity
 Fairfield County, with a heavy concentration of Republicans and commuters who work in New York, has long felt itself alien to the rest of the state and to the state government, which has been run by Democrats for most of the last 40 years. And Mr. Weicker, a former Greenwich Republican who abandoned his party last year to run as a third-party independent, lost badly in the county.
The county gets less state aid in such areas as education than less affluent areas of the state receive. The local economy is also far less tied to the engine of state spending than is the economy around Hartford.
Mr. Weicker argues that the income tax would resolve a $2.4 billion gap in state revenues and stimulate the sagging economy at the same time by allowing tax cuts to businesses. More than a few residents here don't see the connection.
K. Ross Hughes, a retired paper-company executive from Greenwich, spoke for many Fairfield residents when he said, "It's going to kill the economy of this area -- that's about all I can say."
There is, however, some support for the plan. State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Republican from Greenwich, said that fully a third of his mail favors the Weicker proposals, mostly because of the proposed reduction in dividend taxes.
 
Measuring the Effects
 State officials say that while some Fairfield residents would see a sharp increase in their taxes, a greater proportion of residents in Fairfield County would find their taxes staying the same or reduced under Mr. Weicker's plan than in any other part of the state.
The Weicker proposal would lower the tax on corporate profits, for example -- now the highest in the nation at 13.8 percent -- to 11.5 percent. The 8 percent sales tax, the highest statewide rate in the nation, would be lowered to 4.25 percent. Taxes on dividends and interest, also the highest in the nation at 14 percent for incomes above $100,000, would be treated the same as wages and taxed at 6 percent. The capital-gains tax, on profits from the sale of investments like real estate and stocks, would be lowered to 6 percent from the current 7 percent.
The large number of Fairfield County residents who commute to work in New York already pay income taxes there. Such commuters would continue to pay income taxes where they work, and those taxes would effectively cancel out their income-tax liability in Connecticut.
The reductions in taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains would be likely to benefit Fairfield residents the most, since so much investment income is concentrated in the county.
"It's a real hard call, but I think we should give him a chance," Jan McCurry, a bank loan officer who works in Greenwich, said of Mr. Weicker. "I would like to see the wealthier segment pay a little bit more."
 
Climate for Businesses
 One of the biggest concerns of Fairfield County residents and officials is whether the Weicker plan would make the area less desirable for corporations. They say the county's successful combination of lower taxes and an attractive quality of life could be thrown out of balance.
For the commercial real-estate lenders and builders who have created an industry out of wooing major corporations from New York City, anxieties about the tax plan have been heightened by the recession. Eve without an income tax, it has been five years since the last Fortune 500 company moved here.
Morgan Stanley, the investment banking house, is considered by many to be a test case for the Weicker plan. The company, now based in Manhattan, is considering a move to Stamford that would be the biggest corporate relocation ever for this state. Up to 4,200 employees would be moved and 1.2 million square feet of new office space would be built.
"There's no question that it's going to hurt competitiveness," Dennis J. Donovan, a senior vice president at Moran Stahl & Boyer, a consulting firm that specializes in business relocation, said of the tax plan.
But Mr. Donovan said that if some of the new tax money were used to address other problems that have already diminished the area's appeal -- especially traffic congestion -- the advantages and disadvantages would probably equal out.
Theodore F. Brophy, retired chairman of the GTE Corporation, which was one of the first major companies to relocate from New York in 1970, said in an interview that Connecticut's periodic fiscal crises and high corporation taxes have already made it "less attractive as a place to be than when GTE moved up here."
But, he added, everything is relative. "I would guess," Mr. Brophy said, "that New York is also less attractive than it was."

HEADLINE: Campeau Units Report Losses

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, March 4

 BODY:
The Campeau Corporation's two department store subsidiaries -- the Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores -- today reported losses in January and said they expected the slow economy would continue to hurt results in the near term.
The department stores, which are operating under protection of United States bankruptcy laws, said in a statement that "consumer activity was weaker than expected in January, reflecting the impact of the war and the continuing recession."
Federated reported a loss of $69 million for the four weeks that ended on Feb. 2. That compared with a profit of $51 million in the five weeks that ended on Jan. 5. Sales fell to $211 million from $772 million.
Allied Stores said it had a loss in January of $55 million, compared with a December profit of $23.4 million. Sales tumbled to $127 million, from $414 million in the five weeks that ended on Jan. 5.

HEADLINE: Tough Choice for New York: Pay Debt Cost or Halt Repairs

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Prices of Manhattan apartments may be soft and the city's bridges may be crumbling, but in one category, at least, New York remains on top: It piles on more long-term debt in most years than any borrower other than the United States Government.
In the 1970's the city's burden of debt was a symptom of its financial woes -- borrowing to mask poor fiscal management and to pay operating expenses. But today's heavy borrowing has a concrete purpose, literally. It is for rebuilding the city. 
 The city's ferocious appetite for debt stems largely from a decision made in 1988 by the Koch administration to accelerate sharply its spending on infrastructure, like roads, bridges and the maintenance of city school buildings.
The city's Office of Management and Budget has estimated that even if the capital budgets of Houston, Chicago, Philadelphia and Los Angeles -- whose total population is 30 percent more than New York City's -- were all rolled into one, that would still equal only 55 percent of New York City's capital program in its 1992 fiscal year. That point is not diminished even if spending by the county governments of those other cities is included.
 
'Uncharted Waters'
 While most residents applauded the decision to rebuild, the cost of financing this program has now led the city, in its fiscal straits, to an agonizing policy choice: whether it can afford the cost and depressing economic effects now of servicing that debt versus whether it can afford not to fix school buildings, bridges and roadways.
The $22.4 billion in debt the city already has on its books will require it to devote 75 cents of every new dollar of revenue raised this year to meeting interest and principal payments. And over the next four years, the city has plans to issue $17.8 billion more in long-term bonds.
"We're in uncharted waters," said one city official. "Nobody has ever tried to issue this much debt before." The State of California comes the closest, but, as financial experts point out, its economy is many times the size of New York City's, and California enjoys a triple-A rating, which makes its bonds more attractive to investors.
The administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch planned to pay for much of that capital investment program with borrowed money. And since the mid-1980's the city has chosen to defer repaying some of its debt and instead to roll it over into the future. The result of these decisions is that debt service payments are higher now, when the city is in a recession, than they were during the boom years of the 1980's, when the city's tax base increased by 50 percent. Mr. Koch makes no apologies for his decision to increase capital spending but says the city must now cut back, given its financial condition.
 
A Bulge in Payments
 Over the next three fiscal years, just as the city is trying to help spark a recovery, it faces a bulge in interest and principal payments that could force it to curtail its spending on infrastructure. Such cutbacks, debt analysts said, would depress construction activity and dampen any nascent recovery.
The administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins has already responded to the city's mounting debt problems by paring the city's capital commitment program by $2.3 billion over the next four years, a step that reduced borrowing costs by $1.4 billion. But officials say that may not be enough.
"We will probably need to evaluate it again before May," said City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. The city's final report on its 10-year capital strategy is due in May.
The possibility of another round of cuts in the city's capital spending has already set off a fierce debate within various agencies over the city's future. While some city officials worry that New York cannot sustain its huge borrowing program because the marketplace cannot absorb that many bonds, others say the alternative -- sharp cutbacks in spending on infrastructure -- could so damage the city's roads and bridges that it would undermine the city's long-term future.
What everyone does seem to agree on is that the city's debt load is rapidly becoming an important policy issue. It began creeping up in size in the mid-1980's, but New York City and the Municipal Assistance Corporation rose to the top of the debt rankings in 1986 and have remained there since, except for last year, when it was surpassed by the New York State Dormitory Authority. The city's anticipated $4 billion-a-year borrowing program assures it its place on top for the next few years.
In the next fiscal year alone, debt service payments are due to rise by $962 million, or an amount equal to around half of the city's forecasted budget deficit of more than $2 billion. Paradoxically, nearly a third of that increase is due to payments on debt issued by the M.A.C. in the 1970's to help pull the city out of its last economic crisis.
 
Major Element of Gaps
 "The sharp rise in debt service is clearly the major element of the huge budget gaps confronting the city," the office of the State Deputy Comptroller for New York City warned last November in a report on the city's economy.
Debt service payments, it is estimated, will consume more than 11 percent of the city's revenues by 1994, up from 6.3 percent last year. And even that forecast may prove to be optimistic if income-tax and property-tax revenues continue to fall short of expectations, as they have recently. In the mid-1970's, when the city was mired in a debt crisis, debt service consumed about 15 percent of the city's budget.
There are a number of steps that the Dinkins administration could take to reduce the impact on the budget and the economy of the city's looming debt load. It could refinance some of that debt, stretching the interest payments over a longer time period. But when that idea was broached recently by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, which monitors the city's finances, the proposal was quickly dismissed by city officials as fiscally irresponsible and it has garnered little political support since then.
 
A Quirk With Implications
 Another option is to increase the market for the city's bonds by diversifying the name under which they are issued. Unlike many other states and municipalities, New York has issued the bulk of its debt under the city's name instead of, say, a city housing agency or a transportation authority. Though largely a historical quirk, that has important financial and political implications.
Most mutual funds, which are the largest buyers of the city's bonds, have internal guidelines that prohibit them from investing more than 5 percent of their portfolios in the bonds of any one issuer. And since New York City has been issuing so many billions of bonds under one name for so many years, and has plans to continue doing so, some funds may soon approach that limit.
Gary Swayze, a portfolio manager at Fidelity Investments, said two of its mutual funds that buy New York City bonds are about a third of the way toward their 5 percent ceiling on these bonds.
Although investor demand for New York bonds has been strong so far, Dinkins administration officials and debt analysts are not sure how long the financial markets can continue to absorb quarterly bond offerings of $1 billion or more, particularly if the city's economic climate continues to deteriorate and there is further downgrading of the city's debt rating.
 
'Sheer Volume'
 In its most recent $1 billion bond offering, the city ended up paying an interest rate about 1 percentage point higher than comparable municipal borrowers. Mr. Swayze of Fidelity attributed that higher rate to "the sheer volume of issuance rather than credit quality."
Maintaining access to the bond markets is a particularly sensitive issue at City Hall, for even the "substantial likelihood" that access might be lost could trigger the intervention of the State Financial Control Board.
The Dinkins administration is working hard to design new borrowing entities that would finance equipment the city buys each year and the renovation of two hospitals. But even if the city was successful in creating these new programs, it would reduce its $4 billion-a-year borrowing plan by only $500 million a year.
The more the city decentralizes its borrowing authority, the more far-reaching the policy repercussions will be. To convince investors that the new entities are truly independent, they have to have their own earmarked source of revenues. And that could lead to an increase in user fees for city services that were previously paid out of general revenues.
 
Charging for Water
 In 1986, for instance, the city established the Municipal Water Authority, which has since issued $3.24 billion of bonds under its own name. Money to pay the interest and principal on that debt comes from new user fees that are being charged on water as a result of the city's recent efforts to install meters throughout the city. The authority's rate consultant has estimated that water and sewer rates will have to rise 18.3 percent in the next fiscal year and 18.9 percent the next year to cover expenses, which include debt service.
In addition to the likelihood of more "revenue enhancement" measures, a decentralization of the city's borrowing authority could have longer-term implications for the way the city is run.
If the city's borrowing is divided among a host of new authorities, however, it will be the appointed officials who run those entities and decide how their financial resources should be used. Just as city officials and assistance corporation officials have frequently disagreed over how M.A.C. surpluses should be used, the existence of a host of other borrowing authorities could slowly devolve decision-making power away from elected officials and into the hands of other appointees.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
And Now, a Commission on S.& L.'s

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Hundreds of articles, scores of scholarly papers and more than a dozen full-length books have been written in the last two years alone on the causes of the savings and loan mess.
But they were not authoritative enough for Congress. On the night of Saturday, Oct. 27, just before adjournment of the 101st Congress, without a recorded vote and almost unnoticed in the press, the lawmakers established a commission to study the savings and loan issue: the National Commission on Financial Institution Reform, Recovery and Enforcement. 
 At a cost of $1 million, the commission will take its place beside the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission, the Ukraine Famine Commission and who knows how many other panels that have been set up because Congress wanted to do something and did not know what.
Nothing much has happened since the law was passed. The commission is supposed to have eight private citizens as members: two appointed by the President, two by the Senate Democratic leadership, two by the House Democratic leadership and one each by the Senate and House Republican leadership. None have been named yet, and the $1 million has not been appropriated.
"What with the war and everything else, people have been busy, and this has not been on a fast track," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who was the House sponsor.
Still, a law is a law. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said last week that he had submitted the names of potential commission members to the White House. The Congressional leaders said they were working on it. (House Speaker Thomas S. Foley has a staff assistant whose full-time job is to find people for the slots on more than 150 commissions and boards he is responsible for filling.)
Sooner or later the panel members will be appointed, the money will be allocated, a staff will be formed and office space will be found.
After nine months, the life span of the panel set by the law, the commissioners will call a news conference and distribute a thick report. The findings are entirely predictable.
In brief, economic circumstances in the late 1970's and early 1980's, particularly unusually high interest rates, made the savings and loans unprofitable. They were saddled with long-term, low-interest mortgage loans at a time when they were forced to pay high rates to depositors.
To keep them in business, Congress, which was unusually tight with some of the lobbyists and operators, changed the rules and permitted savings and loans to get into risky areas like commercial real estate and junk bonds.
Meanwhile, the state and Federal regulatory agencies were understaffed and ill-equipped. The Reagan Administration preferred not to intervene in unpleasant economic problems, saying the free market should be allowed to take its course.
But free-market principles did not apply. Federal deposit insurance meant that the Government and not the operators of the savings and loans bore most of the financial risk. So when speculative deals went sour, sometimes because of incompetence and sometimes because of corruption, the taxpayers were left holding the bag, to the tune of hundreds of billions of dollars.
In other words, there is plenty of blame to go around.
Administration officials say they will cooperate with the commission, though they see it as a pain in the neck. "It's going to take an enormous amount of everyone's time, collecting documents and preparing testimony, and in the end they're just going to come up with what everyone already knows," said one official.
So why yet another commission? Surely, the lawmakers would have accomplished more and earned more political credit if they had used the $1 million, say, to hire more clerks at understaffed unemployment offices.
Mr. Schumer and Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, one of the chief Senate sponsors, say their primary motive was to get an authoritative report that would persuade their colleagues that allowing banks to enter new businesses would not run the risk of another savings and loan disaster.
But even the sponsors' enthusiasm seems to have waned. "I don't consider it to be one of my monumental legislative accomplishments," said Senator Dodd.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Loans To Chrysler Called Near

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 4

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation has reached a tentative accord with its banks that if approved would give the company a financial cushion until its depressed sales and profits improve, financial executives who spoke with Chrysler officials said today.
Chrysler has been unable to comply with some conditions of its existing $2.6 billion revolving line of credit, which expires in 1993. Under terms of the tentative agreement, those loans would be replaced by $1.7 billion in new loans with different terms. 
 Chrysler executives met Friday at the company's headquarters in Highland Park, Mich., near Detroit, with a consortium of 38 banks led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. The New York-based financial executives said an agreement could be made final within two weeks.
Chrysler asked the banks to reorganize its existing agreement because it could not comply with some of the covenants, or terms, of the loan since its balance sheet had deteriorated in recent months, the sources said.
 
Sensitive Negotiations
 The executives, who consult regularly with Chrysler financial managers, agreed to speak only on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the negotiations.
Chrysler posted a small profit for the fourth quarter of 1990, but it has said that it expects a large loss in the current quarter, which ends on March 31. The company said last week that it was reducing its salaried work force by about 3,000 employees.
Recent reductions in the quality ratings of Chrysler's debt securities to "junk bond" status have made it too expensive for the company to borrow in the public debt markets. Hence, Chrysler's cash flow has been strained and the company has accelerated cost-cutting moves intended to conserve its cash at a time of slow vehicle sales.
Under terms of the tentative agreement, the executives said, about 40 percent of the $1.7 billion would be restricted for use by Chrysler's finance subsidiary, which makes auto loans and does other types of lending. The rest of the amount, about $1 billion, could be drawn by the corporate parent to pay operating expenses or to develop new models.
Telephone requests seeking comment from the lenders working with Chrysler were not returned. Chrysler aknowledged that it had talked with bankers, but said it had not reached a definitive agreement.
It was not immediately clear when the loan agreement would expire or what terms would apply to the loan.
Covenants are conditions of a loan agreement that require the borrower to maintain a certain level of financial health, as measured by various ratios of its capital and profit compared with its debts and obligations. In the event that the borrower fails to meet the terms of the covenants, the lender can usually cut off credit or declare that the loans must be paid immediately.
Chrysler has not earned strong profits for more than two years, eroding its financial cushion and the amount it can spend to develop new vehicles. But the auto maker's executives have been saying that they will introduce a new Jeep model and a new midsize car next year that they expect will help profits. Moreover, they think the entire vehicle market will recover strongly.
Chrysler directors are scheduled to vote on Thursday in New York on the future of the company's 30-cent quarterly dividend, which most automotive analysts predict will be cut or omitted. Dropping the dividend would save $60 million a quarter.
Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, had once said that Chrysler would continue to pay its dividend "short of a nuclear war." But he backed off from that position recently as the company's financial condition continued to deteriorate.
Chrysler's bankers last year agreed to extend up to $2.6 billion in unsecured credit to the No. 3 American auto maker. The terms of the accord obligated the banks to lend Chrysler the money unless it underwent an important change in financial condition.
 
Change in Condition
 Under the agreement, the reduction in the company's debt ratings by itself changed the company's financial condition. And banks have generally become more wary of unsecured loans in recent months because of the weakness of the economy and concern about the financial condition of the nation's banks.
But when Chrysler reported its fourth-quarter profit of $31 million on Feb. 7, Robert S. Miller, the company's vice chairman, said, "I do not anticipate some big fistfight" with the bankers over an extension of credit.
Still, Chrysler is expected to write off $257 million in the current quarter, which will directly reduce the company's profit, because it has adopted a more conservative method of accounting for customer rebates and low-interest financing.

HEADLINE: Computers Gain New Respect as Translators

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER years of limited progress and effort, there is now a renaissance of interest in using computers to translate languages. Scientists believe that with the help of more powerful computers, advances in artificial intelligence and new approaches to translation, the long-sought goal of machine translation may be at hand.
Researchers once believed machine translation would be a relatively simple task of having computers match words in dictionaries and apply a few rules of grammar. But different concepts among languages, varying uses of parts of speech, idioms, nuance, contextual meanings, sentence structure and other factors proved daunting. 
 For example, the sentence "The hunters shot at the ducks and I saw several fall" is immediately comprehensible to all speakers of English, but can pose a vexing conundrum for a computer trying to determine whether it was the hunters or the ducks that fell.
Likewise, the declarative statement "I can fish" could easily be translated, "I work in a cannery."
The initial brute-force approach of using powerful computers containing large dictionaries, syntax rules and powerful mathematical methods to solve problems, or algorithms, did not fade away entirely. Several commercial companies, including Systran Translation Systems Inc. of La Jolla, Calif., continued to refine such systems and now claim 85 percent or better accuracy in translating specialized documents into several languages.
"Systran proved that machine translation could be done and that there was a market for rudimentary translation," said Dr. Yorick Wilks, head of the Computing Research Laboratory at New Mexico State University. "The translations are rough, but useful. However, they require human translators to do pre-editing and post-editing to deal with ambiguities and to create a first-rate finished product."
One promising alternative to the brute force approach lies in the analysis of meaning. Methods are being developed that infer meaning by the context in which a word is used, said Dr. Jaime G. Carbonell, director of the Center for Machine Translation at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh.
Using artificial intelligence techniques that simulate human thinking, it should be possible to organize semantic information in a hierarchical fashion so that the computer can pick the most likely meaning from a list of abstract possibilities, he said. In translating "I took the cake from the table and ate it," for example, a computer could tell that "ate" referred to cake and not table by knowing that something you eat has to be edible.
"By using semantic information, you can infuse the system with a degree of common sense it didn't have before when you used only syntax and word order," Dr. Carbonell said.
Another approach receiving considerable attention is the use of "unified grammars" or "interlinguas" that contain common grammar concepts and universal meanings. Using this approach, all languages are considered modules or spokes of a wheel that address a hub, which contains a common, central set of meanings -- kind of an Esperanto for machine translation -- before being translated into one another.
The interlingual approach should simplify translation by having a central, intermediate "language" in which all terms or concepts have only one meaning for any sense in which they are used in the tongue being translated. The intent is to avoid the passion of poets but the pitfall of translators: ambiguity.
For instance, the English word "bank" can mean, among other things, a financial institution, the land bordering a river or creek, a mound or heap of something, or, as an aviation verb, the turn of an airplane. In an interlingua, each would have a separate representation or code.
The Tradux Corporation of Pompano Beach, Fla., has begun marketing an interlingual system, called Ultra, that was developed by the Wilks group at New Mexico State. Robert P. Irwin, the company president, said the program's English, Spanish, German, Japanese and Chinese language modules have dictionaries designed for simple business correspondence. Each contains only 10,000 meanings because the interlingual approach allows for greater simplicity while producing highly accurate translations with only minimal editing.
 
The Simpler, the Better
 "If you want to add a language, all you have to do is develop a module and not a whole new program with a different set of rules for that language relating to each of the others," Mr. Irwin said.
Interlingual programs now require mainframe or work-station computer power. But Toltran Ltd. of Barrington, Ill., has developed a new translation system for personal computers. It analyzes the base meanings of words without prefixes or suffixes, and the structure of words to tell their parts of speech, tense and semantic traits, such as their relationships to other words in phrases.
"The simpler the system, the better," said Bruce G. Tolin, the author of the program, who contends that his method exploits commonalities in words from different languages that others have not noticed.
Computer translation work almost came to a halt in the United States after an influential 1966 study by the National Academy of Sciences recommended that research in the area be curtailed. The report said there was little hope that computer approaches of that day would produce systems that could match the cost and quality of human translators.
After more than 20 years of almost no Federal support for computer translation, at least by civilian agencies, Government money is beginning to filter back into the field. Financing from the National Science Foundation has risen to about $400,000 annually to support three small university machine translation projects. And the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is expected to announce a new $1 million a year cooperative program involving New Mexico State, Carnegie-Mellon and the University of Southern California to develop the interlingual approach further.
Dr. Carbonell of Carnegie-Mellon said that the technology for computer language translation was ready and that it was more economically necessary than it was 25 years ago.
 
European Requirements
 "The research really didn't end," Dr. Carbonell said. "It kind of went underground. There absolutely has been progress, although this is not a guarantee we will be successful."
Dr. Carbonell and others in the language translation area said the current American push was being inspired by the pressure of world trade and an increasing interest in language and international affairs.
The European Economic Community has required that by 1992, those doing business with its member countries must translate product instructions and certain correspondence into its 10 official languages. Increased trade with Japan, Korea and other nations in the Far East is fueling interest in translations.
The effort to use computers to translate language now spans a range of size and sophistication from giant mainframe machines to hand-held devices the size of calculators or credit cards. The small devices, such as those made by Microlytics Inc. and Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc., use advanced data compression technology to put thousands of words and hundreds of phases in several languages at the fingertips. They have more translating power than mainframe computers did 25 years ago.
Alan W. Portela of Systran said it costs about $45 per page for a human translator to translate from one language to another manually, compared with about $20 per page for current machine translation that is later checked by a human. Unedited machine translation directly from one language to another, with less than perfect accuracy, has also proved to be enough for some users.
Thomas F. Seal, president of Alpnet Inc., a Salt Lake City company that uses a computer-aided translation system to assist human translators, said it would probably be 25 years before anyone developed machine translations that approach what humans can do. He and others said they doubted whether any machine would ever be able to handle translations of diplomatic correspondence, classic literature or legal documents.
"Humans in the loop with computers means you can allow for subtlety, nuance and ambiguity in human language that no computer alone can handle," Mr. Seal said. "After years of research in machine translation, which seems to attract interest every five to seven years or so but then goes away when people get dissatisfied with the progress, there have not been any fundamental breakthroughs. If it ever happens, I think it will have to be something radically different."

GRAPHIC: Diagrams: 'Conventional Approach'
 
Many machine translation approaches resemble an 1880's telephone network with each "user," or language, directly wire to every other user for translation purposes. There are so many combinations, valuable computer space is tied up.
 
'A Possible Solution'
 
A newer approach is analogous to a telephone switchboard, with a self-contained intermediate program language that stores material to be translated into any other language. It minimizes storage needs and does not favor any single language. (Source: Toltran Ltd.)

HEADLINE: Fans Mourn Loss of an Interracial Soap Opera

BYLINE: By C. GERALD FRASER

 BODY:
Washed out by low ratings, television's first interracial soap opera devoted to the adventures and misadventures of black and white families, "Generations," has left behind a group of disappointed viewers, many of them black professionals, still yearning to tune in tomorrow.
After broadcasting 407 episodes, NBC took "Generations" off the air at the end of January. It had lasted for 13 months. 
 Describing the serial in 1989, as it was about to go on, the network said that it was "a contemporary daytime drama set in Chicago" and that it centered "on the relationships of two families -- one white, the Whitmores; one black, the Marshalls -- whose lives have been linked for generations."
Now it is gone for good. An NBC spokesman, Rob Maynor, said, "If it doesn't deliver, it doesn't stay on the air."
The cancellation annoyed a number of the show's regular viewers. One New Jersey working couple taped the 30-minute show daily for evening viewing. They were perturbed "on the day of the final segment to find out that most of it was superseded by a war bulletin, leaving a seemingly inexplicable ending and adding insult to injury."
 
'It Was Different'
 The cancellation also upset Marsha Hunt, a Philadelphia novelist. "It was a very good show," she said in a telephone interview. "It was different. The story line was not who's sleeping with whom. It showed a real relationship between the two women."
Ms. Hunt did not rest on her disappointment. "I don't sit back," she said. "When people say blacks don't write in, I'm not one of them. When they say blacks don't call in, I'm not one of them." She wrote, she called and she organized "The Coalition to Save 'Generations.' "
She said she had 12 people in 12 states "running groups" that had sent "around a thousand" save-"Generations" letters to local stations, NBC, prospective syndicators and PBS, which they view as a potential broadcaster of the serial.
Ms. Hunt voiced several complaints, echoed in the letters. One was that the serial had been broadcast in poor time slots. In New York, it came on at 12:30 P.M., opposite the No. 1 soap, "The Young and the Restless." In some cities, Ms. Hunt said, "Generations" came on at 2:30 A.M. She also said that the soap had not been given enough time on the air to develop an audience.
 
Were Ratings Accurate?
 She questioned whether the show's low Nielsen ratings accurately reflected the number of viewers. "There are few Nielsen boxes in homes in minority communities," she said. A Nielsen Media Research vice president, Jack Loftus, said yesterday that 11 percent of households in the Nielsen population sample are black.
Mr. Maynor, the NBC spokesman, said the network had dropped "Generations" "because it didn't get the size of audience we wanted."
"We wanted more than we had," he continued. "It was the lowest-rated soap opera on the air. It had the smallest audience, it didn't deliver for advertisers and it wasn't attractive to affiliates."
Consequently, he said, the network does not intend to revive the show.
 
Creator of the Show
 Sally Sussman, a writer who had received two Emmy award nominations as a member of the writing staff of "The Young and the Restless," created "Generations," serving as both its executive producer and head writer.
In a telephone interview, she said, "I came up with the idea four years ago and sold it to NBC to create the first racially balanced show." She said it had been well received .
"Most shows are given more than two years to find an audience," she said. "The nature of the soap opera business is that it takes two years to find itself and find an audience. The current climate at NBC, in terms of economics, did not lend itself to continuing the show. It was expensive to produce and had a soft advertising market. And they decided to cancel. It was a valid reason from their perspective, but I think it was short-sighted."
In New York, the editor in chief of Soap Opera Weekly, Mimi Torchin, agreed. "It was intelligent and fast moving," she said. "A new show always gets off to a slow start. They're always terrible in the beginning. Until you are in these people's lives, know the background, it's hard to get involved, until you care about them."
The probationary period for most serials is, she agreed, usually two years. For example, she said, NBC dropped "Texas" only after 28 months. She also cited "Loving" and "Santa Barbara" as two long-running soaps that have never achieved high ratings.
Ms. Torchin, speaking of the "Generations" cancellation, said: "Blacks are only 11 percent of the total viewing audience, and there was not enough of a black audience to watch it." She added: "It was known as 'the black soap' in the heartland. There's still a lot of racism and whether it was racism per se, there was resistance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The cast of "Generations" celebrating the soap opera's 400th episode last fall. The show was canceled at the end of January. (NBC)

HEADLINE: World's Film Dealers Converge on Santa Monica

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 4

 BODY:
If you want to buy the Korean movie, video and television rights for Kevin Costner's next picture, "Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves," the American Film Market here is the place to be. But even if you are interested only in acquiring "Chopper Chicks in Zombietown" for exhibition in Suriname, it still makes sense to put in an appearance.
For everyone except Hollywood's seven major studios, in fact, the American Film Market, which opened on Thursday and continues through Friday, is an unparalleled opportunity to buy and sell movies on the international market. This year, some 2,000 independent movie and video producers and distributors from 59 countries, Argentina to Zimbabwe, are scurrying from one hotel room to another in search of deals. 
 "It's a bazaar here," said Mark Damon, head of Vision International, an American company whose offerings include titles such as "Hard Promises" and "Kickboxer II." He was waiting for several Spanish businessmen in a lavish suite overlooking the Pacific Ocean. "Our people speak French, German, Italian and Spanish, and in an eight-day period, we'll have between 300 and 400 meetings and generally close $25 million to $35 million in sales."
Increasingly, the movies bought and sold at the market consist less of action-adventure and horror films than of glossier upmarket fare of the sort the studios have traditionally produced, such as the Academy Award nominated "Misery" or "The Long Walk Home," which are attracting a lot of attention here. Titles such as "Suburban Commando" or "Housesitter: The Night They Saved Siegfried's Brain" this year account for only 10 percent of the films being offered, down from one-third or more in years past.
To attract buyers, the more than 200 companies participating in the market have continuous showings of promotional reels in their temporary offices and full screenings at nearby theaters. Other lures include gigantic posters, colorful brochure handouts, lifesize cardboard cutouts of bikini-clad starlets and free Continental breakfasts.
 
Bigger Than Cannes
 In the corridors, other buyers and distributors are hoping to strike deals to finance future productions together, which helps explain the presence of the occasional banker in a pinstripe suit. Though tight security is supposed to keep out such interlopers, a few would-be screenwriters and producers without credentials are also around, trying to drum up interest in their projects.
First held in 1981, the American Film Market has grown to become the busiest single motion picture industry trade fair in the world, surpassing even the much better known Cannes International Film Festival. Last year the market reported $362 million in sales of films and services, versus $345 million for Cannes, according to statistics compiled by the American Film Marketing Association, which organizes and hosts the event here.
"For us, the A.F.M. is No. 1," Ahmad Golchin of the Pharco Film Company, which has headquarters in the United Arab Emirates, said as he roamed the seventh floor corridor of Loew's Santa Monica Beach Hotel, where the event is being held. "Cannes is pleasure with business thrown in. The A.F.M. is all business."
Mr. Golchin said he had bought more than 40 films at last year's market and hoped to buy as many this year. His partner, Salim Ramia, said that even for those who may not buy even one movie, the event is useful in scouting coming movie trends, keeping an eye on competitors and pressing the flesh with foreign business partners normally accessible only by phone or fax.
 
Difficult Times
 Despite the large amounts of business being done here, though, these are difficult times for independent movie producers and distributors. Exhibitors at the market say they face international challenges ranging from the imposition of quotas and other possible trade restrictions in the European Community to the apparent saturation of the video market in many countries.
In Western Europe, they complain, the major Hollywood studios are buying up theaters or theater chains and making it difficult for movies other than their own to obtain bookings. With the collapse of Communism, the same process is beginning to happen in East European countries like Hungary, which are experiencing a movie boom now that they suddenly have access to 45 years of Western films.
"The majors have more resources to move in on a quicker basis, and in Eastern Europe they are trying to get into an advantageous position," said William Shields, chairman of the American Film Marketing Association. "The bulk of those theaters are controlled by a few companies, and we have to hope that demand creates supply and there will be a lot of building of new theaters."
<> <>
In addition, distributors fear that the 12 members of the European Community, countries, which will become a single economic entity at the end of next year, will follow through on threats to impose quotas on the entry of American movies, which would drive prices down. But the centralization of the movie business is also being felt by movie buyers, who say they are feeling squeezed too.
 In Asia, where two decades of economic growth have created a growing middle class with a hunger for both movies and video, the principal problem continues to be piracy. Distributors complain that countries such as the Philippines and Thailand make few purchases because the illegal duplication of films is so widespread.
"It is a challenging time," Mr. Shields said. "Business until recently was very good and perhaps too easy. It's gotten a bit tougher and more demanding, and that is going to require everyone's business acumen."

HEADLINE: The President's Popularity

 BODY:
It's a stunning figure: As the Persian Gulf war ended, President Bush's popularity, in a USA Today poll, shot up to 91 percent. That prompted a gleeful Representative Newt Gingrich to say, "The number of people who don't like George Bush is almost down to the number of people running for the Democratic nomination."
A popularity figure of anything like 91 percent surely includes a fair number of fair-weather friends. For instance, only four months ago, the same Representative Gingrich ignited anger in the White House for his harsh denunciation of the President's budget deal with Congress. 
 But even so, 91 percent! With support like that, there's room for many fickle friends to depart and still leave the President a commanding favorite in 1992. The election is now just 20 months away and so far, apart from George McGovern, no Democrats have even declared.
Without denying President Bush an ounce of the pride and credit he has earned in the war, caution is in order. Republican glee is as exaggerated as Democratic gloom. The experience of other Presidents demonstrates a cold truth about such surges of popularity: They don't last.
Whenever Americans confront grave international events, they rally round the flag -- and the President. After the American hostage-taking in Iran, President Carter's popularity as measured by the Gallup Poll initially shot up by 6 and then by 13 points. This is what John Mueller of the University of Rochester defines as a "rally event," and it was already evident in Mr. Bush's poll ratings. In early January, The New York Times/CBS News Poll found his approval rating to be 58 percent. A few days later -- after the air war against Iraq began -- it leaped to 86 percent.
The catch is that the popularity arising from such rally events is temporary. Professor Mueller and other scholars find that what creates lasting effects on a President's standing are economic events. And these can be appraised by correlating approval ratings with changes in the unemployment rate.
In April 1981, for instance, the unemployment rate was 7.2 percent and President Reagan's popularity stood at a strong 68 percent, in the wake of an assassination attempt. By the start of 1983, unemployment had leapt to 10.8 percent -- while Mr. Reagan's popularity had plummeted to an alarming 35 percent.
There's fragility evident in Mr. Bush's present standing. Despite all the popular support for his policies in the gulf, little seems to translate into support for his other policies. In recent weeks, approval for his handling of the economy has consistently been 40 points lower than his gulf rating.
Portentously, the unemployment rate has been going up since June, rising almost a full point to 6.1 percent in January, and it's likely to keep climbing. That's sure to mean bad news for Mr. Bush. But to stop at that would be as shortsighted as it is to make too much of the present 91 percent. Between now and the next election, the President's popularity is likely to change -- and change again.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Forgotten Friends

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
This is a letter of regret to certain foreign friends with whom I have lost touch since Iraq began the Persian Gulf war in August.
They are men and women who live in danger because they struggle against oppression, in their own lands, far from the Middle East. 
 I have in mind these friends: Chinese students and workers rotting in Communist jails, citizens of the Baltics trying to redeem the independence stolen from them, Tibetan scholars traveling from nation to nation desperately reminding the world of the existence of a captive, devastated nation, and democratic activists in the Soviet Union fighting Mikhail Gorbachev as he resolutely marches forward into the past.
Perhaps "lost touch" is too self-forgiving a phrase. I knew what they were going through but like most of my colleagues and our Government found mind and work seized by a danger that seemed far more immediate in our own lives, Saddam Hussein.
 I would get letters now and then from the Soviet Union or the Baltics, or from a wandering Tibetan, or an American fighting for the Chinese students saying please do not forget.
 Never any recrimination, because they all understood. After all, what print or TV time could the Dalai Lama or a Baltic president expect when competing with the ugly-mouthed Iraqi Ambassador to Washington, who proclaimed his master's inevitable victory a half-dozen times a day.
 So while the spotlight was on one dictatorship, others were taking advantage of the shadows.
The Chinese Communists handed out long sentences to Chinese who were heroes in the U.S. during the Tiananmen spring. Foreign correspondents in Beijing reported what they could collect about the kangaroo trials, but the world's eyes watered with boredom.
By the time the "trials" were held international sanctions against Beijing had virtually been dropped. High representatives of Communist China were again being toasted in Washington and other capitals. Still, Beijing is sensitive to outside criticism, terribly. Foreign alertness is often the only protection for Beijing's prisoners.
Beijing's objective is to have it three ways -- tighten restrictions, punish Tiananmen "offenders" and persuade the world that all is peace and harmony inside China.
As put by Asia Watch, the American human rights group: "The war in the gulf provides a perfect cover for carrying out this strategy."
 Ever since 1950, Tibetans have been tortured, murdered and deported by the Communist Chinese occupiers to eradicate their national memory. That failed. But Beijing does not yield and in July ordered a "tough new crackdown" on the independence movement.
In all its time of suffering, Tibet never got much attention in the U.S. Washington wants to forget its existence. For the press it is too remote, too enclosed by Chinese barricades. So with the gulf war on, the newest crackdown in Tibet was blacked out. But he is a good and strong man, the Dalai Lama. He and his people will go on fighting, not much thanks to us.
Mikhail Gorbachev cannot hide the Soviet Union as Beijing blanks out Tibet and most of China. If we read the newspapers -- TV has not been adequate on the Soviet Union during the gulf war, I am delighted to report -- we know that the repression in the Baltics continues every day. We know that soldiers and the K.G.B. now can march into every Soviet business, every home searching for "economic crimes."
Foreigners who invest money in the Soviet Union while Mr. Gorbachev reigns are asking to hear an unpleasant sound -- the midnight knock on the door.
We know that Mr. Gorbachev is taking back control of the press, TV and the economy as fast as he can. All of this seems a deliberate decision by Mr. Gorbachev to risk civil war if that is the price of propping up the Soviet system to which he clings.
We know, but we doze and our Government hardly twitches. Washington has pawned its freedom of protest in return for the Kremlin's on-and-off support in the gulf. When Mr. Gorbachev tried to rescue Saddam Hussein by preventing the ground attack, President Bush adroitly tripped him. But Mr. Bush somehow felt obliged to go on saying thank you, thank you to Mr. Gorbachev.
Now the big postwar question will occupy us. Will there be a new Middle East or will it remain a place of war and hate? But now at least we should be able to lift our heads, and remember all friends who share the one overriding value of freedom, from Moscow to Lhasa.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
L.A. Joe Group Headed By New York Retailer

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Meir Panigel, who owns eight clothing stores in New York City, has become the principal shareholder and head of a group that has bought the owner of L.A. Joe, the 70-store closeout chain. The core units of the chain are 55 former Heck's discount stores in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky in what are mostly economically depressed rural areas.
The closeout chain was sold to the Panigel group less than a year after the brothers Joe and Avi Nakash, owners of Jordache Enterprises, the jeans maker, bought the Heck's stores. At that time, the discount chain had failed to turn a profit after emerging from voluntary bankruptcy. But Joe Nakash said in a statement, "Despite a sluggish economy, we were able to expand the chain from 55 to 70 stores, and sales have been surprisingly good." 
 In a recent interview in L.A. Joe's Manhattan offices amid telephone conversations and hurried interchanges with partners, the 45-year-old Mr. Panigel said: "We feel that 70 stores are enough for us to build on and we hope to do so by increasing business in each. We are planning to add more branded goods and jewelry, and in those stores located in the hunting country, we will add guns and ammunition."
The short, dark-haired Mr. Panigel is a native of Israel whose family, he said, has been in that country for more than 10 generations. After acquiring some retail experience there, he came to the United States in 1982 and started a wholesale clothing business in Hoboken, N.J. Afterward, he opened his own retail chain, the American Sneakers and Jeans Company, comprising eight stores in urban locations and shopping centers in the New York area.
The Nakashes, whose Jordache jeans business now accounts for about $600 million in sales, said they had decided to divest themselves of the L.A. Joe chain because it did not meet their criteria of profit return and also made excessive demands on their time. Mr. Panigel, who was part of the original buying group for Heck's, will continue to serve as president of the Retail Acquisition Corporation, the company that owns L.A. Joe. The new transaction provides for a three-year deferral on the Nakashes' loans to the retail chain, where additional financing has also been obtained.
"I want to build up our sales this year to $150 million, from $133 million last year," Mr. Panigel said. "This is a period when closeout merchandise is very much in demand, especially in our operating area, where many people do not make much money. There are lots of merchandise available, too, in the clothing industry because regular retail business has been slow."

HEADLINE: About New York;
Economic Ills: Poor Are Sicker, Clinic Is Poorer

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
A frail woman stopped by the East New York Neighborhood Family Care Center to pick up some medicine. She also needed to talk.
Two of her three children are gone. So the Housing Authority ordered her to move to a smaller apartment in the same project. Moving costs ate up her Social Security check, and she could afford neither food nor rent. There is no running water in her bathroom. The son remaining with her, who is in his 20's and has epilepsy, had just suffered a particularly violent seizure. 
 The woman was fighting to hold it together, and hers isn't an unusual story in this tattered patch of Brooklyn. Her tears were bitter.
Martha Robinson, whose title is patient representative, arranged for a church to help pay the woman's rent and for an organization for the elderly to give her food. Hardly traditional medicine, but it was all in a day's work at the health clinic, born in a storefront in 1975 after community residents staged sit-ins in the Mayor's office to demand it.
"The word no is just not used around here," declared Miss Robinson.
The East New York center, at 2094 Pitkin Avenue, is one of five in the city. It provides services from obstetrics to classes for pregnant teen-agers to geriatrics. The focus is defensive, preventing illness.
Dr. J. Emilio Carillo, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, wants to shift poor people's basic care from hospital emergency rooms to such centers. But the centers are bleeding.
 State and city budget cuts have reduced the staff of the East New York center by 35 over the last two years, to 130, and more cuts are coming. Moreover, the Bush Administration has proposed shifting Federal money now going to centers into a new program to stem infant mortality.
 No one objects to saving babies. But New York City is fighting the proposed cut in community health funds in Washington as the latest blow to the sick and needy. Overall Federal spending for public health has been reduced in each of the last 10 years, a pattern other levels of government have emulated.
The effect of the cuts is debatable. But many Americans -- particularly the poor -- are clearly having more health problems. There is a new epidemic of measles, a steep rise in tuberculosis and a huge increase in sexually transmitted diseases.
Dr. Carillo speaks forcefully of "bad political choices at every level -- choices that are leaving many of our poor communities literally fighting for their lives."
The need for places like the East New York center is underlined by an increase from 35,000 patient visits five years ago to more than 50,000 last year. Antonio Martin, the center's administrator, says the number could grow by another 15,000 in each of the next two years.
Why? "Our patients are a lot sicker," he said.
The major killers of blacks, who make up half the center's patients -- heart disease, hypertension, strokes and cancer -- are rising astronomically. So are diseases disproportionately striking Hispanic people, who account for 45 percent of the patients -- diabetes, kidney illness and stomach cancer.
People entering the center the other day were greeted by a nurse chirping things like, "What's happening, Joe?" A sign announced a potluck dinner. Junior high students were learning to take blood pressure. Miss Robinson was packing literature for a health fair.
In the basement, mammograms are now available. A $100,000 machine was purchased 18 months ago, but wasn't used until Feb. 6. Mr. Martin explains that a major reason for the delay was the difficulty of finding a radiologist willing to work here for modest pay.
One was finally found, part time. So the women of Brooklyn, who account for nearly a third of the state's breast-cancer cases, are lining up. "I've been putting it off since last year, even though my mother has cancer, " Joann Ellis said in the waiting room.
One alternative to community centers is emergency rooms, far more expensive. Another is private clinics that have come to be called Medicaid mills because most of their patients are subsidized by that program. But many poor people aren't eligible for Medicaid.
And neither takes a preventive approach. At Medicaid mills, a hypertension patient will likely be tossed some pills, says Dr. Edward Toseland, the center's medical director. At the East New York clinic, he will be sent to a nutritionist.
But in this kind, gentle, unexpectedly cheerful corner of a merciless world, absolutely nothing is getting easier. "We are seeing a lot of the end stage of disease," said Dr. Pamela Sass, director of family medicine.
"The staff is becoming tired," Dr. Toseland sighed. "They really are."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Dry California Turns to the Pacific

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 5

 BODY:
With California in the grip of a five-year drought, cities and utility companies in this state are building the nation's first large-scale plants to desalt seawater.
In turning to desalting, cities like Santa Barbara and companies like Southern California Edison are using a technology already extensive in the Middle East and other parts of the world to produce fresh water. Until now the high construction costs and operating costs of such plants made little economic sense in the United States. 
 In Southern California, it could cost about four times as much to produce fresh water from seawater in a modern desalting plant as it would to obtain water from natural sources.
But the demand for water from a growing population, the effects of the drought on the cost and availability of normal supplies and technical improvements in the desalting process have caused planners in some areas to increasingly consider desalting.
"As other sources of water become more expensive or less available, desalination becomes more attractive," said Gary Snyder, the chief engineer for the Metropolitan Water District. The agency supplies water for the Los Angeles area and is involved in several pilot programs and studies on desalting water from the Pacific Ocean.
The process is already well under way in coastal communities that suffer from particularly acute water problems. Later this spring Southern California Edison, a unit of the SCE Corporation, will start the first permanent seawater desalting plant intended to serve a residential community in this country.
The plant is on Catalina Island, off the coast near Long Beach. The drought and new construction on Catalina have combined to leave the island with an urgent need for new sources of water.
The $2 million to $3 million plant, financed by a developer who needed the water to complete a luxury condominium project, will produce 132,000 gallons of fresh water a day, more than a quarter of the island's total needs.
Santa Barbara, on the central coast of California, is completing plans to build a desalting plant to help ease a critical drought in that area. Other coastal areas, including Marin County, north of San Francisco, are studying the construction of desalting plants.
Not everyone agrees it is time to turn to desalting. Some experts here say California, even after a long drought, is a long way from the chronic water shortages that would justify the hundreds of millions of dollars needed to build strings of desalting plants. Large-scale desalting in California would also inevitably face opposition on environmental grounds, since it would require building huge industrial plants along the coast of a state that has increasingly limited coastal development.
Environmentalists say that conservation is a far more efficient way of dealing with the water shortage, and that it would be a mistake to invest in desalting just to allow the state's extraordinary growth rate to continue.
Still, the California drought has also prompted the Federal Government to consider financing research into advances in desalting. Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, proposed legislation last month that would provide $10 million for research next year, with that increasing to $50 million two years later. Senator Simon said he had already won support from the Bush Administration, which asked for $10 million for the program in its proposed budget for next year.
"Desalination and water shortages have begun to attract more attention," Mr. Simon said. "Soon, the people of Illinois and other states will be paying more for groceries because of California's drought. The irony is California has hundreds of miles of coast and huge potential sources of water just offshore."
The California drought and the increased public awareness of desalting resulting from news coverage of desalting plants in the Persian Gulf during the war with Iraq have created a potential business boom for the desalting industry.
The worldwide industry is dominated by large companies like Bechtel and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan, both of which are major builders of plants in the Middle East. In the United States, smaller companies like Ionics Inc., which have an expertise in the synthetic membranes used to filter salt from water in one type of desalting process, are also seeing increased demand. Ionics is a water treatment company based in Watertown, Mass.
 
'Tremendous Interest'
 Executives at several companies said they had never had so many inquiries from communities interested in exploring desalting.
"There is tremendous interest," said Leon Awerbuch, the manager of desalting and power programs for the Bechtel Corporation, the San Francisco-based engineering and construction company.
Desalting has been in use for more than 30 years. According to the International Desalination Association, 7,500 desalting plants are operating in 120 countries with a total production capacity of nearly 3.5 billion gallons a day. Desalting plants are relatively common in a few regions of the United States, including Florida, but they are used almost exclusively to purify brackish ground water in coastal areas rather than to treat seawater. Brackish ground water generally has about 10 percent of the salt content in seawater.
Two basic technologies are now used to remove the salt. The most common is distillation, which involves boiling salt water in a series of chambers, with the resulting steam condensing into fresh water. Distillation accounts for 61 percent of the world's total desalting capacity. The world's largest plant, the 270-million-gallon-a-day Jubail operation in Saudi Arabia, uses the distillation technology, as do most other major plants in the Middle East.
 
The Filter Method
 The other commonly used process and the one increasingly popular for smaller projects, like those in many Caribbean nations and most of those under way or planned in California, is called reverse osmosis. Reverse osmosis involves injecting water under high pressure through a fine membrane that filters out both suspended and dissolved solids, leaving nothing but pure water.
Reverse osmosis takes less energy than distillation because the water needs no boiling. The drawback is that reverse osmosis plants generally have less capacity because of the limits of the membranes to hold up under the pressurized flow of water.
Utility executives and other experts say a modern desalting plant could produce fresh water from seawater for $1,000 an acre foot. An acre foot is 326,000 gallons, or enough to supply two households for a year. The cost of water from natural sources in Southern California is about $250 an acre foot in normal times. That has risen in some areas because of the drought. On Catalina, for example, the cost from natural sources is about the same as for desalting.
 
Costs Compared
 Advocates of desalting say the price of natural water in California, which has long been subsidized by government spending for the state's huge system of dams, reservoirs and aqueducts, will inevitably rise as demand outpaces supply. And they say that the cost of desalting will fall as the technology continues to improve.
"I'm of the belief that we can no longer rely on Mother Nature to provide water for California," said Richard Polanco, a Democrat in the California State Assembly who has proposed legislation to finance more desalting plants. "The water bureaucrats are touting conservation and cutbacks, which are essential, but what California really needs is to manufacture its own supply of water, which we can do with desalination."
Santa Barbara has hired Ionics, the water treatment company. The city is studying a $36 million plant that could produce nearly 9 million gallons a day within a year, although plans for a smaller plant are also under consideration. The larger plant could supply more than half of Santa Barbara's needs. But half of the desalted water would probably be sold to surrounding water districts.
Last month a consortium from Bechtel and five California utilities said they hoped to build a desalting plant with a capacity of 100 million gallons a day in conjunction with an electric power plant on the Pacific Coast near Tijuana, Mexico.
Most experts think the largest plants will continue to use the distillation technology. Some industry executives have high hopes for a variation of the distillation process, known as multiple effect distillation, that can operate at lower temperatures and therefore reduce energy costs.
They also say there is greatly increased interest in building distillation plants in conjunction with electric power generation plants, using the leftover heat from the power generation to drive the desalting process. There is also work under way into new technologies. The Puraq Company of Stamford, Conn., is working with a process to separate fresh water from salt water with a chemical solvent.
"There is continued advancement in the technologies," said Mr. Awerbuch of Bechtel. "Right now we're not reducing costs by anything like 10 or 20 percent a year, but there's continued improvement in distillation and in reverse osmosis, both in capital cost reduction and in the energy component."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reverse osmosis units at Southern California Edison's Catalina Island seawater desalting plant. It is the first plant of its kind intended to serve a residential community in the United States. (Joan Kerr) (pg. D7)
 
Diagrams: 'Desalting Water on Catalina Island'
 
Reverse osmosis, a popular technology for small- and medium-sized desalting plants, will be used on Santa Catalina Island off California. It is the first seawater-desalting plant for an American residential community.
 
1. Salt water is filtered to remove big particles.
 
2. A pump pushes the salt water inot a reverse osmosis unit.
 
3. Cylinders with membranes remove impurities and salt from the water.
 
4. The water is treated with chlorine, lime and carbon dioxide. (pg. D1);
 
'Desalting Water With Flash Distillation'
 
Multistage flash distillation is the most common process for desalting seawater, accounting for more than half of the output from water-desalting plants worldwide. Many plants in the Middle East use this process.
 
1. Cold seawater enters a feed tube that passes through a series of chambers to a heater.
 
2. Heated water enters a chamber where it boils. The steam, which is salt-free, hits the outside of the pipe carrying cold seawater and condenses.
 
3. The seawater that did not boil is pumped into another chamber, with lower pressure. Becuase the boiling point drops as pressure decreases, no more heat has to be added. Steam once again condenses and the process is repeated in additional chambers.
 
4. Fresh water enters usable supplies and a salty concentrate is discharged. (pg. D7)
