HEADLINE: Factory Orders Down In January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Factory orders for manufactured goods dropped by 1.7 percent in January, their third straight decline, the Government said today, but analysts saw signs of some improvement by summer.
"We should start seeing some rebound late in the second quarter," said Evelina Tainer, an economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. 
 But the Commerce Department report showed that America's manufacturing sector remained mired in the recession, with orders for durable and nondurable goods dropping to a seasonally adjusted rate of $230.6 billion in January.
 
December Drop Is Revised
 Even the level of orders in December, originally reported to have been unchanged from November, was worse than first thought. The department revised it down to a decline of five-tenths of a percent.
A 5.8 percent decline in November was the largest one-month plunge on record after orders peaked in October at $250.1 billion.
Since factory orders are a gauge of manufacturing industry plans for production, a decrease often forecasts a slump and future layoffs.
In fact, the Labor Department reported earlier that factory payrolls fell by 69,000 in January, bringing manufacturing job losses since January 1989 to 900,000.
 
Analysts Are Optimistic
 But some analysts believe the worst of the recession may have passed. Ms. Tainer noted that non-military orders for capital goods, excluding aircraft, rose by 3.1 percent in January, to $30.7 billion, after a 1.5 percent gain in December.
"It goes along with our view of a recovery," she said of the gauge.
But in January, durable and non-durable orders fell.
The revised decline in orders for durable goods, items ranging from cars to computers that are expected to last more than three years, was twice as steep as first reported last week.
Durable goods orders actually were down by 1.8 percent, to $117.8 billion, rather than by seven-tenths of a percent as originally reported.
 
Transportation Orders Down
 Transportation equipment orders fell by 3.9 percent, to $30.6 billion, after a 13.2 percent gain a month earlier. A large drop in aircraft orders offset an increase in motor vehicles. Excluding the transportation category, orders fell by 1.4 percent.
Electrical machinery orders fell by 12.1 percent, to $18.6 billion, nearly erasing a 14.5 percent increase in December.
Military orders dropped by 9.7 percent, to $7.2 billion, after a 51.6 percent gain in December during the buildup for the Persian Gulf war. Excluding the category, orders fell by 1.4 percent.
Orders for nondurable goods fell for the fourth straight month, by 1.7 percent, to $112.8 billion. They had fallen by 3.9 percent in December.
Unfilled orders, an indication of how busy factories will be in future months, slipped by two-tenths of a percent, to $519.5 billion. Inventories were unchanged at $374.9 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Higher; Gold Is Down in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against most foreign currencies yesterday as traders nervously watched ethnic unrest in the Baltic republics of the Soviet Union and speculated about the prospects for economic growth in the United States.
Currency traders began buying dollars on reports describing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's trouble maintaining Soviet control in the Baltic region, said Curtis Perkins, a trader for Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. The dollar typically strengthens in times of international turmoil. 
 A trader at the Marine Midland Bank said the dollar gained because of large commercial demand in Europe and perceptions that the worst of the American recession had passed. The rebuilding of eastern Germany is expected to increase demand for dollars in the coming months.
 
Yen Loses Ground
 Nicholas Sargen of Salomon Brothers said the yen lost ground against the dollar after the release of a survey on Japanese capital spending. The Bank of Japan survey predicted only a 1 percent rise in capital spending for the 1991 fiscal year, a sharp drop from 17 percent in 1990.
"This is one of the clearest indications we have of the slowing in the Japanese economy," Mr. Sargen said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.47 yen to close at 134.88 yen. Later in London, the dollar regained almost all of that and was quoted at 135.30 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York, the dollar fetched 136.30 yen, up 0.81 yen from late Monday.
The British pound declined against the dollar in New York, closing at $1.8913, down from $1.9008 Monday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday levels, included: 1.5440 German marks, up from 1.53265; 1.32545 Swiss francs, down from 1.3355; 5.2590 French francs, up from 5.2185; 1,153.50 Italian lire, up from 1,144.75, and 1.15705 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15515.
In London, gold traded at a bid price of $365.25 an ounce late yesterday, down from $366 late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $364.20, down from $365.60 late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $1.19 to close at $365.33.
At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $364.70 a troy ounce, down $3.20 from Monday's closing of $367.90. New York's Republic National Bank quoted a later bid of $364 an ounce, down $3.40.
Silver traded in London at a bid price of $3.86 an ounce, up from $3.82 on Monday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery closed at $3.841 an ounce, down from Monday's close of $3.856.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
On Dividends, Bad News Grows

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to dividends, the good news is almost always much greater than the bad news. That is a sign of the enduring strength of the American economy and a reason for long-term increases in stock prices.
But this year, the amount of good news is getting to be less and less, and the bad news is growing rapidly. Such crescendos of bad news typically come at the bottoms of bear markets, but this one is coming with stock indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500 at a record level. 
 Last year, the overall dividends on the S.&P. 500 came to $12.10 per unit of the S.& P. 500, then worth $330.22. But by the end of the year the indicated rate -- the amount that would be paid if all companies maintained their current payouts -- was $12.33. In January, with companies announcing increases, the indicated rate rose to $12.40 on Feb. 1.
But with many companies cutting dividends, among them General Motors, the indicated rate had fallen to $12.19 by early this week, Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter, said yesterday. At that dividend level, the S.& P. 500 now yields 3.24 percent. By contrast, at the end of last year, when the indicated dividend level was higher and share prices lower, the indicated yield was 3.73 percent.
Whether that low level of dividends proves a problem is likely to depend on whether the economy recovers soon, as stock buyers seem to expect, and just how long it takes for companies to respond to improved business by raising payouts.
Historically, stock prices have often been in dangerously high territory when the dividend payout fell below 3 percent, as happened in 1987. Using actual dividend payouts, rather than indicated levels, S.& P. calculates that the low payout in that year, as prices peaked in August, was 2.86 percent.
There is still room for further increases in share prices by those measurements, but they would seem to indicate that the biggest part of the rally is behind us. To get to a 3 percent yield, at the current level of dividends, the S.& P. would have to rise 7.9 percent, to 406.33. A 2.86 percent yield would be reached if the index climbed 13.1 percent, to 426.22. Those increases are far smaller than the 27.5 percent gain that has been registered since prices hit bottom on Oct. 11.
Another way of looking at dividend levels is simply to count announcements of dividend changes. By that measure, the last couple of months have reached lows not seen since the 1958 recession, falling below the figures recorded in such severe downturns as 1974-75 and 1981-82.
By S.& P.'s count, 101 companies announced good dividend news for their shareholders last month -- including initial dividends, increases and extra dividends. That was the lowest figure for any February since 1958. Because dividend announcements are seasonal, with many companies announcing them early in the year, comparisons must be made to similar months of previous years.
Even so, there are more companies announcing good news for shareholders than announcing bad news. By S.& P.'s count, 47 companies announced bad news in February, by either cutting or eliminating their payouts.
Among the companies that have announced higher payouts in recent weeks are Coca-Cola, Kellogg, B. F. Goodrich, Pitney Bowes, and Kimberly-Clark. Wall Street's woes are well known, but Morgan Keegan, a regional brokerage firm with headquarters in Memphis, bolstered its payout. And while the number of banks cutting or eliminating payouts continues to grow -- First City Bancorporation of Texas eliminated its payout yesterday -- some other, generally smaller, banks have managed to increase theirs. Among them are Commercial Bancorp of Oregon and First National Bancorp of Georgia.
Still, that run of good news is at the lowest level in years, and an important issue is whether the trend will soon turn around. "By the second half of the year, I think we will see some improvement," said Mr. Kaufman of S.&P. He added that for now "the figures are getting to be lopsided." Mr. Kaufman noted that the ratio of 101 companies raising dividends in February, compared with 23 cutting them, was 4.39 to 1.
That was the lowest figure for any month since July 1982, when it was just 3.6. At that time, stock prices were bottoming and stocks were set to begin a major bull market.
For those who follow dividend announcements seeking clues to future stock market action, the picture is mixed. Typically in the past, when companies were announcing relatively few dividend increases, share prices were low and the dividend yield was relatively high. It was at that time, when both corporate boards and investors were most depressed, that stocks were destined to rise as spirits recovered.
Now, it appears that corporate boards remain worried, a fact reflected by the low level of dividend increases, but share buyers are far more optimistic and prices, as measured by dividend yields, are relatively high.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Live Cattle Prices at High; Oil Up as Rise Continues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Live cattle futures prices hit an all-time high of 81.60 cents a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting strength in cash cattle prices.
Live cattle futures settled 0.48 cent to a cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 81.47 cents a pound, after surging to 81.60 cents earlier in the session. The prices exceeded the previous record intraday high of 81.25 cents and a record settlement of 81.10 cents reached on Dec. 17. 
 Feeder cattle were 0.15 cent to 0.55 cent higher, with the March contract at 90.32 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.12 cent to 1.15 cents higher, with April at 52.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.95 cent to 1.85 cents higher, with March at 64.87 cents a pound.
Cattle futures have risen steadily for more than three weeks, along with prices paid on the cash market by meatpackers to obtain supplies for slaughter.
Oil prices inched up on the New York Mercantile Exchange as fears of dwindling gasoline supplies drove the market higher for a seventh straight session.
Crude oil was 6 cents lower to 18 cents higher, with the contract for April at $20.43 a barrel; home heating oil was 0.54 cent to 0.96 cent higher, with April at 57.09 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1 cent to 1.5 cents higher, with April at 70.90 cents a gallon; natural gas was unchanged to 1.5 cents lower, with April delivery at $1.355 a 1,000 cubic feet.
Analysts have attributed the rally in cattle futures mainly to the lack of an increase in cattle marketing that was expected to occur last month. Retail demand for beef has held steady. The anticipated supply bulge is tied to Government reports showing the United States cattle herd to be the largest since 1974.
Dale Durchholz, livestock analyst with Agrivisor Inc. in Bloomington, Ill., said the livestock markets might be drawing strength from the general relief over the end of the Persian Gulf war and a related perception that the economic recession might be short.
Wheat and soybean futures prices rose strongly for the fourth straight day on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rising worries about dry growing conditions in the Plains states and southern Brazil. Corn futures closed mostly higher.

HEADLINE: New Banking Restrictions Are Proposed

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee proposed legislation today that would require banks to suspend dividend payments and bonuses for senior executives if they failed to satisfy regulatory requirements.
The measure by the Senator, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, is the latest to address the crisis in the banking industry and the dwindling money in the program that insures depositors. 
 The Senator's plan says that if a bank falls below its required level of capital -- the amount of investment in the bank that can be used as a cushion against losses -- it must suspend dividend payments, limit its growth and file a plan to restore its financial condition. If it fails to follow the plan, then it must suspend bonuses to executives. Regulators would also have the authority to restrict a bank's business, limit the interest rates it pays for deposits, dismiss top bank officials and require a new election of directors.
The proposal is a marked contrast to the Bush Administration's sweeping recommendation to strike down laws, going back to the Depression, that restrict interstate banking and generally prohibit investment banks and commercial banks from merging. The most likely elements of Senator Riegle's plan to be adopted are those that give the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation the authority to impose bank premiums on institutions based upon their financial health and that limit Federal insurance coverage for joint accounts.
At a hearing today of the Banking Committee, Mr. Riegle said he had not ruled out considering the Administration's plan, but strongly suggested that its only real hope of passage would be in pieces. That approach would mean those parts of the plan dealing with the most pressing problems would be considered first.
Mr. Riegle and Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said today that the most urgent issue facing Congress was how to bolster the dwindling resources of the $8.4 billion F.D.I.C. Some estimates say the fund, which insures individual accounts up to $100,000, could be insolvent by the end of the year, given the rising number of large bank failures.
Mr. Reischauer said the deposit insurance system and taxpayers "could be severely strained" if Congress acted to expand the power of banks before it addressed bank insurance.
In contrast, the Treasury Department has remained silent on specific approaches to working out the troubles of the insurance fund, leaving it almost entirely in the hands of the F.D.I.C. The chairman of the F.D.I.C., L. William Seidman, last week proposed a $25 billion increase in the agency's authority to borrow money.

HEADLINE: A New Car for Malaysia, New Influence for Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
In the early 1980's, the Prime Minister of Malaysia set a goal that most developing nations would never attempt: to build a national car that would put Malaysians on the move and spur the industrialization of a country known mostly for its rubber plantations and tin mines.
No one in Malaysia had ever built a car before, and the project nearly died. Then, three years ago, the Malaysian managers were dismissed and the country called in a team of Japanese led by a no-nonsense production engineer from Mitsubishi. 
 Today, Japan's mark is hard to miss. At rush hour each morning, swarms of identical models of Southeast Asia's first native car, the four-door compact Proton Saga, jam Kuala Lumpur's streets. On the long road up to the Cameron Highlands it is not uncommon to see Protons, with their signature Malaysian flag on the hood ornament, being inspected by tribesmen who walk along the road with the long blowguns they still use for hunting.
The Proton is a symbol not just of the speed with which countries like Malaysia are trying to replicate the industrial booms of South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore, but also of how Japan has gradually tranformed itself into the single most important element in the region's economy. The strategy reaches well beyond Malaysia and is part of Tokyo's industrial plan for turning much of Southeast Asia into Japan's manufacturing backyard.
Indeed, Japan's economic embrace of this region has gone virtually unchallenged. While American oil companies are active here and many American high-tech companies run assembly operations in Singapore and on Malaysia's west coast, most American companies that left the region during the Vietnam War never returned.
Japanese executives hope the lure of Eastern Europe will distract their American and European competitors. After five years of intense investments, Japan's economic reach through the area is nearly all-encompassing, challenged only by a recent investment spurt from other Asian countries, particularly Taiwan.
The Japanese strategy is to play an unobtrusive but commanding role, trying to stay as inconspicuous as possible in a country that it invaded just 50 years ago. The Proton is perhaps the best example of that effort -- and its success.
 
Biggest Industry in Malaysia
 In return for their technology and expertise, Mitsubishi Motors and the leader of its huge industrial group, the Mitsubishi Corporation, own nearly a third of the Proton, which is now Malaysia's biggest industrial enterprise. They have taken hundreds of eager workers who grew up amid Malaysia's lush hill country and tea plantations, shipped them to Japan for six months and sent them back to lecture on the wonders of quality circles and just-in-time manufacturing.
Taking a page from Japan's own post-World War II industrial history, Malaysian officials have set up a series of tax incentives and trade barriers that make buying a $10,000 Proton the most affordable choice for the top slice of Malaysian consumers who buy cars. Mitsubishi's network of auto suppliers, who know a sure bet when they see one, are setting up joint ventures with local companies.
As a result, two of every three cars sold in Malaysia last year were Protons. (The others tend to be small Japanese imports, primarily Toyotas and Nissans, and a few Mercedes.) And in true Japanese fashion, Malaysia barely got the hang of stamping body parts before it started exporting. Already, more than 20,000 Protons -- minus the flag on the hood -- have been sold in Britain, once Malaysia's colonial ruler. The buyers are not attracted to the Proton by luxury -- it is drawn from Mitsubishi designs that date from the mid-1980's, with seats that are a bit cramped and a roof that is a little too low -- but rather by its relatively low price and its Japanese quality.
 
'The Natural Choice'
 "Obviously this is not the kind of industry we could build ourselves," said Rafidah Aziz, Malaysia's Minister of International Trade and Industry. "Turning to the Japanese was really the natural choice."
The Japanese presence is most evident here and in Thailand, Tokyo's main manufacturing outposts. The outskirts of Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur are dotted with factories producing Japanese-brand refrigerators, auto parts, television tubes and computer components.
The factories free Japan's highly paid workers to concentrate on manufacturing much higher-tech, higher-value-added goods, Japanese industrialists say, and they serve a political purpose as well: goods shipped abroad from those foreign factories are not counted in Japan's trade surplus.
 
Heavy Foreign Investment
 Last year alone, Japan received approval from the Malaysian Government for $1.5 billion in manufacturing investments in Malaysia, seven times that of the United States. Taiwan invested even more, $2.3 billion. The results are beginning to show: Malaysia seems likely to overtake Japan soon as the world's No. 1 exporter of room air-conditioners, chiefly because the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company is producing 800,000 cars a year here and plans to increase that level soon.
As Thai and Malaysian labor costs rise, Japanese businesses are scrambling for access to Indochina, especially poverty-stricken countries like Vietnam. Like the United States, the Japanese Government banned aid to Vietnam after its occupation of Cambodia 12 years ago, but Japan never joined the American ban on commercial ties.
 
Expecting 'More Thailands'
 Though they complain that progress in Vietnam is often stop and go, Japanese trading houses are already positioning themselves to swap consumer goods for Vietnamese oil and timber, and they are dangling the lure of factories in front of a Communist Government desperate for hard currency.
"These markets look small, so America decides they are not worth the trouble," a senior executive of one of Japan's biggest trading houses said. "That's how you missed Thailand. And 10 years from now, there will be more Thailands."
In part, Japan has been successful in Southeast Asia because its companies are willing to tread lightly. Unlike many American competitors, the Japanese do not insist on majority ownership. They seem less fazed by occasional political instability, shrugging their shoulders at the bloodless military coup in Thailand a week ago. In most cases they exert careful control by placing Japanese in the top management posts and carefully doling out technology.
 
Difficulty in Proton's Beginning
 The Proton is a prime example. When Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad first approached Mitsubishi, he hoped the project would become an element of his long-range plans for a steady industrial buildup led by the country's Malayan majority. While the Malayans hold the political power in the country, the economic scene has long been dominated by the ethnic Chinese, who account for a third of the population. So at first Mitsubishi held back and let Mr. Mahathir put Malayans in charge of the plant.
No sooner had Mitsubishi moved in the equipment -- giant presses and the assembly line -- than the project began to run aground. Production began in the middle of a recession, and for the first three years the plant turned out less than a third of the 80,000 cars it was intended to build each year. Last year it produced slightly more than 80,000, and in 1993 it hopes to turn out more than 120,000.
Thailand and Indonesia, highly protective of their own fledgling automobile industries, refused to import the Proton. Quality was mediocre, at best. Crucial parts had to be imported from Japan. And the factory itself was a mess. "It had all the right equipment," said one Malaysian supervisor, "and no one in charge who knew how to use it."
Eventually Mr. Mahathir did just what Mitsubishi expected: He turned to them to provide management. "I think that even if we had been here from the start, we would have had big problems," said Kenji Iwabuchi, Proton's managing director, who is on loan from Mitsubishi Motors. "But the car was not yet of Japanese quality."
 
Gathering at 8:30 A.M.
 Mr. Iwabuchi and his team of Japanese managers started what he called the "morning market," a gathering at the plant at 8:30 A.M. to pore over the previous day's problems. Robots were installed to improve the quality of welding. Malaysian employees started to show up for Japanese-language classes. In a few months they will begin machining their own engine parts.
The car has already won some overseas awards, and the Proton has begun to make money. Last year it introduced a peppier model with a bigger engine, and there is talk about taking the company public.
And Mr. Mahathir, better known in Asia for his harsh dealings with political opponents, is creating an image as a car designer and marketer. His sayings are posted on the factory floor. Meetings on how to design the next model -- something a little more fashionable, a little faster, a little more Malayan -- are often held in his office.
"The Prime Minister has some strong views; a few weeks ago, he wanted a new shape for the steering wheel," Mr. Iwabuchi said, in a tone that suggested that the steering wheel was about to change shape.
Whether Mr. Mahathir is meeting his social goals, however, is an open question. While 67 percent of the car is now domestically produced, only a fraction of that work goes to the "bumiputera," the native Malays. The Government is giving grants and other advantages to small bumiputeras -- increasing tension with the Chinese community -- but success is slow.
 
Dependence and Good Will
 And the company seems so dependent on its Japanese managers that many doubt they can be replaced.
"Eventually, this has to be Malaysian-spearheaded," Mrs. Rafidah, the Trade Minister, said. "It will not be run by Mitsubishi forever." The Government will not extend tax breaks indefinitely, she said, and recently it decided to let other makers sell cars that compete with the Proton.
But for now, the Proton has done exactly what Japanese officials hoped for: It made Japanese industry an integral part of one of the world's fastest-growing economies, with minimal risk. It is the first step, some Japanese say, to a de facto trade grouping, in which different Southeast Asian nations specialize in technologies that will feed Japan's biggest industrial giants.
And it is building up a lot of good will for the Japanese, who may need it next winter. That is the 50th anniversary of Japan's invasion and occupation of Malaysia during World War II, an anniversary neither Government is likely to mark too loudly.

HEADLINE: Trump Revises Project Plan For West Side

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Standing at City Hall in the presence of old enemies eager to embrace him, Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had abandoned his plans for a Trump City on the Upper West Side, and would substitute a much smaller, mostly residential project and waterfront park.
With Mayor David N. Dinkins at his side, the developer who epitomized the building boom of New York in the 1980's, said the leaner 1990's had helped persuade him to agree with a coalition of civic groups that fought his plans for a complex that was to have included a 150-story building, the world's tallest, and proposed an alternative. 
 "All you folks convinced me to do really what was right," Mr. Trump said of his plans to give the city land to let it move an elevated stretch of the West Side Highway between 59th and 72d Streets further inland and to build the city a 23-acre park along the Hudson River, all under the working name of Riverside South, though he emphasized no final name had been chosen.
 
'A Boost to Your Pride'
 Asked by a reporter if the compromise was a blow to his ego, Mr. Trump, whose recent financial setbacks made a deal attractive now, blushed and asked Mr. Dinkins whether it should be.
"No, it should not," replied the Mayor, smiling at one of the few bits of good news he has been able to announce amid the city's fiscal doldrums. "It should be a boost to your pride."
It was a scene few among the more than 100 civic, elected and appointed officials, and reporters in the Blue Room could have imagined months ago, involving a developer whose past dealings with the city have sometimes been so nasty that a former deputy mayor, Alair A. Townsend, once said she would not believe him "if his tongue were notarized."
But yesterday, Linda Davidoff, executive director of the Parks Council, one of the groups that led the fight against Mr. Trump's original plan for the more than 70-acre site of the abandoned Penn Central rail yards, kissed him and said that when the new project was done, "Donald, I hope you're going to say to yourself, 'This is the best deal I ever made.' "
Under the compromise, Mr. Trump would withdraw his old proposal for a zoning change that would let him build a project of 14.5 million square feet -- which would have produced towers from 60 to 70 stories and has been stalled for year. His new plan calls for a project of 8.3 million square feet -- which, if approved, would mean a variety of buildings in the 30- to 40-story range, about 5,500 residential units. Overall, if the new plan were approved, Mr. Trump could build more than t one million square feet more than he could without any zoning change at all.
 
No Big Parking Garage
 Mr. Trump would give up plans for a 7,400-car commercial parking garage and a large shopping mall and instead proposed only parking for residents and visitors and street-level neighborhood shops. At the southern end of the site, he would build television and motion-picture studios and about 300,000 square feet of office space, though he said he had no specific tenants in mind.
Instead of being set off from the rest of the Upper West Side, the development would extend the existing street-grids to the new park.
Because of his own financial troubles, it is highly unlikely that Mr. Trump can obtain bank financing to build on the site himself any time soon. His arrangement with his creditors requires that income from any assets go first toward paying off his creditors.
But breaking the political logjam over the site, and obtaining the higher zoning, would mean that a property that has been only a drain for years would be more valuable for him to sell off parts to other developers, which he has said he plans to do, while reserving some for himself.
 
Plans for Monitoring Project
 Still, the compromise is little more than a broad outline and will require months of study and eventual approval by the City Planning Commission and the City Council. And local elected officials and the civic groups with whom he compromised made it clear that they were not abandoning their intention to monitor plans for the project.
State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, speaking for several other legislators, praised Mr. Trump's new proposal, but when he said, "it has yet to be established that even a density of 8.3 million square feet is required to make the development economically viable," Mr. Trump could not resist interrupting to exclaim, "It is!"
While Mr. Trump tried to assure widespread support for his new plan, not all groups in the neighborhood endorsed it fully. One, the Coalition for a Livable West Side, supported the idea for the park but said the proposed size of the project was still too large.
Asked if he would seek tax abatements from the city to make it easier for him to develop the project, Mr. Trump said, "We'll be asking for nothing different from any other developer in the city of New York."
Moving the West Side Highway is a major element of the plan, but even representatives of the civic groups conceded it might not happen for a decade. The existing stretch of road is in such bad shape that the state is moving to rehabilitate it, mostly with Federal money, but supports tearing it down eventually.
Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that there was no guarantee that more Federal money would be available for a new road some day, but he said the city was confident it could make a good case.
Despite the air of bonhomie, Mr. Trump's former foes made it clear that they thought they won more than he did. Catharine Cary, executive director of Westpride, another part of the coalition that opposed the plan, ticked off a list of changes and said, "There will be no world's tallest building."
Mr. Trump interrupted to say, "Here." Ms. Cary rejoined, "Watch out, L.A."
Looking around the crowded room, Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, whose district includes the site, said, "My last word is that if Donald Trump had known it was going to be this big a thing, he would have done it years ago."
Mr. Trump said, "I went with the punches, but they were good punches."

HEADLINE: Dow Closes At 2,972.52, Up by 58.41

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Investors climbed on the Wall Street bandwagon yesterday, driving stock prices sharply higher and lifting trading volume to its highest level in almost a month. Several market indexes established new highs.
The Dow Jones industrial average -- now only 27 points short of its July record -- soared 58.41 pints, or 2 percent, to 2,972.52. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index and the New York Stock Exchange composite index each advanced to new highs, a clear demonstration that investors were coming in across the board. 
 Analysts could not point to any one factor to explain the wave of market euphoria but pointed to a steadily building series of individual events that together meant the economy was gradually improving.
 
'A Lot of Small Things'
 "It's a combination of a lot of small things." said Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist for County NatWest Securities. "One huge plus," he said, was that the dollar rallied yesterday against both the Japanese yen and the German mark.
"This tells foreign investors that maybe the U.S. is not such a bad place to invest," Mr. Canelo added.
Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said, "The fundamentals don't look particularly inspiring, but I learned a long time ago you don't argue with the stock market."
In an even stronger sign of broad stock buying, the Wilshire 5,000 index, representative of just about every stock, reached a record 3,582.30, up 68.48, or almost 2 percent. The buying frenzy broke the former record of 3,523.47, established just a week before the market collapse in October 1989.
Trading volume, the strongest since Feb. 12, soared to 253.7 million shares, from 199.8 million on Monday. Only 3 stocks dropped to new lows, while 183 stocks rose to new highs, including Litton Industries, which rose 2 1/2, to 86 1/4, after a reaching a new high of 86 1/2. Program trading, typically 10 percent of the day's activity, accounted for almost 24 points of the Dow's gain, Birinyi Associates said.
Except for a small selloff in the final 30 minutes, the Dow moved sharply higher throughout the session. Short-sellers, who sell borrowed stock and hope to profit from price declines, moved in several times during the day but were repeatedly forced to buy back their stock to avoid losses.
 
Big Board Steps In
 Buying was so heavy that the Dow was ahead 50 points by 2:39 P.M., at which point the New York Stock Exchange intervened and imposed its 50-point rule.
When the Dow moves ahead 50 points or more, the Big Board bars program traders from buying any stock, in the S.& P. 500 for example, at a price higher than the previous price, in effect halting most activity for the rest of the day. The procedure is also used when prices are falling to prevent program trading from exaggerating price movements.
Four stocks -- I.B.M., Philip Morris, Procter & Gamble and Westinghouse -- accounted for more than a fourth of the gain in the Dow blue chips.
I.B.M., the leader, jumped 2 7/8, to 133 1/2, with almost 2.5 million shares changing hands. Philip Morris, a highly recommended growth stock, climbed 2 1/4, to 67 5/8, with 3.6 million shares changing hands. Procter & Gamble, which has its eyes on Revlon Inc., rose 1 5/8, to 84 3/4, while Westinghouse, project leader for an international group planning to upgrade the Soviet air-traffic control network, advanced 1 5/8, to 29 5/8. Trading in Westinghouse stock jumped to 3.1 million shares.
"It's very hard to point to any fundamental development," Mr. Johnson said of yesterday's strong advance. "The market's been saying for some time that the recession is going to end and recovery will start at the end of the second or start of the third quarter."
But, he said, "The reason it's doing as well as it's doing is the behavior of the market itself. A lot of investors -- institutional and individual -- still have meaningful cash positions and are feeling uncomfortable with them. There's a growing sense of urgency to get it into the market. The return on cash is looking more dismal with every passing day, and the market is looking better with every passing day."
He said that "the stock market is saying that forecasts on the economy and on earnings are way too pessimistic" but added that he found it "hard to make the case for a strong recovery."
Even so, he said, "My experience says I should take the message of the stock market seriously -- and buy."
Ticking off a list of positive economic indicators, Mr. Canelo of County NatWest noted optimistic signals in the index of leading indicators, the purchasing managers index, the purchasing managers order index, commodity prices, the Barron's confidence index and the dollar.
Asked when the Dow might break the record, which is just short of 3,000, he replied without being more specific, "in short order." He said that oil stocks in the Dow were "dragging it down" and from that standpoint "it's already there."
Nevertheless, he added, "We have a good chance of going into the 3,100 to 3,200 area before valuations look too high. It won't be immediately," he went on, "maybe later this year."
Looking at all the new highs, he said: "The leadership here is still in the small stocks. This is a broad, strong market move. It's telling us the turn in the economy will be sooner rather than later."

HEADLINE: From the Cities to the Coal Mines, Pain of Cutbacks Is Vivid;
Virginia Beach: Will It Choose The 'T' Word?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.

 BODY:
Unlike almost anyone else in Virginia, officials here in the state's largest city are openly talking about raising taxes.
"The Governor's position is that he is cutting the fat from government, and that this is what the taxpayers want," said Mayor Meyera E. Oberndorf, a political independent. "We're going to have to ask the citizens just how much tax increase they are willing to commit to." 
 The recession caught the city in the midst of an enormous growth spurt that has required large expenditures. Schools, fire stations, jails and roads are under construction to accommodate a 50 percent growth in population in a decade, to 393,000 in 1990.
Social services are particularly vulnerable. "We're looking at real pain here, not potential pain," said Hector A. Rivera, an assistant manager in the human services agency.
"Infants are dying because we can't provide enough prenatal and postnatal care to indigent women, and mentally ill people may have to wait 60 days before seeing a therapist."
Tax increases are not taboo here, in part because property taxes are lower than in neighboring communities and living expenses are relatively low.
The city's per capita income, $16,844 in 1988, is higher than that in most of the state, though slightly below a statewide average skewed by wealthier areas of northern Virginia.
This year, the city coped with a $15.4 million shortage in its $453 million budget, including a $5.2 million reduction in state aid, by imposing a hiring freeze, delaying road maintenance, buying fewer library books and making scores of other nips and tucks.
Officials anticipate reductions in expenditures of more than $19 million in the next fiscal year and they say there are no more easy ways to save money, which is why they are talking about the possibility of raising taxes.
The schools, which depend on the state for 41 percent of their $294 million budget, are considering returning 48 administrators to the classroom, charging for driver education courses and adult education programs and raising the price of school lunches.
But still, many officials favor Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's fiscal policies. "I support the Governor," said Dr. S. John Davis, the acting Superintendent of Schools, who is a former State Superintendent. "He's showing the country that it is possible to maintain government with a satisfactory level of services with declining revenues."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Chronic Poverty, Black and White

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IS the "underclass" problem really just a black and Hispanic problem? It is a conclusion easily drawn, says Ronald Mincy, an economist at the Urban Institute, and not only by racists. Almost all the big-city neighborhoods plagued by chronic poverty and social decline are black or Hispanic ghettos. And it is these neighborhoods that have been the focus of study, not to mention handwringing, by policy analysts.
But according to Mr. Mincy's new analysis, now circulating in unpublished form, the specter of the underclass also haunts smaller cities. And there, a substantial minority are white. 
 The new findings should help drive home the reality that not every unwed teen-ager with a baby and every high school dropout with a gun has a dark skin. Perhaps as important, Mr. Mincy suggests, it should push researchers toward economic explanations of the underclass phenomenon.
Poor people are simply people who do not have enough money, wherever they happen to live. The underclass consists of the fraction of poor people -- perhaps two million of them -- whose ability to dig their way out is thwarted by life in neighborhoods overwhelmed by violence, drugs and collective despair.
Explanations for the emergence of this spatially concentrated underclass in the last few decades rest, uneasily, on a foundation of economic and social change. William Julius Wilson, a pioneer in the field, argues that declining job opportunities for unskilled workers in cities put great stress on urban blacks. Meanwhile, the end of legal discrimination in work and housing allowed striving blacks with middle-class values to follow the jobs to suburbia. That stripped the old ghettos of positive role models for the young, not to mention the stabilizing influences of churches, P.T.A.'s and fraternal organizations.
Nicholas LehmanLemann, a social theorist and writer, has pressed another, yet more unsettling explanation. The urban culture of the underclass, he argues, is a self-destructive echo of a rural black culture weakened by harsh discrimination and dependence on whites. This explanation is quite different because it turns on the consequences of in-migration rather than out-migration. But Mr. Wilson and Mr. LehmanLemann share the implicit assumption that the underclass problem is a black problem. And 1980 census data from America's 100 largest cities seem to bear them out.
Some 68 percent of residents of "extreme poverty" neighborhoods -- neighborhoods in which at least two-fifths of the population live below the poverty line -- are black. An additional 21 percent are Hispanic, while just 10 percent are white. The figures seem even gloomier in light of the fact that poor blacks are far more likely to live in the worst neighborhoods of the megalopolis than poor whites. All told, one poor black in six lives in an "extreme poverty" neighborhood in a big city, compared with just one poor white in a 100.
The fallacy here, argues Mr. Mincy, is that big cities are not a good statistical surrogate for the nation as a whole. He tailors his data base, combining all of the Census's "extreme poverty" neighborhoods with all neighborhoods ranking high, by four criteria of social decline: single females with children, households on welfare, adult males not in the work force and high teen-age dropout rates. And here the racial profile looks quite different.
Whites represent 28 percent of the population of underclass neighborhoods in cities of less than one million, and roughly 20 percent of the underclass population in all metropolitan areas. What is more, they are not simply the remnants of white ethnic groups living in black or Hispanic neighborhoods; most live in neighborhoods predominantly white.
The goods news here is that racism alone cannot explain the existence of America's underclass. Plainly, racism never prevented whites with a healthy work ethic from fleeing failing neighborhoods. Nor did values forged by discrimination turn whites into criminals, drug addicts or welfare mothers. The bad news is that researchers still do not have a clear sense of why a few million poor people have seemingly been lost to the common culture, or how they might be pulled back into it.
The focus on the big-city underclass, Mr. Mincy believes, has unfairly fed the view that chronic poverty is a minority problem and that non-race-specific policies cannot do much to solve it. But the more realistic profile of the underclass does not, in itself, suggest a politically acceptable palliative. The country that could mobilize to smash the Iraqi Army in 100 hours is rendered helpless by the specter of 15-year-olds with infants and drug habits.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Made Vehicle Sales Off 4.7% in Late February

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 5

 BODY:
Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 4.7 percent in late February, compared with a year earlier, auto makers reported today. Analysts said sales remained fairly weak, but not at the dismally low levels of January.
For the month, the drop in sales of domestic and imported vehicles was 13.6 percent. February vehicle sales were the lowest in seven years. 
 The 10 manufacturers with United States plants sold 183,017 domestically made cars in late February, down 5.9 percent from a year earlier. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.9 million in late February, well below the 6.9 million pace of the period last year. For the last 30 days, the annual selling rate was 6 million.
Light-truck sales dropped 2.1 percent, to 102,081 vehicles, in the 10-day period, which included 7 selling days, the same as last year.
Some auto executives and dealers said the end of the war had brought more customers to their showrooms.
 
Caution Lingers
 "People are still cautious, but they're more willing to get out and spend some pent-up money," said John Ward, sales manager at Galeana Chrysler-Plymouth in Fort Myers, Fla.
Consumer confidence in the economy showed a modest improvement in the first half of February, according to surveys conducted by the Conference Board in New York.
"We anticipate a more enthusiastic March reading," said Fabian Linden, who directs the survey.
For all of February, auto makers sold 625,424 imported and domestic cars, down 13.3 percent from last year. Light-truck sales dropped 14.1 percent for the month, to 286,912.
Honda's car sales fell 37.1 percent in late February. For the month, Honda's sales were down 21.3 percent.
General Motors' sales of American-built cars fell 16.9 percent in late February, to 76,034 cars. Sales of G.M.'s light trucks dropped 10.8 percent, to 38,035 vehicles.
The Ford Motor company sold 50,815 domestically produced cars in late February, an increase of 9.8 percent. Ford's light-truck sales dropped 6 percent, to 33,041 vehicles.
 
Chrysler Truck Sales Down
 Chrysler's total light-truck sales for the month fell 2.2 percent compared with a year earlier, to 57,726 vehicles, despite an increase in mini-van sales, which rose 47 percent in February compared with a year earlier.
Chrysler was able to gain market share in light trucks, to 20.1 percent in February, compared with 17.7 percent a year earlier. An aggressive rebate program helped to raise sales of mini-vans in particular.
Sales of Chrysler's United States-made cars dropped 11.6 percent in February, to 54,370 cars. The company's share of the car market rose, however, to 8.7 percent, from 8.5 percent last year.
General Motors' share of the car market fell to 34.9 percent in February, from 36.4 percent last year. Ford's car market share rose to 22.1 percent, from 21.6 percent a year earlier. The American car market shares of Honda, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company all declined.

GRAPHIC: Graph: 'U.S. Vehicle Sales' shows seasonally adjusted annual selling rates for American-made cars from 9/89 to 1/91

HEADLINE: Rally Benefits Some Retailers

 BODY:
Amid the general market surge, the stocks of eight retailing companies reached 52- week highs yesterday, reflecting a perception among investors that the recession could end in the current quarter.
The new highs included Albertson Stores, up $2.50, to $42; Dillard Department Stores, $1.125, to $106; Food Lion, 25 cents, to $16.375; Gap, 62.5 cents, to $47; Home Depot, $2.125, to $51.75; K Mart, $1.25, to $38.625, and Limited, $1.50, to $25.75.
"We think the recession will end in the second quarter," said Daniel D. Barry, Kidder, Peabody's retail analyst in New York. "After being hammered last fall, retail stocks outperformed the market, and now the new highs are telling us that the end of the war will definitely lead to a pickup."
Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Capital Funding, said retailing stocks are historically among the first to respond to economic change.

HEADLINE: Panicky Need for Farm Land Leads Nicaraguan Peasants Into Fatal Clash

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PUEBLO NUEVO, Nicaragua, March 1

 BODY:
As peasants buried four of their number killed in a gun battle last week, they said it was the need for land that had led them into a fatal encounter with armed operators of a Sandinista-run farm cooperative.
With Nicaragua's economy reduced almost to subsistence levels by more than a decade of war and socialism, this rare year of peace has produced a panicky drive for land in the countryside as the May planting season approaches. The fighting last Thursday at Corinto Farm here in the northern province of Jinotega, in these mountains where rebels for so long waged war against the Sandinista Army, is perhaps the sharpest reminder of the nation's land problems. 
 "When you don't have any work you look for a place to plant corn," explained a threadbare man holding a machete at the foot of the rutted road leading steeply up to the hillside cemetery. "That's what we were all doing when they started to shoot at us."
 
'We Had Only Machetes'
 "They may have gotten frightened, but we went with no intention of killing anyone," he continued. "We had only machetes. A poor man has to carry that."
Although the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is obligated by the terms of the disarmament agreement reached last year to give priority to resettling the more than 20,000 former guerrilla fighters -- or contras -- and their families, the episode at Corinto Farm demonstrates that fear of hunger is becoming generalized over rural Nicaragua.
Efforts to satisfy the land need are complicated by a chaotic property rights situation, including more than 10 years of confiscations and nationalizations under the Sandinistas; the return to the country of former property owners, some of them ex-contras, who are now trying to recover their land, and efforts by former members of the Sandinista Army to get land or get into existing cooperatives.
The demand for land extends far beyond the former contras and overshadows the fact that the commission handling the return and resettlement of the ex-rebels, directed by the Organization of American States, has made giant strides in recent months in its program to provide land and simple housing materials to them.
 
Over 7,500 Ex-Contras Settles
 Santiago Murray, an Argentine economist sent by the O.A.S. from Washington to oversee the repatriation program, said over 7,500 ex-contras and their families had been resettled in cooperative arrangements on 124 large farms that were in government hands.
The O.A.S. has a total of 22,400 people on its rolls as ex-contras and, with families, has been feeding almost 95,000 people a month, a program that is to end with the August harvest. Mr. Murray said about a third of the ex-contras are from urban backgrounds and are trying to resettle in towns and cities, and that several thousand others owned their land before the war and are trying to recover it. That leaves about 5,000 for whom the Government and the O.A.S. still hope to find land.
Of the peasants who marched into the farm near here, only a handful were demobilized contras. The others, while probably never combatants, appeared by their comments to have been supporters of Mrs. Chamorro in the elections last year when she defeated former President Daniel Ortega and the Sandinista Front.
"We didn't vote for Dona Violeta to have the same army as before," said one of the mourners. "She has to use a tough hand on the army."
 
Politics and Desires
 Some said they had been working at Corinto until recent months but had been dismissed by the members of the cooperative that the former Sandinista Government had set up on the farm.
As part of the accords that produced a peaceful transition last year, Mrs. Chamorro kept the Sandinista Army and its commander, Gen. Humberto Ortega, but obtained his commitment to reduce the size of the army. In the competition for land, the firepower usually seems to be behind those former soldiers or their collaborators.
There have been a number of other shootings around the country in recent months involving land disputes, and in most cases the victims were either peasants who had voted for Mrs. Chamorro or ex-contras.
Besides those buried here, at least one other person -- the search continued for bodies -- died after some 250 men, women and children walked into the Corinto Farm last Thursday morning with what they said was the intention of trying to negotiate with the cooperative members for bits of land on which to plant.
 
Men With Rifles Waiting
 The peasants said about 20 men with automatic rifles were waiting on the entry road and opened fire. Since the property, like most cooperative farms in this area, also served as a Sandinista army base during the war with the contras, it would not have been unusual for the army to have left large numbers of weapons with trusted civilians or former soldiers.
Lieut. Douglas Ruiz Espinoza, leader of the army patrol that arrived at the farm after the shooting, said his information was that the peasants had arrived with heavy weapons, including mortars. But people who saw the peasants on the road beforehand said they had only machetes.
The fact is that Nicaragua, a land the size of Iowa with fewer than four million people, has more than enough land to satisfy its population, but most of the eastern two-thirds of the country lacks infrastructure.
 
Contras Came From Region
 The result is that most of the pressure for land is in these rich and pleasant coffee mountains of the northwest. In addition, most of those looking for land grew up here and do not want to leave. Likewise, most of the contras came from this region.
Mr. Murray of the O.A.S. said the resettlement program for the ex-contras had originally been planned around so-called "development poles," with the idea of helping populate other parts of the country. But one such pole, in the southeast around the community of El Amendro, was largely abandoned because the settlers thought there were not enough roads and other facilities.
The Government also does not always know who owns what or whether a particular farm is already being worked. This results from a combination of Sandinista giveaway programs and from the property registration system, which is done by hand.
Mr. Murray said that because of conflicting property claims, some farms have ended up being divided three ways: a third of the land for returning former owners, a third for a Sandinista cooperative and a third for ex-contras.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As peasants prepared graves at a rural cemetery in Pueblo Nuevo, in northern Nicaragua, relatives and friends, rear, raised their hands to show Government officials their willingness to testify about how the victims died in a land battle with armed supporters of the former Sandinista Government. (Raoul Shade for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
A New Mideast Balance

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
Secretary of State James Baker says he is going to the Middle East to listen and consult, and not to present an American peace plan or impose solutions. But that is what all our Secretaries of State say en route to selling U.S. peace plans.
 Indeed, in his next breath, he admits he has a two-track approach for direct talks between Israel and Arab states and for dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians. The theory here seems eminently sensible, and he and President Bush are understandably eager to use victory over Iraq to shape a peaceful future for the Mideast. 
 But their speed of action hints at something troubling: Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker also may be overeager to please their partners in war and are therefore embarking on a vast and delicate diplomatic enterprise before digesting how the war has altered the strategic landscape in the Mideast and how those changes affect American interests.
 Though the fighting ended a mere week ago, two features of the new landscape are already clear: With Iraq cut down to size, no new Arab state stands on the horizon powerful enough to threaten its neighbors and U.S. concerns. With Soviet power sharply reduced, Washington has less cause to worry about Arabs running off to Moscow.
 These features, in turn, suggest that the Bush Administration should think hard about exactly what the U.S. would gain from pressuring Israel to trade land for a potentially risky peace.
 To begin with, the war has leveled the Arab playing field. For the first time since the early 1960's, no single Arab or Muslim figure now looms over the region. There is no Nasser, no Anwar Sadat, no Ayatollah Khomeini, and Saddam Hussein is only a shell of his former self.
 For some time to come, Washington does not have to run around gathering up Arab allies to thwart a brother Arab from acquiring too much power, power that could be used to control oil and threaten the survival of Israel. Egypt has the manpower but lacks the money. Saudi Arabia has the money but not the manpower. Syria has no money and a middling military force. Iraq is diminished. Islamic fundamentalism emanating from Iran presents a genuine threat to stability, but it cannot be combated by alliances.
 The war also clearly revealed that the Soviet Union has become a less central player. Since the end of World War II, the overriding objective of U.S. policy in the Mideast has been to limit Moscow's influence over Mideast oil and geography.
 American support for Israel often got in the way of this larger goal. Arabs would turn to or threaten to turn to Moscow for arms and side with Moscow's policies to punish Washington for backing the Jewish state.
 The U.S. swallowed these costs because its commitment to Israel sprang from deep moral and political roots, and because Israel represented a strong military friend in an unfriendly region. But for the most part, Israel seemed more a strategic liability than a strategic asset.
 Now, with the Soviet Union weakened internally and its arms discredited in combat, the U.S. can help Israel without fearing that the Arabs will reach out reflexively to Moscow.
 These happy strategic facts -- no dominant and unfriendly Arab state and declining Soviet influence -- should not become grounds for complacency. There is still considerable potential in the region for upheaval within Arab states.
 But would U.S. pressure on Israel to empower Palestinians significantly affect those internal struggles? It might. But it is more likely that the fates of friendly Arab leaders will pivot on whether they provide their people economic hope and political dignity.
 Oil remains a worrisome matter. But the Western response, in any event, should be to reduce dependence on Persian Gulf oil. This area will still be volatile even with Arab-Israeli agreements.
 It may well be that Arabs and Israelis need peace in the Mideast far more than the U.S. The debilitating mutual hatred and cost of arms prevents both from seriously addressing their internal problems. Israel, in particular, will have to find funds from its limited resources for settling Soviet immigrants who represent the nation's future. Israelis and Arabs also ought to worry a lot about the growth of nuclear and missile arsenals in a climate of hate.
 For peace, these common interests have to sink in, and the Bush Administration can help that process along. But the U.S. is blessed now with a strong strategic position and does not have to rush off to twist arms and make new commitments.

HEADLINE: Can't City Hall Stop Inflation of Bureaucracy?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I live and work in downtown Brooklyn. I have watched with wonderment the new building under construction on the block bounded by Livingston, Schermerhorn, Boerum and Smith streets, which is to be occupied by the New York City Transit Authority (at a very substantial rent, no doubt).
As I understand it, the Transit Authority will continue to occupy its present building as well. In other words, the swollen bureaucracy has grown so as to necessitate an entire new office building. No wonder fares are going up again! 
 While I'm on the subject, the Board of Education, also in downtown Brooklyn, occupies not only 110 Livingston Street (a large building) and 65 Court Street (an even larger building), but it has also spilled over into yet a third building, at 347 Baltic Street (a former school building). There are numerous offices at other sites throughout the city, as well.
If New York City is serious about doing something to rectify its fiscal problems, it must begin by cleaning its own house. it is inconceivable that the support staff that occupies all this space could possibly be required to operate these agencies effectively.
Let's put our limited resources into the delivery of services, that is, better schools and safer, more efficient subways, not into pushing paper. If not, let us frankly admit that city agencies have become, to a large extent, little more than arms of the welfare system.
 
NANCY H. FINK
Brooklyn, Feb. 22, 1991

HEADLINE: Howard Slims Down and Reaffirms Its Tradition

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Less than a year after he was appointed president of the nation's most important black center of higher education, Franklyn G. Jenifer has steered through a set of sweeping changes intended to alter the shape and strengthen the tradition of Howard University.
The changes, which were recommended by Dr. Jenifer and approved by Howard's board of trustees on Saturday, include closing one of the university's largest schools, the School of Human Ecology, which teaches home economics and nutrition, and eliminating several programs, including undergraduate programs in social work, education, geology, pharmacy and astrophysics. 
 Such pruning is intended to cut costs and allow Howard to focus its resources on fields where it is strongest and the need is greatest. The move is a recognition, Dr. Jenifer said, that even this large historically black university with 12,000 students cannot be all things to all African-American people.
But while it cuts back some programs, Howard is adding others, including centers for international affairs, urban affairs, entrepreneurial studies and Islamic studies.
 
Raising Its Sights
 Dr. Jenifer said the university will try to improve its overall academic standing by toughening admissions criteria without simply raising minimum scores for the Scholastic Aptitude Test, and by imposing a more rigid review process for faculty appointments.
"The basic thing I was trying to do is say Howard has made a choice for enhanced quality over quantity," Dr. Jenifer said in a telephone interview from his university office in Washington yesterday.
Howard's campus has been ringing with debate since a sweeping reassessment began last spring, after Dr. Jenifer took office in April. Some of the strongest criticism has come from the 1,200 full-time faculty members. Dr. Jenifer has said that no tenured professors will be let go, but some part-time instructors, particularly in the schools of education and human ecology, may be.
Even so, the University Senate supports Dr. Jenifer. "The president's report is an excellent solution and first step toward repositioning Howard University for the 21st century," the chairman of the senate Dr. Taft Broome, said in a statement yesterday. Many of the recommendations were first made in a report last fall by a study commission set up by Dr. Jenifer.
 
Decisive and Frank
 Dr. Jenifer's quick actions in reshaping the 124-year old university were prompted by a worsening financial situation and a growing sense that Howard had become too complacent. The efforts are considered exceptional in the degree to which Dr. Jenifer involved administrators, faculty and students, and in the frankness with which the university's shortcomings were discussed.
Most of the changes approved will be put into effect beginning next September, but it could be four years before they are completed. That gives students now enrolled in programs that are now targets of elimination a chance to complete their degrees.
The largest disruption will take place at the School of Human Ecology, with its 600 students, 69 percent of them women. Admissions standards there are among the lowest at the university, and faculty research projects were criticized by a university commission as not being "nationally significant."
The founding dean of the school, Cecile H. Edwards, who is now a professor there, called its closing "unconscionable."
 
After Intense Study
 Yesterday Dr. Jenifer said it had been "a very tough decision," but he said some programs would be shifted to other colleges. For example, he said, the program in interior design would be placed in the school of architecture.
Many of the changes approved by the trustees on Saturday were first proposed by a commission of 34 faculty members and community leaders, which studied all 18 of the university's schools and colleges and released a report last November.
After the report came out, some members of the university community expressed fears that Howard was abandoning its historic commitment to black people in order to become more like other large research universities.
The commission's chairman said Dr. Jenifer had honored the spirit of the commission's recommendations. "He told us to be bold, and we were," said Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., the commission chairman who also is chairman of the Department of Surgery at the Howard College of Medicine.
 
Medical College and Issue
 The medical college was one area where Dr. Jenifer substantially differed with the commission, which pronounced the college to be "in serious trouble," with a declining enrollment and a faculty it called "out of touch with the latest trends."
The commission at first recommended the university offer early retirement to the entire tenured staff, as a way of rejuvenating the leadership of the medical college. In a later report, the commission softened its criticism.
Dr. Jenifer made no substantial changes in the college, which has trained 22 percent of the nation's black doctors and 30 percent of its black dentists. "I did not agree with the commission analysis totally," Dr. Jenifer said. "The performance of the college may not be up to what we would like to see, but put in context, it's not bad."
 
S.A.T. Is Discussed
 Dr. Jenifer also declined to adopt the commission's recommendation that the minimum combined score on the S.A.T. for freshmen be raised to 1,000 by 1994. It is now about 800.
Dr. Jenifer said such a rigid standard would hurt minority students from poor urban school districts where such tests are not emphasized. Instead, he asked for the development of a Howard University Index, which would consider a student's high school grade-point average, class ranking and S.A.T. score for admissions decisions.
He also imposed a requirement that the average score on the index be raised every year for each school or college. That could eventually mean the average S.A.T. score in the Howard Index would be 1,000 anyway, Dr. Jenifer said. However students who did poorly on the test but had a good grade-point average or high class ranking still could be admitted.

HEADLINE: A Real Estate Fortune Dissolves

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Daniel Mauck Galbreath had a reputation as a conservative real estate developer. But even his cautious stewardship could not save his business or the family fortune.
As head of the eighth-largest real estate development company in the country, he guides a family-run business that has erected skyscrapers for Borden Inc., the Mobil Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company. And Forbes magazine put his wealth at about $340 million only a year ago. 
 But nearly empty office buildings, meager rents and $800 million in debts, much of which he cannot repay, have virtually wiped out his fortune.
 
Not Like Most Developers
 The Galbreath family, unlike most real estate developers in the 1980's, rarely constructed a building without first signing up a significant number of tenants. They would painstakingly line up a major corporation as an anchor tenant before breaking ground, take a fee for putting the project together and reduce their long-term risk by taking limited owership stakes in the buildings.
But the swift and severe drop in market values for commercial office buildings and the denial of bank credit to developers have doomed several Galbreath projects and taken nearly all of the family's wealth with them. Monument Tower, in Indianapolis, for example, was started in 1987 with a $181 million loan, but today the 48-story building, the tallest in the state, is valued at only about 60 percent of the original loan. With more than half of the space unleased and the loan in default, Citicorp the principal lender, is on the verge of seizing the property.
Because Mr. Galbreath personally guaranteed some of the loans, he is struggling to avoid bankruptcy for himself as well as his company, the Galbreath Company of Columbus, Ohio.
Even if he manages to stave off bankruptcy, and hold onto a piece of his empire, his estranged wife is seeking half of his fortune in a divorce battle that has raged for three years. If that were not enough, the grandchildren of his late stepmother are accusing him in Federal court of defrauding her estate of millions of dollars and valuable thoroughbred horses. He won the first round in court, but the case is on appeal.
"These are difficult times for my business and myself," the 62-year-old Mr. Galbreath said with a sigh recently.
The disintegration of the Galbreath family fortune illustrates both the severity of this real estate recession and how developers who were once lauded for their conservative financings and careful gambles are being swamped along with the highfliers.
"We didn't do anything different in the 1980's than we did in the 1970's or 1960's," Mr. Galbreath said. But when property values sank, and banks refused to refinance his loans, Mr. Galbreath and his company were ruinously squeezed.
The estimated worth of the Galbreath real estate empire, which began in the Great Depression when Mr. Galbreath's late father, John W. Galbreath, turned a profit selling foreclosed houses, is now between $40 million and $50 million, down from more than $250 million in 1989. (He says the $340 million estimate by Forbes was exaggerated.)
The $50 million includes primarily small slices of equity in real estate partnerships that have not soured, several houses, horses and two sprawling horse farms as well as various pieces of art. But against those assets, Mr. Galbreath is personally liable for about $50 million, meaning that his net worth, after liabilities, is now nil.
Gone, too, are some of the trappings of this wealth. The family owned the Pittsburgh Pirates baseball team for 40 years and several noted race horses including Chateaugay and Proud Clarion, which both won the Kentucky Derby. Since this collapse, the family has parted with their private jet, a limousine in New York and put a limit to the free-spending ways at the 4,300-acre horse farm near the family's Columbus, Ohio home and a 650-acre farm near Lexington, Ky. (An annual practice of seeding the entire acreage with bluegrass has been dropped.)
 
Avoiding Bankruptcy
 If Mr. Galbreath is lucky, he will avoid bankruptcy by giving up big buildings like Monument Tower in Indianapolis to his lenders. He may also be able to hold onto his homes, including a home for the horse races in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., the apartment in Manhattan's River House and, at least for a while, the horse farms.
"At this point there is the objective to maintain the pride of the family by allowing them to keep certain things," said one of the participants in the Galbreath bank negotiations who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Several participants in the negotiations have said that the developer will be left with about $3 million in assets, made up mostly of property that he may have to sell.
While he shared some of the risks of building with partners, Mr. Galbreath, through his main development subsidiary, 100 East Broad Corporation, expanded rapidly during the go-go years of the 1980's and personally guaranteed more than $17 million of bank debt on some of his projects.
Besides Monument Tower, another doomed Galbreath project is Esperante, an office tower in West Palm Beach, Fla. It is almost 60 percent leased but Mr. Galbreath and his partners do not have enough cash to maintain debt payments until the rest of the building can be leased, a process that is likely to take years. That project will probably be taken by the banks. The loans on both projects are in default.
 
Casting Blame
 Like some many developers, Mr. Galbreath blames everybody but himself for much of his undoing. Bankers would not lend as freely as they once did; that is why he took the risk of personally backing some of the loans. Monument Tower would have been successful, he said, if Indianapolis had not been overrun with rival developers who threw up buildings and in the process pushed down rents. In West Palm Beach, many of the same factors hurt the Esperante project when another large building was built across the street.
"Indianapolis, for example, is big enough to handle our product; the problem is that some other people came in there and built also," Mr. Galbreath said recently.
The Galbreath company's main undoing came from the rapid deflation of real estate values and the sudden denial of credit to developers by lenders. In the past, the company would have been able to sell or refinance one of its properties to raise cash. But with the tightening of credit to real estate developers, the company has had to rely solely on the cash flow from its half-leased or half-built projects to make interest payments on its loans.
With new buildings very hard to lease at rates that cover construction and design costs, the Galbreath partnerships are stuck with properties that will probably not generate enough cash to cover their debt for several years.
"A year ago you had a lot of liquidity in the real estate markets, and if you were a creditor of Dan Galbreath's you weren't really worried," said a banker close to the negotiations. "That liquidity is gone."
By last summer the Galbreath cash squeeze had grown to crisis proportions. In July, Mr. Galbreath sought outside help by calling in a real estate workout specialist, Robert L. Sind of the Recovery Management Corporation, to to find a way to ease the cash shortage and reorganize the debts. But he may have arrived too late because by September Mr. Galbreath's company had begun to default on bank loans.
As is typical in workout negotiations, the smaller Galbreath creditors are jockeying to be bought out of the problem at the expense of the larger ones like Citicorp and Westinghouse Credit Corporation, which is owed about $30 million.
 
Asserting Leadership
 Citicorp, as the largest creditor, has begun asserting its leadership position within recent weeks and even tried to control all the cash flowing through the Galbreath enterprises, but that was rejected by the other creditors.
Banc One in Columbus and Bank Ohio have filed suits against Mr. Galbreath and his company. Those banks as well as several smaller creditors, including Chemical Bank, Barnett Banks, Huntington National Bank in Columbus, and Fifth Third Bank in Cincinnati can quickly force the developer to seek bankruptcy protection.
If any of the smaller creditors move to seize Galbreath assets, the developer will almost certainly seek bankruptcy protection and that is what the larger creditors are trying to avoid.
Whatever the final outcome of the talks, the people involved say there will not be very much left of the family's former life of luxury. The horse farms might eventually have to be sold, but no one expects a buyer to pay a price that would significantly improve Mr. Galbreath's financial position.
And then there is still the looming liability from the divorce, estate taxes to pay on his late father's estate, and messy accusations in the suit by the grandchildren. His cash outlay so far in the latter dispute is about $8 million.
