HEADLINE: Virginia in Distress: Test for a New Governor -- A Special Report;
Can Austerity Be Wilder's Path to Power?

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM with MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

DATELINE: RICHMOND

 BODY:
L. Douglas Wilder has spent his 14 months as Governor of Virginia watching every politician's nightmare, a plunge in revenue.
Through the 1980's Virginia sizzled. As the economy and population boomed, the state government built new roads and expanded colleges, raised school standards and gave more help to the poor, elderly and mentally ill. Then in 1990, just as the nation's first elected black Governor took office, things fell flat. 
 Yet unlike other recession-stricken governors who are anguishing over the hard choices, Mr. Wilder seems almost to revel in his state's money woes. "I think it's fortunate," said the Governor, a Democrat, about his seemingly rotten timing. "It gives me an opportunity to do things I may never have had a chance to do in terms of streamlining government."
Refusing to discuss raising taxes as he slashes funds for state agencies, schools and local governments, he is unabashedly trying to transform fiscal distress into a political asset, and perhaps even a shot at the White House.
No political Hamlet, the 60-year-old Governor has already used his austerity platform to gain mention as a contender for the 1992 Democratic national ticket. He is often mentioned as an attractive Vice-Presidential candidate and some experts say his ambitions reach still higher.
"Clearly, the adamancy of his stand is linked to his Presidential ambitions," said Larry J. Sabato, a political scientist at the University of Virginia.
In frequent talks around the country Mr. Wilder, a suave and confident figure, portrays himself as the leading edge of a "new mainstream" that rejects the old tax-and-spend mentality, instead pursuing "fiscal responsibility with compassion."
While this is hardly an original slogan, even for a Democrat, Mr. Wilder has been more aggressive than most, both in trumpeting austerity at home and in accusing the Bush Administration and many Democrats of profligacy.
In Virginia, Mr. Wilder's first principle in coping with the budget crisis has been a rigid pledge of no new taxes; he has even held a $200 million reserve fund as a cushion against surprises. He has cut spending substantially but also used a host of time-honored tactics to dull or postpone the pain: accounting gimmicks to create spending money, construction delays; passing of burdens to city and county governments, and putting off the worst hardships until next year.
His gamble is that an economic recovery will soon begin to ease the pressure. In any case, he does not have to worry about re-election as Governor when his term ends in 1993: state law forbids it.
Mr. Wilder's budgetary approach has generally gone over well in Virginia. But some Virginians are beginning to ask whether the state will pay a price for his national ambitions. "It will be a great 20-second sound bite -- he's the guy who did a better job than Mario Cuomo," said State Senator Joseph V. Gartlan Jr., a Democrat who has been one of the Governor's sharpest critics. "This could take him through 1992 and the Democratic Convention, but then we've got to come back and run the state."
 
Governor Sees Stand As Guidepost for Future
 In an interview in the Virginia Statehouse, a building designed by Thomas Jefferson that exudes the dual histories of the nation and the Confederacy, Mr. Wilder often waxed Reaganesque as he insisted that his measures were good for the state. "I'm not interested in just balancing the budget," he said. "We want to eliminate waste and spending wherever we can, so that when times do get better we don't go back to business as usual."
The recession hit Virginia in an era of dramatic growth and change, as its profile, once dominated by tobacco farms and coal mines, became more urban and suburban, requiring big increases in government services. But its social services, especially for the poor, are still relatively low.
Virginians are not heavily taxed by national standards; Virginia ranked 43d among the 50 states in 1989 in state and local taxes as a proportion of personal income. But in a theme he says Republican Presidents have only mouthed as they ran up deficits and taxes, Mr. Wilder argued that higher taxes would hurt an overburdened middle class.
Virginia's budget shortage is serious, though not as deep as those facing several other states, including New York. It amounts to 15 percent of planned expenditures over two years from the $12 billion general fund, which includes most discretionary spending.
The Governor, who served in the State Assembly for 16 years before his election as Lieutenant Governor in 1985, is especially proud of the $200 million "rainy day fund" he set up -- money he has insisted on keeping in reserve on the ground that things may get still worse.
"He understands symbolic politics very well," said Robert D. Holsworth, a political scientist at Virginia Commonwealth University. "He can claim he maintained a reserve fund even in times of stress. I don't think people are interested in the details of the budget."
According to polls by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research, the proportion of Virginians rating his job performance excellent or good has declined slightly, to 44 percent in January from 48 percent last summer, The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Wilder, who is from Richmond, won election in 1989 with barely more than 50 percent of the vote, including 41 percent of the white vote, an exceptional showing for a black candidate. He began his political career as as a strong liberal but became more conservative in the 1980's as his sights shifted to statewide office.
Virginia operates on a two-year budget, which has given Mr. Wilder more time than most beleaguered governors to ease in cuts, concentrating them in the second fiscal year of the cycle, which begins this July. He was also able to find relatively painless ways to offset about a third of the deficit, like transferring lottery profits from construction projects to general spending, and raising the assumptions about future interest earnings from the employee retirement fund, allowing reduced current contributions by the state.
Still, two-thirds of the shortage, which totals more than $2 billion for the two-year cycle, will be met by spending cuts, said Paul W. Timmreck, Secretary of Finance. State agency budgets are being reduced by amounts ranging from 10 percent to 25 percent; salaries have been frozen, programs curbed and at least 660 workers, out of a force of more than 100,000, will be laid off. A college and university system that is the state's pride is in turmoil, with schools forced to delay needed construction, cut student aid, raise tuition and reduce course offerings.
The Governor has taken relatively little from welfare programs, which he calls the "compassion" side of his equation, though payments have been frozen. But state cuts have put an added burden on county and city governments, which also face declining revenue and often depend heavily on the state to finance schools, law enforcement, health programs and other services.
 
Criticism and Sympathy From State Educators
 School and university officials have been among the most vocal critics. "I understand what he is doing politically," said Michael G. Basham, Superintendent of Schools in Scott County, a poor Appalachian region where schools are struggling to improve. "But I don't much care about his national aspirations, I care about the kids in Scott County. Personally, I think Virginia has got to do much more for education, and taxes have got to be raised."
Local officials and educators around the state, in interviews, expressed deep concerns about the prospects for essential services and education. But even many who are directly affected express sympathy for the Governor's aproach.
Frank Horton, chairman of the Board of Supervisors of Russell County, also in the Appalachians, spoke sadly of the reductions under way in "programs we struggled 30 years to build," like music and art classes, guidance counselors and physical education in elementary school. "We're trying to cut back community services to bare bones and give the savings to schools," he said.
Still, "no one envies the Governor's position," said Mr. Horton, a Democrat, adding, "I think in general he's doing what he feels is right."
Here in Richmond, the capital, which faces many typical problems of urban poverty, the fall in state aid and local revenue has forced a freeze on hiring and other economies. The city's Department of Social Services has been unable to fill 40 vacancies in a staff of 520 in a year when economic distress has expanded its clients by 10 percent.
But the elected black political leadership, which controls city government, has generally supported the Governor's policies, although some black church leaders and others say he gives too little attention to the poor.
Sometimes sliding into a folksy drawl, Mr. Wilder makes it all sound easy. "I don't mind being a bad guy at all," he said, dismissing the complaints of public employees, teachers, college administrators and local officials as special pleading.
"There has been no serious curtailment in the delivery of services," he said. "People are saying it's calamity and woe. But how can we find all this to cut in state government and they can't find it in some local government?"
The real test is yet to come, as the steeper cuts of the 1992 fiscal year pull counties and school systems through a much tighter wringer and they have to choose between cuts in services or increases in taxes.
Some of the consequences may only be felt over time, critics say, long after Mr. Wilder has left the scene.
Gerald L. Baliles, the Democrat who preceded Mr. Wilder as Governor, says the state's continued prosperity requires more investments in new highways, port equipment, schools, prisons, mental health programs and other social services.
"If these cuts are sustained over time and made deeper," he said, "it will definitely affect the quality of our education, it will impair the ability of the state to compete in this country and in world markets, it will definitely have an impact on care of the elderly and the mentally ill and on prisons."
 
Unloading the Guns Of Republican Rivals
 For now, Mr. Wilder finds himself in a comfortable political place. Virginia Republicans, unable to attack him as a free-spending liberal, have been undercut on a potent issue, although they say that some of the money produced by Mr. Wilder's shifts in funds and his accounting measures are dangerous departures from fiscal integrity.
"He says he won't raise taxes, which is commendable," said Stephen D. Haner, executive director of the state legislature's Joint Republican Caucus. "But he's using every other despicable thing in the annals of budget chicanery."
Liberal Democrats have been reluctant to push for new taxes, especially since all members of the State Legislature face re-election this year. In February the Democratic-controlled Legislature essentially bought the Governor's budget proposals, although it restored some education funds.
Through his actions and those of his advisers, Mr. Wilder has entered the strange domain of presumed national candidates.
Some political experts have questioned the depth of his experience, an issue that causes Paul Goldman, chairman of the Virginia Democratic Party and a close adviser of the Governor, to bristle. "How come first-term governors in California and New York are considered Presidential timber and not others?" he asked. "We're not chopped liver down here."
Mr. Wilder says he has "no plans" to run for national office. "I think Cuomo says he has no plans to have plans," he said, enjoying the chance to tweak a potential rival but also the potential leader, in some visions, of a Cuomo-Wilder ticket. "But I just have no plans."
"I do intend to be very involved on the issues that affect the American people," Mr. Wilder added. "I'll be pushing fiscal responsibility, yes sir."

HEADLINE: Still Hooked on Oil

BYLINE: By Al Gore; Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, is the chairman of the Senate subcommittee on science, technology and space.

 BODY:
WASHINGTON
 The Bush Administration's new national energy strategy proposes to deal with our energy crisis the way we dealt with Saddam Hussein before he invaded Kuwait: by pretending the problem will go away if we humor it. What we need instead is the resolve and leadership with which President Bush dealt with Saddam Hussein after he invaded Kuwait. 
I voted to authorize force in the Persian Gulf, and I agree with the President that this conflict has been about values far more important than oil, but I do not want to see an increase in our dependence on the oil underneath that chronically unstable region. Yet according to bipartisan analysis, the Bush strategy will result in an overall increase in U.S. oil imports, from approximately 50 percent to 60 percent when the plan is fully implemented by 2030.
 The Administration argues that we will be better off than we would be otherwise, but that ignores alternative policies -- energy efficiency, conservation and renewable sources -- that could dramatically reduce our dependence on imported oil and fossil fuels generally. Mr. Bush proposes instead sacrificing one of our last, most pristine wilderness areas -- the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge -- for an uncertain oilfield that would provide, at best, a few months' supply at our current rate of consumption.
 And while President Bush claims that the answer is the marketplace, and that the unaided forces of supply and demand can solve the problem for us, his plan offers not a single proposal for addressing the enormous hidden costs of burning and wasting such vast quantities of fossil fuels. What about the cost to our national security of increased dependence on Middle Eastern oil? Where is it addressed in the market?
 What about the hidden costs that burning more oil imposes on the environment? Where are they addressed in the market? Global warming may be hard to think about, but it is rapidly being recognized as one of the most serious problems humans face. The White House effort to pretend it does not exist reminds me of the point made by scientist Carl Sagan, when he quotes a song by Dire Straits: "Denial ain't just a river in Egypt."
 Cheap oil and energy conservation are not naturally linked. The new energy marketplace -- itself distorted by the billions we have just correctly invested in restoring stability to the world's largest reserves of oil -- will discourage investment in alternative energy sources and dampen consumer interest in greater energy efficiency.
 The victory of capitalism over Communism in the philosophical war of the last 75 years has been as decisive as the victory by the coalition against the forces of Saddam Hussein. In the aftermath of both victories, we need to focus on what comes next. As for the economic system we advocate for ourselves and all the world, it is time to address forthrightly what economists call the "externalities" -- those hidden costs we would rather forget.
 With oil prices dropping, there is no better time for a bolder energy policy. We should ask the President for political leadership and the kind of courage he showed in the gulf in order to accelerate the development of energy alternatives, confront our addiction to fossil fuels, especially foreign oil, and measure the full costs of the energy choices we make.
 The President's skills, personal experience and most trusted advisers are in the realm of foreign policy. Thus far, he has not shown corresponding strength in meeting the pressing needs of this country closer to home. Perhaps that is why his domestic policy decisions seem to be so vulnerable to short-term political considerations. Whatever the reason, he discarded the recommendations of his own Energy Secretary and adopted a proposal driven above all by the desire to avoid discomfiting the voters for the next 20 months. But what about the next 20 years?
 On energy policy, the President misreads the mood of the nation. In the Persian Gulf, we showed our remarkable ability as a nation to pull together in a crisis. Americans will show the same determination to avoid another Middle East crisis if their leaders address these issues forcefully, honestly and now.

HEADLINE: U.N. Group Condemns Burmese on Rights Record

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 6

 BODY:
The United Nations Human Rights Commission has voted unanimously in secret session in Geneva to condemn the military Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, for rights violations as a result of a confidential report prepared by a United Nations inspector who recently visited the country.
The report said that the nation's military authorities continued to detain political opponents and that the authorities had failed to answer "serious and persistent allegations of torture and mistreatment" of these prisoners.Burmese rulers have also made no preparations for carrying out their promise to return the country to democratic, civilian rule, the report said. 
 The Burmese Government has made no response to the condemnation, which took place Feb. 26.
The 25-page confidential report was written by Sadako Ogata of Japan, who was sent to investigate human rights in Myanmar last November by the Human Rights Commission. Mrs. Ogata was later named United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
As a resut of Mrs. Ogata's findings, the 43-nation Human Rights Commission, which monitors the way governments treat their citizens, voted the condemnation and agreed to send another inspector to check on Myanmar's human rights record next year, diplomats and human rights workers said.
The Commission hears complaints about human rights abuses, with its confidential meetings intended to give members a chance to persuade governments to change policies without losing face. The group's annual six-week meeting in Geneva is to end Friday.
At the same confidential session, the Commission also condemned the governments of the Sudan and Chad for widespread human rights violations and decided to examine their records again next year, officials said.
But the organization agreed to stop monitoring Zaire's human rights record after receiving promises from the Government to treat its citizens better, the officials said.
In her report on Myanmar, Mrs. Ogata said Gen. Saw Maung's Government, which calls itself the State Law and Order Restoration Council, continued to detain "a large number of persons, including prominent leaders of political parties," especially those from the National League for Democracy, which won the elections last year.
In May 1990, candidates of the National League for Democracy won more than 80 percent of the seats in apparently free elections for a National Assembly. The results stunned the military, which has not turned over power to the assembly or allowed it to meet. The vote was the first since the military took power in a coup in 1962.
Mrs. Ogata wrote of restrictions on individual freedom including a night-time curfew, a ban on public meetings and the continued shutdown of all universities, depriving some 120,000 students of education. Criticism of the Government remains banned by law, she said.
Although the military government has made official commitments to drafting a new Constitution and introducing democratic government, Mrs. Ogata said it had no timetable and refuses to open a serious dialogue with the country's political parties.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Weighs Sanctions
 WASHINGTON, March 6 (Reuters) -- The United States is considering imposing economic sanctions against Myanmar, Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon told the House East Asian and Pacific subcommittee today.
"We are currently considering what economic sanctions against Burma might be appropriate and will notify Congress promptly of the outcome of our assessment," Mr. Solomon said.
Congress passed an amendment to the 1990 trade act calling on President Bush to impose economic sanctions if he could not certify that Myanmar had made reforms and improved its performance on narcotics suppression.
"Burma cannot meet these requirements and we have so informed Congress," said Mr. Solomon, who said the United States has ended all forms of economic aid to Myanmar and was urging other countries to do the same.

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
Bank Regulators Losing in Court

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
A SERIES of Federal court decisions has held that regulators were overzealous in seizing some failed banks and savings and loans and that the Government could be liable for hundreds of millions of dollars in damages to investors.
In different cases, judges found that regulators overstepped their authority by reneging on promises to buyers of troubled savings and loans, by pushing healthy banks into insolvency, or by illegally trying to squeeze millions of dollars from owners of failed financial institutions.
Only a score of such lawsuits have been brought against the Government -- a minuscule number compared with the thousands of failed banks and savings and loans seized by regulators each year -- and many rulings are being appealed. But the trend has been against the Government, and some think it points to a disturbing pattern of regulators trying to reduce the cost of Federal bailouts at the expense of the law.
The validity of that interpretation, however, is still a matter of debate.
Rosemary Stewart, a lawyer with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington and former director of enforcement for the Office of Thrift Supervision, thinks the courts have recognized that regulators "are going too far."
"In a vengence mentality after the savings and loan crisis," she said, "the Government is trying to get everything it possibly can."
But Alfred J. T. Byrne, general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation, feels the court decisions "reflect either a misunderstanding or a misapplication of the new law, or both."
"We do not draw any conclusion that there is a tide flowing against the Government agencies," he said.
No one contests the power of regulators to seize assets of insolvent banks and savings and loans in order to protect depositors' money. But several cases turn on interpretations of the savings and loan industry bailout legislation enacted by Congress in August 1989.
Two cases test the retroactive application of that law. They involve the seizure by regulators in March 1989 of several healthy Texas banks after their parent banks, MBank in Dallas and the Texas American Bank in Fort Worth, became insolvent.
Regulators pushed more than a dozen healthy subsidiary banks of the two companies into insolvency by failing to fully repay loans that the subsidiary banks made to the parents. Two courts have said that the subsidiaries are owed full payment under then-prevailing banking laws, but the Government is appealing on the ground that the 1989 bailout law permited only partial repayment.
The F.D.I.C. has since lobbied successfully to have the 1989 bailout law permit unequal payments to creditors of failed banks.
In another group of cases, regulators' attempts to abrogate concessions given to entice investors to buy failing savings and loans have been challenged. Eight of these cases have gone against the Government, four have gone in its favor and, in two others, the court said it had no jurisdiction.
The Government has lost three other cases that involved attempts by regulators to collect money from owners of failed savings and loans by forcing them to put up new capital after institutions were declared insolvent.
The 1989 bailout law is also being questioned in a group of cases involving concessions given by regulators to buyers of troubled savings and loans before the law's enactment. Regulators contend that the new law permits them to disregard these concessions, which are generally forbearances allowing newly acquired savings and loans to operate with lower capital requirements or more liberal lending policies than permitted by law.
One of the best known in this group of cases involves Far West Federal Bank, a Portland, Ore., savings and loan that regulators sold to investors in 1987. In return for investing some $27 million of capital, the Government gave the new investors 10 years to meet capital requirements and approved a liberal lending policy.
But with the 1989 bailout law, regulators told Far West that it was out of compliance with the law and that its owners faced daily fines of up to $1 million. Far West quickly complied, but as a result began losing money; officers and depositors fled and its balance sheet shrank.
Far West's owners now say the Government can take the institution back -- they just want their $27 million returned, along with $100 million in damages. United States District Judge Owen M. Panner agreed, ruling that regulators violated Fifth Amendment guarantees against illegal seizure of property and that their action was "economic suicide" for Far West." Damages have yet to be set.
A final batch of rulings against the Government involves attempts by regulators to collect money by enforcing capital requirements after a savings and loan failed. One leading case involves a Texas company named Tetco, which in 1983 bought a Texas savings and loan in San Antonio called the Bexar Savings Association. To get deposit insurance, Tetco agreed to certain capital levels and to add more when necessary. Over time, Tetco sunk some $25 million into Bexar.
Bexar, however, suffered losses and was declared insolvent and seized by regulators in February 1989, wiping out Tetco's investment. The Government then sued Tetco for $558 million -- the amount needed for Bexar to meet its capital requirements if it were still alive. But United States District Judge Lucius D. Bunton in San Antonio dismissed the Government's claim, as did judges in two similar cases elsewhere.

HEADLINE: Surveys Find Americans Satisfied With Quality of Health Services

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Although many consumers are worried about the cost of medical care, results of two surveys that were announced Monday found Americans are generally satisfied with the quality of health services.
Based on telephone interviews in six countries last fall, one of the poll-takers, Louis Harris & Associates, said Canadians were even more likely than Americans to say they were "very satisfied" with medical services. Canadian and American consumers differed as to which types of services were satisfactory. A separate poll of Americans by the Gallup Organization reported similar results. 
 Canada has a national health care system that is financed by taxpayers, and doctors' incomes are lower, on average, than in the United States.
"Nobody in either country hates the care they are getting," said Robert J. Blendon, chairman of health policy at Harvard University's School of Public Health. "It is the payment system that makes Americans angry."
The Commerce Department estimates that national spending on health care will be $756.3 billion in 1991, $80 billion more than last year.
 
Domestic Effect Feared
 Thomas O. Pyle, chief executive of the Harvard Community Health Plan, a health maintenance organization based in Brookline, Mass., that sponsored the Harris survey, said, "The increase alone would be greater than the estimated cost of Desert Storm." He said rising medical spending "is beginning to cut into our ability as a nation to educate people and deal with other pressing problems."
More than 70 percent of the 1,006 Americans surveyed by Harris said too much is spent on hospitals and doctors, while fewer than 25 percent of the 1,026 Canadians questioned said doctors and hospitals receive too much.
Polls of 1,000 people typically have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Sixty percent of Canadians and 55 percent of Americans said they were "very satisfied" with their health systems. Forty-five percent were very satisfied in West Germany, 39 percent in Britain, 28 percent in Sweden, and 12 percent in Japan.
Health care spending in the United States is the highest in the world, $2,051 per capita, followed by Canada with $1,483. Among the six countries, life expectancy is highest in Japan and Canada, at 79 years, and lowest in the United States, 75.6 years.
Only 32 percent of Canadians were very satisfied with the waiting periods they faced for surgery for conditions that were not life-threatening. Fifty percent of Americans said access to such surgery was very satisfactory. Fifty-eight percent of Americans and 48 percent of Canadians said they were very satisfied with the availability of high-technology tests, procedures and equipment.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Wheat Off After 4-Day Rise; Livestock and Meat Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wheat prices fell slightly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as profit taking ended a four-day advance that lifted the value of a bushel of wheat by as much as 10 percent. Other grain and soybean futures also finished mostly lower.
On other commodity markets, coffee futures surged; energy futures were mostly lower; precious metals rose, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
 Wheat futures settled 1 3/4 cents lower to 1/2 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in March at $2.74 a bushel; corn was 1 3/4 cents lower to 1/4 cent higher, with March at $2.46 1/4 a bushel; oats were 1/4 cent to 1/2 cent lower, with March at $1.20 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 1 1/2 cents to 5 cents lower, with March at $5.93 3/4 a bushel.
The grain markets opened higher, but the rally faltered after soybeans for March delivery failed to rise above $6 a bushel, an important psychological barrier.
Analysts had predicted a downward correction in the wheat market, which began its run-up last Thursday from $2.52 1/4 a bushel for March deliveries. The March wheat contract peaked at $2.77 1/2 in intraday trading yesterday.
The surge represented a revival for wheat prices, which fell to four-and-a-half-year lows early this year in response to slack export demand and a bumper world crop.
 
Coffee at 5-Month Highs
 Coffee futures soared to five-month highs on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange as dwindling supplies sent roasters to the futures market to lock in prices.
Oil prices retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange, snapping a seven-day rise as traders speculated that OPEC's attempts to cut production of crude might not proceed smoothly. But near-term gasoline futures posted their eighth consecutive move higher, reflecting concern over shrinking domestic supplies and refinery capacity as the summer driving season approaches.
Precious metals rallied as spot silver neared 4 cents an ounce on hopes of an economic recovery, and platinum recovered about a third of Tuesday's decline.
Livestock and meat futures were narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in U.S. Trading After Earlier Gains Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other currencies in late profit taking in New York yesterday after posting earlier gains overseas.
Gold advanced in New York, rising $1.20 on the Commodity Exchange to close at $365.90 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $366.25, up $2.25. 
 Analysts said the dollar rose abroad and in early New York trading after the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that the recession was not deepening and that the economy might improve in coming months.
"What that suggests to the financial markets is that the Fed is unlikely to ease any time in the near future and, consequently, short-term interest rates would stop moving down," said Kevin Logan, chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
 
'Risky Day to Have a Position'
 Profit taking set in after the dollar failed to rise above 1.55 German marks in New York, Mr. Logan said.
An important economic indicator, the February unemployment report, is being released tomorrow, and traders did not want to leave themselves open to sharp losses if the data were weaker than expected.
"It's always a risky day to have a position," Mr. Logan said. "The data's so volatile."
The dollar closed at 1.5380 German marks in New York, down from 1.5440 late Tuesday. In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.5405 marks from 1.5325.
The British pound gained against the dollar in New York, rising to $1.8950, from $1.8913 late Tuesday. Earlier in London, sterling fell to $1.8895 from $1.9015.
The dollar also lost ground against the Japanese yen, falling to 135.70 yen in New York, from 136.30 late Tuesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.67 yen to close at 136.55 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Tuesday, included: 1.3390 Swiss francs, down from 1.34545; 5.2360 French francs, down from 5.2590; 1,148.00 Italian lire, down from 1,153.50, and 1.15855 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15695.
Other late dollar rates in Europe included: 1.3450 Swiss francs, up from 1.3385; 5.2470 French francs, up from 5.2210; 1.7368 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7275; 1,151.75 Italian lire, up from 1,144.00, and 1.1598 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1542.
Silver advanced to $3.868 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, from $3.856 late Tuesday. In earlier London trading, silver rose to a late bid price of $3.93, from $3.86 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Awards Grants to Aid Technology

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The Commerce Department announced $9 million in matching grants to companies yesterday that are designed to foster innovative civilian technologies and restore American competitiveness.
The grants are part of a program that some in Congress and industry hope will grow into a larger effort by the Government to help United States technology become more competitive internationally. 
 The 11 grant winners include large companies, like the Bell Laboratories unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, and start-up manufacturers like Hampshire Instruments Inc. of Marlborough, Mass., a maker of an inexpensive X-ray lithography system.
 
Many Activities Supported
 The technologies given grants involve the manufacture of inexpensive flat-panel display screens, advanced X-ray lithography research, a project to provide an economical solution to correcting errors in precision machine tools, and advanced superconductor research.
The Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation of Austin, Tex., was awarded a grant for a radical new form of computer memory based on holographic images in photorefractive crystals.
George A. Uriano, director of the the Advanced Technology Program of the Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology, said the agency was financing projects that fall between basic research and technology development.
"There is still quite a debate going on," he said. "Clearly it's perceived to be a different type of program that would help to redefine the Government role."
The Bush Administration has been opposed to providing help to specific industries like semiconductors or television manufacturers, which have asked for support to develop technologies that could compete with Japanese and European companies.
Some members of Congress have called for the creation of a civilian counterpart to the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, a Pentagon agency that will spend almost $1.4 billion on advanced research.
The debate reached a crucial point last April, after Craig I. Fields, the director of the agency, called Darpa, was removed in a dispute over its role. Dr. Fields had advocated using agency financing to support civilian technology.
 
Matching Funds Required
 The companies that received the Commerce Department awards are required to provide a matching amount of their own monwey. Mr. Uriano said that the program had received 250 proposals and that winners had been judged on scientific, technical and commercial merit.
Congress has allocated an additional $35.9 million for grants this year and President Bush has requested an additional $35.9 million for the fiscal year 1992, Mr. Uriano said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed, Altering Trend

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the week that ended yesterday, the first such week after several weeks of declines.
According to analysts at Donoghue's, the Federal Reserve's effort to counter the recession with interest rate cuts is nearing an end. They see the question now as whether the central bank will have to ease more to get the economy moving. 
 Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said he believed the Fed might have to ease further, but that the major easing moves were over. Money market fund yields, he said, will now probably fall into a drifting pattern with a slight downward tendency, but with no probability of moving higher.
 
Longer Holding Period
 Tax-exempt money funds reported that the average number of days that securities were being held in portfolios in the week was up three days, to 51. Assets declined a modest $277 million, to $91.5 billion. Analysts said a potential existed for tax-exempt assets to decline further as a strong stock market competed for funds.
The average seven-day compounded tax-exempt yield for the week rose by 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.14 percent, while the 30-day compounded average yield fell 12 basis points, to 4.23 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt yield is 5.75 percent for those in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 6.17 percent in the 33 percent bracket.
 
Calvert Has Top Return
 Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Calvert Tax Free Reserves Money Market fund produced the best return on investment, with a yield of 5.20 percent. The fund is managed by the Calvert Group in Washington.
Assets of taxable funds rose by $1.2 billion in the week, to $456.6 billion, a record. The cash inflow was all into consumer funds, where assets rose by $1.8 billion, to $345.9 billion. About $200 million of the cash flow to consumer funds went into Treasury and government-agency funds. Institutional-fund assets declined by $600 million, to $110.7 billion.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 11 basis points, to 6.38 percent, and the 30-day yield fell 13 basis points, to 6.54 percent.
The Strong Money Market fund paid the best return on investment for the week, with a yield of 7.28 percent. The fund is managed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds and are included in The Bank Rate Monitor national index, showed an average rate of return unchanged in the week, at 5.62 percent.

HEADLINE: International Energy Agency Ends Emergency Oil Sales

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 6

 BODY:
The International Energy Agency, a group of 21 industrial nations, decided today to end emergency sales of oil from government strategic reserves, a program instituted to insure sufficient supplies during the Persian Gulf war.
In suspending the program, officials of the Paris-based agency said they were confident that oil supplies would remain in balance with demand for the short term, even if it took a long time for Kuwaiti and Iraqi oilfields to resume production. 
 "The agency at the moment does not see any immediate problem on the supply front," said Geoffrey Chipperfield, a British energy official who is chairman of the agency's governing board.
Under the emergency plan, which took effect on Jan. 17, member governments made available an extra two million barrels of oil a day from their reserves, and took conservation measures to reduce consumption by an additional 400,000 barrels a day.
The plan was the first time in the agency's 17-year history that the governments of the industrial world used an emergency program of drawing from reserves to calm the markets in the case of supply disruptions.
"The plan certainly was a success," Mr. Chipperfield said. "There was no shortage of supplies. The markets were reassured."
 
OPEC Dialogue Sought
 Oil analysts say the agency's plan of releasing stocks -- along with the success of the anti-Iraq coalition in defending Saudi oilfields -- helped drive down oil prices from about $30 a barrel after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 to less than $20 a barrel at present.
Mr. Chipperfield said his agency, which represents industrial oil-importing nations, would soon consider beginning a dialogue with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
OPEC officials have long urged a dialogue, with some members suggesting that industrial nations might help build and finance new refineries, while OPEC members promised to insure a steady supply of oil.
According to the agency's monthly oil market report, which was released today, world oil consumption -- excluding demand in what had been the Soviet bloc -- will be 54.3 million barrels a day, up from 53.7 million in last year's first quarter. The agency said oil supplies would be 53.5 million barrels a day in the first quarter.
This means that oil stocks will be reduced by about 800,000 barrels a day, which agency officials said was not at all worrisome.
Quincy Lumsden, the agency's chief economist, predicted that in the 1990's, world oil consumption would increase by 1.5 percent to 2 percent a year.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Reserve Sales

DALLAS, March 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- In the United States, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve has not accepted bids for oil since it signed contracts in the first week of February to ship 17.3 million barrels of crude to 13 buyers. Deliveries began last month from three of the reserve's six locations along the Gulf Coast and will be completed by the end of March, said a senior official who asked not to be identified.

HEADLINE: Rally Isn't Curing Wall St. Blues

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
After months of gloom, investors returned to buying stocks with a passion in the first months of 1991, sending the Dow Jones industrial average climbing at a giddy rate -- a rise of more than 500 points since mid-January. Investors, who had pulled back from the market as losses spread in 1990, are suddenly making money again.
So why is the joy so restrained on Wall Street? 
 One big reason is that most investment houses are now in so many other lines of business that they no longer look solely to the stock market for their profits. In the last decade, firms have expanded their businesses in mergers and acquisitions, securities underwriting and bond trading. That means that because of their expansion, firms like Merrill Lynch & Company and Shearson Lehman Brothers, which depended mostly on their retail brokerage operations a decade ago, have much less in profits to gain or lose on daily stock trading.
 
Diversification Costs
 Much of the expansion has cost Wall Street firms so dearly that they have yet to recover, even as the stock market has rallied. Meantime, the firms, and their well-heeled parents, have to keep paying the overhead and other expenses to stay in those businesses. That quickly sops up revenue, especially when it comes from primarily one source.
"In order to have reasonable returns and pay people a reasonable amount, you have to have a big year across the board, in every business," said Michael D. Madden, the co-head of investment banking at Lehman Brothers. "That is why people aren't kicking up their heels."
Yesterday, the stock market gave investors even more cause for joy. The Dow briefly spilled over 3,000 twice before easing to 2,973.27, up 0.75. [Page D12.]
Of course, with Big Board trading volume topping 200 million shares several times this year, many firms have made money from increased commissions, a greater value for their own portfolios and trading profits. And while that makes executives at these firms happy, they have also painfully learned in the last four years that what goes up can come crashing down.
"You're only talking about a change in business for a few weeks," said Donald Marron, chairman of the Paine Webber Group, "and you need a period of time before you get an emotional change. All of us have been conditioned in the last few years to brief flurries of improvements followed by declines, so there is a wait-and-see attitude now."
On a pretax basis, Wall Street has earned $250 million to $350 million since the start of the year, or as much as $2 billion at an annualized rate, said Michael Lipper, president of the Lipper Analytical Securities Corporation. But Mr. Lipper said the windfall had not been distributed evenly, with the retail brokerages with low expenses profiting most.
A report sent this month by the Securities Industry Association, a trade group, to the heads of Wall Street securities firms indicated the change from last year. An informal survey by the group found retail business had jumped between 20 percent and 40 percent since the allied air strikes in the Persian Gulf began in mid-January. Profits from trading, a business that thrives on large movements in the market, also appeared to be good.
"With costs squeezed down, many of you should be experiencing a most welcome profit improvement," the report said.
But at the large investment houses, the money being made on Wall Street this year is not nearly enough to pay for all the employees, office space and technology their businesses require.
 
Takeovers and Underwriting
 Take the business of mergers and acquisitions, which fueled Wall Street's boom in the 1980's. In the first two months of this year, only a total of $16.1 billion in takeover deals was announced, according to the Securities Data Corporation. That is down significantly from the $29 billion announced in the first two months of last year, and the $40.1 billion in the first two months of 1989.
Fees to investment banks for underwriting securities have also fallen. According to Securities Data, Wall Street received $313.6 million in fees in the first two months of this year for underwritings, compared with $338 million in the first two months of 1990 and $401.9 million in the first two months of 1989.
That puts the high-cost businesses, like investment banking, under increased pressure to pay their own freight.
"A few weeks of even a really good stock market have not convinced people that the long-term problems they have seen in the business" are all behind them, said George M. Cohen, a partner who focuses on banking and securities at Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton.
 
Tension on the Job
 With Wall Street entering its fourth year of recession -- last year the industry lost as much as $500 million by some estimates -- few people believe the troubled times are over. Fears of losing a job, declining salaries and bonuses, a tougher enviroment for doing business because of increased competition and the almost universal belief that there are too many firms to survive have made Wall Street an increasingly tense place to work.
Wall Street's problem is expense -- many securities firms have simply been spending too much to make strong profits. Even after the dismissals of thousands of employees and pay cuts for others, many executives say that painful times will continue until the industry transforms itself into a smaller business.
"The cost structure of Wall Street has been so dramatically increased over the past decade that even though you may see a minor increase in profitability, it is not enough to recapitalize the industry," said Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker who works with Lazard, Freres & Company. "There still has to be a real re-examination, probably by each firm, about what is its business, and maybe a redefinition of what the business is all about."
 
60,000 Jobs Lost
 Since the stock market crash in 1987, such re-examinations have resulted in the elimination of about 60,000 jobs. Dismissals became virtually a daily ritual on Wall Street last fall and have continued even during the market rally.
"People have been very shaken by what has happened in the past three or four years and realize that there is a lot of work ahead," said Jean-Louis Lelogeais, a management consultant who specializes in capital markets with the consulting firm of Booz Allen & Hamilton.
The retrenchment of Wall Street has continued in recent weeks. Indeed, some of Wall Street's most venerable firms have been shrinking their payrolls. Goldman, Sachs & Company has let at least 20 people go in the last few weeks, according to Wall Street executives and search firms that are now trying to place the former employees.
"Even with the rally, people working at some firms are worried about their jobs, they are worried about their friends' jobs, or they are doing the firing themselves," said Thomas W. Strauss, the president of Salomon Brothers Inc. "It is not a period where happiness is going to return overnight."
Wall Street's overpopulation problem has other consequences. With so many deal makers chasing so few deals, some firms have been slashing their prices, cutting into the profit on transactions, a tactic called narrowing the spreads.
"Since you still have lots of people around competing, the spreads are very, very tight," Mr. Lelogeais of Booz Allen said. "When you plot the continued spread compression against volume of business, even when the volume comes up, the revenue can come down."
For example, Mr. Madden of Shearson said that for a securities firm to gross $100 million from underwriting corporate debt, which used to be fairly common, the amount of debt issued would have to total at least $150 billion. "That's about equal to the entire Federal deficit," he said.
 
Disappointing Bonuses
 For those who have kept their jobs, pay has been a second focus of concern. A large number of Wall Street employees are finding that their 1990 bonuses, many of which were awarded in the last two months and can constitute a huge proportion of annual salary, had shrunk substantially.
One firm with grumbling workers is Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, which analysts said would be giving out the worst bonuses on Wall Street. Employees said the bonuses were as much as 60 percent lower than the previous year. The firm will also give part of its bonuses in securities, which some employees there have derisively tagged as "wampum."
Beyond bonuses, many of the survivors on Wall Street have a deeper concern: Will their firm stay in business? Executives know that the industry suffers from overcapacity -- meaning there are far too many firms for the business there is to do.
 
Threatening to Close
 Late last month, the chairman of the Britain's NatWest Group, Lord Alexander, said that the investment banking subsidiary, County NatWest, "must become profitable in a year or two if we're to remain in that business."
That pronouncement hit especially hard at the firm's American division, where more than 60 employees had been hired as a group after their jobs at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ended with that firm's collapse last year.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: KUWAIT;
Shooting of Kuwaiti Lawyer Has the Opposition Afraid

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, March 6

 BODY:
An assassination attempt last week against a prominent critic of the Kuwaiti Government has created a climate of fear among other dissidents, who asserted today that Government loyalists were using violence and intimidation to smother a postwar movement toward democracy.
The Government critic, Hamid al-Jouan, a 43-year-old lawyer and former member of the Kuwaiti Parliament, was left paralyzed below the waist after a bullet shattered part of his spine in an attack at his Kuwait City home on Thursday. 
 Even as their euphoric countrymen celebrated freedom after a harsh seven-month occupation by Iraq, several Kuwaitis associated with the pro-democracy movement said they now feared for their safety and believed that attacks on other opponents of the Government were likely.
 
Assertions of Intimidation
 The timing of the attack, which came less than than two days after Kuwait was captured by American and allied soldiers, was not accidental, they said.
Associates of Mr. Jouan, including the chairman of one of the nation's largest banks, have made the assertion that members of Kuwait's ruling Sabah family, a very large extended family or clan, might have ordered the attack in an effort to intimidate political opponents in the first days after the allies swept into Kuwait.
The Sabah family, which has controlled Kuwait since th middle of the 18th century and until recently has resisted calls to share Government authority with a freely elected legislature, denied any involvement in the shooting.
The banker, Abdul Aziz al-Sultan, chairman of the Gulf Bank of Kuwait, said in an interview today that he did not believe the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, had anything to do with the attack on Mr. Jouan.
But he said that a group of "hawks" within the Emir's extended family had been involved in the shooting and in threats that had been made against other pro-democacy advocates in Kuwait.
 
Warnings to Critics
 He said he knew of at least two Kuwaiti men who had been visited at their homes or offices during the Iraqi occupation and warned that they faced an unspecified threat if they "attacked the Sabahs or were critical of the Sabahs" once the Iraqis had been ousted.
"I do believe that some factions of the Sabah family are involved" in the shooting and the threats, he said. "It's got to be related to people who are after the pro-democracy movement," he continued. "The young Sabahs are very undemocratic."
Mr. Sultan offered no evidence to support his allegation about a tie between the ruling family and the attack on Mr. Jouan. Other dissidents have said there is evidence implicating members of the Sabah family in the shooting, although they have not produced the information publicly.
Kuwait's Ambassador to the United States and a member of the Sabah family, Saud Nasir al-Sabah, said in an interview on the ABC News program "Nightline" that his family had been disturbed by the shooting and had nothing to do with it.
 
Oppostion Members Hide
 He said he was "extremely disappointed" in the statements made by Mr. Sultan, referring to the banker as a good friend and "a very responsible person."
He continued, "I would caution Mr. Sultan and others not to fall into the trap of people trying to drive a wedge between the Kuwaiti people."
As a result of the shooting of Mr. Jouan, some pro-democracy advocates in Kuwait and overseas have gone into hiding.
An economist and a former member of the Kuwaiti Parliament, Abdullah al-Nibadri, said he had begun sleeping in a different house each night in the last week, to foil any attempt by assassins to track him down.
 
Shot in the Chest
 "We are worried," he said in an interview. "I think somebody is hatching plans."
He said he first heard rumors in November that assassination squads might be formed by Government loyalists to kill Kuwaiti dissidents.
"We heard rumors of schemes of eliminating opposition members," he said. "After Hamid's case, we think the threat is becoming serious."
In an interview today in a hospital intensive-care unit, where he is being protected around the clock by armed guards, Mr. Jouan said he did not know the identity of his assailant or another man who drove the getaway car.
"He was a Kuwaiti, in his early 20's," said Mr. Jouan, who lay in bed in obvious pain as his wife, Khawla, looked on somberly. "He knocked on the door -- the garden door, the back door, and he called me by my nickname."
"I thought he was a very dear friend who had come to celebrate the liberation," he said. "I opened the door and he shot me at very near range, less than two yards."
He said he did not believe the Sabahs were involved in the shooting. The assailant, he said, was probably "from a group against democracy" who were trying to send a threatening message to others who have called for greater political freedom in Kuwait.

Inquiry on Occupation of Kuwait
 UNITED NATIONS, March 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United Nations announced today that it was sending a high-level mission to Kuwait to investigate reports of killings and other atrocities committed by Iraqi forces during the occupation, and to assess damage caused to property.
The mission is to collect information from the Kuwaiti Government as well as from humanitarian and other organizations.

HEADLINE: After 20 Lost Years, Arverne Skeptically Awaits Renewal

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
From the elevated A train rattling through Arverne, Queens, one sees a vast new town stretching along the oceanfront below -- shopping malls bustling with people, thousands of town houses, ribbons of newly carved roads, parks and playgrounds.
One sees this only with the imagination working hard. Otherwise all that is there is a huge, bleak reality -- block after block of barren, littered, weed-filled lots sprawling over two miles, the legacy of two decades of doomed plans. 
 Now this 300-acre wasteland in the Rockaway section, one of America's most notorious examples of redevelopment gone nowhere, is the subject of crucial negotiations to determine its fate: will it become a new seaside settlement, or will its heritage of failure carry into the future?
 
Series of Hurdles
 New York City officials and a group of developers are struggling to hammer out an agreement intended to lead to a 10-year, $1.5 billion program to build a new community for nearly 20,000 people on the site, the largest vacant piece of land available for development in New York City.
The 7,500 apartments would mostly be in three- and four-story town houses and would be priced to sell or rent to families with annual incomes of $45,000 to $80,000. Stores, movie theaters and a refurbished boardwalk and beach are also part of the package.
But to reach an agreement, Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration and the developers, Oceanview Associates of Manhattan, must overcome a series of major hurdles: a recession-ridden economy, the city's dire fiscal problems and a reduction in the project's scale forced by a politically savvy community determined to have a say.
Administration officials acknowledge the difficulties but are confident that an accord will be reached. Many residents and civic leaders on the Rockaway peninsula share the optimism.
But many others remain skeptical, and their reasons go beyond the real estate slump that has caused a number of other development plans in the city to falter.
 
'We're Still Waiting'
 In Arverne, limbo has been the rule for 20 years, in good times as well as bad. Proposals for the site have come and gone like sand castles built on the beach nearby.
"Hotels, casinos, this and that, and we're still waiting," Zetta Gibson, a 33-year-old postal worker who lives on Beach 56th Street, near the renewal site, said on a recent afternoon. She was referring to one of the past visions, for an Atlantic City-like complex, championed in the late 1970's by Donald R. Manes, then the Queens Borough President. It never got the backing it needed from the State Legislature.
But Cornell Byrd, 36, a security guard who lives on Shore Front Parkway, near the site, said he thought the present efforts would lead to something. "There's a lot of money to be made on this," he said.
Glancing toward the renewal tract, where discarded tires, mattresses and other trash were abundantly strewn, he said: "They have a lot of property here and nothing's been done with it. They have to do something with it."
 
Holtzman Raises Questions
 Top city officials also have varying outlooks. "We had 20 years of the old Madison Square Garden site before something came of it," said one optimist, Barbara J. Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, referring to the block between at Eighth and Ninth Avenues at 50th Street that is now home to the Worldwide Plaza complex.
But Ms. Fife acknowledged in an interview that the Arverne project "may not happen in the next couple of years, until market conditions change" and chances of financing improve.
Even less sanguine is City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. Through a spokeswoman, she said she had "not received any information that would change" her opinion of last summer, when she was the only member of the Board of Estimate to vote against the Rockaways proposal.
Ms. Holtzman said at the time that the Dinkins administration and the developers had not presented the kind of detailed financial plan that "gives us some confidence in the structure and strength of the proposal."
In fact, among the knotty issues still unsettled in the current negotiations on the deal's final terms, those involved say, is one raised by Ms. Holtzman last summer: How a fiscally stricken city can come up with more than $100 million to finance its share of the public works costs in the project, including two new schools and a portion of the new roads and sewers.
Another issue is whether the city can keep its commitment to use Oceanview's payment for the city-owned land to finance more than 1,000 homes for lower-income families elsewhere, including 800 in adjoining Edgemere. When the Koch administration announced the project two years ago, it said Oceanview would pay $90 million for the site, but this has since been reduced to under $70 million, Ms. Fife said.
The price reduction -- and a sharp increase in the city's share of the public-works costs -- stems from scaling down the project to 7,500 apartments from the 10,000 originally planned. The cut followed vehement opposition to the larger proposal by many in the Rockaways, who argued that local public services like transportation, health care and firefighting could not handle an influx of 10,000 families.
A spokeswoman for Oceanview, Michele de Milly, also acknowledged that "the financing is not in place" for the apartments and other aspects of the plan that Oceanview would be responsible for. But she predicted that loans would be forthcoming once an agreement was reached with the city, given the developer's track record.
Oceanview is a joint venture of Forest City Development, which has built more than 60,000 units of housing across the country, and the Ratner Group and Park Tower Estates, which have carried out large-scale commercial developments.
Ms. de Milly declined to give the latest projections for the apartment prices, either if sold as condominiums -- as originally planned -- or leased as rentals, as she said some might now be. But Felice Michetti, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, has previously said that the condos, at least, would range from about $135,000 to $177,000.
 
Quick to Raze, Slow to Rise
 Once a thriving summer vacation area where working-class families rented bungalows, Arverne fell on hard times after World War II; the vacationers went elsewhere and the bungalows were converted to year-round housing for the poor. The area quickly decayed and in 1968 nearly 4,000 structures were rapidly razed.
But little of the envisioned new housing materialized. Obstacles included the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, sharp cutbacks in Federal housing subsidies, local resistance to more subsidized housing in the area -- several low-income public housing projects already had already been built nearby -- and developers' lack of interestin building unsubsidized housing there.
Nor did the administration of Mayor Abraham D. Beame get far when it proposed in 1975 that Arverne be developed as a recreational complex.
As a result, the only significant construction on the 300 acres has been an apartment complex occupying about 20 acres, the 1,100-family Ocean Village, dating from the early 70's.
It stands like a settlement on the moon. "It's just dead around here," Lisa Anderson, 21, a nurse, said as she toted shopping bags back to her apartment.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE ARABS;
Arab Nations Propose Forming Peacekeeping Force for Gulf

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 6

 BODY:
Foreign ministers from Arab nations that went to war with Iraq proposed today that additional Egyptian and Syrian troops be sent to the Persian Gulf, as the nucleus of an Arab peacekeeping force that would replace United States and Western forces.
The proposal came at the end a two-day meeting in Damascus, at which officials of Egypt, Syria and six Arab gulf nations, including Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, outlined a broad series of measures for improving regional security and economic cooperation now that the war with Iraq is over. 
 Among other things, the eight Arab nations declared that now is the time to convene an international peace conference to address "the Israeli occupation of Arab land and insure the rights of the Palestinian people." They said the confrerence should meet under the auspices of the United Nations.
Last weekend in Cairo, a high-level official of the Egyptian Government suggested that an international conference on the Middle East ought to begin before the end of the year.
 
Praise From France
 In outlining its plan for an Arab peacekeeping force, the published text of the draft declaration that concluded the meeting revealed few details, and did not indicate when additional Arab troops might replace Western soldiers now in the region. But it said that the new Arab force would be purely defensive in nature.
In discussing the proposal, Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria said Arab nations "will not permit a repetition of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, with all the destruction and divisions it left among the Arabs."
While Arab countries are not keen to have Western soldiers remain too long on the ground in the gulf, Western diplomats here said Arab governments had privately urged the United States to maintain a military presence in the region by leaving some military supplies behind and even increasing the number of United States Navy ships patrolling inside the gulf.
The plan for an all-Arab peacekeeping force drew quick praise from France, which has troops in the region. French officials said today that Foreign Minister Roland Dumas told a Cabinet meeting that France "supported the principle of an Arab buffer force," along the lines proposed in Damascus.
 
Iran Criticizes Security Plan
 But Iran, which was not part of the allied coalition, and now stands as the gulf's major military power after the defeat of Iraq, was critical of the proposal.
In a commentary on the Teheran radio, Iran argued that security measures for the Persian Gulf should involve exclusively those states that border on the gulf.
But in public and private discussions, officials in Cairo have said they intend to be sensitive to the concerns of neighbors like Iran and Turkey, which are large, non-Arab countries with whom they share a common culture and religion.
While the Arab countries of the gulf have vast oil wealth, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 showed they have virtually no ability to defend themselves against aggressors.
Egypt, which maintains a standing army of about 320,000 soliders, sent 35,000 troops and 400 tanks to join the allied coalition. Syria, which has an army of about 300,000, sent 20,000 troops and 300 tanks to the gulf.
Diplomats here say that in return for supplying the troops to guarantee security to oil-producing Arab nations in the gulf, Egypt and Syria are hoping to reap a windfall in new investment to help their sagging economys.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcies Rise by 16%

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Personal bankruptcies rose for the sixth straight year in 1990 to a record level, with the depressed Northeast showing the biggest increase in filings, a trade group said today.
A record 718,107 Americans filed for personal bankruptcy last year, up 16 percent from 1989, the group, the American Financial Services Association, said. 
 Economists said the record number of bankruptcies underscored the weak state of the economy. But they also said the distress stemmed from legal and social change. "It's more acceptable and easier to file for bankruptcy than it used to be," said David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
The 1990 figures, compiled by the Administrative Office of United States Courts, show the steepest overall increase since 1986.

HEADLINE: Treasury Acts to Curb Tax Benefits in Bailouts

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The Treasury Department said today that it would seek to eliminate certain tax benefits that have been claimed by the owners of 199 savings associations sold in 1988 by the Government.
One Treasury official estimated that the decision, which officials in the department concede will almost surely be contested in the courts, would give the Government an additional $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion from the 1988 deals. These sales of savings and loans seized by the Government to private entrepreneurs have been strongly attacked in Congress as giveaways. Regulators have predicted that the cost to taxpayers of the bailout of these institutions would ultimately exceed $69 billion. 
 Executives at the savings associations involved said today that they would not comment until they had a chance to analyze the ruling.
 
Letter From Brady
 The Treasury's position was outlined in a letter sent this week to some members of Congress by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Mr. Brady said that in the absence of Congressional action, the Treasury would seek to end deductions of losses and expenses by the owners of the 199 associations when those losses and expenses are reimbursed by regulators.
If, for example, an institution has an asset with a $100 book value that is sold at $40, the Government has agreed to make up the difference. Until now, the Internal Revenue Service has not objected when the institution still took the $60 as a loss for tax purposes. The Treasury said today that it would no longer permit such deductions and that the I.R.S. was prepared to bring the matter to court if savings associations failed to abide by it.
A Treasury official who insisted on not being identified said that permitting the deductibility of such assets "creates a perverse incentive" of encouraging associations to sell assets covered by the guarantees at the lowest possible price.
Administration officials conceded that the tax code was ambiguous in the area, leaving their position in the hands of the Federal courts.
"From the point of view of sound tax and financial policy, taking into account both the costs to the Government and the appropriate economic incentives for assisted institutions, it is clear that assisted institutions should not be allowed a tax deduction for losses or expenses that are reimbursed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation," Mr. Brady said in his letter. "Unfortunately, as a legal matter, the deductibility of covered losses and expenses under existing law is less clear."
 
Congressional Action Sought
 The letter added that without "a clear Congressional directive to the country," the Government would take the position that such assistance is taxable. "Congressional clarification of this issue seems not only desirable but essential," Mr. Brady said.
A "technical advice memorandum" issued in 1986 by the I.R.S. said such deductions were permissible.
The Treasury official who asked not to be identified said the memorandum was not legally binding on the Government and served mainly as guidance that need not always be followed by the I.R.S. The official said the memorandum would prevent the I.R.S. from seeking penalties and fines for the failure of associations to pay sufficient taxes.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Citicorp has sold $600 million in preferred stock to a group of investors and completed one of the key portions of its plan to strengthen its finances. [D1.]
Amgen won a stunning victory over the patents to one of the most lucrative new drugs on the market. A Federal appeals court ruled that Genetics Institute had no rights to the drug that is used to combat anemia. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Ban on Replacing Strikers Faces Veto Threat

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said today that the Administration opposed union-supported legislation prohibiting companies from hiring permanent replacements for strikers, as a score of major companies have done in recent years.
Organized labor, which for years has seen its membership steadily erode, regards the use of replacement workers as a lethal threat to its power and has made banning the practice its highest priority in Congress this year. A bill to do that has 202 sponsors, nearly all of them Democrats, and could come to the full House for a vote before this summer. 
 "If the bill were presented to the President," Mrs. Martin told a hearing on the bill by a subcommittee of the House Education and Labor Committee, "his senior advisers would recommend a veto." Current labor laws, she said, have established a healthy balance in employer-worker relations that suits the public interest. She said the legislation would leave "little incentive for unions to moderate the use of the strike weapon."
Mrs. Martin's comments, the first from the Administration on the legislation, were no surprise to Democrats in the House or to labor unions. But in threatening a veto so early in the legislative process and in leaving little apparent room for compromise, Mrs. Martin surprised some labor leaders.
"It's astounding that so early in the process they would recommend a veto," said John J. Sheehan, chief lobbyist for the United Steelworkers of America. In a statement to the committee, Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said current law gave management incentives to provoke strikes and get rid of unions and blunted the strike as labor's ultimate weapon in negotiating disputes.
"If an employer can replace strikers permanently, that negates the right to strike," said Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn.
Representative William L. Clay, a Missouri Democrat who wrote the House bill, said: "She made it crystal clear. There is no room to negotiate."
 
Reagan Brought Practice Back
 Mr. Clay said there was little doubt the House would enact the bill. Prospects are less certain in the Senate, where Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, has introduced a similar measure.
Under current law, employers have been free to put strikers out of their jobs permanently by hiring substitutes, but the practice was rare until 1981 when President Ronald Reagan used it to end a strike by Federal air traffic controllers. In the ensuing years, companies like the International Paper Company, Colt Industries, Eastern Airlines, Greyhound, Continental Airlines, the Chicago Tribune Company, and most recently its New York subsidiary, The Daily News, took on permanent replacements.
In most cases, the companies, with histories of sour labor relations, had fallen into difficult financial circumstances and were looking for help from wage cuts and staff reductions. Most companies avoid using permanent replacements, partly because of the difficulty they face in training a new work force and partly to preserve cooperative relationships with workers.
Representatives of organized labor and Mrs. Martin noted that there was a sharp decline in strikes in the 1980's. Last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports, there were 45 strikes at companies with 1,000 or more workers. The annual average of strikes at companies of the same size since 1980 is 80. In the three decades before the 1980's the Bureau recorded a low of 181 strikes at such companies in 1963, and a record of 437 in 1953.
But the two viewed the decline entirely differently. Mrs. Martin sees a calm born of harmony from labor and management working together. Labor sees a calm born of fear, of workers who refuse to strike because they can be punished with the permanent loss of their jobs. Without the threat of a strike, unions see themselves as powerless in collective bargaining.
"The 80's saw many employers who were willing to sacrifice long-term labor stability for the immediate gratification of busting a union," said Representative Pat Williams, the Montana Democrat who is the chairman of the Labor-Management Subcommittee to which Mrs. Martin spoke.
But Mrs. Martin said that if the right to permanently replace economic strikers was prohibited, "there would be little incentive for unions to moderate the use of the strike weapon."
