LENGTH: 2789 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE PRESIDENT;
Transcript of President Bush's Address on End of the Gulf War

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's address last night to a joint session of Congress, and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley's introduction, as recorded by The New York Times:
FOLEY. Mr. President, it is customary at joint sessions for the chair to present the President to the members of Congress directly and without further comment. But I wish to depart from tradition tonight and express to you on behalf of the Congress and the country and through you to the members of our armed forces our warmest congratulations on the brilliant victory of the Desert Storm operation.
Members of the Congress, I now have the high privilege and distinct honor of presenting to you the President of the United States.
 BUSH. Mr. President and Mr. Speaker, thank you, sir, for those very generous words spoken from the heart about the wonderful performance of our military. Members of Congress: Five short weeks ago, I came to this House to speak to you about the State of the Union. And we met then in time of war. Tonight, we meet in a world blessed by the promise of peace.
From the moment Operation Desert Storm commenced on Jan. 16 until the time the guns fell silent at midnight one week ago, this nation has watched its sons and daughters with pride -- watched over them with prayer. As Commander in Chief, I can report to you: Our armed forces fought with honor and valor. And as President, I can report to the nation aggression is defeated. The war is over.
This is a victory for every country in the coalition, for the United Nations. A victory for unprecedented international cooperation and diplomacy, so well led by our Secretary of State James Baker. It is a victory for the rule of law and for what is right.
Desert Storm's success belongs to the team that so ably leads our armed forces, our Secretary of Defense and our Chairman of the Joint Chiefs: Dick Cheney and Colin Powell.
And while you're standing, this military victory also belongs to the one the British call the "Man of the Match," the tower of calm at the eye of Desert Storm, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf.
And let us, recognizing this was a coalition effort, let us not forget Saudi General Khalid, Britain's General de la Billiere, or General Roquejoffra of France, and all the others whose leadership played such a vital role. And most importantly, most importantly of all, all those who served in the field.
I thank the members of this Congress. Support here for our troops in battle was overwhelming. And above all, I thank those whose unfailing love and support sustained our courageous men and women: I thank the American people.
 
World After War
 Tonight -- tonight, I come to this House to speak about the world, the world after war.
The recent challenge could not have been clearer. Saddam Hussein was the villain, Kuwait the victim. To the aid of this small country came nations from North America and Europe, from Asia and South America, from Africa and the Arab world, all united against aggression.
Our uncommon coalition must now work in common purpose to forge a future that should never again be held hostage to the darker side of human nature.
Tonight in Iraq, Saddam walks amidst ruin. His war machine is crushed. His ability to threaten mass destruction is itself destroyed. His people have been lied to, denied the truth. And when his defeated legions come home, all Iraqis will see and feel the havoc he has wrought. And this I promise you: For all that Saddam has done to his own people, to the Kuwaitis, and to the entire world, Saddam and those around him are accountable.
All of us grieve for the victims of war, for the people of Kuwait and the suffering that scars the soul of that proud nation. We grieve for all our fallen soldiers and their families, for all the innocents caught up in this conflict. And yes, we grieve for the people of Iraq, a people who have never been our enemy. My hope is that one day we will once again welcome them as friends into the community of nations.
 
Four Key Challenges
 Our commitment to peace in the Middle East does not end with the liberation of Kuwait. So tonight, let me outline four key challenges to be met.
First, we must work together to create shared security arrangements in the region. Our friends and allies in the Middle East recognize that they will bear the bulk of the responsibility for regional security. But we want them to know that just as we stood with them to repel aggression, so now America stands ready to work with them to secure the peace.
This does not mean stationing U.S. ground forces in the Arabian Peninsula, but it does mean American participation in joint exercises involving both air and ground forces. It means maintaining a capable U.S. naval presence in the region, just as we have for over 40 years. And let it be clear: Our vital national interests depend on a stable and secure gulf.
Second, we must act to control the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and the missiles used to deliver them. It would be tragic if the nations of the Middle East and Persian Gulf were now, in the wake of war, to embark on a new arms race. Iraq requires special vigilance. Until Iraq convinces the world of its peaceful intentions -- that its leaders will not use new revenues to rearm and rebuild its menacing war machine -- Iraq must not have access to the instruments of war.
And third, we must work to create new opportunities for peace and stability in the Middle East. On the night I announced Operation Desert Storm, I expressed my hope that out of the horrors of war might come new momentum for peace. We've learned in the modern age, geography cannot guarantee security and security does not come from military power alone.
All of us know the depth of bitterness that has made the dispute between Israel and its neighbors so painful and intractable. Yet, in the conflict just concluded, Israel and many of the Arab states have for the first time found themselves confronting the same aggressor. By now, it should be plain to all parties that peacemaking in the Middle East requires compromise. At the same time, peace brings real benefits to everyone. We must do all that we can to close the gap between Israel and the Arab states and between Israelis and Palestinians. The tactics of terror lead absolutely nowhere; there can be no substitute for diplomacy.
A comprehensive peace must be grounded in United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 and the principle of territory for peace. This principle must be elaborated to provide for Israel's security and recognition, and at the same time for legitimate Palestinian political rights. Anything else would fail the twin tests of fairness and security. The time has come to put an end to Arab-Israeli conflict.
The war with Iraq is over. The quest for solutions to the problems in Lebanon, in the Arab-Israeli dispute, and in the gulf must go forward with new vigor and determination. And I guarantee you no one will work harder for a stable peace in the region than we will.
Fourth, we must foster economic development for the sake of peace and progress. The Persian Gulf and Middle East -- and Middle East -- form a region rich in natural resources with a wealth of untapped human potential. Resources once squandered on military might -- military might must be redirected to more peaceful ends. We are already addressing the immediate economic consequences of Iraq's aggression. Now, the challenge is to reach higher to foster economic freedom and prosperity for all the people of the region. By meeting these four challenges we can build a framework for peace. I've asked Secretary of State Baker to go to the Middle East to begin the process. He will go to listen, to probe, to offer suggestions, to advance the search for peace and stability.
I've also asked him to raise the plight of the hostages held in Lebanon. We have not forgotten them. And we will not forget them.
To all the challenges that confront this region of the world, there is no single solution, no solely American answer. But we can make a difference. America will work tirelessly as a catalyst for positive change.
But we cannot lead a new world abroad if, at home, it's politics as usual on American defense and diplomacy. It's time to turn away from the temptation to protect unneeded weapons systems and obsolete bases. It's time to put an end, it's time to put an end to micro-management of foreign and security assistance programs, micro-management that humiliates our friends and allies and hamstrings our diplomacy. It's time to rise above the parochial and the pork barrel, to do what is necessary, what's right and what will enable this nation to play the leadership role required of us.
The consequences of the conflict in the gulf reach far beyond the confines of the Middle East. Twice before in this century, an entire world was convulsed by war. Twice this century, out of the horrors of war hope emerged for enduring peace. Twice before, those hopes proved to be a distant dream, beyond the grasp of man.
Until now, the world we've known has been a world divided, a world of barbed wire and concrete block, conflict and cold war.
And now, we can see a new world coming into view. A world in which there is the very real prospect of a new world order. In the words of Winston Churchill, a "world order" in which "the principles of justice and fair play . . . protect the weak against the strong." A world where the United Nations, freed from cold war stalemate, is poised to fulfill the historic vision of its founders. A world in which freedom and respect for human rights find a home among all nations.
The gulf war put this new world to its, its first test. And my fellow Americans, we passed that test.
For the sake of our principles, for the sake of the Kuwaiti people, we stood our ground. Because the world would not look the other way, Ambassador Al-Sabah, tonight Kuwait is free. Where is he? And we're very happy about that.
 
Lessons of History
 Tonight, as our troops begin to come home, let us recognize that the hard work of freedom still calls us forward. We've learned the hard lessons of history. The victory over Iraq was not waged as "a war to end all wars." Even the new world order cannot guarantee an era of perpetual peace. But enduring peace must be our mission.
Our success in the gulf will shape not only the new world order we seek but our mission here at home.
In the war just ended, there were clear-cut objectives, timetables and, above all, an overriding imperative to achieve results. We must bring that same sense of self-discipline, that same sense of urgency, to the way we meet challenges here at home.
In my State of the Union Address and in my budget, I defined a comprehensive agenda to prepare for the next American century.
Our first priority is to get this economy rolling again. The fear and uncertainty caused by the gulf crisis were understandable. But now that the war is over, oil prices are down, interest rates are down and confidence is rightly coming back. Americans can move forward to lend, spend and invest in this, the strongest economy on earth.
We must also enact the legislation that is key to building a better America, For example, in 1990, we enacted an historic Clean Air Act. And now we've proposed a national energy strategy. We passed a child care bill that put power in the hands of parents. And today, we're ready to do the same thing with our schools, and expand, expand choice in education. We passed a crime bill that made a useful start in fighting crime and drugs. This year we're sending to Congress our comprehensive crime package to finish the job. We passed the landmark Americans With Disabilities Act. And now we've sent forward our civil rights bill. We also passed the aviation bill. This year we've sent up our new highway bill.
And these are just a few of our pending proposals for reform and renewal.
 
Call for Domestic Action
 So tonight, I call on the Congress to move forward aggressively on our domestic front. Let's begin with two initiatives we should be able to agree on quickly. transportation and crime. And then, let's build on success with those and enact the rest of our agenda. If our forces could win the ground war in 100 hours, then surely the Congress can pass this legislation in 100 days. Let, let that be a promise we make tonight to the American people.
When I spoke in this House about the state of our union, I asked all of you: If we can selflessly confront evil for the sake of good in a land so far away, then surely we can make this land all that it should be. In the time since then, the brave men and women of Desert Storm accomplished more than even they may realize. They set out to confront an enemy abroad, and in the process, they transformed a nation at home.
Think, think of the way they went about their mission -- with confidence and quiet pride. Think about their sense of duty, about all they taught us, about our values, about ourselves.
We hear so often about our young people in turmoil, how our children fall short, how our schools fail us, how American products and American workers are second class. Well, don't you believe it. The America we saw in Desert Storm was first-class talent.
And they -- and they did it -- they did it using America's state-of-the-art technology. We saw the excellence embodied in the Patriot missile and the patriots who made it work.
And we saw soldiers who know about honor and bravery and duty and country and the world-shaking power of these simple words.
There is something noble and majestic about the pride, about the patriotism, that we feel tonight.
So, to everyone here, and everyone watching at home, think about the men and women of Desert Storm. Let us honor them with our gratitude. Let us comfort the families of the fallen and remember each precious life lost.
Let us learn from them as well. Let us honor those who have served us by serving others.
Let us honor them as individuals, men and women of every race, all creeds and colors, by setting the face of this nation against discrimination, bigotry and hate. Eliminate that.
I'm sure that many of you saw on -- on the television -- the unforgettable scene of four terrified Iraqi soldiers surrendering. They emerged from their bunker broken, tears streaming from their eyes, fearing the worst. And then there was an American soldier. Remember what he said? He said: "It's O.K. You're all right now. You're all right now."
That scene says a lot about America, a lot about who we are. Americans are a caring people. We are a good people, a generous people. Let us always be caring and good and generous in all we do.
 
March Home From Gulf
 Soon, very soon, our troops will begin the march we've all been waiting for, their march home. And I have directed Secretary Cheney to begin the immediate return of American combat units from the gulf.
Less than two hours from now, the first planeload of American soldiers will lift off from Saudi Arabia headed for the U.S.A. That plane will carry the men and women of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division bound for Fort Stewart, Ga. This is just -- this is just the beginning of a steady flow of American troops coming home.
Let their return remind us that all those who have gone before are linked with us in the long line of freedom's march. Americans have always tried to serve, to sacrifice nobly for what we believe to be right.
Tonight, I ask every community in this country to make this coming Fourth of July a day of special celebration for our returning troops. They may have missed Thanksgiving and Christmas, but I can tell you this: For them and for their families, we can make this a holiday they'll never forget.
In a very real sense, this victory belongs to them, to the privates and the pilots, to the sergeants and the supply officers, to the men and women in the machines, and the men and women who made them work. It belongs to the regulars, to the Reserves, to the National Guard. This victory belongs to the finest fighting force this nation has ever known in its history.
We went halfway around the world to do what is moral and just and right. And we fought hard, and -- with others -- we won the war. And we lifted the yoke of aggression and tyranny from a small country that many Americans had never even heard of, and we ask nothing in return.
We're coming home now proud, confident, heads high. There is much that we must do at home and abroad. And we will do it. We are Americans.
May God bless this great nation, the United States of America. Thank you all very much.
Thank you guys. Thank you very, very much.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: POLITICS;
Cease-Fire in the Capital Comes to a Bitter Close

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Hours before Congressional leaders gave a warm welcome to President Bush at a joint session tonight, the political cease-fire imposed by the Persian Gulf war came to a snarling end.
Congressional Democrats displayed growing dismay today over Republican efforts to paint them as weak and unpatriotic for opposing war against Iraq, and Senator Al Gore of Tennessee took the Senate floor to accuse the Republicans of "poisoning our national politics." 
 At virtually the same moment two Republican Senators, Phil Gramm of Texas and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, attacked the Democrats for contending that Republican economic policies had hurt the poor, saying Congressional Budget Office statistics showed that the poor had thrived under President Ronald Reagan's policies.
Each side was working hard to deflate the other party's most potent political issue.
 
A Haunting Vote
 To Democrats, the dazzlingly quick success of the war not only dimmed already distant hopes for the White House but also has appeared to shake the earlier confidence many expressed that their votes in Congress against the use of force in the gulf would not prove politically life threatening as long as they had been thoughtfully explained.
To Republicans, the Democratic votes against using force have presented sudden new opportunities, but decades of Democratic success in labeling them as the party of the rich serve as a sleepless reminder of a fundamental problem that the Democrats can resurrect in a hurry, as they did in the last days of the 1990 campaign.
Senator Gore, who is the only prominent Democratic Presidential hopeful to vote in favor of war against Iraq and thus is politically well positioned on the issue, was responding to a growing Republican message. It was epitomized last week when Mr. Gramm said the opposition of Democratic leaders to going to war showed that "Democrats cannot be trusted to define the destiny of America, that Democrats cannot be trusted to make America a world leader."
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley assailed Republicans on Tuesday for this theme, saying that despite the unity of the war effort, some Republicans "want to disunite the country again for political purposes."
 
G.O.P. Tactic: Ridicule
 Republicans have largely avoided direct attacks on the Democrats for their votes on Jan. 12 against authorizing the use of force, but their ranging fire comes close.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republicann whip, has argued that it is best to attack the Democrats for votes against weapons systems that worked in the gulf and to recruit gulf veterans as Republican candidates.
He also urged ridiculing the Democrats as obstructionists, with a gulf war theme. On Tuesday the Georgia Republican, on the Fox Morning News television program, said, "If Norm Schwarzkopf had had to report to the Democratic Congress, we'd still be unloading the first five tanks and debating which way they should point."
Mr. Gore today condemned the Republicans for trying to "manipulate votes of conscience into political tools." He called on Mr. Bush to "impose the political discipline some Republicans appear to need to put the national good before their poilitical maneuvering."
In an interview later, Mr. Gore said his concern in making the speech was not the possible political threat to Democrats. His own vote in favor of force was cast without political reckoning, he said, and added he is still not looking at the issue in those terms.
 
Reagan and the Poor, Revisited
 Mr. Gore said that instead, his concern was over the risk of losing an opportunity when "victory ought to be seen as an opportunity for our nation to seek a transformation of our national politics," away from its triviality.
At a news conference held while Mr. Gore was making his floor speech, Senators Gramm and Domenici said they were trying to dispel the impression circulated by Democrats that recent tax law changes favored the rich and that the Republican policies of the 1980's had generally enabled the rich to get richer while the poor got poorer.
Mr. Domenici, the top Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said Congressional Budget Office figures proved that "during the 80's, the rich got richer and the poor got richer."
He offered a chart showing that the income of the poorest fifth of the nation's families had grown 11.8 percent from 1983 to 1989, while that of the richest fifth had increased by 12.2 percent.
 
Statistics Skirmish
 The Senator said this was in stark contrast to what happened from 1979 to 1983, a period that he termed recession years attributable to the policies of the Carter Administration, even though President Jimmy Carter left office on Jan. 20, 1981. In those years, Mr. Domenici said, the income of the poorest fifth of the nation's families declined by 17.4 percent, while that of the richest fifth increased by 4.8 percent.
George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader, scorned the Republicans' selection of comparative years as "an obvious statistician's trick" intended to avoid any blame for the current recession. He also said that Mr. Domenici's figures showing greater gains for poor families from 1983 to 1989, under Mr. Reagan, than from 1975 to 1979, under Mr. Carter, overlooked the fact that gains in six years of expansion ought to be greater than those in four years.
Reflecting the central importance of the "fairness" issue to Democratic campaigns, Mr. Mitchell made it clear that the Republican arguments would be met full force. He said Democrats were going over all the Gramm-Domenici numbers and would offer a thorough rebuttal on Thursday.
Mr. Gramm, chairman of the Republican Senate campaign committee, said the statistics showed that under Mr. Carter's policies, whose effect he dated from 1978 to 1982, "every income group in the country got poorer."
 
'Very Good Jobs'
 He also contended that the numbers demonstrated that the jobs created in the 1980's were not, as Democrats argue, low-paying jobs. "The number of poor-paying jobs actually declined," he said, citing an 8.9 percent decrease in the number of farm workers from 1982 to 1989 and a 31.3 percent increase in managerial and professional jobs in that period.
Mr. Domenici said this showed the jobs were "very, very good jobs, not hamburger flipper jobs."
Mr. Gramm said the Congressional Budget Office data also showed that Democrats were wrong when, arguing that Social Security tax increases had outweighed the effect of income tax cuts, they said the Federal tax structure had become more regressive.
He said the data showed that the share of Federal taxes paid by the bottom 40 percent of all families had gone from 8.6 percent of the total in 1980 to 8.9 percent in 1985 and fallen to 8.2 percent in 1990. And the share paid by the top 1 percent, the top 5 percent, the top 10 percent and the top 20 percent, he said, increased in each of those periods.

Domenici that show poorest Americans fared no worse than others for most of the Reagan years. (Source: Senators Gram and Domenici from data supplied by the Congressional Budget Office)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Tokyo's Prospects Depend on Rates

BYLINE: By James Sterngold

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE swift conclusion of the Persian Gulf war has cleared up a big uncertainty hanging over the world economy. But in Japan, the removal of that question mark has merely permitted investors to focus on a host of other knotty uncertainties that are leaving the outlook here uncharacteristically muddy.
Suddenly, investors in the United States, who had been fretting over an ailing economy and the prospects of a prolonged war, seem much more certain about the future than do the Japanese, who import 70 percent of their oil from the Middle East and seemed to have the most to gain from war's end. 
 What makes the situation particularly vexing for the Japanese is that the issue turns not on a host of unpredictable forces, but on one human decision: When will the Bank of Japan cut interest rates?
Over the last few days, the Tokyo stock exchange has largely taken its cue from the bubbly New York market, bounding along behind Wall Street's victory strut.
The 225-stock Nikkei index gained 469.51 points yesterday and another 14.97 points today, to close at 26,397.96. Since the beginning of the year, the Nikkei has risen 10.6 percent. The rebound has been especially appreciated after the steep market slide last year, which wiped out nearly 40 percent of the value of shares here. The Nikkei is still 12,000 points below its high, while on Wall Street the Dow Jones industrial average is flirting with a record.
The Tokyo market's improvement has come just in time to help salvage the fiscal year most companies in Japan follow. That period ends March 31. At the least, the unrealized losses that many investors are sitting on will shrink.
But there is a surprising lack of consensus on where Japanese stocks are heading. "The market is a little pricey," said Lawrence S. Prager, a senior analyst for Nikko Securities. "This economy is still in the process of slowing down."
Liam Newberg, senior analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, noted that the bond market was leading the way. With bond yields sliding, investors have been more willing to bet that the central bank might act. In fact, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Government bond closed at 6.6 percent yesterday, down from about 8.5 percent last fall.
"Bonds are headed in the right direction," he said, adding that he expected no substantial drop from here.
Kermit Schoenholtz, an economist at Salomon Brothers, takes an opposite view. He agreed that the economy was stalling -- Salomon expects growth of about 2.2 percent in the fiscal year, compared with the Japanese Government's forecast of 3.8 percent -- but said the slowdown would force the central bank's hand. Interest rates will drop, big investors will not be forced to sell shares at distressed prices and corporate profits will rebound.
"It's a virtuous circle at play," Mr. Schoenholtz said.
Andrew Ballingal, the chief strategist here for Barclays de Zoete Wedd, counts himself among the bears. One reason he contends that the Tokyo market has been swept up too quickly behind Wall Street is because a good part of the buying has come from the United States, not Japan.
According to Tokyo stock exchange figures, foreigners have been net buyers of a little more than $10 billion worth of Japanese equities in 1991, and Mr. Ballingal said anecdotal evidence indicated that most of the money came from America. He added that the inflow could not be counted on to cover up for long what has been steady selling by most Japanese investors, who have been burdened by high interest rates.
The Bank of Japan raised interest rates sharply over the last two years to cool the overheated economy and reduce inflationary expectations. So, just about every week the papers have been filled with speculation on when the inevitable cut in rates will come. But Yasushi Mieno, the central bank's governor, repeated again this week that he felt the economy was still strong and that inflationary pressures remained substantial.
In the meantime, the central bank released a survey of business confidence on Tuesday that suggested corporations were hunkering down for even slower economic expansion. Capital spending, an engine of growth in recent years, is expected to expand just 1.1 percent this year, according to the survey, down from more than 15 percent growth in 1990. That has only deepened the guessing on when the central bank will act to stave off a recession.
"In my view, this is a bear market rally," said Mr. Ballingal, who added that any interest rate reductions would be slight. "If this does turn into a bull market, it will be anemic."
Mr. Schoenholtz countered, "There are conflicting forces, but we think there will be a psychological shift that will help the market." Salomon, he said, sees the Nikkei average testing the 30,000 level by midyear.

LENGTH: 1220 words

HEADLINE: Recession Steals Into a Stronghold of Wealth

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J.

 BODY:
The Rev. Fred Baldwin, the tweed-clad priest at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church, takes tea every day at 4 in the rectory, an Edwardian country house down the hill from the Somerset Hills Country Club.
Tea at century-old St. Bernard's is not the sort of setting where one would expect to find people talking about losing their jobs, declaring bankruptcy and how to find work. But those were the topics the other day when Mr. Baldwin was joined by three parishioners: a Wall Street broker, an investment banker and a salesman for a health-care company. 
 "Bernardsville is what you think the American Dream is -- the country club, successful careers, the dream house," Mr. Baldwin said. "All of the real problems are kept in secret. But now with the recession and unemployment, people can't keep up the facade anymore."
Recession has touched New Jersey, and wealthy Bernardsville, in the Somerset Hills horse country, has not escaped. These men were available for tea on a weekday afternoon because they had all lost their jobs in the last year. Mr. Baldwin said that out of 150 families in his parish, at least 15 have been hit by unemployment.
To the men, their sitting down together is a recognition of a big change in their lives, not only in financial circumstances but also in how much control they feel they have, and how they view work. To others, the fact that St. Bernard's has so many members like these men that it has been moved to form a support group for them is the ultimate sign that life is changing.
Mr. Baldwin commented critically about self-indulgent spending the other day as he drove through one of the new subdivisions of million-dollar "trophy" houses that have sprung up in the area. Some of them stood empty.
Bernardsville, a town of about 7,000 people 30 miles west of New York City, has always been a place where to move in is to have arrived. St. Bernard's, a stone Gothic church amid woods and gardens, was founded in the late 19th century by a group of tycoons. More recently, the younger parishioners have included executives who commute to the nearby A.T. & T. headquarters or, farther, to Wall Street.
 
Cucumbers and Stories
 At the rectory, over cucumber sandwiches and Earl Grey tea, the investment banker said: "This guy at my office called me in on Dec. 6. He said, 'Look, there's been a downturn in business, blah, blah, blah.'
"I sort of glazed over and -- blip! -- there it is. I was out. You can't work on Wall Street without knowing which way the wind is blowing, but it still hit me like a brick."
Mr. Baldwin, who moved here six years ago from St. James Episcopal Church on Madison Avenue, reminds his parishioners that he knows what it is to be downwardly mobile. He is in the process of getting a divorce from a highly paid options trader.
Not all the parishioners who are affected by the recession had high-paying jobs. One is a private-school language teacher who said she would be laid off next fall.
Some concede that when they were making money they were spending too much of it too quickly.
"It's kind of like the ant and grasshopper story," said Philip McCarthy, an unemployed construction manager. "The ant puts everything away. I've been the grasshopper for 20 years. Who knows where the money went? I used to like to work on cars. I owned three or four at one time -- sports cars, BMW's. Now all I have is the house."
Mr. McCarthy wasn't earning nearly six figures. But the investment banker, who is 29 years old, was -- easily.
"I knew I wasn't worth six figures," he said.
Like the other two men, the investment banker would speak only anonymously, saying he feared that being identified might hurt his chances of finding another job. He said he had liquified his IRA's and could hold out another six months without a job.
The salesman, who is 42, received a week's severance pay when his company lost a major contract and laid him off a month ago. He said he was not worried yet, but he did say he will cut off his car phone soon.
The Wall Street broker, who had been earning $400,000 a year at a securities firm, is in the worst shape. He had to sell his house -- for $400,000, the same price he paid -- and move in with his brother-in-law. His BMW and Jaguar were repossessed. He is about to declare bankruptcy. His wife has gone to work as a secretary.
"Back in the 80's, you really didn't save," said the broker, who has two small children. "You thought the next year was going to be good. I was on my way to becoming a millionaire. A lot of the money went into the house, cars, education for the kids, vacations. I would get my suits custom made, at $1,000 to $1,500 a suit. The suits are about all I have left."
Bernardsville looks just as prosperous and staid as it did five years ago, the boom years. The stately houses are still standing on their meticulously landscaped 5- and 10-acre wooded lots. One of the town's famous residents, Millicent Fenwick, the frugal Republican former Congresswoman, said that as she drives around in her Chevrolet she is still dismayed by all the BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes.
"I hate conspicuous waste," Mrs. Fenwick said the other day, noting further that in her 81 years she has been the holder of a single credit card -- American Express -- which she ripped up not long ago.
 
Town Changing 'Inwardly'
 There is no sign of a mass renunciation of credit cards among Mrs. Fenwick's fellow townspeople. But life is somehow different.
"Outwardly, everything is the same," said James Garrison, a longtime member of St. Bernard's and an executive in search of work. "But inwardly something has changed."
At the True Value Hardware Store on Route 202, the owner, James Clark, said his customers were no longer snatching up top-of-the-line items like gas grills and brass mailboxes. David Neill, whose family established the MJ Neill Fuel Company in 1917, said some of his most reliable customers had fallen behind.
 
Empty Million-Dollar Homes
 Dorothy Castro, a real-estate broker, says she knows of more than 30 houses in the area selling for $1 million and up. Some were built in the last three years and never occupied.
"Three or four years ago everybody wanted a huge house worth a million dollars," Mrs. Castro said. "A lot of people got in over their heads."
Last week, 10 men and 6 women gathered at St. Bernard's for the first meeting of the Career Support Group. The broker and the salesman from the tea were there. So was Janice Logg, who lost her job as a bank manager last August in a takeover. Ms. Logg has sent out 250 resumes. So far, no job.
Philip McCarthy, who tried to start his own business a year ago, was at the group session, too.
"I figured with my associations and acquaintances over the last 23 years I could draw up enough work to keep me busy," Mr. McCarthy said before the meeting. "By the middle of August I had called hundreds of people. They said, 'We don't have any work.' " Ten years ago, he said, "I would've been swamped" with job offers.
Mr. McCarthy has been rewriting "an old-fashioned boiler plate resume," reading books like "How to Get a Better Job in This Crazy World" and reconsidering his future.
"I'd like to go to work for a large corporation, put in my 20 years and collect my pension," he said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Improved Outlook for Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the end of the war with Iraq "removed a troublesome uncertainty" from the nation's economy and improved the chances that the recession would be relatively short and mild.
"The relief from lower energy prices along with a potential boost to confidence from the end of the gulf war should be laying the groundwork for some firming in consumer spending in coming months," Mr. Greenspan, the Government's most influential economic policy maker, said in testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee. 
 Although he acknowledged that "the economy continues to edge down," Mr. Greenspan suggested that the Fed would not cut interest rates further to stimulate the economy without clearer signs that trends were unfavorable.
"Whether further adjustments to policy will be required to foster an upturn in output and employment is not yet clear. Any decision in that regard will depend on how trends in real activity, inflation and monetary aggregates unfold."
 
Some Rates Up a Bit
 Some mortgage and bond rates have risen slightly since the Federal Reserve last reduced the interest rates it controls five weeks ago. But "this should not materially interfere with an upturn in activity," Mr. Greenspan said.
The next gauge of the economy comes Friday, when the Labor Department releases data on employment and joblessness in February. Economists who are predicting an end to the recession by late spring or early summer expect the new figures to show that payroll employment fell by about 100,000 jobs last month and that the unemployment rate was lower than 6.5 percent. The unemployment rate was 6.2 percent in January.
The anticipated employment statistics would indicate that while the economy continued to slide, a recovery might be possible without further action by the Federal Reserve. But if the situation proves to be worse than expected, many economists believe, the Federal Reserve might be persuaded to step in with lower interest rates.
 
Negative Factors
 The chairman said that a number of negative factors persisted in the economy, including the continued scarcity of credit and weakness in the real estate market. But he said he expected "the turn to occur within a reasonably short period of time."
He added, "The scales appear to tip slightly in favor of suggesting that the current downturn might well prove milder than most of the recessions in the past 40 years."
Mr. Greenspan's forecast is not surprising, since he has been saying for weeks that the recession would probably not be severe if the war was short. But this was his first public appearance since the end of the war last week, so his appraisal was closely watched in political circles and financial markets.
"Anecdotal reports" in the days after hostilities ended are encouraging about the economy picking up, Mr. Greenspan said, but he cautioned that "hard economic data for the period will not be available for some weeks."
 
Stance on Banking Revisions
 On another matter, Mr. Greenspan said he supported most elements of the Bush Administration's proposal to change the nation's banking laws and thought it was especially important to remove restrictions against banks opening branches nationwide. He said he might quarrel with some aspects of the proposed legislation but did not identify them.
Federal Reserve officials said this week that Mr. Greenspan and the other Fed governors were strongly opposed to the part of the Administration proposal that would relieve the Fed of supervisory authority over many of the nation's largest banks.
Mr. Greenspan said he expected some large banks to merge in the next few years, but he said most small community banks would probably survive. "Local knowledge is a very important economic value," he said. "Community banks are going to be very difficult to competitively dislodge."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: THE WHITE HOUSE;
BUSH, URGING WIDER PEACE, HINTS AT PRESSURE ON ISRAEL TO YIELD LAND FOR SECURITY

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
President Bush said tonight that he would immediately begin bringing American troops home from the Persian Gulf. But he pledged to maintain a strong diplomatic presence in the Middle East and to redouble efforts to solve the stubborn Arab-Israeli conflict.
"Our commitment to peace in the Middle East does not end with the liberation of Kuwait," Mr. Bush told a joint session of Congress, adding to applause: "The time has come to put an end to the Arab-Israeli conflict." 
 In remarks almost certain to be perceived by Israel as a signal that he intends to seek important concessions from its Government, Mr. Bush re-emphasized longstanding American policy that Israel must trade territory that it seized during wars with its Arab neighbors in exchange for peace and secure borders.
 
3-Minute Ovation
 The President was welcomed by a three-minute ovation from lawmakers, who wore yellow ribbons in their lapels, waved small American flags and chanted his name. The Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, introduced Mr. Bush by giving him "our warmest congratulations on the brilliant victory of the Desert Storm operation."
Mr. Bush, looking quietly pleased and at moments emotional, basked in the atmosphere of triumph, which produced cheers at his every mention of the military.. The enthusiastic response seemed more typical of a political convention than a joint session.
While the evening was not supposed to be a partisan occasion, many Republicans wore yellow buttons that said "I voted with the President," referring to the January vote in which Congress authorized the use of force in the Persian Gulf.
In his pledge to seek long-term solutions, the President said that efforts should be made "to close the gap between Israel and the Arab states -- and between Israel and Palestinians."
Mr. Bush said, "By now, it should be plain to all parties that peacemaking in the Middle East requires compromise," [Transcript, page A8.]
 
Baker Mission to Mideast
 Coming on the eve of the departure of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for the Middle East, Mr. Bush's remarks seemed likely be viewed in Israel as an appeal to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to make territorial concessions to the Palestinians.
But the address also clearly signaled to Arab leaders that Washington will encourage them to deal directly with Israel, and to move toward formal recognition of Israel and its sovereignty. Mr. Bush did not mention any specific plans, and he left it unclear what solution he envisaged to the Palestinian problem.
Palestinians have generally sought an independent nation carved out of the occupied West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip, or at the minimum, an autonomous homeland somehow linked to Jordan.
In calling for bolder steps to end the enmity in the Middle East, Mr. Bush's comments seemed to mark a departure from the more incremental diplomacy the Administration has pursued in the region.
 
U.N. Resolutions Cited
 He cited United Nations Security Council Resolution 242 of November 1967, which called on Israel to give up unspecified amounts of territory it had captured during the June 1967 war in return for recognition by the Arab countries of its borders.
He also cited Security Council Resolution 338 of October 1973, which was approved after the war of that month and called for negotiations between Israel and the Arabs.
Israel did return Sinai, which it had captured from Egypt, as part of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty of 1979, but it has generally refused to give the Golan Heights back to Syria or the West Bank to Jordan. Arab nations have refused to sign peace treaties with Israel unless all the occupied land was returned. The situation has been complicated by the Palestinian campaign for a state or homeland.
In the nationally televised speech, Mr. Bush promised that he would not back away from America's difficult new responsibilities in a region left roiling and recast by the Persian Gulf war.
 
Savoring U.S. Victory
 The speech, capping a half-year of extraordinary diplomatic and military maneuvers that put the nation on an emotional roller-coaster, was a time for the President to savor the nearly unanimous accolades for his skill in cementing a disparate coalition and conducting a swift and victorious war.
After resisting the national ebullience that followed the cease-fire, saying he wanted to stay apart from the heady mood until he could tell the American people that the last "t" was crossed and "i" was dotted, Mr. Bush finally declared victory.
"As Commander in Chief, I can report to you: Our armed forces fought with honor and valor," he said. "As President, I can report to the nation: Aggression is defeated. The war is over."
The applause was also fervid as the President thanked his commanders, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the field commander of American forces. Mr. Cheney and General Powell attended the session.
Mr. Bush said he had directed Mr. Cheney to begin the immediate return of American combat units from the gulf.
 
'A Steady Flow' Homeward
 "Less than two hours from now, the first planeload of American soldiers will lift off from Saudi Arabia headed for the U.S.A.," he said. "It will carry men and women of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division bound for Fort Stewart, Ga. This is just the beginning of a steady flow of American troops coming home."
Just after midnight Eastern time, the first troops boarded planes bound for the United States, military officials in Saudi Arabia said. The infantry division contains about 30,000 troops, about 700 of whom are scheduled to return this week, they said.
The Administration's inclination seems to be to speed up the withdrawal of American troops, because they could be a lightning rod for anti-American sentiment in the region and because the President had promised to bring the troops home as soon as he could.
Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have indicated that they would prefer to see a large contingent of American ground forces remain in the region at least for the better part of the year, but Mr. Bush is eager to fulfill his pledge that the war was not an excuse to install a permanent, large American ground force in the area.
He outlined his plan for "the world after war" that he will refine in a series of meetings with allied leaders next week.
 
'Darker Side of Human Nature'
 "Our uncommon coalition must now work in common purpose to forge a future that should never again be held hostage to the darker side of human nature," he said.
Tonight, Mr. Bush allowed himself to gloat just a little, as he basked in the bipartisan applause and the national joy at the outcome of the war.
Once again underscoring that the country has "kicked the Vietnam syndrome," as he put it last week, the President even proposed a special holiday within a holiday to thank the troops.
"I ask every community in this country to make this coming Fourth of July a day of special celebration for our returning troops," he said. "They may have missed Thanksgiving and Christmas, but I can tell you this: For them and for their families, we can make this a holiday they'll never forget.
"In a very real sense, this victory belongs to them -- to the privates and the pilots, to the sergeants and the supply officers, to the men and women in the machines, and the men and women who made them work."
Mr. Bush had been invited to Capitol Hill tonight for a celebration; politicians here wanted to capture and promote the feeling that the nation had moved beyond the gloomy sense of America's decline as a world and economic power, as well as years stained by political scandal and marred Presidencies.
"Tonight in Iraq, Saddam walks amidst ruin," Mr. Bush said, referring to Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi President. "His war machine is crushed. His ability to threaten mass destruction is itself destroyed. His people have been lied to, denied the truth. And when his defeated legions come home, all Iraqis will see and feel the havoc he has wrought."
The President made it clear that he had not yet finished his bout with Mr. Hussein, when he said: "And this I promise you: For all that Saddam has done to his own people, to the Kuwaitis, and to the entire world, Saddam and those around him are accountable."
Mr. Bush seemed to acknowledge that, now that he had acted so decisively and effectively abroad, he faced new expectations at home. He said he hoped that same sense of "mission" and "duty" would help America deal with its domestic problems.
"In the war just ended, there were clear-cut objectives, timetables and, above all, an overriding imperative to achieve results," he said. "We must bring that same sense of self-discipline, that same sense of urgency, to the way we meet challenges here at home.
"Our first priority is to get this economy rolling again," Mr. Bush said. He called on Congress to act quickly on proposals on transportation and crime.
"If our forces could win the ground war in 100 hours, then surely Congress can pass this legislation in 100 days," Mr. Bush said, but the speech lacked any specific new proposals.
 
Unease on Economy
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll indicated strong public eagerness for Mr. Bush to shift his focus to the domestic economy. Sixty-one percent said he "should be paying more attention to the economy" now than he had been, while 32 percent said he had already been paying enough attention.
While Mr. Bush has been preoccupied with the Kuwait crisis, domestic problems have worsened. The number of jobless workers has increased by 700,000, to 7.7 million, since Aug. 2. The number of people receiving welfare and food stamps has risen sharply.
Republicans have been prodding President Bush to capitalize on his success in the Persian Gulf war by moving boldly on domestic issues, but they fear he may squander what they see as a rare opportunity.
 
Administration Domestic Agenda
 The President emphasized the need for new attention to the domestic situation, and recapitulated legislative proposals the Administration has already put forth.
These included grants to local school boards to encourage programs that help give parents the choice of sending their children to private or parochial schools; an energy plan that focuses on the Administration's interest in allowing additional oil exploration on Alaska's North Slope; a civil rights bill that has been the center of an angry battle between the White House and civil rights groups; a crime program that includes increased penalties for repeat offenders who use guns, and a new highway bill.
Many members of Congress have argued that Mr. Bush's agenda is unimaginative and meager. These legislators contend that civil rights and social welfare legislation are needed in the nation to which members of the armed forces will return. Often, they quote Lloyd George, the British Prime Minister at the end of World War I, who said that he wanted to make Britain "a fit country for heroes to live in."
 
'Four Key Challenges'
 Mr. Bush outlined what he called "the four key challenges" that needed to be met in the Middle East.
He said the allied coalition must work together "to create shared security arrangements in the region."
"Our friends and allies in the Middle East recognize that they will bear the bulk of the responsibility for regional security," he said.
Working to secure the peace in the region, he said, "does not mean stationing U.S. ground forces on the Arabian Peninsula, but it does mean American participation in joint exercises involving both air and ground forces. And it means maintaining a capable U.S. naval presence in the region, just as we have for over 40 years."
Second, he said, the allies must act to control the proliferation of nuclear weapons and missiles in the region. "It would be tragic now, in the wake of war, to embark on a new arms race," he said. "Until Iraq convinces the world of its peaceful intentions -- that its leaders will not use new revenues to rearm and rebuild its menacing war machine -- Iraq must not have access to the instruments of war."
 
Arab-Israeli Conflict
 Third, he said, America must pursue new opportunities for peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict.
"All of us know the depth of bitterness that has made the dispute between Israel and its neighbors so painful and intractable," he said. "Yet, in the conflict just concluded, Israel and many of the Arab states have for the first time found themselves confronting the same aggressor.
"By now, it should be plain to all parties that peacemaking in the Middle East requires compromise," he said, adding that there must be "legitimate Palestinian political rights."
Finally, Mr. Bush said, "We must foster economic development for the sake of peace and progress."

U.S. Withdrawal Plans
 WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Pentagon said tonight that 7,168 American servicemen and women would begin the initial withdrawal of American forces from the Persian Gulf, arriving at their home bases on Friday and Saturday.
Over all, the earliest redeployments will total more than 14,000 troops: 7,386 Army, the Air Force 1,854, the Navy 2,177 and the Marines 2,900.
In addition to the contingent from the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, some 900 troops from the 82nd Airborne Division, and detachments from the 2d Armored Division and the 197th Separate Brigade will be among the first soldiers coming back to the United States, officials said.

HEADLINE: Tape of Beating by Police Revives Charges of Racism

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 6

 BODY:
A two-minute amateur videotape of the beating of a black motorist by a group of police officers has jarred Los Angeles and revived charges that the police department has failed to confront an alleged pattern of police brutality and official abuse of minorities among its officers.
The videotape, which shows officers taking turns swinging their nightsticks like baseball bats at the man and kicking him in the head as he lay on the ground early Sunday, also brought renewed criticism of Police Chief Daryl F. Gates, who has aroused controversy with his comments on race and drugs. 
 The victim of the beating, Rodney Glen King, 25 years old, was released this evening with no charges filed against him. Looking bruised and battered, he described the incident to reporters, saying, "I'm just glad I'm not dead."
Speaking from a wheelchair and wearing a cast on one ankle, Mr. King said, "I was scared for my life, so I lay down real calmly and took it like a man."
Robert Rentzer, Mr. King's lawyer, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that the police had wanted prosecutors to bring charges of battery on an officer and resisting arrest.
Don Eastman, a deputy District Attorney, said that the police had failed to support the contention that Mr. King resisted arrest and that his office had sent the case back to the police for further investigation, the A.P. reported.
As the videotape was played and replayed on local and network television, investigations were announced by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Los Angeles County District Attorney's office and the police department's Internal Affairs Division.
Mayor Tom Bradley, a former police officer, said he was outraged and called for a thorough investigation.
 
Officers Off Field Duty
 The Mayor said the police officers involved had been taken off field duty pending the outcome of the investigations. "They are on other assignments," he said. "They are not going to be working the streets and dealing with the public."
Noting that Chief Gates was a civil servant whose job was protected by law, Mr. Bradley stopped short of calling for the chief's removal, saying, "He must choose when the time has come for him to retire."
Civil rights organizations, including the American Civil Liberties Union and black and Hispanic advocacy groups joined in the public condemnation, saying there was a pattern of violence and racial abuse among Los Angeles law-enforcement agencies.
The public affairs office of the Police Department did not return telephone calls today for comment on the incident. It was not known if any of the officers involved were black.
 
F.B.I. Inquiry on Rights
 Two City Council members demanded that hearings begin immediately into the incident and into the broader questions of police conduct that it raises.
A spokesman for the F.B.I., Fred Reagan, said the bureau was investigating possible civil rights violations. At the District Attorney's office, a spokeswoman, Sandi Gibbons, said it was considering filing criminal charges.
In Washington, John Dunne, Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, said that the F.B.I. investigation would run parallel to that of the local authorities and that his office would review its findings. He said a determination would be made later whether to begin a Federal prosecution.
Chief Gates insisted that the beating was "an aberration" and said it should not cause people to judge the entire department. Police reports on the incident said Mr. King tried to charge at one of the officers after being stopped for speeding.
Witnesses said Mr. King had not fought the officers but had pleaded with them to stop hitting him.
Mr. King, who is unemployed, was hospitalized for two days before being transferred Tuesday to the Los Angeles County Jail for investigation of evading police officers and evading parole. He was released last December from prison after serving six months on a second-degree robbery conviction.
Mr. King said today that he had cooperated with the police when they pulled him over. As he lay face down outside his car, he said, "they walked over and they handcuffed me and tied me and they shocked me, shocked me with some kind of device that they use."
"And they struck me across the face," he said. "After they shocked the first time they paused for a minute, then they struck me across the face with a billy club and then shocked me again on the other side of my shoulder.
He added, "And after that they continued to pound on me and beat on me. All over my body."
His wife, Crystal Waters King, said her husband had suffered a broken leg and that "his whole face looks deformed" from the beating.
 
Tape Is Called Difference
 "It's horrible," said Karol Heppe, executive director of the Police Misconduct Lawyers Referral Service, after viewing the tape. The tape shows some of about a dozen police officers jostling each other to take turns beating the man, inflicting more than 30 blows with nightsticks and a number of kicks.
"It's horrible, but I must tell you that we receive complaints in this office of that kind of conduct on a weekly basis, if not on a daily basis," she said of the private civil rights organization. "The difference this time is that there was somebody there to videotape it. That's the only difference."
Ms. Heppe said complaints of abuses by the city's 8,400-member police department have risen steadily in recent years, though prosecutions of police officers remain rare.
In one of the most recent cases, she said, Joe Morgan, a member of the baseball Hall of Fame, was awarded $540,000 by a jury on Feb. 14 after being detained and physically abused by policemen who accused him of being a drug courier. On Nov. 9 a jury awarded $750,000 to the victim of a police shooting.
The Los Angeles County Sheriff's office has also been accused of violence and racial discrimination. In one pending case the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. said deputies in the Lynwood station had engaged in 40 documented incidents of "shooting, killing, brutality, terrorism, house-trashing and other acts of lawlessness."
Two months ago a jury here indicted five sheriff's deputies and one Los Angeles police officer for incidents of brutality and theft and for coverups while they operated as a narcotics unit.
In another case involving videotaped evidence, this time shot by a television crew, jury selection was under way today in the trial of two police officers in nearby Long Beach. The two officers were accused of assaulting a black man, Don Jackson, in January 1989.
Recent complaints against the Los Angeles Police Department have also included accusations of racial discrimination within and outside its ranks.
Last January the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing said the Los Angeles Police Department had systematically denied promotions and job advancement to black officers. The formal accusation followed recent complaints that the department also discriminates against Hispanic officers.
Chief Gates, who is white, has caused further irritation among black and Hispanic residents by remarks they have seen as insensitive. In one instance he suggested that blacks die as a result of choke holds because their bodies are somehow abnormal; in another he asserted that a Salvadoran resident who killed a police officer had no place in the United States.
Mr. Gates, who became police chief in 1978, seems to relish the controversy that surrounds him when he makes statements like one last September when he proposed to a United States Senate committee that casual drug users should be shot.
Commenting on the videotaped beating, he said: "Even if we determine that the officers were indeed out of line in this case, it is an aberration. I would hope the public would not, on the basis of this one tape, make up their minds about the Los Angeles police."
 
Victim Called Cooperative
 George Holliday, 31 years old, an amateur photographer, said he began taping with his newly purchased video camera after he and his wife saw about 10 police cars stop a white sedan across the street from their second-floor apartment at about 1 A.M. Sunday.
The police later said they had pursued the car after it was observed speeding on the Foothill Freeway at up to 115 miles an hour. Mr. Holliday's apartment is in Lakeview Terrace, a community in the San Fernando Valley 20 miles from downtown Los Angeles.
"Before they started hitting him, he was pretty much cooperative," Mr. Holliday said. "It was a weird feeling. I was trying to think, 'What could he have done to deserve that?' "
Ramona Ripston, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California, said: "This is not an isolated incident. We need to investigate not only this incident but the training program, the tone and leadership of the department and the attitude toward minorities."

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 478 words

HEADLINE: Save Gasoline a Better Way

 BODY:
The best way to reduce the use of fuel and clean up the atmosphere is for Congress to pass a stiff energy tax. But the Administration's national energy strategy virtually ignores tax hikes or any other conservation measure, an omission that many in Congress rightly want to reverse.
Yet Congress, too, seems determined to duck taxes. Senator Richard Bryan of Wisconsin has won considerable support for a different approach, a bill that would raise average fuel-efficiency standards for new cars from 27.5 miles per gallon to 40. Mr. Bryan's regulatory approach is tempting, but it won't work as well as higher taxes. That's because fuel-efficiency standards -- known as CAFE standards -- lower only fuel use per vehicle for new cars. But CAFE has not significantly lowered total fuel use. In recent years, fuel use per vehicle has gone down, and total fuel use has gone up. 
 Compared with a tax, CAFE standards affect a much smaller segment of the energy market. They apply only to new cars, which account for less than 10 percent of gasoline consumption. Worse yet, they hold down driving costs. And Congress treats CAFE as a substitute for a stiff gasoline tax, keeping gas prices down.
These lower driving costs encourage people to drive more miles, which offsets part of the impact of higher fuel economy. CAFE also works against itself in another way. Manufacturers may be forced to adopt expensive technologies, making new cars more expensive, encouraging drivers to keep old gas-guzzlers.
Safety is also a serious issue. To meet CAFE, manufacturers sell smaller cars. According to studies by Robert Crandall of the Brookings Institution, 1989 cars were 500 pounds lighter than they would have been without CAFE. That will boost fatalities in these cars by about 2,500 and serious injuries by 25,000. True, higher gas taxes would also make small cars more attractive, but less so. Taxes primarily encourage everyone to drive less.
Over all, the fuel savings generated by CAFE standards are small, according to studies by Prof. Robert Leone of Boston University. Energy taxes would be more effective. A higher gas tax would encourage everyone to drive less, buy more fuel-efficient cars, share rides and, eventually, live closer to work. According to some studies, a gasoline tax as small as 5 cents per gallon would achieve as much conservation as Mr. Bryan's bill, but at a fraction of the cost to the economy. A broad tax applying to all fossil fuels would fight pollution and global warming even better.
Congress, fearful of voter wrath over tax increases, could offset a higher gas tax with lower payroll taxes. That way the Federal deficit would be unaffected, one regressive tax would replace another and the nation's needs for energy, and clean air, would be protected. That's the core of a sensible national energy strategy.

HEADLINE: Top Salvador Rebel Alters His Goals

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 6

 BODY:
Moving away from his coalition's ideological roots, the senior military commander of the Salvadoran rebel army asserted this week that his group could no longer be considered a Marxist movement, and added that one-party rule in El Salvador would be "absurd."
In his first major public comments since the collapse of the Soviet bloc, the commander, Joaquin Villalobos, said that his coalition's goals would not be achieved through armed revolution, but through participation as an unarmed political movement in a pluralistic, "competitive" democracy. 
 Describing what he termed an important transformation in the rebels' thinking in the wake of recent world events, Mr. Villalobos said the guerrilla coalition had moved beyond Marxism, which he called "just one more political theory, like any other." He said its military goals had shifted from defeating or reforming the Salvadoran Army to winning a permanent disarmament of both sides under the supervision of the United Nations.
Portraying orthodox Communism as an extreme position comparable to El Salvador's right wing, Mr. Villalobos said his coalition, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, now hoped to model El Salvador's future on such prominent capitalist countries as Germany, Japan and nearby Costa Rica, which has no army and is closely tied to the United States economy.
 
'Cut Off the Extremes'
 "In El Salvador there is a need to isolate or cut off the extremes," Mr. Villalobos said. "In our case that means the thinking of dogmatic Stalinism and traditional, classic Communism. At the other extreme, it is the orthodox right wing, which in El Salvador is something from the Stone Age."
Mr. Villalobos' comments, made in an unusual set of interviews here over recent days, came amid continued news of guerrilla attacks and military clashes in El Salvador as the country moved toward municipal and legislative elections on Sunday. During the last week, guerrillas briefly took over part of the exclusive residential section of Escalon in the capital and attacked the country's main hydroelectric plant in the northern province of Chalatenango, leaving 23 people dead.
The nature and timing of the remarks suggested the possibility that they were designed to appeal to the guerrillas' foreign critics and to present an image of moderation on the eve of the coming elections, which the rebels have pledged not to interrupt.
But the statements marked a striking departure from the traditional revolutionary positions of Mr. Villalobos' coalition, which has long taken such doctine with deadly seriousness and has been considered one of the most ideologically rigid guerrilla movements in the region.
The remarks also appeared to underline what the guerrilla commander described as the "new political reality" that his movement now faces after a 18 months of dramatic political upheaval affecting its key international supporters. Those developments have included wholesale change in the Soviet Union, the Eastern bloc nations and Nicaragua, and deepening crisis in Cuba, which has long been a principal ally of the Salvadoran guerrilla cause.
 
Compromise Now His Objective
 Believed to be about 40 years old, Mr. Villalobos rarely grants interviews and has spent most of the last decade living secretly abroad or in the hills of El Salvador, directing rebel forces against the Salvadoran army and its American military advisers. But he and other members of the guerrilla high command have devoted increasing effort to talks with the Salvadoran Government toward a negotiated compromise that he said is now the principal objective of the insurgent movement.
American officials have accused the guerrilla movement of trying to stall the negotiations -- which began last spring and are being carried out under the supervision of the United Nations -- by demanding a complete dissolution of the Salvadoran military, something the officials maintain is politically impossible.
Mr. Villalobos, whose faction within the coalition is known as the People's Revolutionary Army, has been singled out by American officials as a stronghold of left-wing intransigence. But he defended the guerrilla demand on the Salvadoran military as the only way to break the country's culture of violence and "vaccinate" it against renewed civil war.
"The confrontation has taken place in terms of the fact that one side envisions a reform of the military, while we envision the disbanding of the army and the demilitarization of the country as the best way to guarantee democracy in El Salvador and to give it greater possibilities for economic development," Mr. Villalobos said.

HEADLINE: Ex-Morgan Officer Is Seen As Next World Bank Chief

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Barber B. Conable Jr. told associates today that he would not seek a second five-year term as president of the 155-nation World Bank, the largest dispenser of aid to developing countries.
According to Administration and banking officials, he is expected to be succeeded by Lewis T. Preston, who retired as chief executive of J. P. Morgan & Company in 1989. 
 Mr. Conable's surprise announcement to the bank's executive board closes a chapter of expansion and reorganization for an institution that provides more than $20 billion a year in loans and grants to the world's poorest countries and serves as a pillar of the global economic system.
Mr. Conable, who had earlier served as a Congressman from upstate New York, told President Bush several days ago that he wanted to return to his home in Alexandria, N.Y., where he would be close to his children and grandchildren, bank officials said.
American officials emphasized that Mr. Conable, who is 68 years old, could have had a second term had he wanted it.
Although the bank is a multilateral institution, the United States, which provides 20 percent of the bank's capital, traditionally names the chief executive.
White House and Treasury officials have quietly consulted with other member countries on the Preston appointment. American officials said they expected no major international objections.
According to White House officials, President Bush personally selected Mr. Preston, who is an old friend and who headed Morgan, the nation's fourth-largest banking company, throughout the last decade.
A Harvard graduate, Mr. Preston, 64, is a former marine with what associates have said is a crisp, even gruff, manner.
 
Wide International Experience
 He is a banker with wide international experience. As head of Morgan's London office in the 1960's, Mr. Preston led the bank into the emerging Eurocurrency market. In the last decade, he expanded the bank aggressively into new revenue areas, like commodity and currency trading.
Mr. Preston is close not only to President Bush but also to other senior officials in the Administration. In 1985, he was one of a half-dozen leading bankers with whom Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, consulted in creating the Baker plan, which eased the debt burden for developing countries that pursued significant economic reforms.
Mr. Preston took an early retirement from Morgan two years ago, which surprised many in the industry. There was no official explanation. According to a report in The American Banker at the time, he had suffered a mild heart ailment.
As head of Morgan, he earned more than $2 million a year. As head of the World Bank, his pay is expected to be around $200,000 a year.
Mr. Conable was described by associates as "very happy" with the choice of Mr. Preston, who will be the eighth head of the institution since its founding after World War II.
Mr. Preston is expected to take over the World Bank in September. Mr. Conable, whose term officially expires June 30, will remain in office until then, bank officials said.
Mr. Conable has been credited with dramatically strengthening the World Bank's position in global development.
A long time member of the House Ways and Means Committee, he was able to use his political experience to advantage in convincing Congress to go along with a near doubling of the institution's capital -- to $171 billion.
Capital supports the bank's loans, which at $20.7 billion last year, were about a third higher than the foreign-aid budgets of either the United States or Japan.
Later this year, the five-year term of Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, also expires. Many analysts think that Mr. Camdessus, 57, a former French central banker, will remain for a second term.

HEADLINE: Housing in Jersey City;
Condo Tower Rises Along the Hudson

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Such is the allure of waterfront living that a Long Island development company is betting that the residences it will begin marketing here on March 16 will sell, even in a soft market.
The initial phase of the 525-unit development -- the Towers at Portside -- consists of 203 condominiums in a 19-story tower under construction along the Hudson at the foot of Washington Street in the historic Paulus Hook district of this city, minutes from lower Manhattan. Units range in size from 540 square feet for the smallest studio to 1,800 for the largest three-bedroom model. Duplex penthouses have as much as 3,300 square feet. Prices range from $134,900 to $1.3 million. 
 There will also be 26 two- and three-bedroom town houses ranging from 900 to more than 1,700 square feet and priced from $190,000 to $355,000. They are set atop 31,000 square feet of retail and office space.
The commercial space, divided into 1,200-square-foot blocks, is to be offered as condominiums at prices averaging $150 a square foot. Completion is expected by December.
The project, among the first in that part of the city, is being built by the DeMatteis Organizations of Uniondale, L.I., and Waterview Associates of Jersey City. The architect is Gruzen, Samton, Steinglass of Manhattan.
Parts of New Jersey, like other areas in the Northeast, are still saturated with new and resale houses, especially condominiums. But Nancy Katz, the DeMatteis director of sales and marketing, said her company was pressing ahead with Portside because "a good product will sell in any market, and we feel this market is entering the end of its down cycle."
Phillip Venezia, sales director for the project, said there were several reasons to hope it would attract buyers. He said the nationwide movement back to the cities is still strong, as is the desire to live near the water. The project overlooks the Tidewater Basin and offers views of the Manhattan skyline as well as of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island.
"The significance of this project for Jersey City is that it is opening up a new section of the waterfront to development," said Robert Cotter, director of urban research and design for the city's Department of Housing and Economic Development. Much of the residential development that has transformed Jersey City's waterfront -- once a desolate tract of old factories and rotting rail yards -- has taken place on its northernmost reaches, Mr. Cotter said. Still, more than half of the riverfront redevelopment district, extending two miles along the river and roughly eight blocks inland, is awaiting renewal.
Mr. Cotter said as much as 16 million additional square feet of office space and 12,000 more residences could be built. About 4,500 of those units may rise in and around the Paulus Hook district, where Portside is situated.
Most of them will be part of Colgate-Palmolive's plan to replace the company's old plant with a 34-acre complex that will also include a 400-room hotel and six million square feet of offices. Work is under way on the first 1.2-million-square-foot tower, where Merrill Lynch is planning to relocate 2,500 employees in 500,000 square feet.
Among Portside's amenities will be a health club and a branch of the Jersey City Public Library, which will built in the first phase. There are also plans for a day care center.
Mr. Venezia said Portside's second phase would consist of 296 units in a 25-story tower and 31,000 additional square feet of commercial space, including a two-story restaurant. He said construction of that phase would begin after the first was substantially sold.
The other riverfront project on the market is the James Monroe, a 443-unit, 33-story condominium tower at Newport -- the mixed-use complex that will ultimately contain more than 9,000 residences. The Monroe offers 570-square-foot studios; 1,377-square-foot, two-bedroom apartments, and 2,136-square-foot, three-bedroom duplexes. Prices range from $145,750 to $565,000, said Edward Cortese, vice president of marketing for the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, which is developing the project with Melvin Simon & Associates of Indianapolis and the Glimcher Company of Columbus, Ohio.
In October the developers defaulted on a $150 million mortgage for four occupied rental towers with 1,503 units in Newport. The group "is current on all our interest payments" and is working on refinancing the apartment towers, Mr. Cortese said. The condominium project was not affected, he added.
The group is also planning Towers of America -- 750 condominiums in two towers -- in the same complex. A timetable has not yet been set.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors to the Statue of Liberty embarking near Towers at Portside, a 19-story condominium residence on Washington Street in Jersey City. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Higher As Traders Await Jobs Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher on world currrency markets yesterday in choppy trading.
Gold prices were mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery advanced $1 to settle at $366.90 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $366.60, up 35 cents an ounce. 
 Traders said the market was awaiting the February unemployment report, due to be released today by the Labor Department. Many expect the data to confirm the growing belief that the recession may be bottoming out.
"It will have a big impact on all markets," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
The dollar is expected to benefit if unemployment improves, since the Federal Reserve would have little reason to reduce interest rates further if the economy is recovering. Lower interest rates have a negative effect on the dollar because they make dollar-denominated securities less valuable for investors.
But earlier in Tokyo trading, the dollar fell 0.92 yen to close at 135.63 yen. Later in London, it was quoted higher, at 135.75 yen. In New York, the currency settled at 135.65 yen, down from 135.70 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8865, down from $1.8895 late on Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.8885 to buy a pound, less than $1.8950 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Wednesday, included: 1.5460 German marks, up from 1.5380; 1.3480 Swiss francs, up from 1.3390; 5.2645 French francs, up from 5.2360; 1,154.50 Italian lire, up from 1,148.00, and 1.1595 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1586.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's, included: 1.5465 German marks, up from 1.5405; 1.3495 Swiss francs, up from 1.3405; 5.2675 French francs, up from 5.2470; 1.7430 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7368; 1,155.25 Italian lire, up from 1,151.75, and 1.1595 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1598.
